Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Judicial Code
===============================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 1 - Juries and Witnesses
******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Jury and Witness Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(1): "Clerk" or "clerk of the court" means the person so designated by title and includes any deputy clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(2): "Court" means trial court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(3): "Jury" means a body of persons temporarily selected from the citizens of a particular county invested with the power to present and indict a person for a public offense or to try a question of fact.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(4): 78B-1-106 "Master jury list" means the source lists as prescribed by the Judicial Council under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(5): " Prospective jury list" means the list of prospective jurors whose names are drawn at random from the master jury list and are determined to be qualified to serve as jurors.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(6): "Public necessity" means circumstances in which services performed by the prospective juror to members of the public in either a public or a private capacity cannot adequately be performed by others.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(7): "Trial jury" means a body of persons selected from the citizens of a particular county before a court or officer of competent jurisdiction and sworn to try and determine by verdict a question of fact.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(8): "Undue hardship" means circumstances in which the prospective juror would:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(8)(a): be required to abandon a person under his or her personal care or incur the cost of substitute care which is unreasonable under the circumstances;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(8)(b): suffer extreme physical hardship due to an illness, injury, or disability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-102(8)(c): incur substantial costs or lost opportunities due to missing an event that was scheduled prior to the initial notice of potential jury service.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-103 Jurors selected from random cross section -- Opportunity and obligation to serve.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-103(1): It is the policy of this state that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-103(1)(a): persons selected for jury service be selected at random from a fair cross section of the population of the county:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-103(1)(b): all qualified citizens have the opportunity in accordance with this chapter to be considered for service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-103(1)(c): all qualified citizens are obligated to serve when summoned, unless excused.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-103(2): A qualified citizen may not be excluded from jury service on account of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, occupation, disability, or economic status.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104 Jury composition.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(1): A trial jury consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(1)(a): 12 persons in a capital case;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(1)(b): eight persons in a noncapital first degree felony aggravated murder or other criminal case which carries a term of incarceration of more than one year as a possible sentence for the most serious offense charged;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(1)(c): six persons in a criminal case which carries a term of incarceration of more than six months but not more than one year as a possible sentence for the most serious offense charged;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(1)(d): four persons in a criminal case which carries a term of incarceration of six months or less as a possible sentence for the most serious offense charged; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(1)(e): eight persons in a civil case at law except that the jury shall be four persons in a civil case for damages of less than $20,000, exclusive of costs, interest, and attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(2): Except in the trial of a capital felony, the parties may stipulate upon the record to a jury of a lesser number than established by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(3)(a): The verdict in a criminal case shall be unanimous.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(3)(b): The verdict in a civil case shall be by not less than three-fourths of the jurors.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(4): There is no jury in the trial of small claims cases.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-104(5): There is no jury in the adjudication of a minor charged with what would constitute a crime if committed by an adult.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105 Jurors -- Competency to serve -- Persons not competent to serve as jurors -- Court to determine disqualification.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(1): A person is competent to serve as a juror if the person is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(1)(a): a citizen of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(1)(b): 18 years of age or older;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(1)(c): a resident of the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(1)(d): able to read, speak, and understand the English language.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(2): A person who has been convicted of a felony which has not been expunged is not competent to serve as a juror.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(3): The court, on its own initiative or when requested by a prospective juror, shall determine whether the prospective juror is disqualified from jury service.  The court shall base its decision on:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(3)(a): information provided on the juror qualification form;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(3)(b): an interview with the prospective juror; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(3)(c): other competent evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-105(4): The clerk shall enter the court's determination in the records of the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-106 Master jury list -- Inclusive -- Review -- Renewal -- Public examination.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-106(1): The Judicial Council shall designate one or more regularly maintained lists of persons residing in each county as the source lists for the master jury list.  The master jury list shall be as inclusive of the adult population as is reasonably practicable.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-106(2): The Judicial Council shall by rule provide for the biannual review of the master jury list to evaluate the master jury list's inclusiveness of the adult population.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-106(3): Not less than once every six months the Administrative Office of the Courts shall renew the master jury list by incorporating any additions, deletions, or amendments to the source lists.  The Administrative Office of the Courts shall include any additional source lists designated by the Judicial Council upon the next renewal of the master jury list.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-106(4): The person having custody, possession, or control of any list used in compiling the master jury list shall make the list available to the Administrative Office of the Courts at all reasonable times without charge.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-107 Master prospective jury list -- Juror qualification form -- Content.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-107(1): When a jury trial is anticipated, the jury clerk shall obtain from the master jury list the number of prospective jurors necessary to qualify jurors to empanel a jury in that case.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-107(2): Prospective jurors shall be randomly selected from the county in which the trial will be held. A prospective juror shall remain on the prospective jury list until there is no longer a need to empanel a jury in that case.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-107(3): The Judicial Council shall by rule govern the process for the qualification of jurors and the selection of qualified jurors for voir dire.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-107(4): The process shall gather the following from a prospective juror:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-107(4)(a): confirmation of the prospective juror's name, address, email address, and daytime telephone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-107(4)(b): information on whether the prospective juror is competent under statute to serve as a juror; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-107(4)(c): the prospective juror's declaration that the responses to the requests for information are true to the best of the person's knowledge.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-108 Qualified prospective jurors not exempt from jury service.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No qualified prospective juror is exempt from jury service.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109 Excuse from jury service -- Postponement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(1): (1)(a) A court may excuse an individual from jury service:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(1)(a): upon a showing:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(1)(a)(i): of undue hardship;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(1)(a)(ii): of public necessity;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(1)(a)(iii): that the individual is a mother who is breastfeeding a child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(1)(a)(iv): that the individual is incapable of jury service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(1)(b): (1)(a) for any period for which the grounds described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(2): (1); (1)(a) An individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-109(3): The court may postpone jury service upon a showing of good cause.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110 Limitations on jury service.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(1): In any two-year period, a person may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(1)(a): be required to serve on more than one grand jury;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(1)(b): be required to serve as both a grand and trial juror;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(1)(c): be required to attend court as a trial juror more than one court day, except if necessary to complete service in a particular case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(1)(d): if summoned for jury service and the summons is complied with as directed, be selected for the prospective jury list more than once.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(2): (1)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(2)(a): (1)(d) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(2)(b)(i): All population figures used for this section shall be derived from the most recent official census or census estimate of the United States Bureau of the Census.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-110(2)(b)(ii): If population estimates are not available from the United States Bureau of the Census, population figures shall be derived from the estimate of the Utah Population Committee.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-111 Food allowance for jurors -- Sequestration costs.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-111(1): Jurors  may be provided with a reasonable food allowance under the rules of the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-111(2): When a jury  has been placed in sequestration by order of the court, the necessary expenses for food and lodging shall be provided in accordance with the rules of the Judicial Council.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-112 Jurors -- Preservation of records.
------------------------------------------------------------------
All records and papers compiled in connection with the selection and service of jurors shall be preserved by the clerk for four years, or for any longer period ordered by the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-113 Jury not selected in conformity with chapter -- Procedure to challenge -- Relief available -- Exclusive remedy.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-113(1): Within seven days after the moving party discovered, or by the exercise of diligence could have discovered the grounds therefore, and in any event before the trial jury is sworn to try the case, a party may move to stay the proceedings or to quash an indictment, or for other appropriate relief, on the ground of substantial failure to comply with this act in selecting a grand or trial jury.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-113(2): Upon motion filed under this section containing a sworn statement of acts which if true would constitute a substantial failure to comply with this act, the moving party may present testimony of  the county clerk, the clerk of the court, any relevant records and papers not public or otherwise available used by the jury commission or the clerk, and any other relevant evidence.  If the court determines that in selecting either a grand or a trial jury there has been a substantial failure to comply with this act and it appears that actual and substantial injustice and prejudice has resulted or will result to a party in consequence of the failure, the court shall stay the proceedings pending the selection of the jury in conformity with this act, quash an indictment, or grant other appropriate relief.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-113(3): The procedures prescribed by this section are the exclusive means by which a person accused of a crime, the state, or a party in a civil case may challenge a jury on the ground that the jury was not selected in conformity with this act.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-114 Jury fee assessments -- Payment.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-114(1): The court has discretionary authority in any civil or criminal action or proceeding triable by jury to assess the entire cost of one day's juror fees against either the plaintiff or defendant or their counsel, or to divide the cost and assess them against both plaintiff and defendant or their counsel, or additional parties plaintiff or defendant, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-114(1)(a): a jury demand has been made and is later withdrawn within the 48 hours preceding the commencement of the trial; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-114(1)(b): the case is settled or continued within 48 hours of trial without just cause for not having settled or continued the case prior to the 48-hour period.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-114(2): The party assessed shall make payment to the clerk of the court within a prescribed period.  Payment shall be enforced by contempt proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-114(3): The court clerk shall transfer the assessment to the state treasury, or the auditor of the city or county incurring the juror expenses.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-115 Jurors -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-115(1): Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 3, Contempt A person who fails to respond timely to questions regarding qualification for jury service shall be in contempt of court and subject to penalties under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-115(2): Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 3, Contempt A person summoned for jury service who fails to appear or to complete jury service as directed shall be in contempt of court and subject to penalties under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-115(3): Any person who willfully misrepresents a material fact regarding qualification for, excuse from, or postponement of jury service is guilty of an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-116 Jurors -- Employer not to discharge or threaten employee for jury service -- Criminal penalty -- Civil action by employee.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-116(1): An employer may not deprive an employee of employment, threaten or take any adverse employment action, or otherwise coerce the employee regarding employment because the employee receives a summons, responds to it, serves as a juror, or a grand juror, or attends court for prospective jury or grand jury service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-116(2): An employee may not be required or requested to use annual, vacation, or sick leave for time spent responding to a summons for jury duty, time spent participating in the jury selection process, or for time spent actually serving on a jury.  Nothing in this provision shall be construed to require an employer to provide annual, vacation, or sick leave to employees under the provisions of this statute who otherwise are not entitled to those benefits under company policies.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-116(3): Any employer who violates this section is guilty of criminal contempt and upon conviction may be fined not more than $500 or imprisoned not more than six months, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-116(4): If any employer discharges an employee in violation of this section, the employee within 30 days may bring a civil action for recovery of wages lost as a result of the violation and for an order requiring the reinstatement of the employee.  Damages recoverable may not exceed lost wages for six weeks.  If the employee prevails, the employee shall be allowed reasonable attorney fees fixed by the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-117 Jurors and witnesses -- State payment for jurors and subpoenaed persons -- Appropriations and costs -- Expenses in justice court.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-117(1): The state is responsible for payment of all fees and expenses authorized by law for prosecution witnesses, witnesses subpoenaed by indigent defendants, and interpreter costs in criminal actions in the courts of record and actions in the juvenile court. The state is responsible for payment of all fees and expenses authorized by law for jurors in the courts of record.  For these payments, the Judicial Council shall receive an annual appropriation contained in a separate line item appropriation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-117(2): If expenses, for the purposes of this section, exceed the line item appropriation, the state court administrator shall submit a claim against the state to the Board of Examiners and request the board to recommend and submit a supplemental appropriation request to the Legislature for the deficit incurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-117(3): In the justice courts, the fees, mileage, and other expenses authorized by law for jurors, prosecution witnesses, witnesses subpoenaed by indigent defendants, and interpreter costs shall be paid by the municipality if the action is prosecuted by the city attorney, and by the county if the action is prosecuted by the county attorney or district attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-117(4): Beginning July 1, 2014, the state court administrator shall provide a report during each interim to the Executive Offices and Criminal Justice Appropriations Subcommittee detailing expenses, trends, and efforts made to minimize expenses and maximize performance of the costs under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-117(5): The funding of additional full-time equivalent employees shall be authorized by the Legislature through specific intent language.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-118 Jurors and witnesses -- Judicial Council rules governing fee payment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Judicial Council shall adopt rules governing the method of payment of fees, mileage, and other expenses of jurors and witnesses, authorization for payment, record of payment, and the audit of payment records.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119 Jurors and witnesses -- Fees and mileage.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119(1): Every juror and witness legally required or in good faith requested to attend a trial court of record or not of record or a grand jury is entitled to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119(1)(a): $18.50 for the first day of attendance and $49 per day for each subsequent day of attendance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119(1)(b): if traveling more than 50 miles, $1 for each four miles in excess of 50 miles actually and necessarily traveled in going only, regardless of county lines.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119(2): Persons in the custody of a penal institution upon conviction of a criminal offense are not entitled to a witness fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119(3): A witness attending from outside the state in a civil case is allowed mileage at the rate of 25 cents per mile and is taxed for the distance actually and necessarily traveled inside the state in going only.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119(4): 77-21-3 If the witness is attending from outside the state in a criminal case, the state shall reimburse the witness under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119(5): A prosecution witness or a witness subpoenaed by an indigent defendant attending from outside the county but within the state may receive reimbursement for necessary lodging and meal expenses under rule of the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-119(6): A witness subpoenaed to testify in court proceedings in a civil action shall receive reimbursement for necessary and reasonable parking expenses from the attorney issuing the subpoena under rule of the Judicial Council or Supreme Court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-120 Jurors and witnesses -- Fees in criminal cases -- Daily report of attendance.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every witness in a criminal case subpoenaed for the state, or for a defendant by order of the court at the expense of the state, and every juror, whether grand or trial, shall, unless temporarily excused, in person report daily to the clerk.  No per diem shall be allowed for any day upon which attendance is not so reported.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-121 Jurors and witnesses -- Statement of service -- Certificate.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever a grand juror, or a witness for the state before the grand jury, is finally discharged, the foreman of the grand jury shall furnish to the clerk of the district court a statement containing information necessary for the clerk to make the juror's or witness's certificate.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122 Jurors and witnesses -- Justice court judge -- Certificate of attendance -- Records and reporting.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every justice court shall follow the established disbursement process for juror and witness fees within the town, city, or county, or use the following procedure.Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122(1): A justice court judge shall provide to each person who has served as a juror or as a witness in a criminal case when summoned for the prosecution by the county or city attorney, or for the defense by order of the court, a numbered certificate that contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122(1)(a): the name of the juror or witness;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122(1)(b): the title of the proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122(1)(c): the number of days in attendance;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122(1)(d): the number of miles traveled if the witness has traveled more than 50 miles in going only; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122(1)(e): the amount due.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122(2): The certificate shall be presented to the county or city attorney.  When certified as being correct, it shall be presented to the county or city auditor and when allowed by the county executive or town council, the auditor shall draw a warrant for it on the treasurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-122(3): Every justice court judge shall keep a record of all certificates issued.  The record shall show all of the facts stated in each certificate.  On the first Monday of each month a detailed statement of all certificates issued shall be filed with the treasurer.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-123 Jurors and witnesses -- Limit of time for presentation of certificate.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any holder of a witness's or juror's certificate specified in this title shall be required to present it to the county treasurer or to the county auditor, as the case may be, of the county where the certificate was issued within one year from the date of its issuance. If the same is not presented for payment within that time, it is invalid and will not be paid.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124 Jurors and witnesses -- Statement of certificates -- Contents -- Payment by state.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(1): At the end of each quarter it shall be the duty of the county treasurer and the county auditor of each county to prepare in duplicate and verify under oath a full and complete itemized statement of all certificates issued by the clerk of the district court since the date of the last statement for mileage and attendance of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(1)(a): grand jurors;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(1)(b): trial jurors engaged in the trial of criminal causes in the district court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(1)(c): witnesses summoned by or on behalf of the state in criminal causes in the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(2): The statement shall set forth in detail for each certificate:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(2)(a): the number of the certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(2)(b): the date issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(2)(c): the name of the person in whose favor it was issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(2)(d): the nature of the service rendered; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(2)(e): any other information as may be necessary and required by the state auditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(3): Within 30 days of the end of the quarter one of these statements shall be transmitted to the state auditor and the other filed in the office of the county clerk. Upon the timely receipt of this statement the state auditor shall, unless it is found to be incorrect, draw a warrant in favor of the county treasurer upon the state treasurer for the whole amount of jurors' and witnesses' certificates as shown by the statement, and transmit it to the county treasurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-124(4): The county treasurer shall hold the funds drawn from the state treasury upon the certificates for mileage and attendance of jurors and witnesses as a separate fund for the redemption of jurors' and witnesses' certificates.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-125 Jurors and witnesses -- Certifying excessive fees a felony.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any clerk or judge of any court, county attorney, district attorney, or other officer who certifies false information as a fact, whereby any witness or juror shall be allowed a greater sum than otherwise entitled to under the provisions of this title, is guilty of a felony.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-126 Jurors and witnesses -- Purchase of certificate forbidden -- Penalty.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-126(1): No person connected officially with any of the district courts of this state, and no state, district, county or precinct officer, shall purchase or cause to be purchased any certificate issued to any juror or witness under the provisions of this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-126(2): Any person who violates the provisions of this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-127 Witnesses -- Competency.
--------------------------------------------------------
Every person is competent to be a witness except as otherwise provided in the Utah Rules of Evidence.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128 Who may be witnesses -- Jury to judge credibility.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(1): All persons, without exception, otherwise than as specified in this part, who, having organs of sense, can perceive, and, perceiving, can make known their perceptions to others, may be witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(2): Neither parties nor other persons who have an interest in the event of an action or proceeding are excluded; nor those who have been convicted of crime; nor persons on account of their opinions on matters of religious belief.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(3): The credibility of a witness may be questioned by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(3)(a): the manner in which the witness testifies;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(3)(b): the character of the witness testimony;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(3)(c): evidence affecting the witness' character for truth, honesty, or integrity;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(3)(d): the witness' motives; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(3)(e): contradictory evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-128(4): The jury is the exclusive judge of credibility.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-129 Witnesses -- Subpoena defined.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The process by which the attendance of a witness is required is a subpoena.  It is a writ or order directed to a person and requiring the person's attendance at a particular time and place to testify as a witness.  The person may also be required to bring any books, documents, or other things under the person's control which is required to be produced in evidence.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-130 Witnesses -- Duty when served with subpoena.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A witness served with a subpoena shall:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-130(1): attend at the time appointed with any papers required by the subpoena;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-130(2): answer all pertinent and legal questions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-130(3): unless sooner discharged, remain until the testimony is closed.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-131 Witnesses -- Liability to forfeiture and damages.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A witness who disobeys a subpoena shall, in addition to any penalty imposed for contempt, be liable to the party aggrieved in the sum of $100, and all damages sustained by the failure of the witness to attend.  Forfeiture and damages may be recovered in a civil action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-132 Employer not to discharge or threaten employee for responding to subpoena -- Criminal penalty -- Civil action by employee.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-132(1): An employer may not deprive an employee of employment or threaten or otherwise coerce the employee regarding employment because the employee attends a deposition or hearing in response to a subpoena.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-132(2): Any employer who violates this section is guilty of criminal contempt and upon conviction may be fined not more than $500 or imprisoned not more than six months or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-132(3): Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-132(3)(a): Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration If an employer violates this section, in addition to any other remedy, the employee may bring an action in a court with jurisdiction under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-132(3)(b): Damages recoverable may not exceed lost wages for six weeks.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-132(3)(c): If the employee prevails, the employee shall be allowed reasonable attorney fees.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-133 Witnesses -- Judge or juror may be witness -- Procedure.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The judge or any juror may be called as a witness by either party.  It is in the discretion of the court to order the trial to be postponed, suspended, or take place before another judge or jury.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-134 Witnesses -- Duty to answer questions -- Privilege.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-134(1): A witness shall answer all questions legal and pertinent to the matter in issue, although an answer may establish a claim against the witness.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-134(2): A witness need not give an answer which will subject him to punishment for a felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-134(3): A witness need not give an answer which will degrade his character, unless it is to the very fact in issue or to a fact from which the fact in issue would be presumed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-134(4): A witness must answer as to the fact of any previous conviction of a felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-135 Witnesses -- Proceedings in aid of or supplemental to attachment, garnishment, or execution.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-135(1): 78B-1-134 Notwithstanding the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-135(1)(a): the answer will tend to convict the party or witness of the commission of a fraud;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-135(1)(b): the answer will prove the party or witness has been a party or privy to, or has knowledge of, a conveyance, assignment, transfer or other disposition of property concerned for any purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-135(1)(c): the party, witness, or any other person claims to be entitled, as against the judgment creditor or a receiver appointed or to be appointed in the proceedings, to hold property derived from or through the judgment debtor or to be discharged from the payment of a debt which was due to the judgment debtor or to a person in the debtor's behalf.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-135(2): An answer cannot be used as evidence against the person so answering in a criminal action or proceeding, except in an action for perjury against the person for falsely testifying.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-136 Witnesses -- Rights.
----------------------------------------------------
It is the right of a witness to be protected from irrelevant, improper or insulting questions, and from harsh or insulting demeanor, to be detained only so long as the interests of justice require it, and to be examined only as to matters legal and pertinent to the issue.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137 Witnesses -- Privileged communications.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
There are particular relations in which it is the policy of the law to encourage confidence and to preserve it inviolate.  Therefore, a person cannot be examined as a witness in the following cases:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(1)(a): Neither a wife nor a husband may either during the marriage or afterwards be, without the consent of the other, examined as to any communication made by one to the other during the marriage.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(1)(b): This exception does not apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(1)(b)(i): to a civil action or proceeding by one spouse against the other;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(1)(b)(ii): to a criminal action or proceeding for a crime committed by one spouse against the other;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(1)(b)(iii): to the crime of deserting or neglecting to support a spouse or child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(1)(b)(iv): to any civil or criminal proceeding for abuse or neglect committed against the child of either spouse; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(1)(b)(v): if otherwise specifically provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(2): An attorney cannot, without the consent of the client, be examined as to any communication made by the client to the attorney or any advice given regarding the communication in the course of the professional employment.  An attorney's secretary, stenographer, or clerk cannot be examined, without the consent of the attorney, concerning any fact, the knowledge of which has been acquired as an employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(3): A member of the clergy or priest cannot, without the consent of the person making the confession, be examined as to any confession made to either of them in their professional character in the course of discipline enjoined by the church to which they belong.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(4): A physician, surgeon, or physician assistant cannot, without the consent of the patient, be examined in a civil action as to any information acquired in attending the patient which was necessary to enable the physician, surgeon, or physician assistant to prescribe or act for the patient.  However, this privilege shall be waived by the patient in an action in which the patient places the patient's medical condition at issue as an element or factor of the claim or defense.  Under those circumstances, a physician, surgeon, or physician assistant who has prescribed for or treated that patient for the medical condition at issue may provide information, interviews, reports, records, statements, memoranda, or other data relating to the patient's medical condition and treatment which are placed at issue.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(5): A public officer cannot be examined as to communications made in official confidence when the public interests would suffer by the disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(6): 77-38-203; 77-38-203; 77-38-403; 77-38-403; 77-38-403
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(6)(a): 77-38-203; 77-38-203 A sexual assault counselor as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-137(6)(b): 77-38-403; 77-38-403; 77-38-403 A victim advocate as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-138 Witnesses -- Exempt from arrest in civil action.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who has been in good faith served with a subpoena to attend as a witness before a court, judge, commissioner, referee or other person, in a case where the disobedience of the witness may be punished as a contempt, is exempt from arrest in a civil action while going to the place of attendance, necessarily remaining there and returning therefrom.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-139 Witnesses -- Unlawful arrest -- Void -- Damages recoverable.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The arrest of a witness contrary to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-140 Liability of officer making arrest.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-140(1): An officer is not liable for making the arrest in ignorance of the facts creating the exemption, but is liable for any subsequent detention of the witness, if the witness claims the exemption and makes an affidavit stating:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-140(1)(a): he has been served with a subpoena to attend as a witness before a court, officer or other person, specifying the same, the place of attendance and the action or proceeding in which the subpoena was issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-140(1)(b): he has not been served by his own procurement, with the intention of avoiding an arrest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-140(1)(c): he is at the time going to the place of attendance, returning therefrom, or remaining there in obedience to the subpoena.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-140(2): The affidavit may be taken by the officer, and exonerates him from liability for discharging the witness when arrested.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-141 Witnesses -- Discharge when unlawfully arrested.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court or officer issuing the subpoena, and the court or officer before whom the attendance is required, may discharge the witness from an arrest made in violation of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-142 Witnesses -- Oaths -- Who may administer.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every court, every judge, clerk and deputy clerk of any court, every justice, every notary public, and every officer or person authorized to take testimony in any action or proceeding, or to decide upon evidence, has the power to administer oaths or affirmations.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-143 Witnesses -- Form of oath.
----------------------------------------------------------
You do solemnly swear (or affirm) that the evidence you shall give in this issue (or matter) pending between ____ and ____ shall be the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, so help you God (or, under the pains and penalties of perjury).Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-143(1): An oath or affirmation in an action or proceeding may be administered in the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-143(2): The person swearing or affirming shall express assent when addressed.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-144 Witnesses -- Affirmation or declaration instead of oath allowed.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person may, instead of taking an oath, opt to make a solemn affirmation or declaration, by assenting, when addressed in the following form:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-145 Witnesses -- Variance in form of swearing to suit beliefs.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-145(1): Whenever the court before which a person is offered as a witness is satisfied that the person has a peculiar mode of swearing, connected with or in addition to the usual form, which in the person's opinion is more solemn or obligatory, the court may in its discretion adopt that mode.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-145(2): A person who believes in a religion other than the Christian religion may be sworn according to the particular ceremonies of the person's religion, if there are any.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-146 Witnesses -- Interpreters -- Subpoena -- Contempt -- Costs.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-146(1): When a witness does not understand and speak the English language, an interpreter shall be sworn in to interpret.  Any person may be subpoenaed by any court or judge to appear before the court or judge to act as an interpreter in any action or proceeding.  Any person so subpoenaed who fails to attend at the time and place named is guilty of a contempt.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-146(2): The Judicial Council may establish a fee for the issuance and renewal of a license of a certified court interpreter.  Any fee established under this section shall be deposited as a dedicated credit to the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-146(3): If the court appoints an interpreter, the court may assess all or part of the fees and costs of the interpreter against the person for whom the service is provided.  The court may not assess interpreter fees or costs against a person found to be impecunious.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-147 Witnesses -- Fees in civil cases  -- How paid -- Taxed as costs.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-147(1): The fees and compensation of witnesses in all civil causes shall be paid by the party who causes the witnesses to attend.  A person is not obliged to attend court in a civil cause when subpoenaed unless the person's:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-147(1)(a): fees for one day's attendance are tendered or paid on demand; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-147(1)(b): fees for attendance for each day are tendered or paid on demand.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-147(2): The fees of witnesses paid in civil causes may be taxed as costs against the losing party.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-148 Witnesses -- Only one fee per day allowed.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
No witness shall receive fees in more than one criminal cause on the same day.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-149 Witnesses -- Officials subpoenaed not entitled to fee or per diem -- Exception.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No officer of the United States, or the state, or of any county, incorporated city or town within the state, may receive any witness fee or per diem when testifying in a criminal proceeding unless the officer is required to testify at a time other than during normal working hours.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-150 Witnesses -- When criminal defense witness may be called at expense of state.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A witness for a defendant in a criminal cause  may not be subpoenaed at the expense of the state, county, or city, except upon order of the court.   The order shall be made only upon affidavit of the defendant, showing:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-150(1): the defendant is impecunious and unable to pay the per diems of the witness;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-150(2): the evidence of the witness is material for defendant's defense as advised by counsel, if counsel is in place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-150(3): the defendant cannot safely proceed to trial without the witness.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-151 Witnesses -- Expenses for expert witnesses.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-151(1): The court may appoint any expert witness agreed upon by the parties or of its own selection.  The court shall inform the expert of required duties in writing and a copy shall be filed with the court record.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-151(2): The appointed expert shall advise the court and the parties of findings and may be called to testify by the court or by any party.   The expert witness is subject to cross-examination by each party.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-151(3): The court shall determine the reasonable compensation of the expert and order payment.  The parties may call expert witnesses of their own at their own expense.  Upon a showing that a defendant is financially unable to pay the compensation of an expert whose services are necessary for an adequate defense, the compensation shall be paid as if  the expert were called on behalf of the prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-151(4): 78B-1-119; (3) Payment by the court for an expert witness in a criminal case is limited to the fee and mileage allowance for witnesses under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-152 Witnesses -- Prohibition of expert witness contingent fees in civil actions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-152(1): (1)(a) As used in this section, "contingent fee agreement" means an agreement for the provision of testimony or other evidence and related services by an expert witness in a civil action that specifies:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-152(1)(a): the payment of compensation to the expert witness for the testimony, other evidence, and services is contingent, in whole or in part, upon a judgment being rendered in favor of the plaintiff or defendant in a civil action, upon a favorable settlement being obtained by the plaintiff or defendant in a civil action, or upon the plaintiff in a civil action being awarded in a judgment or settlement damages in at least a specified amount; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-152(1)(b): (1)(a) upon satisfaction of the contingency described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-152(2): A plaintiff or defendant in a civil action may not engage an expert witness by means of a contingent fee agreement unless approval is sought and received from the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-152(3): (2) An expert witness may be engaged by the plaintiff or defendant on the contingency that the expert actually qualify as an expert.  Once the witness is qualified as an expert Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-201(1): "Appointing authority" means the presiding officer or similar official of any court, board, commission, authority, department, agency, legislative body, or of any proceeding of any nature where a qualified interpreter is required under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-201(2): " Deaf or hard of hearing person" and " deaf or hard of hearing parent" means a deaf or hard of hearing person who, because of sensory or environmental conditions, requires the assistance of a qualified interpreter or other special assistance for communicative purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-201(3): "Necessary steps" or "necessary services" include provisions of qualified interpreters, lip reading, pen and paper, typewriters, closed-circuit television with closed-caption translations, computers with print-out capability, and telecommunications devices for the deaf or similar devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-201(4): 78B-1-203; 78B-1-206 "Qualified interpreter" means a sign language or oral interpreter as provided in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-202 Proceedings at which interpreter is to be provided for the deaf or hard of hearing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-202(1): If a deaf or hard of hearing person is a party or witness at any stage of any judicial or quasi-judicial proceeding in this state or in its political subdivisions, including civil and criminal court proceedings, grand jury proceedings, proceedings before a magistrate, juvenile proceedings, adoption proceedings, mental health commitment proceedings, and any proceeding in which a deaf or hard of hearing person may be subjected to confinement or criminal sanction, the appointing authority shall appoint and pay for a qualified interpreter to interpret the proceedings to the deaf or hard of hearing person and to interpret the deaf or hard of hearing person's testimony.  If the deaf or hard of hearing person does not understand sign language, the appointing authority shall take necessary steps to ensure that the deaf or hard of hearing person may effectively and accurately communicate in the proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-202(2): If a juvenile whose parent or parents are deaf or hard of hearing is brought before a court for any reason whatsoever, the court shall appoint and pay for a qualified interpreter to interpret the proceedings to the deaf or hard of hearing parent and to interpret the deaf or hard of hearing parent's testimony.  If the deaf or hard of hearing parent or parents do not understand sign language, the appointing authority shall take any reasonable, necessary steps to ensure that the deaf or hard of hearing parent may effectively and accurately communicate in the proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-202(3): In any hearing, proceeding, or other program or activity of any department, board, licensing authority, commission, or administrative agency of the state or of its political subdivisions, the appointing authority shall appoint and pay for a qualified interpreter for the deaf or hard of hearing participants if the interpreter is not otherwise compensated for those services.  If the deaf or hard of hearing participants do not understand sign language, the appointing authority shall take any reasonable, necessary steps to ensure that the deaf or hard of hearing participant may effectively and accurately communicate in the proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-202(4): If a deaf or hard of hearing person is a witness before any legislative committee or subcommittee, or legislative research or interim committee or subcommittee or commission authorized by the state Legislature or by the legislative body of any political subdivision of the state, the appointing authority shall appoint and pay for a qualified interpreter to interpret the proceedings to the deaf or hard of hearing witness and to interpret the deaf or hard of hearing witness's testimony.  If the deaf or hard of hearing witness does not understand sign language, the appointing authority shall take any reasonable, necessary steps to ensure that the deaf or hard of hearing witness may effectively and accurately communicate in the proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-202(5): If it is the policy and practice of a court of this state or of its political subdivisions to appoint counsel for indigent people, the appointing authority shall appoint and pay for a qualified interpreter or other necessary services for deaf or hard of hearing, indigent people to assist in communication with counsel in all phases of the preparation and presentation of the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-202(6): If a deaf or hard of hearing person is involved in administrative, legislative, or judicial proceedings, the appointing authority shall recognize that family relationship between the particular deaf or hard of hearing person and an interpreter may constitute a possible conflict of interest and select a qualified interpreter who will be impartial in the proceedings.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-203 Effectiveness of interpreter determined.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-203(1): 35A-1-202 Before appointing an interpreter, the appointing authority shall make a preliminary determination, on the basis of the proficiency level established by the Utah State Office of Rehabilitation created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-203(2): If the interpreter is not able to provide effective communication with the deaf or hard of hearing person, the appointing authority shall appoint another qualified interpreter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-204 Appointment of more qualified interpreter.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a qualified interpreter is unable to render a satisfactory interpretation, the appointing authority shall appoint a more qualified interpreter.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-205 Readiness of interpreter prerequisite to commencement of proceeding.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If an interpreter is required to be appointed under this part, the appointing authority may not commence proceedings until the appointed interpreter is in full view of and spatially situated to assure effective communication with the deaf or hard of hearing participants.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-206 List of qualified interpreters -- Use -- Appointment of another.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-206(1): 35A-1-202 The Utah State Office of Rehabilitation created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-206(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-206(2)(a): When an interpreter is required under this part, the appointing authority shall use one of the interpreters on the list provided by the Utah State Office of Rehabilitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-206(2)(b): If none of the listed interpreters are available or are able to provide effective interpreting with the particular deaf or hard of hearing person, then the appointing authority shall appoint another qualified interpreter who is able to accurately and simultaneously communicate with and translate information to and from the particular deaf or hard of hearing person involved.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-207 Oath of interpreter.
----------------------------------------------------
Before he or she begins to interpret, every interpreter appointed under this part shall take an oath that he or she will make a true interpretation in an understandable manner to the best of his or her skills and judgment.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-208 Compensation of interpreter.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-208(1): An interpreter appointed under this part is entitled to a reasonable fee for his or her services, including waiting time and reimbursement for necessary travel and subsistence expenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-208(2): 35A-1-202 The fee shall be based on a fee schedule for interpreters recommended by the Utah State Office of Rehabilitation created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-208(3): Reimbursement for necessary travel and subsistence expenses shall be at rates provided by law for state employees generally.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-208(4): Compensation for interpreter services shall be paid by the appointing authority if the interpreter is not otherwise compensated for those services.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-209 Waiver of right to interpreter.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The right of a deaf or hard of hearing person to an interpreter may not be waived, except by a deaf or hard of hearing person who requests a waiver in writing.  The waiver is subject to the approval of counsel to the deaf or hard of hearing person, if existent, and is subject to the approval of the appointing authority.  In no event may the failure of the deaf or hard of hearing person to request an interpreter be considered a waiver of that right.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-210 Privileged communications.
----------------------------------------------------------
If a deaf or hard of hearing person communicates through an interpreter to any person under such circumstances that the communication would be privileged and the person could not be compelled to testify as to the communications, this privilege shall apply to the interpreter as well.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-1-211 Video recording of testimony of deaf or hard of hearing person.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The appointing authority, on his or her own motion or on the motion of a party to the proceedings, may order that the testimony of the deaf or hard of hearing person and its interpretation be electronically recorded by a video recording device for use in verification of the official transcript of the proceedings.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 2 - Statutes of Limitations
*********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-101 Definitions of "tax title" and "action."
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-101(1): The word "action" as used in this chapter includes counterclaims and cross-complaints and all other civil actions in which affirmative relief is sought.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-101(2): 59-2-1364; 78B-2-206; 78B-2-204; 78B-2-208; 78B-2-214 The term "tax title" as used in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-102 Time for commencement of actions generally.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Civil actions may be commenced only within the periods prescribed in this chapter, after the cause of action has accrued, except in specific cases where a different limitation is prescribed by statute.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-103 Action barred in another state barred in Utah.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A cause of action which arises in another jurisdiction, and which is not actionable in the other jurisdiction by reason of the lapse of time, may not be pursued in this state, unless the cause of action is held by a citizen of this state who has held the cause of action from the time it accrued.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-104 Effect of absence from state.
-------------------------------------------------------------
If a cause of action accrues against a person while the person is out of the state and the person is not subject to the jurisdiction of the courts of this state in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-105 Effect of death.
------------------------------------------------
If an individual entitled to bring an action dies before the expiration of the statute of limitations and the cause of action survives, an action may be brought by the individual's representatives within the later of:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-105(1): the statute of limitations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-105(2): one year after the day on which the individual died.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-106 Effect of death of defendant outside this state.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a person against whom a cause of action exists dies outside the state, the time which elapses between his death and the expiration of one year after this state issues letters testamentary or letters of administration is not a part of the time limited for the commencement of an action against his executor or administrator.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-107 Effect of war.
----------------------------------------------
When a person is an alien subject or a citizen of a country at war with the United States, the duration of the war may not be counted as part of the statute of limitations for the commencement of the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-108 Effect of disability -- Minority or mental incompetence -- Damages.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-108(1): An individual may not bring a cause of action while the individual is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-108(1)(a): under 18 years old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-108(1)(b): mentally incompetent without a legal guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-108(2): During the time that an individual is underage or mentally incompetent, the statute of limitations for a cause of action other than for the recovery of real property may not run.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-108(3): (1) A cause of action under this section includes any claim:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-108(3)(a): for general or special damages; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-108(3)(b): (1) for which a parent or legal guardian of an individual described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-109 Disability must exist when right of action accrues.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person may not take advantage of a disability, unless it existed when the person's right of action accrued.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-110 All disabilities must be removed.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
When two or more disabilities coexist at the time the right of action accrues, the limitation does not attach until all are removed.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-111 Failure of action -- Right to commence new action.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-111(1): If any action is timely filed and the judgment for the plaintiff is reversed, or if the plaintiff fails in the action or upon a cause of action otherwise than upon the merits, and the time limited either by law or contract for commencing the action has expired, the plaintiff, or if he dies and the cause of action survives, his representatives, may commence a new action within one year after the reversal or failure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-111(2): On and after December 31, 2007, a new action may be commenced under this section only once.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-112 Effect of injunction or prohibition.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The duration of an injunction or statutory prohibition which delays the filing of an action may not be counted as part of the statute of limitations.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-113 Effect of payment, acknowledgment, or promise to pay.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-113(1): An action for recovery of a debt may be brought within the applicable statute of limitations from the date:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-113(1)(a): the debt arose;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-113(1)(b): a written acknowledgment of the debt or a promise to pay is made by the debtor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-113(1)(c): a payment is made on the debt by the debtor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-113(2): If a right of action is barred by the provisions of any statute, it shall be unavailable either as a cause of action or ground for defense.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114 Separate trial of statute of limitations issue in malpractice actions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1): (1)(a); (j) An issue raised by the defense regarding the statute of limitations in a case may be tried separately if the action is for professional negligence or for rendering professional services without consent, and against:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(a): a physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(b): a surgeon;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(c): a physician assistant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(d): a dentist;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(e): an osteopathic physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(f): a chiropractor;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(g): a physical therapist;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(h): a registered nurse;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(i): a clinical laboratory bioanalyst;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(j): a clinical laboratory technologist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(1)(k): (1)(a); (j) a licensed hospital, person, firm, or corporation as the employer of any of the persons in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-114(2): The issue raised may be tried before any other issues in the case are tried. If the issue raised by the defense of the statute of limitations is finally determined in favor of the plaintiff, the remaining issues shall then be tried.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-115 Actions by state or other governmental entity.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except for the provisions of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117 Statute of limitations -- Asbestos damages.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(1)(a): Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a statute of limitation or repose may not bar an action to recover damages from any manufacturer of any construction materials containing asbestos and arising out of the manufacturer's providing of the materials, directly or through other persons, for use in construction of any building within the state until July 1, 1991, or until three years after the person or entity bringing the action discovers or with reasonable diligence could have discovered the injury or damages, whichever is later.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(1)(b): (1)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(2): As used in this section, "asbestos" means asbestiform varieties of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(2)(a): chrysotile (serpentine);
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(2)(b): crocidolite (riebeckite);
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(2)(c): amosite (cummingtonite-grunerite);
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(2)(d): anthophyllite;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(2)(e): tremolite; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-117(2)(f): actinolite.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-118 Actions against the United States.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Actions against the federal government regarding real property and that are subject to the federal Quiet Title Act, 28 U.S.C. Sec. 2409a, do not expire under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-119(1)(c): "Victim" means an individual directly harmed by criminal conduct or the individual's representative.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-119(2)(a)(ii): the cause of action is brought within one year from the day on which a final disposition for the criminal proceeding is issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-119(2)(a)(iii): (2)(a)(ii) the cause of action is brought to address any harm resulting from the criminal conduct that was at issue in the criminal proceeding described in Subsection
