Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-201 Actions by the state.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-201(1): The state may not bring an action against any person for or with respect to any real property, its issues or profits, based upon the state's right or title to the real property, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-201(1)(a): the right or title to the property accrued within seven years before any action or other proceeding is commenced; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-201(1)(b): the state or those from whom it claims received all or a portion of the rents and profits from the real property within the immediately preceding seven years.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-201(2): The statute of limitations in this section runs from the date on which the state or those from whom it claims received actual notice of the facts giving rise to the action.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-202 Actions by patentees or grantees from state.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person receiving letters patent or a grant of real property from the state may not bring an action based on the patent or grant unless the state would have been able to bring an action had the patent or grant not been made.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-203 When letters patent or grants declared void.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
When letters patent or grants of real property issued or made by the state are declared void by a court of competent jurisdiction, an action for the recovery of the property shall be brought either by the state, or by any subsequent patentee or grantee of the property, his heirs or assigns, within seven years after such determination.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-204 Seizure or possession within seven years necessary.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An action for the recovery or possession of real property may not be maintained, unless it appears the plaintiff, his ancestor, grantor, or predecessor owned or possessed the property in question within seven years before the commencement of the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-205 Seizure or possession within seven years -- Proviso -- Tax title.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-205(1): An action for the recovery or possession of real property may not be maintained, unless the plaintiff or his predecessor owned or possessed the property within seven years before the commencement of the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-205(2): Actions or defenses brought to recover, take possession of, quiet title, or determine the ownership of real property against the holder of a tax title to the property, may not be commenced more than four years after the date of the tax deed, conveyance, or transfer creating the tax title unless the person commencing the action or defense or his predecessor has actually occupied or been in possession of the property within four years prior to the commencement of the action or defense.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-206 Holder of tax title -- Limitations of action or defense -- Proviso.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An action or defense to recover, take possession of, quiet title to, or determine the ownership of real property may not be commenced against the holder of a tax title after the expiration of four years from the date of the sale, conveyance, or transfer of the tax title to any county, or directly to any other purchaser at any public or private tax sale.  This section may not bar any action or defense by the owner of the legal title to the property which he or his predecessor actually occupied or possessed within four years from the commencement of an action or defense.  This section may not bar any defense by a city or town to an action by the holder of a tax title, to the effect that the city or town holds a lien against the property which is equal or superior to the claim of the holder of the tax title.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-207 Actions or defenses founded upon title to real estate.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An action, defense, or counterclaim to an action based upon title to the property or entitlement to the rents or profits from the property shall be brought:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-207(1): not later than seven years after the act on which it is based; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-207(2): (1) by the ancestor, predecessor, or grantor of the person who owned or possessed the property for seven years before the act in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-208 Adverse possession -- Possession presumed in owner.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-208(1): In an action for the recovery of real property, it is presumed that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-208(1)(a): the person establishing legal title to the property has been in possession of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-208(1)(b): any occupation of the property has been under and in subordination to the legal title.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-208(2): (1) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-209 Adverse possession -- Presumption -- Proviso -- Tax title.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-209(1): In an action for the recovery or possession of real property, to quiet title to or determine the property's owner, the person establishing a legal title to the property is presumed to have been in possession of the property within the time required by law.  The occupation of the property by any other person is considered to have been under and in subordination to the legal title, unless it appears that the property has been held and possessed adversely to the legal title for seven years before the commencement of the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-209(2): If in any action a party establishes prima facie evidence of ownership of any real property under a tax title held by him and his predecessors for four years prior to the commencement of the action, he is presumed to be the owner of the property by adverse possession.  This presumption may be rebutted if it appears that the owner of the legal title or his predecessor has actually occupied or been in possession of the property under the title or that the tax title owner and his predecessors have failed to pay all the taxes levied or assessed upon the property within the four-year period.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-210 Adverse possession -- Under written instrument or judgment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-210(1): Property is considered to have been adversely held if a person in possession of the property, either personally or through another:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-210(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-210(1)(a)(i): possesses a written document purporting to convey title; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-210(1)(a)(ii): possesses a decree or judgment from a court of competent jurisdiction conveying title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-210(1)(b): has occupied the property continuously for at least seven years.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-210(2): If the property consists of a tract divided into lots, the possession of one lot is not considered a possession of any other lot in the same tract.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-211 What constitutes adverse possession under written instrument.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For the purpose of constituting an adverse possession by any person claiming a title based upon a written instrument or a judgment or decree, the property is considered to have been possessed if:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-211(1): it has been usually cultivated or improved;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-211(2): it has been protected by a substantial enclosure;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-211(3): although not enclosed, it has been used for the supply of fuel, fencing timber, for the purpose of husbandry, or for pasturage or for the ordinary use of the occupant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-211(4): where a known farm or single lot has been partly improved, the portion of the farm or lot which may have been left not cleared or not inclosed according to the usual course and custom of the adjoining county is considered to have been occupied for the same length of time as the part improved and cultivated.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-212 Adverse possession -- Under claim not founded on written instrument or judgment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Where it appears that there has been an actual continued occupation of land under claim of title, exclusive of any other right, but not founded upon a written instrument, judgment or decree, the land actually occupied and no other, is considered to have been held adversely.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-213 What constitutes adverse possession not under written instrument.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Land is considered to be possessed and occupied adversely by a person claiming title not founded upon a written instrument, judgment, or decree in the following cases only, where:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-213(1): it has been protected by a substantial enclosure;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-213(2): it has been usually cultivated or improved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-213(3): labor or money amounting to the sum of $5 per acre has been expended upon dams, canals, embankments, aqueducts, or otherwise for the purpose of irrigating the land.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-214 Adverse possession -- Continuous -- Seven years -- Taxes paid.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Adverse possession may not be established unless it is shown that the land has been occupied and claimed continuously for seven years, and that the party and the party's predecessors and grantors have paid all taxes which have been levied and assessed upon the land according to law.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-215 Adverse possession -- Payment of taxes -- Proviso -- Tax title.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Payment of all the taxes levied and assessed upon the real property for a period of not less than four years by the holder of a tax title to the real property or his predecessors is sufficient to satisfy the requirements of this chapter regarding the payment of taxes necessary to establish adverse possession.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216 Adverse possession of certain real property.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(1)(a): "Government entity" means a town, city, county, metropolitan water district, or special district.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(1)(b): "Water facility" means any improvement or structure used, or intended to be used, to divert, convey, store, measure, or treat water.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(a): held by a government entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b): designated for any present or future public use, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b)(i): a street;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b)(ii): a lane;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b)(iii): an avenue;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b)(iv): an alley;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b)(v): a park;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b)(vi): a public square;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b)(vii): a water facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(2)(b)(viii): a water conveyance right-of-way or water conveyance corridor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(3): (2); (4); (3)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(3)(a): a government entity sold, disposed of, or conveyed the right in, or title to, the real property to a purchaser for valuable consideration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(3)(b): (3)(a) the purchaser or the purchaser's grantees or successors in interest have been in exclusive, continuous, and adverse possession of the real property for at least seven consecutive years after the day on which the real property was sold, disposed of, or conveyed as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-216(4): (3) A person who acquires title under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-217 Adverse possession -- Possession of tenant considered possession of landlord.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When a landlord and tenant relationship exists between persons, the possession of the tenant is considered the possession of the landlord until the expiration of seven years after the termination of the tenancy, or, if there has been no written lease, until seven years from the time of the last payment of rent.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-218 Adverse possession -- Possession not affected by descent cast.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The right of a person to the possession of real property is not impaired or affected by a descent cast in consequence of the death of a person in possession of the property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-219 Adverse possession -- Action to redeem mortgage of real property.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An action to redeem a mortgage of real property, with or without an account of rents and profits, may not be brought by the mortgagor, or those claiming under him, against the mortgagee in possession, or those claiming under him, unless an adverse possession of the mortgaged premises for seven years after breach of some condition of the mortgage has been continuously maintained by the mortgagor or those claiming under him.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-220 Redemption when more than one mortgagor.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
If there is more than one mortgagor, or more than one person claiming under a mortgagor, some of whom are not entitled to maintain an action under the provisions of this article, any one of them who is entitled to maintain an action may redeem a divided or undivided part of the mortgaged premises as his interest may appear, and have an accounting for a part of the rents and profits proportionate to his interest in the mortgaged premises, on payment of a part of the mortgage money, bearing the same proportion to the whole of the money as the value of his divided or undivided interest in the premises bears to the whole of the premises.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-221 Actions to recover estate sold by guardian.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
An action for the recovery of an estate sold by a guardian shall be brought by the ward, or any person claiming under the ward, within three years after the termination of the guardianship.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-222 Actions to recover estate sold by executor or administrator.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An action for the recovery of an estate sold by an executor or administrator in the course of a probate proceeding shall be maintained by an heir or other person claiming under the decedent within three years after the sale.  An action to set aside the sale shall be instituted and maintained within three years from the discovery of the fraud or other lawful grounds upon which the action is based.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-223 Minority or disability prevents running of period.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-224 Disabilities -- Time tolled.
------------------------------------------------------------
A statute of limitations may not be applied to a person's ability to bring an action during a period in which the person is:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-224(1): a minor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-224(2): mentally incompetent.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225 Actions related to improvements in real property.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(a): "Abandonment" means that there has been no design or construction activity on an improvement for a continuous period of at least one year.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(b): "Action" means any claim for judicial, arbitral, or administrative relief for acts, errors, omissions, or breach of duty arising out of or related to the design, construction, or installation of an improvement, regardless of whether that action is based in tort, contract, warranty, strict liability, product liability, indemnity, contribution, or other source of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(c): "Completion" means the date of substantial completion of an improvement to real property as established by the earliest of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(c)(i): a Certificate of Substantial Completion;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(c)(ii): a Certificate of Occupancy issued by a governing agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(c)(iii): the date of first use or possession of the improvement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(d): "Improvement" means any building, structure, infrastructure, road, utility, or other similar man-made change, addition, modification, or alteration to real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(e): "Person" means an individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, joint venture, association, proprietorship, or any other legal or governmental entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(f): "Provider" means any person:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(f)(i): contributing to, providing, or performing:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(f)(i)(A): studies, plans, specifications, drawings, designs, value engineering, cost or quantity estimates, surveys, staking, construction, installation, or labor to an improvement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(f)(i)(B): the review, observation, administration, management, supervision, inspections, and tests of construction for or in relation to an improvement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(1)(f)(ii): providing or contributing materials, products, or equipment that is incorporated into an improvement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(2): (7) The Legislature finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(2)(a): exposing a provider to suits and liability for acts, errors, omissions, or breach of duty after the possibility of injury or damage has become highly remote and unexpectedly creates costs and hardships to the provider and the citizens of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(2)(b): these costs and hardships include liability insurance costs, records storage costs, undue and unlimited liability risks during the life of both a provider and an improvement, and difficulties in defending against claims many years after completion of an improvement;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(2)(c): these costs and hardships constitute clear social and economic evils;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(2)(d): the possibility of injury and damage becomes highly remote and unexpected seven years following completion or abandonment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(2)(e): (7) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(3): (3)(b); (c); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(3)(a): (3)(b); (c) Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(3)(b): (3)(a) If a provider is required by an express term of a contract or warranty to perform an obligation later than the six-year period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(3)(c): If a contract or warranty expressly establishes a different period of limitations than this section, the action shall be commenced within that limitations period.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(4): (4)(a); (4)(d); (4); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(4)(a): All other actions by or against a provider shall be commenced within two years from the earlier of the date of discovery of a cause of action or the date upon which a cause of action should have been discovered through reasonable diligence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(4)(b): If the cause of action is discovered or discoverable before completion or abandonment of an improvement, the two-year period begins to run upon completion or abandonment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(4)(c): (4)(a); (4)(d); (4) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(4)(d): (4)(a) If an action under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(5)(b): for a willful or intentional act, error, omission, or breach of duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(6): (3); (4) If an individual otherwise entitled to bring an action did not commence the action within the periods prescribed by Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(7): This section shall not apply to an action for the death of or bodily injury to an individual while engaged in the design, installation, or construction of an improvement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-225(8): This section does not apply to any action against any person in actual possession or control of the improvement as owner, tenant, or otherwise, at the time any defective or unsafe condition of the improvement proximately causes the injury for which the action is brought.

--------------------------------------------------
An action may be brought within six months against a tax collector or the tax collector's designee:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-301(1): to recover any goods, wares, merchandise, other property seized in his official capacity, or the price or value of any of it;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-301(2): for damages for the seizure, detention, sale of, or injury to, any goods, wares, merchandise, or other personal property seized;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-301(3): for damages done to any person or property in making a seizure;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-301(4): for money paid or seized under protest and which, it is claimed, ought to be refunded.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-303 One year -- Actions on claims against county, city, or town.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Actions on claims against a county, city, or incorporated town, which have been rejected by the county  executive, city commissioners, city council, or board of trustees shall be brought within one year after the first rejection.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-304 Within two years.
-------------------------------------------------
An action may be brought within two years:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-304(1): against a marshal, sheriff, constable, or other officer for liability incurred during the performance of the officer's official duties or by the omission of an official duty, including the nonpayment of money collected upon an execution;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-304(2): for recovery of damages for a death caused by the wrongful act or neglect of another;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-304(3): in causes of action against the state and its employees, for injury to the personal rights of another if not otherwise provided by state or federal law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-304(4): in causes of action against a political subdivision of the state and its employees, for injury to the personal rights of another arising after May 1, 2000, if not otherwise provided by state or federal law.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-306 Action against corporate stockholders or directors.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Actions against directors or stockholders of a corporation to recover a penalty or forfeiture imposed, or to enforce a liability created shall be brought within three years after the discovery by the aggrieved party of the facts upon which the penalty or forfeiture attached, or the liability accrued.  Actions against stockholders of a bank pursuant to levy of assessment to collect their statutory liability must be brought within three years after the levy of the assessment.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308 Legislative findings -- Civil actions for sexual abuse of a child -- Window for revival of time barred claims.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(1): The Legislature finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(1)(a): child sexual abuse is a crime that hurts the most vulnerable in our society and destroys lives;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(1)(b): research over the last 30 years has shown that it takes decades for children and adults to pull their lives back together and find the strength to face what happened to them;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(1)(c): often the abuse is compounded by the fact that the perpetrator is a member of the victim's family and when such abuse comes out, the victim is further stymied by the family's wish to avoid public embarrassment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(1)(d): even when the abuse is not committed by a family member, the perpetrator is rarely a stranger and, if in a position of authority, often brings pressure to bear on the victim to ensure silence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(1)(e): in 1992, when the Legislature enacted the statute of limitations requiring victims to sue within four years of majority, society did not understand the long-lasting effects of abuse on the victim and that it takes decades for the healing necessary for a victim to seek redress;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(1)(f): the Legislature, as the policy-maker for the state, may take into consideration advances in medical science and understanding in revisiting policies and laws shown to be harmful to the citizens of this state rather than beneficial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(1)(g): the Legislature has the authority to change old laws in the face of new information, and set new policies within the limits of due process, fairness, and justice.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2): 76-5-401.1 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2)(a): "Child" means an individual under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2)(b): "Discovery" means when a victim knows or reasonably should know that the injury or illness was caused by the intentional or negligent sexual abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2)(c): "Injury or illness" means either a physical injury or illness or a psychological injury or illness.  A psychological injury or illness need not be accompanied by physical injury or illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2)(d): 76-5-401.1 "Molestation" means that an individual, with the intent to arouse or gratify the sexual desire of any individual, touches the anus, buttocks, pubic area, or genitalia of any child, or the breast of a female child, or takes indecent liberties with a child as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2)(e): "Negligently" means a failure to act to prevent the child sexual abuse from further occurring or to report the child sexual abuse to law enforcement when the adult who could act knows or reasonably should know of the child sexual abuse and is the victim's parent, stepparent, adoptive parent, foster parent, legal guardian, ancestor, descendant, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, first cousin, nephew, niece, grandparent, stepgrandparent, or any individual cohabiting in the child's home.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2)(f): "Perpetrator" means an individual who has committed an act of sexual abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2)(g): "Sexual abuse" means acts or attempted acts of sexual intercourse, sodomy, or molestation by an adult directed towards a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(2)(h): "Victim" means an individual who was intentionally or negligently sexually abused.  It does not include individuals whose claims are derived through another individual who was sexually abused.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(3)(a): A victim may file a civil action against a perpetrator for intentional or negligent sexual abuse suffered as a child at any time.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(3)(b): A victim may file a civil action against a non-perpetrator for intentional or negligent sexual abuse suffered as a child:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(3)(b)(i): within four years after the individual attains the age of 18 years; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(3)(b)(ii): if a victim discovers sexual abuse only after attaining the age of 18 years, that individual may bring a civil action for such sexual abuse within four years after discovery of the sexual abuse, whichever period expires later.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(4): The victim need not establish which act in a series of continuing sexual abuse incidents caused the injury complained of, but may compute the date of discovery from the date of discovery of the last act by the same perpetrator which is part of a common scheme or plan of sexual abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(5): The knowledge of a custodial parent or guardian may not be imputed to an individual under the age of 18 years.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(6): 76-2-202 A civil action may be brought only against a living individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(6)(a): intentionally perpetrated the sexual abuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(6)(b): 76-2-202 would be criminally responsible for the sexual abuse in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(6)(c): negligently permitted the sexual abuse to occur.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(7): (6)(a); (b); (7) A civil action against an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(8): (7) A civil action may not be brought as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(8)(a): any claim that has been litigated to finality on the merits in a court of competent jurisdiction prior to July 1, 2016, however termination of a prior civil action on the basis of the expiration of the statute of limitations does not constitute a claim that has been litigated to finality on the merits; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-308(8)(b): any claim where a written settlement agreement was entered into between a victim and a defendant or perpetrator, unless the settlement agreement was the result of fraud, duress, or unconscionability. There is a rebuttable presumption that a settlement agreement signed by the victim when the victim was not represented by an attorney admitted to practice law in this state at the time of the settlement was the result of fraud, duress, or unconscionability.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-310 Actions against public officers -- Within six years.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An action by the state, any agency, or public corporation against any public officer for malfeasance, misfeasance, or nonfeasance in office or against any surety upon his official bond may be brought within six years after the officer ceases to hold his office.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-311 Eight years.
--------------------------------------------
An action may be brought within eight years upon a judgment or decree of any court of the United States, or of any state or territory within the United States.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-312 Action on mutual account -- When considered accrued.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In an action brought to recover a balance due upon a mutual, open, and current account, where there have been reciprocal demands between the parties, the cause of action shall be considered to have accrued from the time of the last item proved in the account on either side.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313 Action to recover deficiency after short sale.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(a): "Deficiency" means the balance owed to a secured lender under a secured loan after completion of a short sale of the secured property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(b): "Obligor" means the person or persons obligated to pay a secured loan.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(c): "Secured lender" means the person or persons to whom the obligation under a secured loan is owed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(d): "Secured loan" means a loan or other credit for personal, family, or household purposes secured by a mortgage or trust deed on secured property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(e): "Secured property" means single-family, residential real property located in the state that is the subject of a mortgage or trust deed to secure a secured loan.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(f): "Short sale" means a sale:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(f)(i): of secured property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(f)(ii): by the owner of the secured property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(f)(iii): that results in the secured lender being paid less than the balance owing under the secured loan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(1)(f)(iv): made with the secured lender's consent and resulting in the secured lender releasing the mortgage or reconveying the trust deed on the secured property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(2): An action to recover a deficiency is barred unless it is commenced no more than three months after the date of recording of a release of mortgage or reconveyance of trust deed with respect to secured property and resulting from a short sale of that property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(3): (2) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(4): (2) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(4)(a): is executed:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(4)(a)(i): between one or more obligors under a secured loan and the secured lender; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(4)(a)(ii): in connection with a short sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-2-313(4)(b): obligates an obligor to pay some or all of a deficiency.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 3 - Actions and Venue

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-101 Husband and wife -- Actions -- Defense -- Absent spouse.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-101(1): If a husband and wife are sued jointly, either or both may defend in each one's own right or for both parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-101(2): Either party to a marriage may sue and be sued in the same manner as if the person is unmarried.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-101(3): When a spouse has deserted the family, the remaining spouse may prosecute or defend in the absent spouse's name any action which the absent spouse might have prosecuted or defended.  All powers and rights the absent spouse might have shall be extended to the remaining spouse.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-102 Injury of a child -- Suit by parent or guardian.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-102(1): Title 34A, Chapter 2, Workers' Compensation Act Except as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-102(2): A civil action may be maintained against the person causing the injury or, if the person is employed by another person who is responsible for that person's conduct, also against the employer.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-102(3): 78A-2-703; 78A-2-705 If a parent, stepparent, adoptive parent, or legal guardian is the alleged defendant in an action for the injury of a child, a guardian ad litem may be appointed for the injured child according to the procedures outlined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-103 Successive actions on same contract.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Successive actions may be maintained upon the same contract or transaction if, after a former action, a new cause of action arises from it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-104 Actions against officers -- Bond required -- Costs and attorney fees.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-104(1): A person may not file an action against a law enforcement officer acting within the scope of the officer's official duties unless the person has posted a bond in an amount determined by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-104(2): The bond shall cover all estimated costs and attorney fees the officer may be expected to incur in defending the action, in the event the officer prevails.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-104(3): The prevailing party shall recover from the losing party all costs and attorney fees allowed by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-104(4): In the event the plaintiff prevails, the official bond of the officer shall be liable for the plaintiff's costs and attorney fees.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-109 Right to life -- State policy -- Act or omission preventing abortion not actionable -- Failure or refusal to prevent birth not a defense.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-109(1): The Legislature finds and declares that it is the public policy of this state to encourage all persons to respect the right to life of all other persons, regardless of age, development, condition, or dependency, including all persons with a disability and all unborn persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-109(2): A cause of action may not arise, and damages may not be awarded, on behalf of any person, based on the claim that but for the act or omission of another, a person would not have been permitted to have been born alive but would have been aborted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-109(3): The failure or refusal of any person to prevent the live birth of a person may not be a defense in any action, and may not be considered in awarding damages or child support, or imposing a penalty, in any action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-201 Title -- Purpose.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-201(1): This part is known as the "Nonresident Jurisdiction Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-201(2): It is declared, as a matter of legislative policy, that the public interest demands the state provide its citizens with an effective means of redress against nonresident persons, who, through certain significant minimal contacts with this state, incur obligations to citizens entitled to the state's protection.  This legislative action is necessary because of technological progress which has substantially increased the flow of commerce between the several states resulting in increased interaction between persons of this state and persons of other states.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-201(3): The provisions of this part, to ensure maximum protection to citizens of this state, should be applied so as to assert jurisdiction over nonresident defendants to the fullest extent permitted by the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-202 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-202(1): The words "any person" mean any individual, firm, company, association, or corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-202(2): The words "transaction of business within this state" mean activities of a nonresident person, his agents, or representatives in this state which affect persons or businesses within the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-206 Service of process.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-206(1): Service of process on any party outside the state may be made pursuant to the applicable provisions of Rule 4 of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-206(2): Service of summons and of a copy of the complaint, if any, may also be made upon any person located without this state by any individual over 21 years of age, not a party to the action, with the same force and effect as though the summons had been personally served within this state.  No order of court is required.  An affidavit of the server shall be filed with the court stating the time, manner and place of service.  The court may consider the affidavit, or any other competent proofs, in determining whether proper service has been made.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-206(3): Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to limit or affect the right to serve process in any other manner provided by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-207 Only claims arising from enumerated acts may be asserted.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Only claims arising from acts enumerated in this part may be asserted against a defendant in an action in which jurisdiction over him is based upon this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-208 Default judgments.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-208(1): A default judgement may not be entered until the expiration of at least 30 days after service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-208(2): A default judgment entered on service may be set aside only on a showing which would be timely and sufficient to set aside a default judgment entered on personal service within this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-209 When exercisable.
-------------------------------------------------
Subject to the applicable statute of limitations, jurisdiction established under this part may be exercised regardless of when the claim arose.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-401 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part shall be known and may be cited as the "Utah Health Care Malpractice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-402 Legislative findings and declarations -- Purpose of act.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-402(1): The Legislature finds and declares that the number of suits and claims for damages and the amount of judgments and settlements arising from health care has increased greatly in recent years.  Because of these increases the insurance industry has substantially increased the cost of medical malpractice insurance.  The effect of increased insurance premiums and increased claims is increased health care cost, both through the health care providers passing the cost of premiums to the patient and through the provider's practicing defensive medicine because he views a patient as a potential adversary in a lawsuit.  Further, certain health care providers are discouraged from continuing to provide services because of the high cost and possible unavailability of malpractice insurance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-402(2): In view of these recent trends and with the intention of alleviating the adverse effects which these trends are producing in the public's health care system, it is necessary to protect the public interest by enacting measures designed to encourage private insurance companies to continue to provide health-related malpractice insurance while at the same time establishing a mechanism to ensure the availability of insurance in the event that it becomes unavailable from private companies.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-402(3): In enacting this act, it is the purpose of the Legislature to provide a reasonable time in which actions may be commenced against health care providers while limiting that time to a specific period for which professional liability insurance premiums can be reasonably and accurately calculated; and to provide other procedural changes to expedite early evaluation and settlement of claims.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-403(37): 58-60-205 "Social service worker" means a person licensed to practice as a social service worker under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-403(38): Title 58, Chapter 41, Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology Licensing Act "Speech-language pathologist" means a person licensed to practice speech-language pathology under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-403(39): "Tort" means any legal wrong, breach of duty, or negligent or unlawful act or omission proximately causing injury or damage to another.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-403(40): "Unanticipated outcome" means the outcome of a medical treatment or procedure that differs from an expected result.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-404 Statute of limitations -- Exceptions -- Application.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-404(1): A malpractice action against a health care provider shall be commenced within two years after the plaintiff or patient discovers, or through the use of reasonable diligence should have discovered the injury, whichever first occurs, but not to exceed four years after the date of the alleged act, omission, neglect, or occurrence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-404(2): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-404(2)(a): in an action where the allegation against the health care provider is that a foreign object has been wrongfully left within a patient's body, the claim shall be barred unless commenced within one year after the plaintiff or patient discovers, or through the use of reasonable diligence should have discovered, the existence of the foreign object wrongfully left in the patient's body, whichever first occurs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-404(2)(b): in an action where it is alleged that a patient has been prevented from discovering misconduct on the part of a health care provider because that health care provider has affirmatively acted to fraudulently conceal the alleged misconduct, the claim shall be barred unless commenced within one year after the plaintiff or patient discovers, or through the use of reasonable diligence, should have discovered the fraudulent concealment, whichever first occurs.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405 Amount of award reduced by amounts of collateral sources available to plaintiff -- No reduction where subrogation right exists -- Collateral sources defined -- Procedure to preserve subrogation rights -- Evidence admissible -- Exceptions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(1): 78B-3-403 In all malpractice actions against health care providers as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(2): (5) Upon a finding of liability and an awarding of damages by the trier of fact, the court shall receive evidence concerning the total amounts of collateral sources which have been paid to or for the benefit of the plaintiff or are otherwise available to him.  The court shall also take testimony of any amount which has been paid, contributed, or forfeited by, or on behalf of the plaintiff or members of his immediate family to secure his right to any collateral source benefit which he is receiving as a result of his injury, and shall offset any reduction in the award by those amounts.  Evidence may not be received and a reduction may not be made with respect to future collateral source benefits except as specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(3): For purposes of this section "collateral source" means payments made to or for the benefit of the plaintiff for:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(3)(a): medical expenses and disability payments payable under the United States Social Security Act, any federal, state, or local income disability act, or any other public program, except the federal programs which are required by law to seek subrogation;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(3)(b): any health, sickness, or income replacement insurance, automobile accident insurance that provides health benefits or income replacement coverage, and any other similar insurance benefits, except life insurance benefits available to the plaintiff, whether purchased by the plaintiff or provided by others;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(3)(c): any contract or agreement of any person, group, organization, partnership, or corporation to provide, pay for, or reimburse the costs of hospital, medical, dental, or other health care services, except benefits received as gifts, contributions, or assistance made gratuitously; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(3)(d): any contractual or voluntary wage continuation plan provided by employers or any other system intended to provide wages during a period of disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(4): To preserve subrogation rights for amounts paid or received prior to settlement or judgment, a provider of collateral sources shall, at least 30 days before settlement or trial of the action, serve a written notice upon each health care provider against whom the malpractice action has been asserted.  The written notice shall state:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(4)(a): the name and address of the provider of collateral sources;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(4)(b): the amount of collateral sources paid;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(4)(c): the names and addresses of all persons who received payment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(4)(d): the items and purposes for which payment has been made.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(5): Evidence is admissible of government programs that provide payments or benefits available in the future to or for the benefit of the plaintiff to the extent available irrespective of the recipient's ability to pay.  Evidence of the likelihood or unlikelihood that the programs, payments, or benefits will be available in the future is also admissible.  The trier of fact may consider the evidence in determining the amount of damages awarded to a plaintiff for future expenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(6): Title 26B, Chapter 3, Part 10, Medical Benefits Recovery A provider of collateral sources is not entitled to recover any amount of benefits from a health care provider, the plaintiff, or any other person or entity as reimbursement for collateral source payments made prior to settlement or judgment, including any payments made under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-405(7): All policies of insurance providing benefits affected by this section are construed in accordance with this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406 Failure to obtain informed consent -- Proof required of patient -- Defenses -- Consent to health care.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(a): When a person submits to health care rendered by a health care provider, it is presumed that actions taken by the health care provider are either expressly or impliedly authorized to be done.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(b): For a patient to recover damages from a health care provider in an action based upon the provider's failure to obtain informed consent, the patient must prove the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(b)(i): that a provider-patient relationship existed between the patient and health care provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(b)(ii): the health care provider rendered health care to the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(b)(iii): the patient suffered personal injuries arising out of the health care rendered;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(b)(iv): the health care rendered carried with it a substantial and significant risk of causing the patient serious harm;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(b)(v): the patient was not informed of the substantial and significant risk;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(b)(vi): a reasonable, prudent person in the patient's position would not have consented to the health care rendered after having been fully informed as to all facts relevant to the decision to give consent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(1)(b)(vii): the unauthorized part of the health care rendered was the proximate cause of personal injuries suffered by the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(2): In determining what a reasonable, prudent person in the patient's position would do under the circumstances, the finder of fact shall use the viewpoint of the patient before health care was provided and before the occurrence of any personal injuries alleged to have arisen from said health care.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(3): It shall be a defense to any malpractice action against a health care provider based upon alleged failure to obtain informed consent if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(3)(a): the risk of the serious harm which the patient actually suffered was relatively minor;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(3)(b): the risk of serious harm to the patient from the health care provider was commonly known to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(3)(c): the patient stated, prior to receiving the health care complained of, that he would accept the health care involved regardless of the risk; or that he did not want to be informed of the matters to which he would be entitled to be informed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(3)(d): the health care provider, after considering all of the attendant facts and circumstances, used reasonable discretion as to the manner and extent to which risks were disclosed, if the health care provider reasonably believed that additional disclosures could be expected to have a substantial and adverse effect on the patient's condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(3)(e): the patient or the patient's representative executed a written consent which sets forth the nature and purpose of the intended health care and which contains a declaration that the patient accepts the risk of substantial and serious harm, if any, in hopes of obtaining desired beneficial results of health care and which acknowledges that health care providers involved have explained the patient's condition and the proposed health care in a satisfactory manner and that all questions asked about the health care and its attendant risks have been answered in a manner satisfactory to the patient or the patient's representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(4): The written consent shall be a defense to an action against a health care provider based upon failure to obtain informed consent unless the patient proves that the person giving the consent lacked capacity to consent or shows by clear and convincing evidence that the execution of the written consent was induced by the defendant's affirmative acts of fraudulent misrepresentation or fraudulent omission to state material facts.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(5): This act may not be construed to prevent any person 18 years old or over from refusing to consent to health care for the patient's own person upon personal or religious grounds.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6): 76-7-304.5; 80-7-105; 26B-7-522 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(a): any parent, whether an adult or a minor, for the parent's minor child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(b): any married person, for a spouse;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(c): any person temporarily standing in loco parentis, whether formally serving or not, for the minor under that person's care and any guardian for the guardian's ward;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(d): any person 18 years old or older for that person's parent who is unable by reason of age, physical or mental condition, to provide such consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(e): any patient 18 years old or older;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(f): any female regardless of age or marital status, when given in connection with her pregnancy or childbirth;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(g): in the absence of a parent, any adult for the adult's minor brother or sister;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(h): in the absence of a parent, any grandparent for the grandparent's minor grandchild;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(i): 80-7-105 an emancipated minor as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(j): a minor who has contracted a lawful marriage;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(k): an unaccompanied homeless minor, as that term is defined in the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act of 1987, Pub. L. 100-77, as amended, who is 15 years old or older; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(6)(l): 26B-7-522 a minor receiving tobacco and nicotine cessation services under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(7): A person who in good faith consents or authorizes health care treatment or procedures for another as provided by this act may not be subject to civil liability.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-406(8): 58-1-509; 58-1-509 Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, if a health care provider fails to comply with the requirement in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407 Limitation on actions against health care providers when parent or guardian refuses to consent to health care of child.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(1): A malpractice action against a health care provider may not be brought on the basis of the consequences resulting from the refusal of a child's parent or guardian to consent to the child's health care, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(1)(a): the health care is recommended by the health care provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(1)(b): the parent or guardian is provided with sufficient information to make an informed decision regarding the recommendation of the health care provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(1)(c): the consent of the parent or guardian is required by law before the health care may be administered.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(2): The sole purpose of this section is to prohibit a malpractice action against a health care provider under the circumstances set forth by this section.  This section may not be construed to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(2)(a): create a new cause of action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(2)(b): expand an existing cause of action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(2)(c): impose a new duty on a health care provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-407(2)(d): expand an existing duty of a health care provider.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-408 Writing required as basis for liability for breach of guarantee, warranty, contract, or assurance of result.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Liability may not be imposed upon any health care provider on the basis of an alleged breach of guarantee, warranty, contract, or assurance of result to be obtained from any health care rendered unless the guarantee, warranty, contract, or assurance is set forth in writing and signed by the health care provider or an authorized agent of the provider.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-409 Ad damnum clause prohibited in complaint.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
A dollar amount may not be specified in the prayer of a complaint filed in a malpractice action against a health care provider.  The complaint shall merely pray for such damages as are reasonable in the circumstances.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412 Notice of intent to commence action.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(1): 78B-3-418 A malpractice action against a health care provider may not be initiated unless and until the plaintiff:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(1)(a): gives the prospective defendant or his executor or successor, at least 90 days' prior notice of intent to commence an action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(1)(b): 78B-3-418 except for an action against a dentist or a dental care provider, the plaintiff receives a certificate of compliance from the division in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(2): The notice shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(2)(a): a general statement of the nature of the claim;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(2)(b): the persons involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(2)(c): the date, time, and place of the occurrence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(2)(d): the circumstances surrounding the claim;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(2)(e): specific allegations of misconduct on the part of the prospective defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(2)(f): the nature of the alleged injuries and other damages sustained.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(3): Notice may be in letter or affidavit form executed by the plaintiff or his attorney. Service shall be accomplished by persons authorized and in the manner prescribed by the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure for the service of the summons and complaint in a civil action or by certified mail, return receipt requested, in which case notice shall be considered served on the date of mailing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(4): Notice shall be served within the time allowed for commencing a malpractice action against a health care provider.  If the notice is served less than 90 days prior to the expiration of the applicable time period, the time for commencing the malpractice action against the health care provider shall be extended to 120 days from the date of service of notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-412(5): This section shall, for purposes of determining its retroactivity, not be construed as relating to the limitation on the time for commencing any action, and shall apply only to causes of action arising on or after April 1, 1976. This section shall not apply to third party actions, counterclaims or crossclaims against a health care provider.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-413 Professional liability insurance coverage for providers -- Insurance commissioner may require joint underwriting authority.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-413(1): The commissioner may, after a public hearing, find that professional liability insurance coverage for health care providers is not readily available in the voluntary market in a specific part of this state, and that the public interest requires that action be taken.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-413(2): The commissioner may promulgate rules and implement plans to provide insurance coverage through all insurers issuing professional liability policies and individual and group accident and sickness policies providing medical, surgical or hospital expense coverage on either a prepaid or an expense incurred basis, including personal injury protection and medical expense coverage issued incidental to liability insurance policies.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414 Periodic payment of future damages in malpractice actions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(1): 78B-3-403 In any malpractice action against a health care provider, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(2): In rendering a judgment which orders the payment of future damages by periodic payments, the court shall order periodic payments to provide a fair correlation between the sustaining of losses and the payment of damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(2)(a): Lost future earnings shall be paid over the judgment creditor's work life expectancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(2)(b): The court shall also order, when appropriate, that periodic payments increase at a fixed rate, equal to the rate of inflation which the finder of fact used to determine the amount of future damages, or as measured by the most recent Consumer Price Index applicable to Utah for all goods and services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(2)(c): The present cash value of all periodic payments shall equal the fact finder's award of future damages, less any amount paid for attorney fees and costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(2)(d): The present cash value of periodic payments shall be determined by discounting the total amount of periodic payments projected over the judgment creditor's life expectancy, by the rate of interest which the finder of fact used to reduce the amount of future damages to present value, or the rate of interest available at the time of trial on one year U.S. Government Treasury Bills.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(3): Before periodic payments of future damages may be ordered, the court shall require a judgment debtor to post security which assures full payment of those damages.  Security for payment of a judgment of periodic payments may be in one or more of the following forms:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(3)(a): a bond executed by a qualified insurer;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(3)(b): an annuity contract executed by a qualified insurer;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(3)(c): evidence of applicable and collectable liability insurance with one or more qualified insurers;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(3)(d): an agreement by one or more qualified insurers to guarantee payment of the judgment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(3)(e): any other form of security approved by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(4): Security which complies with this section may also serve as a supersedeas bond, where one is required.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(5): A judgment which orders payment of future damages by periodic payments shall specify the recipient or recipients of the payments, the dollar amount of the payments, the interval between payments, and the number of payments or the period of time over which payments shall be made.  Those payments may only be modified in the event of the death of the judgment creditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(6): If the court finds that the judgment debtor, or the assignee of his obligation to make periodic payments, has failed to make periodic payments as ordered by the court, it shall, in addition to the required periodic payments, order the judgment debtor or his assignee to pay the judgment creditor all damages caused by the failure to make payments, including court costs and attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(7): The obligation to make periodic payments for all future damages, other than damages for loss of future earnings, shall cease upon the death of the judgment creditor.  Damages awarded for loss of future earnings may not be reduced or payments terminated by reason of the death of the judgment creditor, but shall be paid to persons to whom the judgment creditor owed a duty of support, as provided by law, immediately prior to his death.  In that case the court which rendered the original judgment may, upon petition of any party in interest, modify the judgment to award and apportion the unpaid future damages in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-414(8): (3) If security is posted in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-415 Actions under Utah Governmental Immunity Act.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this part shall apply to malpractice actions against health care providers which are brought under the Utah Governmental Immunity Act if applicable.  This part may not affect the requirements for filing notices of claims, times for commencing actions and limitations on amounts recoverable under the Utah Governmental Immunity Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417 Proceedings -- Authority of panel -- Rights of parties to proceedings.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(1): No record of the proceedings is required and all evidence, documents, and exhibits are returned to the parties or witnesses who provided the evidence, documents, and exhibits at the end of the proceedings upon the request of the parties or witnesses who provided the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(2): The division may issue subpoenas for medical records directly related to the claim of medical liability in accordance with division rule and in compliance with the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(2)(a): the subpoena shall be prepared by the requesting party in proper form for issuance by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(2)(b): the subpoena shall be accompanied by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(2)(b)(i): an affidavit prepared by the person requesting the subpoena attesting to the fact the medical record subject to subpoena is believed to be directly related to the medical liability claim to which the subpoena is related; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(2)(b)(ii): by a written release for the medical records to be provided to the person requesting the subpoena, signed by the individual who is the subject of the medical record or by that individual's guardian or conservator.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(3): Per diem reimbursement to panel members and expenses incurred by the panel in the conduct of prelitigation panel hearings shall be paid by the division.  Expenses related to subpoenas are paid by the requesting party, including witness fees and mileage.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(4): The proceedings are informal and formal rules of evidence are not applicable.  There is no discovery or perpetuation of testimony in the proceedings, except upon special order of the panel, and for good cause shown demonstrating extraordinary circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(5)(a): A party is entitled to attend, personally or with counsel, and participate in the proceedings, except upon special order of the panel and unanimous agreement of the parties.  The proceedings are confidential and closed to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(5)(b): No party has the right to cross-examine, rebut, or demand that customary formalities of civil trials and court proceedings be followed.  The panel may, however, request special or supplemental participation of some or all parties in particular respects.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(5)(c): Communications between the panel and the parties, except the testimony of the parties on the merits of the dispute, are disclosed to all other parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(6): The division shall appoint a panel to consider the claim and set the matter for panel review as soon as practicable after receipt of a request.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-417(7): Parties may be represented by counsel in proceedings before a panel.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-419 Evidence of proceedings not admissible in subsequent action -- Panelist may not be compelled to testify -- Immunity of panelist from civil liability -- Information regarding professional conduct.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-419(1): Evidence of the proceedings conducted by the medical review panel and its results, opinions, findings, and determinations are not admissible as evidence in any civil action or arbitration proceeding subsequently brought by the claimant against any respondent and are not reportable to any health care facility or health care insurance carrier as a part of any credentialing process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-419(2): No panelist may be compelled to testify in a civil action subsequently filed with regard to the subject matter of the panel's review.  A panelist has immunity from civil liability arising from participation as a panelist and for all communications, findings, opinions, and conclusions made in the course and scope of duties prescribed by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-419(3): Nothing in this chapter may be interpreted to prohibit the division from considering any information contained in a statutory notice of intent to commence action, request for prelitigation panel review, or written findings of a panel with respect to the division's determining whether a licensee engaged in unprofessional or unlawful conduct.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-422(1): As used in this section:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424 Limitation of liability for ostensible agent.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(1): 34A-2-104 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(1)(a): 34A-2-104 "Agent" means a person who is an "employee," "worker," or "operative," as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(1)(b): "Ostensible agent" means a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(1)(b)(i): who is not an agent of the health care provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(1)(b)(ii): who the plaintiff reasonably believes is an agent of the health care provider because the health care provider intentionally, or as a result of a lack of ordinary care, caused the plaintiff to believe that the person was an agent of the health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(2): (2)(b) A health care provider named as a defendant in a medical malpractice action is not liable for the acts or omissions of an ostensible agent if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(2)(a): the ostensible agent has privileges with the health care provider, but is not an agent of the health care provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(2)(b): the health care provider has, by policy or practice, ensured that a person providing professional services has insurance of a type and amount required, if any is required, by the rules or regulations as established in:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(2)(b)(i): medical staff by-laws for a health care facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(2)(b)(ii): other health care facility contracts, indemnification agreements, rules or regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(2)(c): (2)(b) the insurance required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(2)(d): there is a claim of agency or ostensible agency in a plaintiff's notice of intent to commence an action, the health care provider, within 60 days of the service of the notice of intent to commence an action, lists each person identified by the plaintiff who the provider claims is not an agent or ostensible agent of the provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-424(3): This section applies to a cause of action that arises on or after July 1, 2010.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-425 Prohibition on cause of action for negligent credentialing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is the policy of this state that the question of negligent credentialing, as applied to health care providers in malpractice suits, is not recognized as a cause of action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-426 Nonpatient plaintiffs.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-426(1): 78B-3-403 For purposes of this section, a nonpatient plaintiff does not include a patient, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-426(2): 78B-3-106; 78B-3-107; 78B-3-502; 81-3-111 This section does not apply to a health care malpractice action brought or seeking recovery under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-426(3): To establish a malpractice action against a health care provider, a nonpatient plaintiff shall be required to show that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-426(3)(a): the health care provider owes a duty to the nonpatient plaintiff;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-426(3)(b): the nonpatient plaintiff suffered a foreseeable injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-426(3)(c): the nonpatient plaintiff's injury was proximately caused by an act or omission of the health care provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-426(3)(d): the health care provider's act or omission was conduct that manifests a knowing and reckless indifference toward, and a disregard of, the injury suffered by the nonpatient plaintiff.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-451 Medical candor process.
-------------------------------------------------------
In accordance with this part, a health care provider may engage an affected party in a process where the health care provider and any other health care provider notified in SubsectionUtah Code Annotated § 78B-3-451(1): conducts an investigation into an adverse event involving a patient and the health care provided to the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-451(2): (1) communicates information to the affected party regarding information gathered during an investigation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-451(3): communicates to the affected party the steps that the health care provider will take to prevent future occurrences of the adverse event; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-451(4): determines whether to make an offer of compensation to the affected party for the adverse event.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453 Nonparticipating health care providers -- Offer of compensation -- Payment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(1): 78B-3-452(1)(b); (1)(a); (b); (c) If any communications, materials, or information in any form during a medical candor process involve a health care provider that was notified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(1)(a): may provide only materials or information from the medical record to the affected party regarding any health care provided by the nonparticipating health care provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(1)(b): may not characterize, describe, or evaluate health care provided or not provided by the nonparticipating health care provider;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(2)(b): If a health care provider determines that an offer of compensation is warranted during a medical candor process, the health care provider shall provide the affected party with a written offer of compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(3): If a health care provider makes an offer of compensation to an affected party during a medical candor process and the affected party is not represented by legal counsel, the health care provider shall:
