Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(3)(b): notify the affected party that the affected party may be legally required to repay medical and other expenses that were paid by a third party, including private health insurance, Medicare, or Medicaid.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(4)(a): All parties to an offer of compensation shall negotiate the form of the relevant documents.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(4)(b): As a condition of an offer of compensation under this section, a health care provider may require an affected party to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(4)(b)(i): execute any document that is necessary to carry out an agreement between the parties regarding the offer of compensation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-453(4)(b)(ii): if court approval is required for compensation to a minor, obtain court approval for the offer of compensation.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-502 Limitation of therapist's duty to warn.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-502(1): A therapist has no duty to warn or take precautions to provide protection from any violent behavior of his client or patient, except when that client or patient communicated to the therapist an actual threat of physical violence against a clearly identified or reasonably identifiable victim.  That duty shall be discharged if the therapist makes reasonable efforts to communicate the threat to the victim, and notifies a law enforcement officer or agency of the threat.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-502(2): (1) An action may not be brought against a therapist for breach of trust or privilege, or for disclosure of confidential information, based on a therapist's communication of information to a third party in an effort to discharge his duty in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-502(3): 80-2-602 This section does not limit or affect a therapist's duty to report child abuse or neglect in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-601 Purpose.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-601(1): The purpose of this part is to facilitate the compensation of injured parties from financial protection funds established pursuant to the Price Anderson Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 2210.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-601(2): Nothing in this part may be construed to impose liability for harm from nuclear incidents for which financial protection is not afforded under the Price Anderson Act.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(1): 78B-3-603; 78B-3-603 "Harm" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(1)(a): 78B-3-603 personal injury, death, or illness, except an injury, death, or illness that is a basis for a claim under either a state or federal workmen's compensation act by an employee of a person liable pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(1)(b): damage to, destruction of, or loss of the use of property other than property at the situs of and used in connection with the activity giving rise to a nuclear incident;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(1)(c): economic loss due to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(1)(c)(i): damage to or loss of the use of property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(1)(c)(ii): environmental degradation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(1)(d): 78B-3-603 expenses reasonably incurred by the state, its political subdivisions, or the agencies of either in protecting the public health and safety and the environment from a nuclear incident or the imminent danger of a nuclear incident, including, but not limited to, precautionary evacuations, emergency response measures, and, after reasonable opportunity for performance of cleanup measures by persons liable pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(2): "Nuclear incident" means an incident which does not arise from an act of war and involves the release of nuclear material which results in personal injury, loss of use of property, or damage due to the radioactive, toxic, explosive, or other hazardous properties of the nuclear material.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(3): "Nuclear material" means radioactive material used or handled in connection with:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(3)(a): a utilization facility or production facility licensed by the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission in accordance with 42 U.S.C. Secs. 2133 or 2134;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(3)(b): a utilization or production facility constructed or operated under a contract for the benefit of the United States where there is a risk of a substantial nuclear incident as determined by the United States Department of Energy or the Nuclear Regulatory Commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(3)(c): disposal, storage, and other activities undertaken pursuant to the Nuclear Waste Policy Act, 42 U.S.C. Secs. 10101 through 10225.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(4): "Radioactive material" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(4)(a): source material as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 2014 (z);
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(4)(b): special nuclear material as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 2014 (aa); or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-602(4)(c): by-product material as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 2014 (e).


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603 Liability imposed and limitations -- Defenses -- Limitations on damages.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(1): Except as provided in this section, any person who owns, holds under license, transports, ships, stores, or disposes of nuclear material is liable, without regard to the conduct of any other person, for harm from nuclear incidents arising in connection with or resulting from such ownership, transportation, shipping, storage, or disposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(2): Except as provided in this section, any person who owns, designs, constructs, operates, or maintains facilities, structures, vehicles, or equipment used for handling, transportation, shipment, storage, or disposal of nuclear material is liable, without regard to the conduct of any other person, for harm from nuclear incidents arising in connection with or resulting from such ownership, design, construction, operation, and maintenance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(3): Liability established by this part shall only be imposed if a court of competent jurisdiction finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(3)(a): the nuclear incident which is the basis for the suit is covered by existing financial protection undertaken pursuant to 42 U.S.C. Sec. 2210; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(3)(b): a person who is liable under this part is a person indemnified as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 2014.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(4): Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah Immunity of the state, its political subdivisions, or the agencies of either from suit are only waived with respect to a suit arising from a nuclear incident:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(4)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(4)(b): when brought by a person suffering harm.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(5): The conduct of the person suffering harm is not a defense to liability, except that this section does not preclude any defense based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(5)(a): the claimant's knowing failure to mitigate damages related to any injury or damage to the claimant or the claimant's property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(5)(b): an incident involving nuclear material that is knowingly and wrongfully caused by the claimant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-603(6): A person may not collect punitive or exemplary damages under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-604 Determination of causation -- Compensation allowed.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-604(1): Causation of radiological injury from a nuclear incident shall be determined by the trier of fact, taking into account epidemiological studies, statistical probabilities, and other pertinent medical and scientific evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-604(2): A claimant under this part shall be entitled to full compensation of the claimant's radiological injuries if the trier of fact determines that it is more likely than not that the claimant's injuries resulted from the nuclear incident.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(1): 26B-6-801 "Disability" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(2): "Search and rescue dog" means a dog:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(2)(a): with documented training to locate persons who are:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(2)(a)(i): lost, missing, or injured; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(2)(a)(ii): trapped under debris as the result of a natural or man-made event; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(2)(b): affiliated with an established search and rescue dog organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(3): 26B-6-801 "Service animal" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(3)(a): 26B-6-801 a service animal, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-701(3)(b): a search and rescue dog.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702 Damages recoverable for harm to or theft of service animal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(1): A person with a disability who uses a service animal, or the owner of a service animal has a cause of action for economic and noneconomic damages against:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(1)(a): any person who steals or, without provocation, attacks the service animal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(1)(b): the owner or keeper of any animal that without provocation attacks a service animal due to the owner's or keeper's negligent failure to exercise sufficient control over the animal to prevent the attack.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(2): The action authorized by this section maybe brought by a person with a disability who uses the service animal, or the owner of the service animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(3): (1) The measure of economic damages in an action brought under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(3)(a): the replacement value of an equally trained service animal, without any differentiation for the age or experience of the animal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(3)(b): costs and expenses incurred by the person with a disability or the owner, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(3)(b)(i): costs of temporary replacement assistance services, whether provided by another service animal or by a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(3)(b)(ii): reasonable costs incurred in efforts to recover a stolen service animal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(3)(b)(iii): court and attorney costs incurred in bringing an action under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(4): If the unprovoked attack on a service animal results in injuries from which the animal recovers so it is able to again function as a service animal for the person with a disability, or if the theft of the service animal results in the recovery of the service animal and the animal is again able to function as a service animal for the person with a disability, the measure of economic damages is the costs and expenses incurred by the person with a disability or the owner as a result of the theft of or injury to the service animal, and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(4)(a): veterinary medical expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(4)(b): costs of temporary replacement assistance services, whether provided by another service animal or a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(4)(c): costs incurred in recovering the service animal, such as a reward; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-702(4)(d): court and attorney costs incurred in bringing an action under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-703 Limitation on cause of action.
--------------------------------------------------------------
A cause of action does not exist under this section if the person with a disability who uses the service animal or the person having custody or supervision of the service animal was committing a civil or criminal trespass at the time of the:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-703(1): theft of, or the chasing or harassment of the service animal by a person who owns or exercises control over the property upon which the trespass is committed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-703(2): attack upon, or the chasing or harassment of a service animal by an animal that is currently kept or maintained on the property where the trespass is committed.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(1): Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act As used in this section, "substance" means any illegal controlled substance under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(2): (3); (2)(a) A person is subject to a civil action by a person or an estate under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(2)(a): unlawfully provided to or administered to the deceased person or the addicted person any substance that caused or contributed to the person's addiction or to the death of the deceased person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(2)(b): (2)(a) unlawfully provided any substance to any person in the chain of transfer of the substance that connects directly to the person who subsequently provided or administered the illegal controlled substance to the addicted person or to the deceased person under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(3)(a): (2) A civil action for treble damages and punitive damages may be brought against any person under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(3)(b): (2) A civil action for treble damages, punitive damages, and costs of addiction treatment or rehabilitation may be brought against any person under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(4): The burden is on the estate or the addicted person to prove the causal connection between the death or addiction, any substances provided or administered to the deceased or addicted person, and the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(5): This section does not establish liability of or create a cause of action regarding:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-801(5)(b): a person who is licensed under Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act, and who acts in accordance with the act.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(1): "Commercial entity" includes corporations, limited liability companies, partnerships, limited partnerships, sole proprietorships, or other legally recognized entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(2): "Digitized identification card" means a data file available on any mobile device which has connectivity to the Internet through a state-approved application that allows the mobile device to download the data file from a state agency or an authorized agent of a state agency that contains all of the data elements visible on the face and back of a license or identification card and displays the current status of the license or identification card.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(3): "Distribute" means to issue, sell, give, provide, deliver, transfer, transmute, circulate, or disseminate by any means.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(4): "Internet" means the international computer network of both federal and non-federal interoperable packet switched data networks.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(5): "Material harmful to minors" is defined as all of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(5)(a): any material that the average person, applying contemporary community standards, would find, taking the material as a whole and with respect to minors, is designed to appeal to, or is designed to pander to, the prurient interest;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(5)(b): material that exploits, is devoted to, or principally consists of descriptions of actual, simulated, or animated display or depiction of any of the following, in a manner patently offensive with respect to minors:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(5)(b)(i): pubic hair, anus, vulva, genitals, or nipple of the female breast;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(5)(b)(ii): touching, caressing, or fondling of nipples, breasts, buttocks, anuses, or genitals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(5)(b)(iii): sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, excretory functions, exhibitions, or any other sexual act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(5)(c): the material taken as a whole lacks serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value for minors.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(6): "Minor" means any person under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(7): "News-gathering organization" means any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(7)(a): an employee of a newspaper, news publication, or news source, printed or on an online or mobile platform, of current news and public interest, while operating as an employee as provided in this subsection, who can provide documentation of such employment with the newspaper, news publication, or news source; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(7)(b): an employee of a radio broadcast station, television broadcast station, cable television operator, or wire service while operating as an employee as provided in this subsection, who can provide documentation of such employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(8): "Publish" means to communicate or make information available to another person or entity on a publicly available Internet website.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(9): "Reasonable age verification methods" means verifying that the person seeking to access the material is 18 years old or older by using any of the following methods:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(9)(a): use of a digitized information card as defined in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(9)(b): verification through an independent, third-party age verification service that compares the personal information entered by the individual who is seeking access to the material that is available from a commercially available database, or aggregate of databases, that is regularly used by government agencies and businesses for the purpose of age and identity verification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(9)(c): any commercially reasonable method that relies on public or private transactional data to verify the age of the person attempting to access the material.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(10): "Substantial portion" means more than 33-1/3% of total material on a website, which meets the definition of "material harmful to minors" as defined in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(11)(a): "Transactional data" means a sequence of information that documents an exchange, agreement, or transfer between an individual, commercial entity, or third party used for the purpose of satisfying a request or event.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1001(11)(b): "Transactional data" includes records from mortgage, education, and employment entities.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1002 Liability for publishers and distributors -- Age verification -- Retention of data -- Exceptions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1002(1): A commercial entity that knowingly and intentionally publishes or distributes material harmful to minors on the Internet from a website that contains a substantial portion of such material shall be held liable if the entity fails to perform reasonable age verification methods to verify the age of an individual attempting to access the material.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1002(2): A commercial entity or third party that performs the required age verification shall not retain any identifying information of the individual after access has been granted to the material.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1002(3): A commercial entity that is found to have violated this section shall be liable to an individual for damages resulting from a minor's accessing the material, including court costs and reasonable attorney fees as ordered by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1002(4): A commercial entity that is found to have knowingly retained identifying information of the individual after access has been granted to the individual shall be liable to the individual for damages resulting from retaining the identifying information, including court costs and reasonable attorney fees as ordered by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1002(5): This section shall not apply to any bona fide news or public interest broadcast, website video, report, or event and shall not be construed to affect the rights of a news-gathering organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1002(6): No Internet service provider, affiliate or subsidiary of an Internet service provider, search engine, or cloud service provider shall be held to have violated the provisions of this section solely for providing access or connection to or from a website or other information or content on the Internet, or a facility, system, or network not under that provider's control, including transmission, downloading, storing, or providing access, to the extent that such provider is not responsible for the creation of the content of the communication that constitutes material harmful to minors.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003 Liability of a parent or guardian for repeated offenses by a minor on school grounds.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003(1): Except as provided in Subsection (6), if a person suffers damages from a minor committing the same offense repeatedly on school grounds for an offense in Title 76, Utah Criminal Code, or Title 80, Utah Juvenile Code, the person may bring a cause of action against a parent or guardian with legal custody of the minor to recover costs and damages caused by the repeated offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003(2): The parent or guardian is not liable for costs or damages under Subsection (1) if the parent or guardian made a reasonable effort to supervise and direct the minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003(3): If a parent or guardian is found liable under this section, the court may waive part or all of the parent's or guardian's liability for costs or damages if the court finds:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003(3)(a): good cause; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003(3)(b): that the parent or guardian reported the minor's wrongful conduct to law enforcement after the parent or guardian knew of the minor's wrongful conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003(4): A report is not required under Subsection (3)(b)(ii) from a parent or guardian if the minor was arrested or apprehended by law enforcement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003(5): An adjudication or a conviction of a minor for a repeated offense under Title 76, Utah Criminal Code, or Title 80, Utah Juvenile Code, is not required for a civil action to be brought under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1003(6): A person may not bring a cause of action against the state, an agency of the state, or a contracted provider of an agency of the state, under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(1): 13-71-101 "Account holder" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(2)(a): "Adverse mental health outcome" means a condition affecting a minor's mental health that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(2)(a)(i): diagnosable by a licensed mental health care provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(2)(a)(ii): acknowledged by professional mental health experts as having a negative impact on a minor's well-being.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(2)(b): "Adverse mental health outcome" includes depression, anxiety, suicidal thoughts or behaviors, and self-harm thoughts or behaviors.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(3): "Algorithmically curated social media service" means a social media service that drives user engagement primarily through the use of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(3)(a): a curation algorithm; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(3)(b): engagement driven design elements.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(4): 13-71-101 "Content" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(a): "Curation algorithm" means a computational process or set of rules used by a social media platform that determines, influences, or personalizes, designed to encourage prolonged or frequent engagement:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(a)(i): the content a user views;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(a)(ii): the order in which content is displayed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(a)(iii): how prominently content is displayed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(a)(iv): the manner in which content is displayed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(b): "Curation algorithm" does not include the curation of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(b)(i): responses to specific user queries or user prompts requesting content related to defined topics or interests selected by the user; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(b)(ii): content to ensure only age appropriate material is provided to a user based on the user's age;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(b)(iii): content that prevents a minor from viewing violent, bullying, threatening, or harassing content; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(5)(b)(iv): content to comply with any state or federal law restricting the display of material harmful to minors.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(6): "Engagement driven design elements" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(6)(a): autoplay features that continuously play content without requiring user interaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(6)(b): scroll or pagination that loads additional content as long as the user continues scrolling; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(6)(c): push notifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(7): "Excessive use" means the use of a social media service by a minor to an extent that the use substantially interferes with the minor's normal functioning in:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(7)(a): academic performance;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(7)(b): sleep;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(7)(c): in-person relationships;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(7)(d): mental health; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(7)(e): physical health.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(8): 13-71-101 "Minor" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(9): "Parent" includes a legal guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(10): "Push notification" means an automatic electronic message displayed on an account holder's device, when the user interface for the social media service is not actively open or visible on the device, that prompts the account holder to repeatedly check and engage with the social media service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(11): 53-3-102 "Resident" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(12): 13-71-101 "Social media company" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(13): 13-71-101 "Social media service" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(14): 13-71-101 "User" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(15): 13-71-101 "Utah account holder" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1101(16): 13-71-101 "Utah minor account holder" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102 Legislative findings.
------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(1): social media services utilize curation algorithms and engagement driven design elements to maximize user engagement;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(2): minors are particularly vulnerable to manipulation by the use of curation algorithms and engagement driven design elements;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(3): a minor's excessive use of an algorithmically curated social media service is likely to cause adverse mental health outcomes in minors, regardless of the content being viewed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(4): the risk of an adverse mental health outcome resulting from the excessive use of an algorithmically curated social media service increases when a minor uses the service for more than three hours per day, or during regular sleeping hours;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(5): algorithmically curated social media services are designed without sufficient tools to allow adequate parental oversight, exposing minors to risks that could be mitigated with additional parental control;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(6): protecting minors from the risks associated with the use of algorithmically curated social media services requires intervention at a societal level, informed by expertise in technology, psychology, and youth mental health;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(7): the state has a long-established role and responsibility in implementing protections and regulations to safeguard the health and welfare of minors;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(8): the state has enacted safeguards around products and activities that pose risks to minors, including regulations on motor vehicles, medications, and products and services targeted to children;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(9): any adverse mental health outcomes for minors that are linked to the excessive use of algorithmically curated social media services are a serious public health concern for the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1102(10): the state has a compelling interest to protect minors in the state against adverse mental health outcomes.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103 Private right of action.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(1): A Utah minor account holder or a Utah minor account holder's parent may bring a cause of action against a social media company in court for an adverse mental health outcome arising, in whole or in part, from the minor's excessive use of the social media company's algorithmically curated social media service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(2): To recover damages in a cause of action brought under this section, a person bringing the cause of action must demonstrate:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(2)(a): that the Utah minor account holder has been diagnosed by a licensed mental health care provider with an adverse mental health outcome; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(2)(b): that the adverse mental health outcome was caused by the Utah minor account holder's excessive use of an algorithmically curated social media service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(3): Except as provided in Subsection (4), a person who brings an action described in Subsection (1), is entitled to a rebuttable presumption that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(3)(a): the Utah minor account holder's adverse mental health outcome was caused, in whole or in part, by the Utah minor account holder's excessive use of the algorithmically curated social media service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(3)(b): the Utah minor account holder's excessive use of the algorithmically curated social media service was caused, in whole or in part, by the algorithmically curated social media service's curation algorithm and engagement driven design elements.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(4): 78B-11-1104 A social media company that complies with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(4)(a): the Utah minor account holder's adverse mental health outcome was not caused, in whole or in part, by the Utah minor account holder's excessive use of the algorithmically curated social media service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(4)(b): the Utah minor account holder's excessive use of the algorithmically curated social media service was not caused, in whole or in part, by the algorithmically curated social media service's curation algorithm and engagement driven design elements.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(5): If a court or fact finder finds that a Utah minor account holder suffered any adverse mental health outcome as a result of the Utah minor account holder's use of a social media company's algorithmically curated social media service, the person seeking relief is entitled to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(5)(a): an award of reasonable attorney fees and court costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(5)(b): an amount equal to the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(5)(b)(i): $10,000 for each adverse mental health outcome incidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(5)(b)(ii): the amount of actual damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(6): A social media company may not be held liable under this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(6)(a): based on the content of material posted by users of the algorithmically curated social media service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(6)(b): for declining to restrict access to or modify user posts based solely on the content of those posts.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1103(7): Nothing in this part shall displace any other available remedies or rights authorized under the laws of this state or the United States.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1104 Affirmative defense.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1104(1): 78B-11-1103; 78B-11-1103 A person is not entitled to the rebuttable presumption described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1104(1)(a): limits a Utah minor account holder's use of the algorithmically curated social media service to no more than three hours in a 24 hour period across all devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1104(1)(b): restricts a Utah minor account holder from accessing the algorithmically curated social media service between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 6:30 a.m.;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1104(1)(c): requires the parent or legal guardian of the minor to consent to a Utah minor account holder's use of the algorithmically curated social media service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1104(1)(d): disables engagement driven design elements for a Utah minor account holder's account.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1104(2): A social media company may utilize settings that are enabled at the device level to impose the requirements described in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1104(3): Notwithstanding Subsection (2), a social media company remains liable to ensure that the Utah minor account holder's account is subject to the restrictions of Subsection (1).


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1105 Waiver prohibited.
---------------------------------------------------
A waiver or limitation, or a purported waiver or limitation, of any of the following is void as unlawful, is against public policy, and a court or arbitrator may not enforce or give effect to the waiver, notwithstanding any contract or choice-of-law provision in a contract:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1105(1): a protection or requirement provided under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1105(2): the right to cooperate with or file a complaint with a government agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1105(3): the right to a private right of action as provided under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1105(4): the right to recover actual damages, statutory damages, civil penalties, costs, or fees as allowed by this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1106 Severability.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1106(1): If any provision of this chapter or the application of any provision to any person or circumstance is held invalid by a final decision of a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3-1106(2): The provisions of this chapter are severable.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-102 Applicability of this chapter -- Venue for the Business and Chancery Court.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-102(1): Except as otherwise provided by another provision of the Utah Code, a plaintiff shall bring an action in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-102(2): The requirements of this chapter do not apply to an action brought in the Business and Chancery Court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-103 Transfer of venue.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-103(1): A court may transfer venue in accordance with Rule 42 of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-103(2): A court to which an action is transferred has the same jurisdiction as if the action had been originally brought in that court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-104 Residence of a business organization.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
For purposes of this chapter, the residence of a business organization is:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-104(1): the county where the business organization's principal place of business is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-104(2): the county where the business organization's registered office is located if the business organization does not have a principal place of business in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-104(3): Salt Lake County if the business organization does not have a principal place of business or a registered office in the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-201 All actions -- Exceptions.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-201(1): Except as otherwise provided by this chapter or another provision of the Utah Code, a plaintiff shall bring an action in the county in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-201(1)(a): the cause of action arises; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-201(1)(b): any defendant resides at the commencement of the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-201(2): If none of the defendants  reside in this state, the plaintiff may bring the action in any county designated by the plaintiff in the complaint.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-201(3): If the defendant is about to depart from the state, the plaintiff may bring the action in any county where any of the parties resides or service is had.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-202 Actions involving real property.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-202(1): A plaintiff shall bring the following actions involving real property in the county in which the real property, or some part of the real property, is situated:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-202(1)(a): for the recovery of real property or of an estate or interest in the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-202(1)(b): for the determination, in any form, of the right or interest in the real property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-202(1)(c): for injuries to real property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-202(1)(d): for the partition of real property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-202(1)(e): for the foreclosure of all liens and mortgages on real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-202(2): If the real property is situated in more than one county, the plaintiff may bring the action in any county in which the real property is situated.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-203 Actions to recover fines or penalties -- Actions against public officers.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-203(1): A plaintiff shall bring an action to recover a fine or penalty in the county where:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-203(1)(a): the cause of action arises; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-203(1)(b): some part of the cause of action arises.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-203(2): If a fine, penalty, or forfeiture imposed by statute is imposed for an offense committed on a lake, river, or other stream of water situated in two or more counties, the plaintiff may bring the action in any county bordering on the lake, river, or stream opposite to the place where the offense was committed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-3a-203(3): Except as otherwise provided by law, a plaintiff shall bring an action against a public officer, or the public officer's designee, in the county where the cause of action arises.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-102(1)(b): the damage or injury was not caused by an intentional or knowing act by the volunteer which constitutes illegal, willful, or wanton misconduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-102(2): The protection against volunteer liability provided by this section does not apply:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-102(3): Nothing in this section shall bar an action by a volunteer against an organization, its officers, or other persons who intentionally or knowingly misrepresent that a financially secure source of recovery does or will exist during a period when such a source does not or will not in fact exist.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-102(4): Nothing in this section shall be construed to place a duty upon a nonprofit organization to provide a financially secure source of recovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-102(5): The granting of immunity from liability to a volunteer under this section does not affect the liability of the nonprofit organization providing the financially secure source of recovery.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(1): "Equine" means any member of the equidae family.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(2): "Equine activity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(2)(a): equine shows, fairs, competitions, performances, racing, sales, or parades that involve any breeds of equines and any equine disciplines, including dressage, hunter and jumper horse shows, grand prix jumping, multiple-day events, combined training, rodeos, driving, pulling, cutting, polo, steeple chasing, hunting, endurance trail riding, and western games;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(2)(b): boarding or training equines;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(2)(c): teaching persons equestrian skills;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(2)(d): riding, inspecting, or evaluating an equine owned by another person regardless of whether the owner receives monetary or other valuable consideration;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(2)(e): riding, inspecting, or evaluating an equine by a prospective purchaser; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(2)(f): other equine activities of any type including rides, trips, hunts, or informal or spontaneous activities sponsored by an equine activity sponsor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(3): "Equine activity sponsor" means an individual, group, governmental entity, club, partnership, or corporation, whether operating for profit or as a nonprofit entity, which sponsors, organizes, or provides facilities for an equine activity, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(3)(a): pony clubs, hunt clubs, riding clubs, 4-H programs, therapeutic riding programs, and public and private schools and postsecondary educational institutions that sponsor equine activities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(3)(b): operators, instructors, and promoters of equine facilities, stables, clubhouses, ponyride strings, fairs, and arenas.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(4): "Equine professional" means a person compensated for an equine activity by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(4)(a): instructing a participant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(4)(b): renting to a participant an equine to ride, drive, or be a passenger upon the equine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(4)(c): renting equine equipment or tack to a participant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(5): "Inherent risk" with regard to equine or livestock activities means those dangers or conditions which are an integral part of equine or livestock activities, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(5)(a): the propensity of the animal to behave in ways that may result in injury, harm, or death to persons on or around them;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(5)(b): the unpredictability of the animal's reaction to outside stimulation such as sounds, sudden movement, and unfamiliar objects, persons, or other animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(5)(c): collisions with other animals or objects; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(5)(d): the potential of a participant to act in a negligent manner that may contribute to injury to the participant or others, such as failing to maintain control over the animal or not acting within his or her ability.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(6): "Livestock" means all domesticated animals used in the production of food, fiber, or livestock activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7): "Livestock activity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(a): livestock shows, fairs, competitions, performances, packing events, or parades or rodeos that involve any or all breeds of livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(b): using livestock to pull carts or to carry packs or other items;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(c): using livestock to pull travois-type carriers during rescue or emergency situations;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(d): livestock training or teaching activities or both;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(e): taking livestock on public relations trips or visits to schools or nursing homes;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(f): boarding livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(g): riding, inspecting, or evaluating any livestock belonging to another, whether or not the owner has received some monetary consideration or other thing of value for the use of the livestock or is permitting a prospective purchaser of the livestock to ride, inspect, or evaluate the livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(h): using livestock in wool production;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(i): rides, trips, or other livestock activities of any type however informal or impromptu that are sponsored by a livestock activity sponsor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(7)(j): trimming the feet of any livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(8): "Livestock activity sponsor" means an individual, group, governmental entity, club, partnership, or corporation, whether operating for profit or as a nonprofit entity, which sponsors, organizes, or provides facilities for a livestock activity, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(8)(a): livestock clubs, 4-H programs, therapeutic riding programs, and public and private schools and postsecondary educational institutions that sponsor livestock activities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(8)(b): operators, instructors, and promoters of livestock facilities, stables, clubhouses, fairs, and arenas.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(9): "Livestock professional" means a person compensated for a livestock activity by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(9)(a): instructing a participant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(9)(b): renting to a participant any livestock for the purpose of riding, driving, or being a passenger upon the livestock; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(9)(c): renting livestock equipment or tack to a participant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(10): "Participant" means any person, whether amateur or professional, who directly engages in an equine activity or livestock activity, regardless of whether a fee has been paid to participate.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(11): (11)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-201(11)(a): "Person engaged in an equine or livestock activity" means a person who rides, trains, leads, drives, or works with an equine or livestock, respectively.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202 Equine and livestock activity liability limitations.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(1): It shall be presumed that participants in equine or livestock activities are aware of and understand that there are inherent risks associated with these activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2): An equine activity sponsor, equine professional, livestock activity sponsor, or livestock professional is not liable for an injury to or the death of a participant due to the inherent risks associated with these activities, unless the sponsor or professional:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(a)(i): provided the equipment or tack;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(a)(ii): the equipment or tack caused the injury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(a)(iii): the equipment failure was due to the sponsor's or professional's negligence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(b): failed to make reasonable efforts to determine whether the equine or livestock could behave in a manner consistent with the activity with the participant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(c): owns, leases, rents, or is in legal possession and control of land or facilities upon which the participant sustained injuries because of a dangerous condition which was known to or should have been known to the sponsor or professional and for which warning signs have not been conspicuously posted;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(d)(i): commits an act or omission that constitutes negligence, gross negligence, or willful or wanton disregard for the safety of the participant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(d)(ii): that act or omission causes the injury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(2)(e): intentionally injures or causes the injury to the participant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(3): Title 58, Chapter 28, Veterinary Practice Act; Title 4, Chapter 25, Estrays; Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 7, Utah Product Liability Act This chapter does not prevent or limit the liability of an equine activity sponsor, an equine professional, a livestock activity sponsor, or a livestock professional who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(3)(a): Title 58, Chapter 28, Veterinary Practice Act a veterinarian licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-202(3)(b): Title 4, Chapter 25, Estrays liable under

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-203 Signs to be posted listing inherent risks and liability limitations.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-203(1): An equine or livestock activity sponsor shall provide notice to participants of the equine or livestock activity that there are inherent risks of participating and that the sponsor is not liable for certain of those risks.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-203(2)(a): posting a sign in a prominent location within the area being used for the activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-203(2)(b): providing a document or release for the participant, or the participant's legal guardian if the participant is a minor, to sign.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-301 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Commonsense Consumption Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(1): "Claim" means any assertion by or on behalf of a natural person, as well as any derivative claim arising from it, and asserted by or on behalf of any other person.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(2): "Food":
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(2)(a): means any raw, cooked, or processed edible substance, beverage, or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale in whole or in part for human consumption;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(2)(b): does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(2)(b)(i): tobacco products;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(2)(b)(ii): alcohol products;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(2)(b)(iii): vitamins or dietary supplements;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(2)(b)(iv): illegal drugs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(2)(b)(v): prescription or over-the-counter drugs.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(3): "Knowing and willful violation" means that the conduct constituting the violation was:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(3)(a): committed with the intent to deceive or injure consumers or with actual knowledge that the conduct was injurious to consumers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(3)(b): not required by regulation, order, rule, ordinance, or any statute administered by a federal, state, or local government agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-302(4): "Condition resulting from long term consumption of food" means the cumulative effect of consumption of food, which includes weight gain, obesity, or other generally known health conditions allegedly caused by or likely to result from the consumption of food.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-303 Prevention of unfounded lawsuits -- Exemption.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-303(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-303(2): (1) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-303(2)(a): a material violation of an adulteration or misbranding requirement prescribed by state or federal statute, rule, regulation, or ordinance and the claimed injury was proximately caused by the violation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-303(2)(b): any other material violation of federal or state law applicable to the manufacturing, marketing, distribution, advertising, labeling, or sale of food, provided that the violation is knowing and willful, and the claimed injury was proximately caused by the violation.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-304 Pleading requirements.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-304(1): 78B-4-303(2) In any action commenced under the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-304(1)(a): the statute, rule, regulation, ordinance, or other law that was allegedly violated;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-304(1)(b): the facts that are alleged to constitute a material violation of the statute, rule, regulation, ordinance, or other law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-304(1)(c): the facts alleged to demonstrate that the violation proximately caused actual injury to the plaintiff.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-304(2): The complaint or petition shall also state with particularity facts sufficient to support a reasonable inference that the violation was with intent to deceive or injure consumers or with the actual knowledge that the violation was injurious to consumers.

---------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-306 Applicability.
----------------------------------------------
The provisions of this chapter apply to all covered claims pending on May 3, 2004, and all claims filed after that date, regardless of when the claim arose.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401 Public policy.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401(1): The Legislature finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401(1)(a): the sport of skiing is practiced by a large number of residents of Utah and attracts a large number of nonresidents, significantly contributing to the economy of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401(1)(b): few insurance carriers are willing to provide liability insurance protection to ski area operators; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401(1)(c): the premiums charged by insurance carriers have risen sharply in recent years due to confusion as to whether a skier assumes the risks inherent in the sport of skiing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401(2): It is the purpose of this act:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401(2)(a): to clarify the law in relation to skiing injuries and the risks inherent in the sport of skiing;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401(2)(b): to establish as a matter of law that certain risks are inherent in the sport of skiing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-401(2)(c): to provide that, as a matter of public policy, an individual engaged in the sport of skiing may not recover from a ski operator for injuries resulting from the risks that are inherent in the sport of skiing.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1): "Inherent risks of skiing" means the dangers or conditions that are an integral part of the sport of recreational, competitive, or professional skiing, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(a): changing weather conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(b): snow or ice conditions as the snow or ice conditions exist or may change, including hard pack, powder, packed powder, wind pack, corn, crust, slush, cut-up snow, or machine-made snow;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(c): surface or subsurface conditions, including bare spots, forest growth, rocks, stumps, streambeds, cliffs, trees, or other natural objects;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(d): variations or steepness in terrain, whether natural or as a result of slope design, snowmaking or grooming operations, or other terrain modifications, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(d)(i): terrain parks;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(d)(ii): terrain features, including jumps, rails, or fun boxes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(d)(iii): all other constructed and natural features, including half pipes, quarter pipes, or freestyle-bump terrain;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(e): impact with lift towers, other structures, or their components, including signs, posts, fences or enclosures, hydrants, or water pipes;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(f): collisions with other skiers;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(g): participation in, or practicing or training for, competitions or special events; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(1)(h): the failure of a skier to ski within the skier's own ability.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(2): "Injury" means any personal injury or property damage or loss.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(3): "Minor" means an individual who is under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(4): "Skier" means an individual present in a ski area for the purpose of engaging in the sport of skiing, nordic, freestyle, or other types of ski jumping, or using skis, a sled, a tube, a snowboard, or any other device.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(5): "Ski area" means any area designated by a ski area operator to be used for skiing, nordic, freestyle or other type of ski jumping, or snowboarding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(6)(a): "Ski area operator" means a person that operates a ski area.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-402(6)(b): "Ski area operator" includes an agent, an officer, an employee, or a representative of the person that operates a ski area.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501 Good Samaritan Law.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1): 53-13-103; 34A-3-113; 53-2d-101; 41-1a-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1)(a): "Child" means an individual of such an age that a reasonable person would perceive the individual as unable to open the door of a locked motor vehicle, but in any case younger than 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1)(b): "Emergency" means an unexpected occurrence involving injury, threat of injury, or illness to a person or the public, including motor vehicle accidents, disasters, actual or threatened discharges, removal or disposal of hazardous materials, and other accidents or events of a similar nature.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1)(c): "Emergency care" includes actual assistance or advice offered to avoid, mitigate, or attempt to mitigate the effects of an emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1)(d): 53-13-103; 34A-3-113; 53-2d-101 "First responder" means a state or local:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1)(d)(i): 53-13-103 law enforcement officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1)(d)(ii): 34A-3-113 firefighter, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1)(d)(iii): 53-2d-101 emergency medical service provider, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(1)(e): 41-1a-102 "Motor vehicle" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(2): A person who renders emergency care at or near the scene of, or during, an emergency, gratuitously and in good faith, is not liable for any civil damages or penalties as a result of any act or omission by the person rendering the emergency care, unless the person is grossly negligent or caused the emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(3): (3)(a)(i); (iii); Title 26A, Chapter 1, Local Health Departments; Title 26B, Chapter 7, Part 3, Treatment, Isolation, and Quarantine Procedures for Communicable Diseases; 26B-7-301; (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(3)(a): (3)(a)(i); (iii); Title 26A, Chapter 1, Local Health Departments; Title 26B, Chapter 7, Part 3, Treatment, Isolation, and Quarantine Procedures for Communicable Diseases; 26B-7-301 A person who gratuitously, and in good faith, assists a governmental agency or political subdivision in an activity described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(3)(a)(i): Title 26A, Chapter 1, Local Health Departments implementing measures to control the causes of epidemic and communicable diseases and other conditions significantly affecting the public health, or necessary to protect the public health as set out in
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(3)(a)(ii): Title 26B, Chapter 7, Part 3, Treatment, Isolation, and Quarantine Procedures for Communicable Diseases investigating and controlling suspected bioterrorism and disease as set out in
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(3)(a)(iii): 26B-7-301 responding to a national, state, or local emergency, a public health emergency as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(3)(b): (3) The immunity in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(4): (4); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(4)(a): A person who uses reasonable force to enter a locked and unattended motor vehicle to remove a confined child is not liable for damages in a civil action if all of the following apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(4)(a)(i): the person has a good faith belief that the confined child is in imminent danger of suffering physical injury or death unless the confined child is removed from the motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(4)(a)(ii): the person determines that the motor vehicle is locked and there is no reasonable manner in which the person can remove the confined child from the motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(4)(a)(iii): before entering the motor vehicle, the person notifies a first responder of the confined child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(4)(a)(iv): the person does not use more force than is necessary under the circumstances to enter the motor vehicle and remove the confined child from the vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(4)(a)(v): the person remains with the child until a first responder arrives at the motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-501(4)(b): (4); (4)(a) A person is not immune from civil liability under this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-502 Donation of food -- Liability limits.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-502(1): A person or entity who donates apparently wholesome food to a nonprofit organization for distribution to the needy is not subject to civil or criminal liability regarding the condition of the food unless an injury or death results from an act or omission of the donor that constitutes gross negligence, recklessness, or intentional misconduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-502(2): A nonprofit organization that distributes either directly or indirectly apparently wholesome food to persons in need at no charge and substantially complies with applicable local, county, state, and federal laws and regulations regarding the storage and handling of food for public distribution is not subject to civil or criminal liability regarding the condition of the food unless an injury or death results from an act or omission of the organization that constitutes gross negligence, recklessness, or intentional misconduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-503 Immunity for transient shelters.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-503(1): As used in this section, "transient shelter" means any person which provides shelter, food, clothing, or other products or services without consideration to indigent persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-503(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-503(3): This section does not prohibit an action against a person for damages or injury intentionally caused by that person or resulting from his gross negligence.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504 Donation of nonschedule drugs or devices -- Liability limitation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1): 58-17b-102; 58-17b-102; 58-17b-102; 58-17b-102; 78B-3-403; Title 58, Occupations and Professions; 58-17b-102; 58-37-2; 58-17b-102; 58-17b-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(a): 58-17b-102 "Administer" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(b): 58-17b-102 "Dispense" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(c): 58-17b-102 "Distribute" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(d): 58-17b-102 "Drug outlet" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(d)(i): 58-17b-102 a pharmacy or pharmaceutical facility as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(d)(ii): a person with the authority to engage in the dispensing, delivering, manufacturing, or wholesaling of prescription drugs or devices outside of the state under the law of the jurisdiction in which the person operates.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(e): 78B-3-403; Title 58, Occupations and Professions "Health care provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(e)(i): 78B-3-403; Title 58, Occupations and Professions a person who is a health care provider, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(e)(ii): a person outside of the state with the authority to prescribe, dispense, or administer prescription drugs or devices under the law of the jurisdiction in which the person practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(f): 58-17b-102; 58-37-2; 58-17b-102 "Nonschedule drug or device" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(f)(i): 58-17b-102; 58-37-2 a prescription drug or device, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(f)(ii): 58-17b-102 a nonprescription drug, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(1)(g): 58-17b-102 "Prescription drug or device" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(2): A drug outlet is not subject to civil liability for an injury or death resulting from the defective condition of a nonschedule drug or device that the drug outlet distributes at no charge, in good faith, and for a charitable purpose to a drug outlet or health care provider for ultimate use by a needy person, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(2)(a): the drug outlet complies with applicable state and federal laws regarding the storage, handling, and distribution of the nonschedule drug or device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(2)(b): the injury or death is not the result of any act or omission of the drug outlet that constitutes gross negligence, recklessness, or intentional misconduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(3): A health care provider is not subject to civil liability for an injury or death resulting from the defective condition of a nonschedule drug or device that the health care provider distributes to a drug outlet or health care provider for ultimate use by a needy person or directly administers, dispenses, or distributes to a needy person, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(3)(a): the health care provider complies with applicable state and federal laws regarding the storage, handling, distribution, dispensing, and administration of the nonschedule drug or device;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(3)(b): the injury or death is not the result of any act or omission of the health care provider that constitutes gross negligence, recklessness, or intentional misconduct; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(3)(c): in the event that the health care provider directly administers, distributes, or dispenses the nonschedule drug or device to the needy person, the health care provider has retained a consent form signed by the needy person that explains the provisions of this section which extend liability protection for charitable donations of nonschedule drugs and devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(4): Title 58, Occupations and Professions Nothing in this section may be construed as:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(4)(a): Title 58, Occupations and Professions permitting a person who is not authorized under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-504(4)(b): extending liability protection to any person who acts outside of the scope of authority granted to that person under the laws of this state or the jurisdiction in which the person operates or practices.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505 Liability of reprocessor of single-use medical devices.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1): (1)(a) For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(a): "Critical single-use medical device" means a medical device that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(a)(i): is marked as a single-use device by the original manufacturer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(a)(ii): is intended to directly contact normally sterile tissue or body spaces during use, or is physically connected to a device intended to contact normally sterile tissue or body spaces during use.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(b): "Original manufacturer" means any person or entity who designs, manufactures, fabricates, assembles, or processes a critical single-use medical device which is new and has not been used in a previous medical procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(c): "Reprocessor" includes a person or entity who performs the functions of contract sterilization, installation, relabeling, remanufacturing, repacking, or specification development of a reprocessed critical single-use medical device.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(d): (1)(a) "Reconditioned or reprocessed critical single-use medical device" means a critical single use medical device that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(d)(i): has previously been used on a patient and has been subject to additional processing and manufacturing for the purpose of additional use on a different patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(d)(ii): (1)(a) includes a device that meets the definition under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(1)(d)(iii): does not include a disposable or critical single-use medical device that has been opened but not used on an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(2): A reprocessor who reconditions or reprocesses a critical single-use medical device assumes the liability:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(2)(a): of the original manufacturer of the critical single-use medical device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-505(2)(b): for the safety and effectiveness of the reconditioned or reprocessed critical single-use medical device.
