Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507 Amusement park rides -- Park responsibilities -- Rider responsibilities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(a)(i): "Amusement park" means any permanent indoor or outdoor facility or park where amusement rides are available for use by the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(a)(ii): "Amusement park" does not include a ski resort, a traveling show, carnival, or fair.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(b): "Amusement ride" means a device or attraction at an amusement park which carries or conveys passengers along, around, or over a fixed or restricted route or course or allows the passenger to steer or guide it within an established area for the purpose of giving its passengers amusement, pleasure, thrills, or excitement.  "Amusement ride" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(b)(i): any water-based recreational attraction, including all water slides, wave pools, and water parks; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(b)(ii): typical rides, including roller coasters, whips, ferris wheels, and merry-go-rounds.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(c): "Intoxicated" means a person is under the influence of alcohol, a controlled substance, or any substance having the property of releasing toxic vapors, to a degree that the person may endanger himself or another, in a public place or in a private place where he unreasonably disturbs other persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(d): "Operator" means any person, firm, or corporation that owns, leases, manages, or operates an amusement park or amusement ride and all employees and agents of the amusement park.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(e): "Rider" means any person who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(e)(i): waiting in the immediate vicinity of an amusement ride in order to get on the ride;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(e)(ii): in the process of leaving the ride but remains in its immediate vicinity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(1)(e)(iii): a passenger or participant on an amusement ride.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(2): An amusement park shall inform riders in writing, where appropriate, of the nature of the ride, including factors which would assist riders in determining whether they should participate in the ride activity and the rules concerning conduct on each ride.  Information concerning the rules of conduct may be given verbally at the beginning of each ride segment or posted in writing conspicuously at the entrance to each ride.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(3): Riders are responsible for obeying the posted rules and verbal instructions of the amusement ride operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(4): A rider may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(4)(a): board or dismount from an amusement ride except at a designated area;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(4)(b): board an amusement ride if he has a physical condition that may be aggravated by participation on the ride;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(4)(c): disconnect, disable, or attempt to disconnect or disable, any safety device, seat belt, harness, or other restraining device before, during, or after movement of the amusement ride has started except at the express instruction of the operator;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(4)(d): throw or expel any object from an amusement ride;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(4)(e): act in any manner contrary to posted or oral rules while boarding, riding, or dismounting from an amusement ride; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(4)(f): engage in any reckless act or activity which may injure himself or others.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(5): A rider may not board or attempt to board any amusement ride if he is intoxicated.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(5)(a): An operator of an amusement park ride may prevent a rider who is perceptibly or apparently intoxicated from boarding an amusement ride.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(5)(b): An operator who prevents a rider from boarding an amusement ride under this section is not criminally or civilly liable if the operator reasonably believes that the rider is intoxicated.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(6): An amusement park shall post signs and notices in conspicuous locations throughout the park informing riders of the importance of reporting all injuries sustained on amusement park premises.  The signs shall contain the location where any injuries may be reported.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(7): A rider, or the parent or guardian of a minor rider on the minor's behalf, may report in writing to the amusement facility or its designated agent any injuries sustained on an amusement ride before leaving the amusement facility premises, unless the rider, or parent or guardian of a minor rider, is unable to file a report because of the severity of the injuries to the rider.  The report shall be filed as soon as reasonably possible and include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(7)(a): the name, address, and phone number of the injured person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(7)(b): if the injured person is a minor, the name, address, and phone number of the parent or guardian filing the report;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(7)(c): a brief description of the incident causing the injury, including the location, date, and time of the injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(7)(d): a description of the injury, including the cause, if known; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(7)(e): the name, address, and phone number of any known witnesses to the incident.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-507(8): (3); (4); (5) The actions of any rider of sufficient age and knowledge to assume the inherent risks of an amusement ride who violates the provisions of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-508 Limitation on liability of hockey facilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-508(1): As used in this section, "hockey facility" means a facility where hockey is customarily played or practiced and the general public is charged an admission fee to attend.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-508(2): The owner or operator of a hockey facility is not liable for any injury to the person or property of any person as a result of that person being hit by a hockey puck or stick unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-508(2)(a): the person is situated completely behind a board, glass, or similar barrier and the board, glass, or barrier is defective; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-508(2)(b): the injury is caused by negligent or willful and wanton conduct in connection with the game of hockey by the owner or operator or any hockey player, coach, or manager employed by the owner or operator.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-511 Regulation of firearms reserved to state -- Lawsuits prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-511(1): 76-10-500 As prescribed by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512 Definitions -- Participation in an agritourism activity -- Limitations on civil liability -- Signage requirement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(a): "Agricultural enterprise" means a farm, ranch, or other agricultural, aquacultural, horticultural, or forestry operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(b): "Agritourism" means the combination of agricultural production with tourism to attract participants from the general public to an agricultural enterprise for the entertainment, recreation, or education of the participants.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(c): "Agritourism activity" means an activity at an agricultural enterprise that a participant engages in or observes for recreation, education, or entertainment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(d): "Inherent risk of an agritourism activity" means a danger, hazard, or condition that is part of an agritourism activity, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(d)(i): surface and subsurface conditions of land, vegetation, or water on the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(d)(ii): unpredictable behavior of domesticated or farm animals on the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(d)(iii): reasonable dangers of structures or equipment ordinarily used where agricultural or horticultural crops are grown or farm animals or farmed fish are raised;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(d)(iv): behavior of insects or wildlife not owned or kept by the operator of the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(d)(v): exposure to pathogens from animals, animal feed, animal waste, or other sources; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(d)(vi): negligent behavior by an individual other than the operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(e): "Operator" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(e)(i): a person who owns or manages an agricultural enterprise where a participant engages in or observes an agritourism activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(e)(ii): a person who provides an agritourism activity at an agricultural enterprise; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(e)(iii): an employee of a person described in Subsection (1)(e)(i) or (ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(f)(i): "Participant" means an individual, other than an operator, who engages in or observes an agritourism activity, regardless of whether the individual pays to engage in or observe the agritourism activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(f)(ii): "Participant" does not mean an individual who is paid to participate in an agritourism activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(1)(g): "Property" means the real property where an agritourism activity takes place.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (3), an operator may not be liable for an injury, illness, death, or damage to personal property of a participant that results from an inherent risk of an agritourism activity if the operator posts the signage described in Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(2)(b): An operator is not required to eliminate an inherent risk of an agritourism activity at the operator's agritourism activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(3): Nothing in Subsection (2):
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(3)(a): limits the liability of an operator if the operator:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(3)(a)(i): acts or omits an act in gross negligence or willful or wanton disregard for the safety of a participant that proximately causes injury, illness, death, or damage to personal property of a participant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(3)(a)(ii): has actual knowledge or reasonably should have known of a dangerous condition on the land, facilities, or equipment used in the agritourism activity that proximately causes injury, illness, death, or damage to personal property of a participant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(3)(a)(iii): has actual knowledge or reasonably should have known of the dangerous propensity of an animal used in an agritourism activity and does not make the danger known to the participant, and the danger proximately causes injury, illness, death, or damage to personal property of a participant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(3)(a)(iv): intentionally injures the participant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(3)(b): prevents or limits the liability of an operator under a product liability law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(3)(c): negates assumption of risk as an affirmative defense.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(4): A limitation on legal liability afforded to an operator under Subsection (2) is in addition to any limitation of legal liability otherwise provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(5): An operator shall post and maintain, in a clearly visible location at each entrance to the property where an agritourism activity takes place or at the location of each agritourism activity, a sign that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(5)(a): is printed in black letters, that are a minimum of one inch in height, on a white background; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-512(5)(b): states, "WARNING: Under Utah law, an operator of an agritourism activity or the property where the activity takes place is not liable for the injury, illness, death, or damage to personal property of a participant that primarily results from the inherent risks of the activity or a participant's failure to follow instructions or exercise reasonable caution. You are assuming the risk of participating in or observing an agritourism activity."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-513(2): An action for defective design or construction may include damage to other property or physical personal injury if the damage or injury is caused by the defective design or construction.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-514(1)(b): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Emergency Management Act "Declared state of emergency" means a state of emergency declared by the governor of this state or by the chief executive officer of a political subdivision, in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-515 Limitation on liability for greenhouse gases.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-515(1): "Greenhouse gas" means water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, ozone, and chlorofluorocarbons.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-515(2): A person residing or doing business in this state may not be held liable for damage or injury to another arising out of any actual or potential effect on climate caused by contributions to emissions of greenhouse gases unless it can be proved by clear and convincing evidence that the person has:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-515(2)(a): violated an enforceable statutory limitation or restriction against emissions of a specific greenhouse gas originating within this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-515(2)(b): violated the express terms of a valid, enforceable operating, air, or other permit issued by a state or federal regulatory agency that has jurisdiction over the greenhouse gas emissions of the person or business.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-515(3): The person bringing the action shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-515(3)(a): specify each greenhouse gas emitted by the defendant which is asserted to give rise to the cause of action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-515(3)(b): show by clear and convincing evidence that unavoidable and identifiable damage or injury has resulted or will result as a direct cause of the defendant's violation of statutory and permitting limits.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-516 Immunity for providing assistance in a suicide emergency.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-516(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-516(1)(a): "Emergency care" means assistance or advice offered to avoid, mitigate, or attempt to mitigate the effects of a suicide emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-516(1)(b): "Suicide emergency" means an occurrence that reasonably indicates an individual is at risk of dying or attempting to die by suicide.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-516(2): A person who provides emergency care at or near the scene of, or during, a suicide emergency, gratuitously and in good faith, is not liable for any civil damages or penalties as a result of any act or omission by the person providing the emergency care, unless the person is grossly negligent or caused the suicide emergency.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-601 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Successor Corporation Asbestos-Related Liability Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(1): "Asbestos claim" means a claim, wherever or whenever made, for damages, losses, indemnification, contribution, or other relief arising out of, based on, or in any way related to asbestos, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(1)(a): the health effects of exposure to asbestos, including a claim for:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(1)(a)(i): personal injury or death;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(1)(a)(ii): mental or emotional injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(1)(a)(iii): risk of disease or other injury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(1)(a)(iv): the costs of medical monitoring or surveillance;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(1)(b): a claim made by or on behalf of a person exposed to asbestos, or a representative, spouse, parent, child, or other relative of the person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(1)(c): a claim for damage or loss caused by the installation, presence, or removal of asbestos.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(2): "Corporation" means a corporation for profit, including a domestic corporation organized under the laws of this state or a foreign corporation organized under laws other than this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(3): (3)(a) "Successor" means a corporation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(3)(a)(i): assumes or incurs or has assumed or incurred successor asbestos-related liability;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(3)(a)(ii): is the successor corporation after a merger or consolidation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(3)(a)(iii): became a successor before January 1, 1972; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(3)(b): (3)(a) is a successor corporation of a corporation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(4): 78B-4-605
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(4)(a): "Successor asbestos-related liability" means liability:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(4)(a)(i): whether known or unknown, asserted or unasserted, absolute or contingent, accrued or unaccrued, liquidated or unliquidated, or due or to become due;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(4)(a)(ii): that is related in any way to an asbestos claim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(4)(a)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(4)(a)(iii)(A): is assumed or incurred by a corporation as a result of or in connection with a merger or consolidation, or the plan of merger or consolidation related to the merger or consolidation with or into another corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(4)(a)(iii)(B): that is related in any way to an asbestos claim based on the exercise of control or the ownership of stock of the corporation before the merger or consolidation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(4)(b): 78B-4-605 "Successor asbestos-related liability" includes liability that, after the time of the merger or consolidation for which the fair market value of total gross assets is determined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-602(5): "Transferor" means a corporation from which successor asbestos-related liability is or was assumed or incurred.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603 Applicability.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(1): 78B-4-604 The limitations in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(2): 78B-4-604; Title 34A, Chapter 2, Workers' Compensation Act; Title 34A, Chapter 3, Utah Occupational Disease Act The limitations in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(2)(a): Title 34A, Chapter 2, Workers' Compensation Act; Title 34A, Chapter 3, Utah Occupational Disease Act workers' compensation benefits paid by or on behalf of an employer to an employee under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(2)(b): a claim against a corporation that does not constitute a successor asbestos-related liability;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(2)(c): an obligation under the National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C. Sec. 151, et seq., as amended, or under a collective bargaining agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(2)(d): a successor that, after a merger or consolidation, continued in the business of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(2)(d)(i): mining asbestos;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(2)(d)(ii): selling or distributing asbestos fibers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-603(2)(d)(iii): manufacturing, distributing, removing, or installing asbestos-containing products that were the same or substantially the same as those products previously manufactured, distributed, removed, or installed by the transferor.

-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-604(1): (2) Except as further limited in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605 Establishing fair market value of total gross assets.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(1): 78B-4-604 A successor may establish the fair market value of total gross assets for the purpose of the limitations under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(1)(a): by reference to the going concern value of the assets or to the purchase price attributable to or paid for the assets in an arms-length transaction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(1)(b): in the absence of other readily available information from which the fair market value can be determined, by reference to the value of the assets recorded on a balance sheet.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(2): Total gross assets include intangible assets.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(3)(a): To the extent total gross assets include any liability insurance that was issued to the transferor whose assets are being valued for purposes of this section, the applicability, terms, conditions, and limits of the insurance may not be affected by this section, nor shall this section otherwise affect the rights and obligations of an insurer, transferor, or successor under any insurance contract or related agreement including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(3)(a)(i): preenactment settlements resolving coverage-related disputes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(3)(a)(ii): the rights of an insurer to seek payment of applicable deductibles, restrospective premiums, or self-insured retentions or to seek contribution from a successor for uninsured or self-insured periods or periods when insurance is uncollectible or otherwise unavailable.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-605(3)(b): (3)(a) Without limiting Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-607 Scope.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-607(1): Courts of this state shall construe this part liberally with regard to successors.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-607(2): This part shall apply to an asbestos claim filed against a successor on or after May 8, 2012.  This part shall apply to a pending asbestos claim against a successor in which trial has not commenced as of May 8, 2012, except that any provision of this part that would be unconstitutional if applied retroactively shall be applied prospectively.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702 Affirmative defense for a breach of system security.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(1): (4) A person that creates, maintains, and reasonably complies with a written cybersecurity program that meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(1)(a): is brought under the laws of this state or in the courts of this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(1)(b): alleges that the person failed to implement reasonable information security controls that resulted in the breach of system security.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(2): (4); (2)(a) A person has an affirmative defense to a claim that the person failed to appropriately respond to a breach of system security if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(2)(a): (4) the person creates, maintains, and reasonably complies with a written cybersecurity program that meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(2)(b): (2)(a) the written cybersecurity program had protocols at the time of the breach of system security for responding to a breach of system security that reasonably complied with the written cybersecurity program under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(3): (4); (3)(a) A person has an affirmative defense to a claim that the person failed to appropriately notify an individual whose personal information was compromised in a breach of system security if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(3)(a): (4) the person creates, maintains, and reasonably complies with a written cybersecurity program that meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(3)(b): (3)(a) the written cybersecurity program had protocols at the time of the breach of system security for notifying an individual about a breach of system security that reasonably complied with the requirements for a written cybersecurity program under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4): (1); (2); (3); 78B-4-703(1) A written cybersecurity program described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(a): being designed to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(a)(i): protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(a)(ii): protect against any anticipated threat or hazard to the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(a)(iii): protect against a breach of system security;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(b): 78B-4-703(1) reasonably conforming to a recognized cybersecurity framework as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(c): being of an appropriate scale and scope in light of the following factors:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(c)(i): the size and complexity of the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(c)(ii): the nature and scope of the activities of the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(c)(iii): the sensitivity of the information to be protected;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(c)(iv): the cost and availability of tools to improve information security and reduce vulnerability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-702(4)(c)(v): the resources available to the person.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-704 No cause of action.
---------------------------------------------------
This part may not be construed to create a private cause of action, including a class action, if a person fails to comply with a provision of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-705 Choice of law.
----------------------------------------------
A choice of law provision in an agreement that designates this state as the governing law shall apply this part, if applicable, to the fullest extent possible in a civil action brought against a person regardless of whether the civil action is brought in this state or another state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-4-706 Severability clause.
----------------------------------------------------
If any provision of this part, or the application of any provision of this part to any person or circumstance, is held invalid, the remainder of this part shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 5 - Procedure and Evidence
********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-101 Right to jury trial.
----------------------------------------------------
In actions for the recovery of specific real or personal property, with or without damages, or for money claimed due upon contract or as damages for breach of contract, or for injuries, an issue of fact may be tried by a jury, unless a jury trial is waived or a reference is ordered.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-102 Jury to decide questions of fact.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
All questions of fact, where the trial is by jury, other than those mentioned in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-103 Court to decide questions of law.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
All questions of law, including the admissibility of evidence, the facts preliminary to admission, the construction of statutes and other writings, the application of the rules of evidence, and all discussions of law are to be addressed to and decided by the court.  Whenever the knowledge of the court is by law made evidence of a fact, the court shall explain the knowledge to the jury, who are to accept it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-203 Judgment against party dying after verdict or decision.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a party dies after a verdict or decision upon any issue of fact, and before judgment, the judgment is not a lien on the real property of the deceased party, but is payable in the course of the administration of the party's estate.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-204 Judgment against sheriff -- When conclusive against sureties on indemnity bond.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If an action is brought against a sheriff for an act done by virtue of his office and he gives written notice to the sureties on any bond of indemnity received by him, the judgment recovered is conclusive evidence of his right to recover against such sureties.  The court may, on motion, and upon five days notice, order judgment to be entered against them for the amount recovered, including costs.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-205 Judgment by confession authorized.
------------------------------------------------------------------
A judgment by confession may be entered without action, either for money due or to become due or to secure any person against contingent liability on behalf of the defendant, or both, in the manner prescribed by law. The judgment may be entered in any court having jurisdiction for like amounts.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-206 Mileage allowance for judgment debtor required to appear.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-206(1): A judgment debtor legally required to appear before a district court or the Business and Chancery Court to answer concerning the debtor's property is entitled, on a sufficient showing of need, to mileage of 15 cents per mile for each mile actually and necessarily traveled in going only, to be paid by the judgment creditor at whose instance the judgment debtor was required to appear.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-206(2): The judgment creditor is not required to make any payment for such mileage until the judgment debtor has actually appeared before the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-301 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Utah Foreign Judgment Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-302 Definition -- Filing and status of foreign judgments.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-302(1): As used in this part, "foreign judgment" means any judgment, decree, or order of a court of the United States or of any other court whose acts are entitled to full faith and credit in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-302(2): A copy of a foreign judgment authenticated in accordance with an appropriate act of Congress or an appropriate act of Utah may be filed with the clerk of any district court in Utah.  The clerk of the district court shall treat the foreign judgment in all respects as a judgment of a district court of Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-302(3): A foreign judgment filed under this part has the same effect and is subject to the same procedures, defenses, enforcement, satisfaction, and proceedings for reopening, vacating, setting aside, or staying as a judgment of a district court of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-303 Notice of filing.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-303(1): The judgment creditor or attorney for the creditor, at the time of filing a foreign judgment, shall file an affidavit with the clerk of the district court stating the last known post-office address of the judgment debtor and the judgment creditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-303(2): Upon the filing of a foreign judgment and affidavit, the clerk of the district court shall notify the judgment debtor that the judgment has been filed.  Notice shall be sent to the address stated in the affidavit.  The clerk shall record the date the notice is mailed in the register of actions.  The notice shall include the name and post-office address of the judgment creditor and the name and address of the judgment creditor's attorney, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-303(3): No execution or other process for the enforcement of a foreign judgment filed under this part may issue until 30 days after the judgment is filed.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-304 Stay.
-------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-304(1): If an appeal from a foreign judgment is pending, the time for appeal has not expired, or a stay of execution has been granted, the court, upon proof that the judgment debtor has furnished security for satisfaction of the judgment in the state in which the judgment was rendered shall stay enforcement of the judgment until the appeal is concluded, the time for appeal expires, or until the stay of execution expires or is vacated.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-304(2): If the foreign judgment debtor, upon motion, shows the district court any ground upon which enforcement of a judgment of a district court of this state would be stayed, the court shall stay enforcement of the foreign judgment upon the posting of security in the kind and amount required to stay enforcement of a domestic judgment.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-305 Lien.
-------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-305(1): 78B-5-202; 78B-5-202 A foreign judgment entered in a district court under this part becomes a lien as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-305(1)(a): a stay of execution has not been granted;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-305(1)(b): the requirements of this chapter are satisfied; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-305(1)(c): 78B-5-202 the judgment is recorded in the office of the county recorder where the property of the judgment debtor is located, as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-305(2): The lien becomes effective at the time and date of recording and expires eight years after date of entry by the court in the foreign jurisdiction unless renewed in Utah as required by Utah law.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-306 Optional procedure.
---------------------------------------------------
This part may not be construed to impair a judgment creditor's right to bring an action in this state to enforce the creditor's judgment.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-307 Uniformity of interpretation.
-------------------------------------------------------------
This part shall be construed to effectuate the general purpose to make uniform the law of those states which enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-320 Grounds for nonrecognition of libel judgments.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A judgment obtained in a foreign jurisdiction may be considered nonrecognizable and unenforceable by the courts of this state if:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-320(1): the judgment was obtained in a jurisdiction outside the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-320(2): the judgment resulted in a libel judgment for damages; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-320(3): the court sitting in this state before which the matter is brought determines that the libel law applied in the foreign court's adjudication process did not provide at least as much protection for freedom of speech and press as would be provided by the United States Constitution and the Utah Constitution.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-321 Foreign libel judgment.
-------------------------------------------------------
For the purposes of applyingUtah Code Annotated § 78B-5-321(1): is a resident of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-321(2): is a person or entity amenable to the jurisdiction of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-321(3): has assets in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-321(4): may be required to take action in this state to comply with the judgment.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-322 Application.
--------------------------------------------
This part applies to all foreign libel judgments filed for enforcement or recognition in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-401 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Uniform Foreign-Money Claims Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(1): "Action" means a judicial proceeding or arbitration in which a money payment may be awarded or enforced in respect of a foreign-money claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(2): "Conversion date" means the banking day next before the date on which money is, in accordance with this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(2)(a): paid to a judgment creditor;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(2)(b): paid to the designated official enforcing a judgment on behalf of the judgment creditor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(2)(c): used to effect a recoupment or set-off of claims in different money in an action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(3): "Distribution proceeding" means a judicial or nonjudicial proceeding for an accounting, an assignment for the benefit of creditors, a foreclosure, for the liquidation or rehabilitation of a corporation or other entity, for the distribution of an estate, trust, or other fund in or against which a foreign-money claim is asserted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(4): "Foreign money" means money other than money of the United States of America.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(5): "Foreign-money claim" means a claim upon an obligation to pay, or a claim for recovery of a loss, expressed in or measured by a foreign money.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(6): "Money" means a medium of exchange for the payment of obligations or a store of value authorized or adopted by a government or by intergovernmental agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(7): 78B-5-405 "Money of the claim" means the money determined as proper by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(8): "Party" means an individual, a corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business trust, partnership or association of two or more persons having a joint or common interest or any other legal or commercial entity asserting or defending against a foreign-money claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(9): "Rate of exchange" means the rate at which the money of one country may be converted into money of another country in a free financial market convenient to or reasonably usable by the party obliged to pay or to state a rate of conversion.  If separate exchange rates apply to different kinds of transactions or events, the term means the rate applicable to the particular transaction or event giving rise to the foreign-money claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(10)(a): "Spot rate" means the rate of exchange at which foreign money is sold by a bank or other dealer in foreign exchange for settlement by immediate payment, by charge to an account, or by an agreed delayed settlement not exceeding two days.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(10)(b): "Bank-offered spot rate" means the rate of exchange at which a bank will issue its draft in the foreign money or will cause credit to become available in the foreign money on a next-day basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-402(11): "State" means a state, territory, or possession of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, or the United States Virgin Islands.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-403 Scope.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-403(1): This part applies only to a foreign-money claim in an action or distribution proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-403(2): This part applies to foreign-money issues notwithstanding the law applicable under the conflict of laws rules of this state to other issues in the action or distribution proceeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-404 Variation by agreement.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-404(1): The effect of provisions of this part may be varied by agreement of the parties made at any time before or after commencement of an action, distribution proceeding, or the entry of judgment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-404(2): The parties may agree upon the money to be used in a transaction giving rise to a foreign-money claim and may use different money for different aspects of the transaction. Stating the price in a foreign money or for a particular transaction does not require, of itself, the use of that money for other aspects of the transaction.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-405 Determining the money of the claim.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-405(1): (2) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-405(1)(a): regularly used between the parties as a matter of usage or course of dealing;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-405(1)(b): used at the time of a transaction in international trade, by trade usage or common practice, for valuing or settling transactions in the particular commodity or service involved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-405(1)(c): in which the loss was ultimately felt or will be incurred by a party.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-405(2): The money in which the parties have contracted that a payment be made is the proper money of the claim for that payment.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-406 Determining the amount of the money of certain contract claims.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-406(1): If an amount contracted to be paid in a foreign money is measured by a specified amount of a different money, the amount to be paid is determined on the conversion date.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-406(2): If an amount contracted to be paid in a foreign money is to be measured by a different money at the exchange rate prevailing on a date prior to default, that exchange rate applies only for payments made a reasonable time after default, not to exceed 30 days.  Thereafter, conversion is made at the bank-offered spot rate on the conversion date.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-406(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-406(3)(a): A monetary claim is neither usurious nor unconscionable because the agreement on which it is based provides that the amount of the debtor's obligation to be paid in the debtor's money shall, when received by the creditor, equal a specified amount of the foreign money of the country of the creditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-406(3)(b): If because of unexcused delay in payment of a judgment or award the amount received by the creditor does not equal the amount of the foreign money specified in the agreement, the court or arbitrator, as the case may be, has jurisdiction to and may amend the judgment or award accordingly.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-407 Asserting and defending a foreign-money claim.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-407(1): A claimant may assert a claim in a specified foreign money.  If a foreign money is not asserted, the claimant makes a claim for a judgment in United States dollars.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-407(2): An opposing party may allege and prove the claim is in whole or in part for a different money than that asserted by the claimant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-407(3): Any party may assert a defense, set-off, recoupment, or counterclaim in any money without regard to the money of other claims.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-407(4): The determination of the proper money of the claim is a question of law.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-409 Conversions of foreign money in a distribution proceeding.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The rate of exchange prevailing at or near the closing of business on the day the proceeding is initiated shall govern all exchanges of foreign money in a distribution proceeding.  A foreign-money claimant in a distribution proceeding must assert its claim in the named foreign money and show the amount of United States dollars resulting from a conversion as of the date the proceeding was initiated.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-410 Prejudgment and judgment interest.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-410(1): With respect to a foreign-money claim, recovery of prejudgment interest and the rate of interest to be applied in the action or distribution proceeding are matters of the substantive law governing the right to recovery under the conflict of laws rules of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-410(2): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-410(3): A judgment on a foreign-money claim bears interest at the same rate applicable to other judgments of this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-411(3): A judgment entered on a foreign-money claim only in United States dollars in another state shall be enforced in this state in United States dollars only.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-413 Effect of currency revalorizations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-413(1): If, after an obligation is expressed or a loss is incurred in a foreign money, the country issuing or adopting that money substitutes a new money in place of that money, the obligation or the loss is treated as if expressed or incurred in the new money at the rate of conversion the issuing country establishes for the payment of like obligations or losses denominated in the former money.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-413(2): (1) If substitution under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-414 Supplementary general principles of law.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless displaced by particular provisions of this part, the principles of law and equity, including the law merchant, and the law relative to capacity to contract, principal and agent, estoppel, fraud, misrepresentation, duress, coercion, mistake, bankruptcy, or other validating or invalidating causes supplement its provisions.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-415 Uniformity of application and construction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
This part shall be applied and construed to effectuate its general purpose to make uniform the law with respect to the subject of this part among states enacting it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-416 Application.
--------------------------------------------
This part applies to actions and distribution proceedings commenced after April 23, 1990.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-450 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Uniform Foreign-Country Money Judgments Recognition Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-451 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-451(1): "Foreign country" means a government other than:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-451(1)(a): the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-451(1)(b): a state, district, commonwealth, territory, or insular possession of the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-451(1)(c): any other government with regard to which the decision in this state as to whether to recognize a judgment of that government's courts is initially subject to determination under the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the United States Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-451(2): "Foreign-country judgment" means a judgment of a court of a foreign country.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452 Applicability.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452(1): (2) Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452(1)(a): grants or denies the recovery of a sum of money; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452(1)(b): under the law of the foreign country where rendered, is final, conclusive, and enforceable.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452(2): This part does not apply to a foreign-country judgment, even if the judgment grants or denies the recovery of a sum of money, to the extent that the judgment is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452(2)(a): a judgment for taxes;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452(2)(b): a fine or other penalty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452(2)(c): a judgment for divorce, support, or maintenance, or other judgment rendered in connection with domestic relations.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-452(3): A party seeking recognition of a foreign-country judgment has the burden of establishing that this part applies to the foreign-country judgment.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453 Standards for recognition of foreign-country judgment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(1): (2); (3) Except as otherwise provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(2): A court of this state may not recognize a foreign-country judgment if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(2)(a): the judgment was rendered under a judicial system that does not provide impartial tribunals or procedures compatible with the requirements of due process of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(2)(b): the foreign court did not have personal jurisdiction over the defendant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(2)(c): the foreign court did not have jurisdiction over the subject matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3): A court of this state may decline to recognize a foreign-country judgment if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3)(a): the defendant in the proceeding in the foreign court did not receive notice of the proceeding in sufficient time to enable the defendant to defend;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3)(b): the judgment was obtained by fraud that deprived the losing party of an adequate opportunity to present the party's case;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3)(c): the judgment or the cause of action on which the judgment is based is repugnant to the public policy of this state or the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3)(d): the judgment conflicts with another final and conclusive judgment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3)(e): the proceeding in the foreign court was contrary to an agreement between the parties under which the dispute in question was to be determined otherwise than by proceedings in that foreign court;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3)(f): in the case of jurisdiction based only on personal service, the foreign court was a seriously inconvenient forum for the trial of the action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3)(g): the judgment was rendered in circumstances that raise substantial doubt about the integrity of the rendering court with respect to the judgment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(3)(h): the specific proceeding in the foreign court leading to the judgment was not compatible with the requirements of due process of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-453(4): (2); (3) A party resisting recognition of a foreign-country judgment has the burden of establishing that a ground for nonrecognition stated in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454 Personal jurisdiction.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(1): A foreign-country judgment may not be refused recognition for lack of personal jurisdiction if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(1)(a): the defendant was served with process personally in the foreign country;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(1)(b): the defendant voluntarily appeared in the proceeding, except for the purpose of protecting property seized or threatened with seizure in the proceeding or of contesting the jurisdiction of the court over the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(1)(c): the defendant, before the commencement of the proceeding, had agreed to submit to the jurisdiction of the foreign court with respect to the subject matter involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(1)(d): the defendant was domiciled in the foreign country when the proceeding was instituted or was a corporation or other form of business organization that had the corporation's or organization's principal place of business in, or was organized under the laws of, the foreign country;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(1)(e): the defendant had a business office in the foreign country and the proceeding in the foreign court involved a cause of action arising out of business done by the defendant through that office in the foreign country; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(1)(f): the defendant operated a motor vehicle or airplane in the foreign country and the proceeding involved a cause of action arising out of that operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(2): (1) The list describing the grounds for personal jurisdiction in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-454(3): (1) A court of this state may recognize grounds for personal jurisdiction other than those described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-455 Procedure for recognition of foreign-country judgment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-455(1): If recognition of a foreign-country judgment is sought as an original matter, the issue of recognition shall be raised by filing an action seeking recognition of the foreign-country judgment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-455(2): If recognition of a foreign-country judgment is sought in a pending action, the issue of recognition may be raised by counterclaim, cross-claim, or affirmative defense.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-456 Effect of recognition of foreign-country judgment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the court in a proceeding under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 78B-5-456(1): conclusive between the parties to the same extent as the judgment of a sister state entitled to full faith and credit in this state would be conclusive; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-456(2): enforceable in the same manner and to the same extent as a judgment rendered in this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-457 Stay of proceedings pending appeal of foreign-country judgment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a party establishes that an appeal from a foreign-country judgment is pending or an appeal will be taken, the court may stay any proceedings with regard to the foreign-country judgment until:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-457(1): the appeal is concluded;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-457(2): the time for appeal expires; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-457(3): the appellant has had sufficient time to prosecute the appeal and has failed to do so.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-458 Statute of limitations.
-------------------------------------------------------
An action to recognize a foreign-country judgment shall be commenced within the earlier of:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-458(1): the time during which the foreign-country judgment is effective in the foreign country; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-458(2): 15 years from the day on which the foreign-country judgment became effective in the foreign country.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-459 Uniformity of interpretation.
-------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to the subject matter of the uniform act among states that enact the uniform act.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-460 Saving clause.
----------------------------------------------
This part does not prevent the recognition under principles of comity or otherwise of a foreign-country judgment not within the scope of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-461 Application to future actions.
--------------------------------------------------------------
This part applies to all actions commenced on or after May 12, 2020, in which the issue of recognition of a foreign-country judgment is raised.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-501 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Utah Exemptions Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(1): 77-32b-102 "Civil accounts receivable" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(2): 77-32b-102 "Civil judgment of restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(3): "Debt" means a legally enforceable monetary obligation or liability of an individual, whether arising out of contract, tort, or otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(4): "Dependent" means the spouse of an individual, and the grandchild or the natural or adoptive child of an individual who derives support primarily from that individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(5): "Exempt" means protected, and "exemption" means protection from subjection to a judicial process to collect an unsecured debt.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(6): "Judicial lien" means a lien on property obtained by judgment or other legal process instituted for the purpose of collecting an unsecured debt.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(7): "Levy" means the seizure of property pursuant to any legal process issued for the purpose of collecting an unsecured debt.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(8): "Lien" means a judicial, or statutory lien, in property securing payment of a debt or performance of an obligation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(9): "Liquid assets" means deposits, securities, notes, drafts, unpaid earnings not otherwise exempt, accrued vacation pay, refunds, prepayments, and other receivables.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(10): "Security interest" means an interest in property created by contract to secure payment or performance of an obligation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(11): "Statutory lien" means a lien arising by force of a statute, but does not include a security interest or a judicial lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-502(12): "Value" means fair market value of an individual's interest in property, exclusive of valid liens.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504 Declaration of homestead -- Filing -- Contents -- Failure to file -- Conveyance by married person -- No execution sale if bid less than exemption -- Redemption rights of judgment creditor.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An individual may select and claim a homestead by complying with the following requirements:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(1): Filing a signed and acknowledged declaration of homestead with the recorder of the county or counties in which the homestead claimant's property is located or serving a signed and acknowledged declaration of homestead upon the sheriff or other officer conducting an execution prior to the time stated in the notice of execution.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(2): The declaration of homestead shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(2)(a): a statement that the claimant is entitled to an exemption and if the claimant is married a statement that the claimant's spouse has not filed a declaration of homestead;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(2)(b): a description of the property subject to the homestead;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(2)(c): an estimate of the cash value of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(2)(d): a statement specifying the amount of the homestead claimed and stating the name, age, and address of any spouse and dependents claimed to determine the value of the homestead.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(3): If a declaration of homestead is not filed or served as provided in this section, title shall pass to the purchaser upon execution free and clear of all homestead rights.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(4): If an individual is married, no conveyance of or security interest in, or contract to convey or create a security interest in property recorded as a homestead prior to the time of the conveyance, security interest, or contract is valid, unless both the husband and wife join in the execution of the conveyance, security interest, or contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(5): Property that includes a homestead may not be sold at execution if there is no bid which exceeds the amount of the declared homestead exemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-504(6): If property that includes a homestead is sold under execution, the sale is subject to redemption by the judgment debtor as provided in Rule 69C of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.  If there is a deficiency, the property may not be subject to another execution to cover the deficiency.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-505 Property exempt from execution.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-505(1): (1)(b); 75-7-503(2)(c); 76-10-501; (1)(a)(xiv); (1)(a)(xiv); (1)(b)(i); (1)(a)(xiv); (1)(a)(xi); (xii); (xiii)
