Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508 Allowable claims against exempt property.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1): 35A-4-103 Notwithstanding other provisions of this part, but subject to the provisions of the Utah Uniform Consumer Credit Code:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(a): A creditor may levy against exempt property of any kind, except unemployment benefits, to enforce a claim for:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(a)(i): alimony, support, or maintenance;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(a)(ii): unpaid earnings of up to one month's compensation or the full-time equivalent of one month's compensation for personal services of an employee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(a)(iii): state or local taxes.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(b): 35A-4-103 The only deductions that can be withheld from unemployment benefits are those listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(c): A creditor may levy against exempt property to enforce a claim for:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(c)(i): the purchase price of the property or a loan made for the purpose of enabling an individual to purchase the specific property used for that purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(c)(ii): labor or materials furnished to make, repair, improve, preserve, store, or transport the specific property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(1)(c)(iii): a special assessment imposed to defray costs of a public improvement benefiting the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-508(2): This section does not affect the right to enforce any statutory lien or security interest in exempt property.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-509 Waiver of exemptions in favor of unsecured creditor unenforceable.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A waiver of exemptions executed in favor of an unsecured creditor before levy on an individual's property is unenforceable.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-510 Assertion of individual's rights by spouse, dependent, or other authorized person.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If an individual fails to select property entitled to be claimed as exempt or to object to a levy on the property or to assert any other right under this part, the spouse or a dependent of the individual or any other authorized person may make the claim or objection or assert the rights provided by this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-511 Injunctive relief, damages, or both allowed against creditor to prevent violation of chapter -- Costs and attorney fees.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An individual or the spouse or a dependent of the individual is entitled to injunctive relief, damages, or both, against a creditor or other person to prevent or redress a violation of this part.  A court may award costs and reasonable attorney fees to a party entitled to injunctive relief or damages.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-512 Property held by joint tenants or tenants in common.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If an individual and another own property in this state as joint tenants or tenants in common, a creditor of the individual, subject to the individual's right to claim an exemption under this part, may obtain a levy on and sale of the interest of the individual in the property.  A creditor who has obtained a levy, or a purchaser who has purchased the individual's interest at the sale, may have the property partitioned or the individual's interest severed.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-513 Exemption provisions applicable in bankruptcy proceedings.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An individual may not exempt from the property of the estate in any bankruptcy proceeding the property specified in Subsection (d) of Section 522 of the Bankruptcy Reform Act (Public Law 95-598), unless the individual is a nonresident of this state and has been for the 180 days immediately preceding filing for bankruptcy.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-601 Statutes as evidence.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-601(1): The recitals in a public statute are conclusive evidence of the fact recited for the purpose of carrying it into effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-601(2): The recitals in a private statute are conclusive evidence between parties who claim under its provisions.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-602 Entries in official records as evidence.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Entries in public or other official books or records, made by a public officer in the performance of the officer's official duties or by any other person in the performance of a duty specially enjoined by the law, are prima facie evidence of the facts stated in the entry.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-603 Entries in course of official duty as evidence.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An entry made by an officer or board of officers, or under the direction and in the presence of either, in the course of official duty is prima facie evidence of the facts stated in the entry.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-604 Certificate of location or purchase of public lands of United States as evidence.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A certificate of purchase or of location of any lands in this state, issued or made in pursuance of any law of the United States, is prima facie evidence that the holder or assignee of the certificate is the owner of the land described in the certificate.  This evidence may be overcome by proof that the land was in the adverse possession of the adverse party, or those under whom the party claims, or that the adverse party was holding the land for mining purposes at the time the certificate is filed.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-605 Histories, scientific books, maps, and charts as evidence.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Historical works, books of science or art, and published maps or charts, when made or published by persons having no interest in a proceeding, are prima facie evidence of facts of general notoriety and interest.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-606 Certificate of acknowledgment as evidence of execution.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Private writings, except last wills and testaments, may be acknowledged or proved, and certified in the manner provided for the acknowledgment or proof of conveyances of real property.  The certificate of acknowledgment or proof is prima facie evidence of the execution of the writing in the same manner as a conveyance of real property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-607 When entries and writings of a decedent are prima facie evidence.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The entries and other writings of a decedent made at or near the time of the transaction, and when the decedent was in a position to know the facts stated in the entry, may be read as prima facie evidence of the facts written about, in the following cases:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-607(1): the entry was made against the interest of the person making it;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-607(2): it was made in a professional capacity and in the ordinary course of professional conduct; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-607(3): it was made in the performance of a duty specially enjoined by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-608 Writings -- How proved.
-------------------------------------------------------
A writing may be proved either:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-608(1): by any one who saw the writing executed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-608(2): by evidence of the genuineness of the handwriting of the maker; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-608(3): by a subscribing witness.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-609 Proof of execution when subscribing witness denies or forgets.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the subscribing witness denies or does not recollect the execution of the writing, its execution may still be proved by other evidence.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-610 When unnecessary.
-------------------------------------------------
If the evidence shows that the party against whom the writing is offered has at any time admitted its execution, no other evidence of the execution need be given if the instrument is one produced from the custody of the adverse party and has been acted upon by the party as genuine.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-611 Proof of wills.
-----------------------------------------------
A last will and testament, except a nuncupative will, is invalid, unless it is in writing and executed in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-612 Proof of instruments affecting real estate.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
An instrument conveying or affecting real property, acknowledged, or proved and certified as provided by law, may, together with the certificate of acknowledgment or proof, be read in evidence in an action or proceeding, without further proof.  The record, or a certified copy of the record, of the conveyance or instrument acknowledged or proved may be read in evidence, with the same effect as the original.  The party offering the certified copy shall prove by affidavit or otherwise, that the original is not in the possession or under the control of the party.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-613 Proof of publication of document, notice, or order.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-613(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-613(1)(a): If a court or judge orders a document or notice published in a newspaper, evidence of the publication shall be made by affidavit of the publisher, the publisher's foreman, or principal clerk with a copy of the publication attached.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-613(1)(b): The affidavit shall state the date and newspaper of publication.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-613(2): 45-1-101
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-613(2)(a): 45-1-101 If a court or judge orders a document or notice published electronically in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-613(2)(b): The affidavit shall state the date of publication.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-614 Filing of affidavit -- Original or certified copy as evidence.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If an affidavit is made in an action or special proceeding pending in a court, it may be filed with the court or clerk of the court.  If not made in an action or special proceeding pending in a court, it may be filed with the recorder of the county where the newspaper is published.  The original affidavit, or a copy certified by the judge of the court or officer having it in custody, is prima facie evidence of the facts stated in the affidavit.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615 Parol evidence of contents of writings -- When admissible.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615(1): The contents of a writing shall be proved by the original writing unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615(1)(a): the original has been lost or destroyed, in which case proof of the loss or destruction shall be made first;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615(1)(b): the original is in the possession of the party against whom the evidence is offered and the party fails to produce it after reasonable notice;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615(1)(c): the original is a record or other document in the custody of a public officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615(1)(d): the original has been recorded, and the record or a certified copy of the record is made in accordance with the law governing the writing offered; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615(1)(e): the original consists of numerous accounts or other documents which cannot be examined in court without great loss of time, and the evidence sought from them is only the general result of the whole.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615(2): If any business, institution, member of a profession or calling, or any department or agency of government, in the regular course of business or activity has kept or recorded any memorandum, writing, entry, print, representation or combination, of any act, transaction, occurrence, or event, and in the regular course of business has caused any or all of the same to be recorded, copied, or reproduced by any photographic, photostatic, microfilm, microcard, miniature photographic, or other process which accurately reproduces or forms a durable medium for so reproducing the original, the original may be destroyed in the regular course of business unless its preservation is required by law.  The reproduction, when satisfactorily identified, is as admissible in evidence as the original itself in any judicial or administrative proceeding whether the original is in existence or not, an enlargement or facsimile of the reproduction is likewise admissible in evidence if the original reproduction is in existence and available for inspection under direction of court.  The introduction of a reproduced record, enlargement or facsimile, does not preclude admission of the original.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-615(3): (1)(c); (d); (1)(a); (b) In the cases mentioned in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-616 Business record -- Admissibility -- Weight.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-616(1): As used in this section, "business" includes business, profession, occupation, and calling of every kind.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-616(2): A writing or record, whether in the form of an entry in a book or otherwise, made as a memorandum or record of any act, transaction, occurrence, or event, shall be admissible as evidence of that act, transaction, occurrence, or event, if made in the regular course of any business, and if it was the regular course of the business to make the memorandum or record at the time of the act, transaction, occurrence, or event or within a reasonable time after.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-616(3): (2) All circumstances, other than those set forth in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-617 Writings bearing obvious alterations -- Explanation required.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-617(1): The party producing as genuine a writing which has been altered, or appears to have been altered after its execution in a part material to the question in dispute must account for the appearance of alteration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-617(2): The party may show that the alteration:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-617(2)(a): was made by another without the party's concurrence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-617(2)(b): was made with the consent of the parties affected by it;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-617(2)(c): was otherwise properly or innocently made; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-617(2)(d): does not change the meaning or language of the instrument.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-617(3): (2) An altered writing that a party cannot adequately explain under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618 Patient access to medical records -- Third-party access to medical records -- Medical records services -- Fees -- Standard form.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1): 78B-3-403; 26B-3-113; 67-11-2 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(a): "Force majeure event" means an event or circumstance beyond the control of the health care provider or the health care provider's third-party service, including fires, floods, earthquakes, acts of God, lockouts, ransomware, or strikes.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(b): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(c): "History of poor payment" means three or more invoices where payment is more than 30 days late within a 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(d): 26B-3-113 "Indigent individual" means an individual whose household income is at or below 100% of the federal poverty level as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(e): "Inflation" means the unadjusted Consumer Price Index, as published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor, that measures the average changes in prices of goods and services purchased by urban wage earners and clerical workers.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(f): "Payment and balance information" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(f)(i): all payments the health care provider has received for providing health care to the patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(f)(ii): the total balance owed to the health care provider for providing the health care to the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(g): 67-11-2 "Qualified claim or appeal" means a claim or appeal under any:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(g)(i): 67-11-2 provision of the Social Security Act as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(g)(ii): federal or state financial needs-based benefit program.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(1)(h): "Third-party service" means a service that has entered into a contract with a health care provider to provide patient records on behalf of a health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(2): Pursuant to Standards for Privacy of Individually Identifiable Health Information, 45 C.F.R., Parts 160 and 164, a patient or a patient's personal representative may inspect or receive a copy of the patient's records from a health care provider when that health care provider is governed by the provisions of 45 C.F.R., Parts 160 and 164.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(3): When a health care provider is not governed by Standards for Privacy of Individually Identifiable Health Information, 45 C.F.R., Parts 160 and 164, a patient or a patient's personal representative may inspect or receive a copy of the patient's records unless access to the records is restricted by law or judicial order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(4): A health care provider who provides a paper or electronic copy of a patient's records to the patient or the patient's personal representative:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(4)(a): shall provide the copy within the deadlines required by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, Administrative Simplification rule, 45 C.F.R. Sec. 164.524(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(4)(b): may charge a reasonable cost-based fee provided that the fee includes only the cost of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(4)(b)(i): copying, including the cost of supplies for and labor of copying; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(4)(b)(ii): postage, when the patient or patient's personal representative has requested the copy be mailed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5): 26B-8-411
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a): 26B-8-411 Except for records provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(i): shall provide the copy within 30 days after receipt of notice;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(ii): may charge a reasonable fee for paper or electronic copies, but may not exceed the following rates:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(ii)(A): $30 per request for locating a patient's records;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(ii)(B): reproduction charges may not exceed 53 cents per page for the first 40 pages and 32 cents per page for each additional page;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(ii)(C): the cost of postage when the requester has requested the copy be mailed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(ii)(D): if requested, the person fulfilling the request will certify the record as a duplicate of the original for a fee of $20; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(ii)(E): any sales tax owed under Title 59, Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(iii): may charge an expedition fee of $20 if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(iii)(A): the requester's notice explicitly requests an expedited response; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(a)(iii)(B): the person fulfilling the request postmarks or otherwise makes the record available electronically within 15 days from the day the person fulfilling the request receives notice of the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(b): Notwithstanding the provisions of Subsection (5)(a)(ii) and subject to Subsection (5)(c), in the event the requested records are not postmarked or otherwise made available electronically by the person fulfilling the request:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(b)(i): within 30 days after the day on which notice is received by the person fulfilling the request, the person fulfilling the request shall waive 50% of the fee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(b)(ii): within 60 days after the day on which notice is received by the person fulfilling the request, the person fulfilling the request shall provide the requested records free of charge to the requester.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(c): Performance under Subsection (5)(b) shall be extended in accordance with Subsection (5)(d) if the person fulfilling the request notifies the requester of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(c)(i): the occurrence of a force majeure event within 10 days from the day:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(c)(i)(A): the force majeure event occurs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(c)(i)(B): the person fulfilling the request receives notice of the request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(c)(ii): the termination of the force majeure event within 10 days from the day the force majeure event terminates.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d): In accordance with Subsection (5)(c), for a force majeure event:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(i): that lasts less than eight days, the person fulfilling the request shall, if the records are not postmarked or otherwise made available electronically within:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(i)(A): 30 days of the day the force majeure event ends, waive 50% of the fee for providing the records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(i)(B): 60 days of the day the force majeure event ends, waive the entire fee for providing the records;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(ii): that lasts at least eight days but less than 30 days, the person fulfilling the request shall, if the records are not postmarked or otherwise made available electronically within:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(ii)(A): 60 days of the day the force majeure event ends, waive 50% of the fee for providing the records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(ii)(B): 90 days of the day the force majeure event ends, waive the entire fee for providing the records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(iii): that lasts more than 30 days, the person fulfilling the request shall, if the records are not postmarked or otherwise made available electronically within:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(iii)(A): 90 days of the day the force majeure event ends, waive 50% of the fee for providing the records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(d)(iii)(B): 120 days of the day the force majeure event ends, waive the entire fee for providing the records.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(e)(i): A third-party service may require prepayment before sending records for a request under this Subsection (5) if the third-party service:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(e)(i)(A): determines the requester has a history of poor payment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(e)(i)(B): notifies the requester, within the time periods described in Subsections (5)(b)(i) and (ii), that the records will be sent as soon as the request has been prepaid.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(e)(ii): The fee reductions described in Subsection (5)(d) do not apply if a third-party service complies with Subsection (5)(e)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(f): If a third-party service does not possess or have access to the data necessary to fulfill a request, the third-party service shall notify:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(f)(i): the requester that the request cannot be fulfilled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(f)(ii): state the reasons for the third-party service's inability to fulfill the request within 30 days from the day on which the request is received by the third-party service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(5)(g): A patient's attorney, legal representative, or other third party authorized to receive records may request patient records directly from a third-party service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(a): A separate notice of request for payment and balance information shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(a)(i): clearly indicate that the request is only for payment and balance information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(a)(ii): indicate the name, telephone number, email address, and address of the requester.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(b): A health care provider or third-party service fulfilling a request for payment and balance information from a patient's attorney, legal representative, or other third-party representative, shall fulfill the request within 30 days after the day on which notice is received by the health care provider or by the third-party service, whichever is fulfilling the request, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(b)(i): mailing a postmarked copy of the information to the requester; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(b)(ii): providing the information electronically or telephonically.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(c): A health care provider or third-party service that is responsible for fulfilling a request for payment and balance information but fails to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(c)(i): fulfill the request within 30 days, in accordance with Subsection (6)(b), shall pay, as a penalty, $50; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(c)(ii): fulfill the request within 60 days shall pay, as a penalty, an additional $150.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(d): A health care provider or third-party service obligated to pay a penalty under Subsection (6)(c) shall pay the amount owed:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(d)(i): to reduce any amount the patient owes to the health care provider for the provision of health care, after any third-party obligations to pay, if the amount owed is more than the penalty;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(d)(ii): directly to the patient, if the requested payment and balance information reflects that the patient owes no amount to the health care provider for the provision of health care services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(d)(iii): allocated between:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(d)(iii)(A): a payment to satisfy the amount the patient owes to the health care provider for the provision of health care, as indicated on the payment and balance information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(d)(iii)(B): a payment in the amount of any remaining penalty obligation to the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(6)(e): A third-party service may satisfy any obligation to pay a penalty under Subsection (6)(c) by remitting the penalty amount to the health care provider to be allocated in accordance with Subsection (6)(d).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(7): A health care provider or third-party service shall, if the health care provider or the third-party service responding to a request for payment and balance information is unable to comply with Subsection (6)(b), provide a written response that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(7)(a): contact information, if known, for the individual who the requester may contact to fulfill the request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(7)(b): the reason for not complying with Subsection (6)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(8)(a): Subject to Subsection (8)(b), a health care provider that contracts with a third-party service to fulfill the health care provider's medical record requests shall file a statement with the Division of Professional Licensing containing:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(8)(b): If an individual health care provider is an employee or contractor of an organization that is a health care provider and that contracts with a third-party service to fulfill the medical record requests for the individual health care provider, the organization may file the statement under Subsection (8)(a) on behalf of the organization's employees and contractors.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(8)(c): A health care provider described in Subsection (8)(a) shall update the filing described in Subsection (8)(a) as necessary to ensure that the information is accurate.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(8)(d): The Division of Professional Licensing shall develop a form for a health care provider to complete that provides the information required by Subsection (8)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(8)(e): The Division of Professional Licensing shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(8)(e)(i): maintain an index of statements described in Subsection (8)(a) arranged alphabetically by entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(8)(e)(ii): make the index available to the public electronically on the Division of Professional Licensing's website.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(9): A health care provider or the health care provider's third-party service shall deliver the medical records in the electronic medium customarily used by the person fulfilling the request or in a universally readable image such as portable document format:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(9)(a): if the patient, patient's personal representative, or a third party authorized to receive the records requests the records be delivered in an electronic medium; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(9)(b): the original medical record is readily producible in an electronic medium.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(10)(a): Except as provided in Subsections (10)(b) through (d), the per page fee in Subsections (4) and (5) applies to medical records reproduced electronically or on paper.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(10)(c)(ii)(B): may not charge a fee for the electronic copy that exceeds $150 regardless of the number of pages and regardless of whether the original medical records are stored in electronic format.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(10)(f)(ii)(B): 90 days of the day the force majeure event ends, shall waive the entire fee for providing the records; and

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(10)(f)(iii)(A): 90 days of the day the force majeure event ends, may not charge a fee for an electronic copy that exceeds $75 regardless of the number of pages and regardless of whether the original medical records are stored in electronic format; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(10)(f)(iii)(B): 120 days of the day the force majeure event ends, shall waive the entire fee for providing the records.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(12)(c): shall provide the health record within 30 days after the day on which the request is received by the health care provider.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-618(13)(c)(ii): Any request for additional copies in addition to the one copy allowed under Subsection (13)(c) is subject to the fee provisions described in Subsection (12).

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620 Calibration certificates for breathalizers.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(1): 53-1-103 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(1)(a): "Breathalizer" means any device used by a law enforcement agency which utilizes a person's breath to estimate blood alcohol content.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(1)(b): "Calibration" means the manual setting of specific levels on a breathalizer by a person trained to reset the machine to insure as accurate results as possible.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(1)(c): "Certificate of calibration" means the document issued by the person who calibrates a breathalizer, attesting to the accuracy of the machine.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(1)(d): 53-1-103 "Department" means the Department of Public Safety created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(1)(e): "Digitize" means to convert content from a tangible, analog form into a digital electronic representation of that content.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(2): The department may digitize and post the digital format of certificates of calibration on its website in a secure location not available to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(3): The secure location shall be available to courts and local prosecutors' offices for use in actions in which it is alleged a party was intoxicated and a law enforcement officer required the party to submit to a breathalizer test.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department shall make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(4)(a): to provide a method for insuring the accuracy of the certificates on the website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-620(4)(b): providing for an attestation to the authenticity of the certificate upon download by a prosecutor or court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-701 Taking of affidavits in this state.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
An affidavit to be used before any court, judge, or officer of this state may be taken before any judge, the clerk of any court, any justice court judge, or any notary public in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-702 Taking of affidavits in another state.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
An affidavit taken in another state or territory of the United States, to be used in this state, may be taken before a commissioner appointed by the governor of this state to take affidavits and depositions in another state or territory, or before any notary public in another state or territory, or before any judge or clerk of a court of record having a seal.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-703 Taking of affidavits in foreign country.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
An affidavit taken in a foreign country, to be used in this state, may be taken before an ambassador, minister, consul, vice consul or consular agent of the United States, or before any judge of a court of record having a seal, in the foreign country.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-704 Certification of affidavits taken before foreign court or judge.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When an affidavit is taken before a judge or court in another state or territory, or in a foreign country, the genuineness of the signature of the judge, the existence of the court, and the fact that the judge is a member of the court, shall be certified by the clerk of the court under the court's seal.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-801 Public and private statutes defined.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Statutes are public and private.  A private statute is one which concerns only certain designated individuals, and affects only their private rights.  All other statutes are public, in which are included statutes creating or affecting corporations.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-802 Tender -- Offer in writing sufficient -- Objection -- Must be specific or waived.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-802(1): An offer in writing to pay a particular sum of money or to deliver a written instrument or specific personal property is, if not accepted, equivalent to the actual production and tender of the money, instrument, or property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-802(2): The person to whom a tender is made shall, at the time, specify any objection to the money, instrument, or property, or it is considered waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-802(3): If the objection is to the amount of money, the terms of the instrument or the amount or kind of property, the person shall specify the amounts, terms, or kind which is required, or be precluded from objection afterwards.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-803 Receipt may be demanded as condition to payment or deposit.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person who pays money, or delivers an instrument or property, is entitled to a receipt from the person to whom the payment or delivery is made, and may demand a proper signature to the receipt as a condition of the payment or delivery.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804 Money deposited in court.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(1)(a): Any person depositing money  in court, to be held in trust, shall pay it to the court clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(1)(b): The clerk shall deposit the money in a court trust fund or with the county treasurer or city recorder to be held subject to the order of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(2): The Judicial Council shall adopt rules governing the maintenance of court trust funds and the disposition of interest earnings on those trust funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(3)(a): Any interest earned on trust funds in the courts of record that is not required to accrue to the litigants by Judicial Council rule or court order shall be deposited in a restricted account.  Any interest earned on trust funds in the courts not of record that is not required to accrue to the litigants by Judicial Council rule or court order shall be deposited in the general fund of the county or municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(3)(b): The Legislature shall appropriate funds from  the restricted account of the courts of record to the Judicial Council to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(3)(b)(i): offset costs to the courts for collection and maintenance of court trust funds; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-804(3)(b)(ii): provide accounting and auditing of all court revenue and trust accounts.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-805 State, state officers, and political subdivisions not required to give bond.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-805(1): In any civil action or proceeding in which the state is a party plaintiff, or any state officer in an official capacity or on behalf of the state, or any county or city or other public corporation is a party plaintiff or defendant, no bond, written undertaking, or security may be required of the state, or any state officer, or of any county, city, or other public corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-805(2): Upon compliance with the other provisions of the law, the state or any state officer acting in an official capacity, or any county, city, or other public corporation, has the same rights, remedies, and benefits as if the bond, undertaking, or security were given and approved as required by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-806 Payment of costs by state.
----------------------------------------------------------
When a state is a party and costs are awarded against it, the costs shall be paid out of the state treasury.  The auditor shall draw a warrant on the General Fund for payment.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-807 Payment of costs by county.
-----------------------------------------------------------
When a county is a party and costs are awarded against it, the costs shall be paid out of the county treasury.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-808 Salaries of public officers subject to garnishment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The state and any subdivision, agency, or institution of the state which has in its possession or under its control any credits or other personal property of, or owing any debt to, the defendant in any action, whether as salary or wages, as a public official or employee may be subject to attachment, garnishment, and execution in accordance with any rights, remedies, and procedures applicable to attachment, garnishment, and execution, respectively, except as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-809 Service of process.
---------------------------------------------------
Process for a garnishment under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-810 Sureties on stay bonds entitled to subrogation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a surety on an appeal executed to stay proceedings upon a money judgment pays the judgment, either with or without action, after its affirmance by the appellate court, the surety is subrogated to the rights of the judgment creditor, and entitled to control, enforce, and satisfy the judgment in all respects as if the surety had recovered the same.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-811 Provisions as to depositions made applicable to nonjudicial proceedings.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of law relating to the taking of depositions in actions pending before the courts of this state are applicable to commissions, boards and officers authorized to subpoena witnesses and take testimony.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-812 Release or settlement of personal injury claim -- When voidable.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-812(1): 78B-5-812; 78B-5-816 Any release of liability or settlement agreement entered into within a period of 15 days from the date of an occurrence causing physical injury to any person, or entered into prior to the initial discharge of the person from any hospital or sanitarium in which the injured person is confined as a result of the injuries sustained in the occurrence, is voidable by the injured person, as provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-812(2): Notice of cancellation of the release or settlement agreement, together with any payment or other consideration received in connection with the release or agreement shall be mailed or delivered to the party to whom the release or settlement agreement was given, by the later of the following dates:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-812(2)(a): within 15 days from the date of the occurrence causing the injuries which are subject of the settlement agreement or liability release; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-812(2)(b): within 15 days after the date of the injured person's discharge from the hospital or sanitarium in which the person has been confined continuously since the date of the occurrence causing the injury.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-813 Statement of injured person -- When inadmissible as evidence.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 78B-5-813(1): a written verbatim copy of the statement has been left with the injured party at the time the statement was taken; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-813(2): the statement has not been disavowed in writing within 15 days of the date of the statement or within 15 days after the date of the injured person's initial discharge from the hospital or sanitarium in which the person has been confined, whichever date is later.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-814 Release, settlement, or statement by injured person -- When rescission or disavowal provisions inapplicable.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-815 Release, settlement, or statement by injured person -- Notice of rescission or disavowal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notice of cancellation or notice disavowing a statement, if given by mail, is given when it is deposited in a mailbox, properly addressed with postage prepaid.  Notice of cancellation given by the injured person need not take a particular form.  It is sufficient if it indicates by any form of written expression the intention of the injured person not to be bound by the settlement agreement, liability release, or disavowed statement.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-816 Right of rescission or disavowal of release, settlement, or statement by injured person in addition to other provisions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-821 Joinder of defendants.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-821(1): A person seeking recovery, or any defendant who is a party to the litigation, may join as a defendant, in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, any person other than a person immune from suit alleged to have caused or contributed to the injury or damage for which recovery is sought, for the purpose of having determined their respective proportions of fault.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-821(2): A person immune from suit may not be named as a defendant, but fault may be allocated to a person immune from suit solely for the purpose of accurately determining the fault of the person seeking recovery and all defendants.  A person immune from suit is not subject to any liability, based on the allocation of fault, in this or any other action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-821(3): 78B-5-818
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-821(3)(a): A person immune from suit may intervene as a party under Rule 24, Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, regardless of whether or not money damages are sought.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-821(3)(b): 78B-5-818 A person immune from suit who intervenes in an action may not be held liable for any fault allocated to that person under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-821(4): Fault may not be allocated to a non-party unless a party timely files a description of the factual and legal basis on which fault can be allocated and information identifying the non-party, to the extent known or reasonably available to the party, including name, address, telephone number and employer.  The party shall file the description and identifying information in accordance with Rule 9, Utah Rules of Civil Procedure or as ordered by the court but in no event later than 90 days before trial as provided in Rule 9, Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-822 Release to one defendant does not discharge other defendants.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A release given by a person seeking recovery to one or more defendants does not discharge any other defendant unless the release so provides.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824 Personal injury judgments -- Interest authorized.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(1): In all actions brought to recover damages for personal injuries sustained by any person, caused by the negligence or willful intent of another person, corporation, association, or partnership, and whether the injury was fatal or otherwise, the plaintiff, including a counterclaim plaintiff or a crossclaim plaintiff, in the complaint may claim interest on special damages actually incurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(2): A plaintiff, including a counterclaim plaintiff or a crossclaim plaintiff, seeking to recover damages for personal injury or wrongful death may claim prejudgment interest if for cases classified as tier 1, pursuant to the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, the plaintiff tenders:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(2)(a): a written settlement demand, including settlement demands under Utah Rule of Civil Procedure 68; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(2)(b): the amount of the demand does not exceed 1-1/3 of the amount of the judgment eventually awarded at trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(3): For purposes of this statute, the determining offer and counteroffer shall be the last written offer or counteroffer timely tendered by a party, provided that the offer or counteroffer is tendered at least 60 days before trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(4): 18-1-4; 31A-22-321; (2) Cases classified as tier 2 or tier 3 by the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure or submitted to binding arbitration in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(5)(a): Any prejudgment interest shall be computed as simple interest.  For first special damages incurred during the year of the occurrence of the act giving rise to the cause of action, any prejudgment interest shall be computed as simple interest accruing from the date on which the first date special damages were actually incurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(5)(b): For special damages incurred in successive years, prejudgment interest shall be calculated from January 1 of each year special damages were incurred.  The court shall calculate prejudgment interest using a per annum rate, which is two percentage points above the prime rate, as published by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System on the first business day in January of the calendar year in which the judgment is entered.  The prejudgment interest rate applied to all cases may not be lower than 5% or higher than 10%.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(6): As used in this section, "special damages actually incurred" does not include damages for future medical expenses, loss of future wages, or loss of future earning capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-824(7): This section applies to any cause of action arising on or after July 1, 2014.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-825 Attorney fees -- Award where action or defense in bad faith -- Exceptions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-825(1): (2) In civil actions, the court shall award reasonable attorney fees to a prevailing party if the court determines that the action or defense to the action was without merit and not brought or asserted in good faith, except under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-825(2): (1); 78A-2-302; (1) The court, in the court's discretion, may award no fees or limited fees against a party under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-825(2)(a): 78A-2-302 finds the party has filed an affidavit of indigency under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-825.5 Attorney fees -- Private attorney general doctrine disavowed.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A court may not award attorney fees under the private attorney general doctrine in any action filed after May 12, 2009.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-826 Attorney fees -- Reciprocal rights to recover attorney fees.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A court may award costs and attorney fees to either party that prevails in a civil action based upon any promissory note, written contract, or other writing executed after April 28, 1986, when the provisions of the promissory note, written contract, or other writing allow at least one party to recover attorney fees.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-827 Attorney fees awarded to state funded agency in action against state or subdivision -- Forfeit of appropriated money.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An agency or organization receiving state funds which, as a result of its suing the state, or political subdivision of the state, receives attorney fees and costs as all or part of a settlement or award, shall forfeit to the General Fund, from its appropriated money, an amount equal to the attorney fees received.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828 Bond required in an environmental action.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1): 63G-4-405 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1)(a): 63G-4-405 "Administrative stay" means a stay or other temporary remedy issued by an agency under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1)(b): "Environmental action" means a cause of action that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1)(b)(i): is filed on or after May 10, 2011; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1)(b)(ii): seeks judicial review of a final agency action to issue a permit by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1)(b)(ii)(A): the Department of Natural Resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1)(b)(ii)(B): the Department of Transportation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1)(b)(ii)(C): the School and Institutional Trust Lands Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(1)(c): "Ultimately prevail on the merits" means, in the final judgment, the court rules in the plaintiff's favor on at least one cause of action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(2): A plaintiff who obtains a preliminary injunction or administrative stay in an environmental action, but does not ultimately prevail on the merits of the environmental action, is liable for damages sustained by a defendant who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(2)(a): opposed the preliminary injunction or administrative stay; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(2)(b): was harmed by the preliminary injunction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(3): A court may not issue a preliminary injunction and an agency may not grant an administrative stay in an environmental action until the plaintiff posts with the court or the agency a surety bond or cash equivalent:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(3)(a): in an amount the court or agency considers sufficient to compensate each defendant opposing the preliminary injunction or administrative stay for damages that each defendant may sustain as a result of the preliminary injunction or administrative stay;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(3)(b): written by a surety licensed to do business in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(3)(c): payable to each defendant opposing the preliminary injunction or administrative stay in the event the plaintiff does not prevail on the merits of the environmental action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(4): (3) If there is more than one plaintiff, the court or agency shall establish the amount of the bond required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(5)(a): If the plaintiff does not ultimately prevail on the merits of the environmental action, the court shall execute the bond and award damages to each defendant who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(5)(a)(i): opposed the preliminary injunction or administrative stay; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(5)(a)(ii): was harmed as a result of its issuance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(5)(b): If the amount of money secured by the surety bond or cash equivalent:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(5)(b)(i): exceeds the damages awarded, the court or agency shall return the excess to the plaintiff; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(5)(b)(ii): is less than the damages awarded, the court or agency shall order the plaintiff to pay the remaining damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-5-828(6): Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a court's or agency's refusal to require the posting of a surety bond or cash equivalent as required by this section is subject to immediate appeal.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 6 - Particular Proceedings
********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Utah Adoption Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102 Legislative intent and findings -- Best interest of child -- Interests of each party.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(1): It is the intent and desire of the Legislature that in every adoption the best interest of the child should govern and be of foremost concern in the court's determination.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(2): The court shall make a specific finding regarding the best interest of the child, taking into consideration information provided to the court pursuant to the requirements of this chapter relating to the health, safety, and welfare of the child and the moral climate of the potential adoptive placement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(3): The Legislature finds that the rights and interests of all parties affected by an adoption proceeding must be considered and balanced in determining what constitutional protections and processes are necessary and appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(4): The Legislature specifically finds that it is not in a child's best interest to be adopted by a person or persons who are cohabiting in a relationship that is not a legally valid and binding marriage under the laws of this state.  Nothing in this section limits or prohibits the court's placement of a child with a single adult who is not cohabiting or a person who is a relative of the child or a recognized placement under the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Sec. 1901 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(5): The Legislature also finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(5)(a): the state has a compelling interest in providing stable and permanent homes for adoptive children in a prompt manner, in preventing the disruption of adoptive placements, and in holding parents accountable for meeting the needs of children;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(5)(b): an unmarried mother, faced with the responsibility of making crucial decisions about the future of a newborn child, is entitled to privacy, and has the right to make timely and appropriate decisions regarding her future and the future of the child, and is entitled to assurance regarding the permanence of an adoptive placement;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(5)(c): adoptive children have a right to permanence and stability in adoptive placements;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(5)(d): adoptive parents have a constitutionally protected liberty and privacy interest in retaining custody of an adopted child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(5)(e): an unmarried biological father has an inchoate interest that acquires constitutional protection only when he demonstrates a timely and full commitment to the responsibilities of parenthood, both during pregnancy and upon the child's birth; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(5)(f): the state has a compelling interest in requiring unmarried biological fathers to demonstrate commitment by providing appropriate medical care and financial support and by establishing legal paternity, in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(6)(a): In enacting this chapter, the Legislature has prescribed the conditions for determining whether an unmarried biological father's action is sufficiently prompt and substantial to require constitutional protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(6)(b): If an unmarried biological father fails to grasp the opportunities to establish a relationship with his child that are available to him, his biological parental interest may be lost entirely, or greatly diminished in constitutional significance by his failure to timely exercise it, or by his failure to strictly comply with the available legal steps to substantiate it.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(6)(c): A certain degree of finality is necessary in order to facilitate the state's compelling interest.  The Legislature finds that the interests of the state, the mother, the child, and the adoptive parents described in this section outweigh the interest of an unmarried biological father who does not timely grasp the opportunity to establish and demonstrate a relationship with his child in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(6)(d): The Legislature finds no practical way to remove all risk of fraud or misrepresentation in adoption proceedings, and has provided a method for absolute protection of an unmarried biological father's rights by compliance with the provisions of this chapter.  In balancing the rights and interests of the state, and of all parties affected by fraud, specifically the child, the adoptive parents, and the unmarried biological father, the Legislature has determined that the unmarried biological father is in the best position to prevent or ameliorate the effects of fraud and that, therefore, the burden of fraud shall be borne by him.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(6)(e): An unmarried biological father has the primary responsibility to protect his rights.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(6)(f): An unmarried biological father is presumed to know that the child may be adopted without his consent unless he strictly complies with the provisions of this chapter, manifests a prompt and full commitment to his parental responsibilities, and establishes paternity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-102(7): The Legislature finds that an unmarried mother has a right of privacy with regard to her pregnancy and adoption plan, and therefore has no legal obligation to disclose the identity of an unmarried biological father prior to or during an adoption proceeding, and has no obligation to volunteer information to the court with respect to the father.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(1): "Adoptee" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(1)(a): is the subject of an adoption proceeding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(1)(b): has been legally adopted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(2): 78B-6-138 "Adoption" means the judicial act that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(2)(a): creates the relationship of parent and child where it did not previously exist; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(2)(b): 78B-6-138 except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(3): "Adoption document" means an adoption-related document filed with the office, a petition for adoption, a decree of adoption, an original birth certificate, or evidence submitted in support of a supplementary birth certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(4): "Adoption proceeding" means any proceeding under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(5): "Adoption service provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(5)(a): a child-placing agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(5)(b): a licensed counselor who has at least one year of experience providing professional social work services to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(5)(b)(i): adoptive parents;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(5)(b)(ii): prospective adoptive parents; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(5)(b)(iii): birth parents; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(5)(c): the Office of Licensing within the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(6): "Adoptive parent" means an individual who has legally adopted an adoptee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(7): "Adult" means an individual who is 18 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(8): "Adult adoptee" means an adoptee who is 18 years old or older and was adopted as a minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(9): "Adult sibling" means an adoptee's brother or sister, who is 18 years old or older and whose birth mother or father is the same as that of the adoptee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(10): "Birth mother" means the biological mother of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(11): "Birth parent" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(11)(a): a birth mother;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(11)(b): a man whose paternity of a child is established;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(11)(c): a man who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(11)(c)(i): has been identified as the father of a child by the child's birth mother; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(11)(c)(ii): has not denied paternity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(11)(d): an unmarried biological father.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(12): "Child-placing agency" means an agency licensed to place children for adoption under Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 1, Human Services Programs and Facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(13): "Cohabiting" means residing with another person and being involved in a sexual relationship with that person.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(14): 80-2-201 "Division" means the Division of Child and Family Services, within the Department of Health and Human Services, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(15): "Extra-jurisdictional child-placing agency" means an agency licensed to place children for adoption by a district, territory, or state of the United States, other than Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(16): "Genetic and social history" means a comprehensive report, when obtainable, that contains the following information on an adoptee's birth parents, aunts, uncles, and grandparents:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(16)(a): medical history;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(16)(b): health status;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(16)(c): cause of and age at death;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(16)(d): height, weight, and eye and hair color;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(16)(e): ethnic origins;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(16)(f): where appropriate, levels of education and professional achievement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(16)(g): religion, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(17): "Health history" means a comprehensive report of the adoptee's health status at the time of placement for adoption, and medical history, including neonatal, psychological, physiological, and medical care history.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(18): "Identifying information" means information that is in the possession of the office and that contains the name and address of a pre-existing parent or an adult adoptee, or other specific information that by itself or in reasonable conjunction with other information may be used to identify a pre-existing parent or an adult adoptee, including information on a birth certificate or in an adoption document.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(19): "Licensed counselor" means an individual who is licensed by the state, or another state, district, or territory of the United States as a:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(19)(a): certified social worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(19)(b): clinical social worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(19)(c): psychologist;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(19)(d): marriage and family therapist;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(19)(e): clinical mental health counselor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(19)(f): an equivalent licensed professional of another state, district, or territory of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(20): "Man" means a male individual, regardless of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(21): "Mature adoptee" means an adoptee who is adopted when the adoptee is an adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(22): "Office" means the Office of Vital Records and Statistics within the Department of Health and Human Services operating under Title 26B, Chapter 8, Part 1, Vital Statistics.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(23): 78B-6-112; 78B-6-119; 78B-6-120; 78B-6-120; 78B-6-122 "Parent," for purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(24): "Potential birth father" means a man who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(24)(a): is identified by a birth mother as a potential biological father of the birth mother's child, but whose genetic paternity has not been established; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(24)(b): was not married to the biological mother of the child described in Subsection (24)(a) at the time of the child's conception or birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(25): "Pre-existing parent" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(25)(a): a birth parent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(25)(b): an individual who, before an adoption decree is entered, is, due to an earlier adoption decree, legally the parent of the child being adopted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(26): "Prospective adoptive parent" means an individual who seeks to adopt an adoptee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(27): "Relative" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(27)(a): an adult who is a grandparent, great grandparent, aunt, great aunt, uncle, great uncle, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepparent, first cousin, stepsibling, sibling of a child, or first cousin of a child's parent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(27)(b): in the case of a child defined as an "Indian child" under the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Sec. 1903, an "extended family member" as defined by that statute.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(28): "Unmarried biological father" means a man who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(28)(a): is the biological father of a child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-103(28)(b): was not married to the biological mother of the child described in Subsection (28)(a) at the time of the child's conception or birth.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(1): Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration; 78A-6-103; 78A-6-350 Notwithstanding Title 78B, Chapter 3a, Venue for Civil Actions, a person shall bring an adoption proceeding in a court with jurisdiction under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(1)(a): in the county where the prospective adoptive parent resides;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(1)(b): if the prospective adoptive parent is not a resident of this state, in the county where:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(1)(b)(iii): a parent of the proposed adoptee resides on the day on which the petition is filed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(1)(c): 78A-6-103; 78A-6-350 if the adoption proceeding is brought in the juvenile court as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(2): All orders, decrees, agreements, and notices in an adoption proceeding shall be filed with the clerk of the court where the adoption proceeding is commenced under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(3): A petition for adoption:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(3)(a): may be filed before the birth of a child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(3)(b): may be filed before or after the adoptee is placed in the home of the petitioner for the purpose of adoption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(3)(c): shall be filed no later than 30 days after the day on which the adoptee is placed in the home of the petitioners for the purpose of adoption, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(3)(c)(i): the time for filing has been extended by the court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(3)(c)(ii): the adoption is arranged by a child-placing agency in which case the agency may extend the filing time.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(4)(b)(i): a prospective adoptive parent; or

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(5): Service of notice described in Subsection (6) shall vest the court with jurisdiction over the person served in the same manner and to the same extent as if the person served was served personally within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(6): In the case of service outside the state, service completed not less than five days before the time set in the notice for appearance of the person served is sufficient to confer jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-105(7): Computation of periods of time not otherwise set forth in this section shall be made in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106 Responsibility for own actions -- Fraud or misrepresentation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(1): Each parent of a child conceived or born outside of marriage is responsible for his or her own actions and is not excused from strict compliance with the provisions of this  chapter based upon any action, statement, or omission of the other parent or third parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(2): 78B-6-133 Any person injured by fraudulent representations or actions in connection with an adoption is entitled to pursue civil or criminal penalties in accordance with existing law.  A fraudulent representation is not a defense to strict compliance with the requirements of this chapter and is not a basis for dismissal of a petition for adoption, vacation of an adoption decree, or an automatic grant of custody to the offended party.  Custody determinations shall be based on the best interests of the child, in accordance with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3): 78B-6-134(3) A child-placing agency and the employees of a child-placing agency may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3)(a): employ any device, scheme, or artifice to defraud;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3)(b): engage in any act, practice, or course of business that operates or would operate as a fraud or deceit upon any person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3)(c): materially and intentionally misrepresent facts or information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3)(d): 78B-6-134(3) request or require a prospective adoptive parent to grant, as a condition of or in connection with entering into an agreement with a child-placing agency, a release of either the prospective adoptive parent's claims or the adoptive child's claims against the child-placing agency regarding any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3)(d)(i): criminal misconduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3)(d)(ii): ethical violations, as established by the Office of Licensing's administrative rules;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3)(d)(iii): bad faith;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-106(3)(d)(iv): intentional torts;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-108 Alien child -- Evidence of lawful admission to United States required.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-108(1): As used in this section, "alien child" means a child under 16 years of age who is not considered a citizen or national of the United States by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-108(2): Any person adopting an alien child shall file with the petition for adoption written evidence from the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service that the child was inspected and:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-108(2)(a): admitted into the United States for permanent residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-108(2)(b): admitted into the United States temporarily in one of the lawful nonimmigrant categories specified in 8 U.S.C. Section 1101(a)(15); or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-108(2)(c): paroled into the United States pursuant to 8 U.S.C. Section 1182(d)(5).

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1 Prebirth notice to presumed father of intent to place a child for adoption.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(1): As used in this section, "birth father" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(1)(a): a potential biological father; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(1)(b): an unmarried biological father.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(2): Before the birth of a child, the following individuals may notify a birth father of the child that the mother of the child is considering an adoptive placement for the child:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(2)(a): the child's mother;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(2)(b): a licensed child-placing agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(2)(c): an attorney representing a prospective adoptive parent of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(2)(d): an attorney representing the mother of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(3): (2) Providing a birth father with notice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(4): (2); (4)(c) The notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(4)(a): the mother's intent to place the child for adoption;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(4)(b): that the mother has named the person receiving this notice as a potential birth father of her child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(4)(c): the requirements to contest the adoption, including taking the following steps within 30 days after the day on which the notice is served:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.1(4)(c)(i): initiating proceedings to establish or assert paternity in a district court of Utah within 30 days after the day on which notice is served, including filing an affidavit stating:
