Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5 Out-of-state birth mothers and adoptive parents -- Declaration regarding potential birth fathers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The procedural and substantive requirements of this section shall be required only to the extent that they do not exceed the requirements of the state of conception or the birth mother's state of residence.Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(1): (1)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(1)(a): (1)(c) For a child who is six months of age or less at the time the child is placed with prospective adoptive parents, the birth mother shall sign, and the adoptive parents shall file with the court, a declaration regarding each potential birth father, in accordance with this section, before or at the time a petition for adoption is filed with the court, if, at any point during the time period beginning at the conception of the child and ending at the time the mother executes consent to adoption or relinquishment of the child for adoption, neither the birth mother nor at least one of the adoptive parents has resided in the state for 90 total days or more, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(1)(b): The child-placing agency or prospective adoptive parents shall search the putative father registry of each state where the birth mother believes the child may have been conceived and each state where the birth mother lived during her pregnancy, if the state has a putative father registry, to determine whether a potential birth father registered with the state's putative father registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(1)(c): In determining whether the 90-day requirement is satisfied, the following apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(1)(c)(i): the 90 days are not required to be consecutive;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(1)(c)(ii): no absence from the state may be for more than seven consecutive days;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(1)(c)(iii): any day on which the individual is absent from the state does not count toward the total 90-day period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(1)(c)(iv): the 90-day period begins and ends during a period that is no more than 120 consecutive days.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-110.5(2): (1); (1)(b) The declaration filed under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-111 Criminal sexual offenses.
---------------------------------------------------------
An unmarried biological father is not entitled to notice of an adoption proceeding, nor is the consent of an unmarried biological father required in connection with an adoption proceeding, in cases where it is shown that the child who is the subject of the proceeding was conceived as a result of conduct that constitutes a sexual offense under

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-114 Adoption by married persons -- Consent.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-114(1): A married man who is not lawfully separated from his wife may not adopt a child without the consent of his wife, if his wife is capable of giving consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-114(2): A married woman who is not lawfully separated from her husband may not adopt a child without his consent, if he is capable of giving his consent.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115 Who may adopt -- Adoption of adult.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1): As used in this section, "vulnerable adult" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1)(a): an individual who is 65 years old or older; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1)(b): an adult who is 18 years old or older, and who has a mental or physical impairment that substantially affects that adult's ability to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1)(b)(i): provide personal protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1)(b)(ii): provide necessities such as food, shelter, clothing, or medical or other health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1)(b)(iii): obtain services necessary for health, safety, or welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1)(b)(iv): carry out the activities of daily living;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1)(b)(v): manage the adult's own resources; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-115(1)(b)(vi): comprehend the nature and consequences of remaining in a situation of abuse, neglect, or exploitation.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-117(6)(b)(iv)(A): the child's age;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-117(6)(b)(iv)(B): the child's gender;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-117(6)(b)(iv)(C): the child's development;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-117(6)(b)(iv)(G): any other relevant information;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-117(6)(b)(v): the individual can provide evidence of all of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-117(6)(b)(v)(A): the relationship with the child is of long duration;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-117(6)(b)(v)(B): that an emotional bond exists with the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-117(6)(b)(v)(C): that adoption by the individual who has committed the disqualifying offense ensures the best interests of the child are met; and

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-118 Relative ages.
----------------------------------------------
A person adopting a child must be at least 10 years older than the child adopted, unless the petitioners for adoption are a married couple, one of which is at least 10 years older than the child.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119 Counseling for parents.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(1): Subject to Subsection (2)(a), before relinquishing a child to a child-placing agency, or consenting to the adoption of a child, a parent of the child has the right to participate in, or elect to participate in, counseling:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(1)(a): by a licensed counselor or an adoption service provider selected by the parent participating in the counseling;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(1)(b): for up to three sessions of at least 50 minutes per session completed prior to relinquishing a child or within three months following the relinquishment of a child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(1)(c): subject to Subsection (2)(b), at the expense of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(1)(c)(i): child-placing agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(1)(c)(ii): prospective adoptive parents.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(2)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (1), a parent who has the right to participate in the counseling described in this section may waive that right.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(2)(b): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(c), the total amount required to be paid by a child-placing agency or the prospective adoptive parents for the counseling described in Subsection (1) may not exceed $400, unless an agreement for a greater amount is signed by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(2)(b)(i): the parent who receives the counseling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(2)(b)(ii): the child-placing agency or prospective adoptive parents.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(3): Before a parent relinquishes a child to a child-placing agency, or consents to the adoption of a child, the parent shall be informed of the right described in Subsection (1) by the:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(3)(a): child-placing agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(3)(b): prospective adoptive parents; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(3)(c): representative of a person described in Subsection (3)(a) or (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(4): If the parent who is entitled to the counseling as described in Subsection (1) elects to attend one or more counseling sessions following the relinquishment of a child:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(4)(a): the parent of the child shall inform the child-placing agency or prospective adoptive parents of this election prior to relinquishing the child to a child-placing agency or consenting to the adoption of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(4)(b): the parent of the child and the child-placing agency or attorney representing a prospective adoptive parent of the child shall enter into an agreement to pay for the counseling in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(a): Subject to Subsections (3)(b) and (c), before the day on which a final decree of adoption is entered, a statement shall be filed with the court that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(a)(i): is signed by each parent who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(a)(i)(A): relinquishes the parent's parental rights; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(a)(i)(B): consents to the adoption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(a)(ii): states that, before the parent took the action described in Subsection (5)(a)(i)(A) or (B), the parent was advised of the parent's right to participate in the counseling described in this section at the expense of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(a)(ii)(A): child-placing agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(a)(ii)(B): prospective adoptive parents.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(b): The statement described in Subsection (5)(a) may be included in the document that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(b)(i): relinquishes the parent's parental rights; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(b)(ii): consents to the adoption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(c): Failure by a person to give the notice described in Subsection (3), or pay for the counseling described in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(c)(i): shall not constitute grounds for invalidating a:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(c)(i)(A): relinquishment of parental rights; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(c)(i)(B): consent to adoption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(c)(ii): shall give rise to a cause of action for the recovery of damages suffered, if any, by the parent or guardian who took the action described in Subsection (5)(c)(i)(A) or (B) against the person required to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(c)(ii)(A): give the notice described in Subsection (3); or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-119(5)(c)(ii)(B): pay for the counseling described in this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1 Implied consent.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(1)(a): "Abandonment" means failure of a father, with reasonable knowledge of the pregnancy, to offer and provide financial and emotional support to the birth mother for a period of six months before the day on which the adoptee is born.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(1)(b): "Emotional support" means a pattern of statements or actions that indicate to a reasonable person that a father intends to provide for the physical and emotional well-being of an unborn child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(2)(a): A court may not determine that a father abandoned the birth mother if the father failed to provide financial or emotional support because the birth mother refused to accept support.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(2)(b): A court may not find that a father failed to provide emotional support if the father's failure was due to impossibility of performance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(3): 78B-6-120(1); 78B-6-110(6); 78B-6-112 Consent or relinquishment, as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(3)(a): abandonment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(3)(b): leaving the adoptee with a third party, without providing the third party with the parent's identification, for 30 consecutive days;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(3)(c): knowingly leaving the adoptee with another person, without providing for support, communicating, or otherwise maintaining a substantial relationship with the adoptee, for six consecutive months; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-120.1(3)(d): 78B-6-110(6); 78B-6-112 receiving notification of a pending adoption proceeding under Subsection

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-121(1): 78B-6-122 Except as provided in Subsections (2)(a) and

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-121.5 Compact for Interstate Sharing of Putative Father Registry Information -- Severability clause.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This compact enables the sharing of putative father registry information collected by a state that is a party to the compact with all other states that are parties to the compact.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122 Qualifying circumstance.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1): 78B-6-121; 78B-6-121
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(a): For purposes of this section, "qualifying circumstance" means that, at any point during the time period beginning at the conception of the child and ending at the time the mother executed a consent to adoption or relinquishment of the child for adoption:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(a)(i): the child or the child's mother resided on a permanent basis, or a temporary basis of no less than 30 consecutive days, in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(a)(ii): the mother intended to give birth to the child in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(a)(iii): the child was born in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(a)(iv): the mother intended to execute a consent to adoption or relinquishment of the child for adoption:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(a)(iv)(A): in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(a)(iv)(B): under the laws of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b): For purposes of Subsection (1)(c)(i)(C) only, when determining whether an unmarried biological father has demonstrated a full commitment to his parental responsibilities, a court shall consider the totality of the circumstances, including, if applicable:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(i): efforts he has taken to discover the location of the child or the child's mother;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(ii): whether he has expressed and demonstrated an interest in taking responsibility for the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(iii): whether, and to what extent, he has developed, or attempted to develop, a relationship with the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(iv): whether he offered to provide and, unless the offer was rejected, did provide, financial support for the child or the child's mother;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(v): whether, and to what extent, he has communicated, or attempted to communicate, with the child or the child's mother;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(vi): whether he has timely filed legal proceedings to establish his paternity of, and take responsibility for, the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(vii): whether he has timely filed a notice with a public official or agency relating to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(vii)(A): his paternity of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(vii)(B): legal proceedings to establish his paternity of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(b)(viii): other evidence that shows whether he has demonstrated a full commitment to his parental responsibilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c): 78B-6-121; 78B-6-121 Notwithstanding the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(i)(A): the unmarried biological father did not know, and through the exercise of reasonable diligence could not have known, before the time the mother executed a consent to adoption or relinquishment of the child for adoption, that a qualifying circumstance existed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(i)(B): before the mother executed a consent to adoption or relinquishment of the child for adoption, the unmarried biological father fully complied with the requirements to establish parental rights and duties in the child, and to preserve the right to notice of a proceeding in connection with the adoption of the child, imposed by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(i)(B)(I): the last state where the unmarried biological father knew, or through the exercise of reasonable diligence should have known, that the mother resided in before the mother executed the consent to adoption or relinquishment of the child for adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(i)(B)(II): the state where the child was conceived; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(i)(C): the unmarried biological father has demonstrated, based on the totality of the circumstances, a full commitment to his parental responsibilities, as described in Subsection (1)(b); or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(ii): 78B-6-121
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(ii)(A): the unmarried biological father knew, or through the exercise of reasonable diligence should have known, before the time the mother executed a consent to adoption or relinquishment of the child for adoption, that a qualifying circumstance existed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(ii)(B): 78B-6-121 the unmarried biological father complied with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(ii)(B)(I): 20 days after the day that the unmarried biological father knew, or through the exercise of reasonable diligence should have known, that a qualifying circumstance existed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(1)(c)(ii)(B)(II): the time that the mother executed a consent to adoption or relinquishment of the child for adoption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(2): 78B-6-121 An unmarried biological father who does not fully and strictly comply with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(2)(a): notice of any judicial proceeding in connection with the adoption of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122(2)(b): consent, or refuse to consent, to the adoption of the child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122.5 Effect of out-of-state paternity adjudication, declaration, or acknowledgment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless a person who is an unmarried biological father has fully and strictly complied with the requirements of SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122.5(1): only has the effect of establishing that the person is an unmarried biological father of the child to whom the order, declaration, or acknowledgment relates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122.5(2): does not entitle the person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122.5(2)(a): notice of any judicial proceeding related to the adoption of the child;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-122.5(2)(c): the right to custody of, control over, or visitation with the child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-123 Power of a minor to consent or relinquish.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-123(1): A minor parent has the power to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-123(1)(a): consent to the adoption of the minor's child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-123(1)(b): relinquish the minor's control or custody of the child for adoption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-123(2): (1) The consent or relinquishment described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-123(3): A minor parent, having executed a consent or relinquishment, cannot revoke that consent upon reaching the age of majority or otherwise becoming emancipated.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-124 Persons who may take consents and relinquishments.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-125 Time period prior to birth mother's consent.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-125(1): A birth mother may not consent to the adoption of her child or relinquish control or custody of her child until at least 24 hours after the birth of her child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-125(2): 78B-6-120; 78B-6-121 The consent or relinquishment of any other person as required by Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-126 When consent or relinquishment effective.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
A consent or relinquishment is effective when it is signed and may not be revoked.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-127 Parents whose rights have been terminated.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Neither notice nor consent to adoption or relinquishment for adoption is required from a parent whose rights with regard to an adoptee have been terminated by a court.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133 Contested adoptions -- Rights of parties -- Determination of custody.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(1): 78B-6-120 If a person whose consent for an adoption is required pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(2)(a): If there are proper grounds to terminate the person's parental rights, the court shall order that the person's rights be terminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(2)(b): If there are not proper grounds to terminate the person's parental rights, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(2)(b)(i): dismiss the adoption petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(2)(b)(ii): conduct an evidentiary hearing to determine who should have custody of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(2)(b)(iii): award custody of the child in accordance with the child's best interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(2)(c): Termination of a person's parental rights does not terminate the right of a relative of the parent to seek adoption of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(3): Evidence considered at the custody hearing may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(3)(a): evidence of psychological or emotional bonds that the child has formed with a third person, including the prospective adoptive parent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(3)(b): any detriment that a change in custody may cause the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(4): If the court dismisses the adoption petition, the fact that a person relinquished a child for adoption or consented to the adoption may not be considered as evidence in a custody proceeding described in this section, or in any subsequent custody proceeding, that it is not in the child's best interest for custody to be awarded to such person or that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(4)(a): the person is unfit or incompetent to be a parent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(4)(b): the person has neglected or abandoned the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(4)(c): the person is not interested in having custody of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(4)(d): the person has forfeited the person's parental presumption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(5): Any custody order entered pursuant to this section may also:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(5)(a): include provisions for:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(5)(a)(i): parent-time; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(5)(a)(ii): visitation by an interested third party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(5)(b): provide for the financial support of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(6): 78B-6-120
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(6)(a): 78B-6-120 If a person or entity whose consent is required for an adoption under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(6)(b): The court may also finalize the adoption if doing so is in the best interest of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(a): A person may not contest an adoption after the final decree of adoption is entered, if that person:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(a)(i): was a party to the adoption proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(a)(ii): was served with notice of the adoption proceeding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(a)(iii): executed a consent to the adoption or relinquishment for adoption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(b): No person may contest an adoption after one year from the day on which the final decree of adoption is entered.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(c): The limitations on contesting an adoption action, described in this Subsection (7), apply to all attempts to contest an adoption:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(c)(i): regardless of whether the adoption is contested directly or collaterally; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(c)(ii): regardless of the basis for contesting the adoption, including claims of fraud, duress, undue influence, lack of capacity or competency, mistake of law or fact, or lack of jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(d): The limitations on contesting an adoption action, described in this Subsection (7), do not prohibit a timely appeal of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(d)(i): a final decree of adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(7)(d)(ii): a decision in an action challenging an adoption, if the action was brought within the time limitations described in Subsections (7)(a) and (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8): A court that has jurisdiction over a child for whom more than one petition for adoption is filed shall grant a hearing only under the following circumstances:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a): to a petitioner:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(i): with whom the child is placed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(ii): who has custody or guardianship of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(iii): who has filed a written statement with the court within eight months after the day on which the shelter hearing is held:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(iii)(A): requesting immediate placement of the child with the petitioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(iii)(B): expressing the petitioner's intention of adopting the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(iv): who is a relative with whom the child has a significant and substantial relationship and who was unaware, within the first eight months after the day on which the shelter hearing is held, of the child's removal from the child's parent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(v): who is a relative with whom the child has a significant and substantial relationship and, in a case where the child is not placed with a relative or is placed with a relative that is unable or unwilling to adopt the child:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(v)(A): was actively involved in the child's child welfare case with the division or the juvenile court while the child's parent engaged in reunification services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(a)(v)(B): filed a written statement with the court that includes the information described in Subsections (8)(a)(iii)(A) and (B) within 30 days after the day on which the court terminated reunification services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(b): if the child:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(b)(i): has been in the current placement for less than 180 days before the day on which the petitioner files the petition for adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(8)(b)(ii): is placed with, or is in the custody or guardianship of, an individual who previously informed the division or the court that the individual is unwilling or unable to adopt the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9)(a): If the court grants a hearing on more than one petition for adoption, there is a rebuttable presumption that it is in the best interest of a child to be placed for adoption with a petitioner:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9)(a)(i): who has fulfilled the requirements described in Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 1, Utah Adoption Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9)(a)(ii)(A): with whom the child has continuously resided for six months;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9)(a)(ii)(B): who has filed a written statement with the court within eight months after the day on which the shelter hearing is held, as described in Subsection (8)(a)(iii); or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9)(a)(ii)(C): who is a relative described in Subsection (8)(a)(iv).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9)(b): The court may consider other factors relevant to the best interest of the child to determine whether the presumption is rebutted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(9)(c): The court shall weigh the best interest of the child uniformly between petitioners if more than one petitioner satisfies a rebuttable presumption condition described in Subsection (9)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(10): Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the division or the child's guardian ad litem from appearing or participating in any proceeding for a petition for adoption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-133(11): The division shall use best efforts to provide a known relative with timely information relating to the relative's rights or duties under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134 Custody pending final decree.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(1)(a): A licensed child-placing agency, or a petitioner if the petition for adoption is filed before a child's birth, may seek an order establishing that the agency or petitioner shall have temporary custody of the child from the time of birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(1)(b): (1)(a) The court shall grant an order for temporary custody under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(1)(b)(i): the birth mother or both birth parents consent to the order;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(1)(b)(ii): the agency or petitioner is willing and able to take custody of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(1)(b)(iii): an order will be in the best interest of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(1)(c): The court shall vacate an order if, prior to the child's birth, the birth mother or birth parents withdraw their consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(2): Except as otherwise provided by the court, once a petitioner has received the adoptee into his home and a petition for adoption has been filed, the petitioner is entitled to the custody and control of the adoptee and is responsible for the care, maintenance, and support of the adoptee, including any necessary medical or surgical treatment, pending further order of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-134(3): Once a child has been placed with, relinquished to, or ordered into the custody of a child-placing agency for purposes of adoption, the agency shall have custody and control of the child and is responsible for his care, maintenance, and support.  The agency may delegate the responsibility for care, maintenance, and support, including any necessary medical or surgical treatment, to the petitioner once the petitioner has received the child into his home.  However, until the final decree of adoption is entered by the court, the agency has the right to the custody and control of the child.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5 Timing of entry of final decree of adoption -- Posthumous adoption.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(1): Except as provided in Subsection (2), a final decree of adoption may not be entered until the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(1)(a): when the child has lived in the home of the prospective adoptive parent for three months; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(1)(b): when the child has been placed for adoption with the prospective adoptive parent for three months.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(2)(a): If the prospective adoptive parent is the spouse of the preexisting parent, a final decree of adoption may not be entered until the child has lived in the home of that prospective adoptive parent for six months, unless, based on a finding of good cause, the court orders that the final decree of adoption may be entered at an earlier time.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(2)(b): The court may, based on a finding of good cause, order that the final decree of adoption be entered at a later time than described in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(3): The court has authority to enter a final decree of adoption after a child's death upon the request of the prospective adoptive parent or parents of the child if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(3)(a): the child dies during the time that the child is placed in the home of a prospective adoptive parent or parents for the purpose of adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(3)(b): the prospective adoptive parent is the spouse of a preexisting parent of the child and the child lived with the prospective adoptive parent before the child's death.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4): The court may enter a final decree of adoption declaring that a child is adopted by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4)(a): both a deceased and a surviving adoptive parent if after the child is placed in the home of the child's prospective adoptive parents:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4)(a)(i): one of the prospective adoptive parents dies;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4)(a)(ii): the surviving prospective adoptive parent requests that the court enter the decree; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4)(a)(iii): the decree is entered after the child has lived in the home of the surviving prospective adoptive parent for at least three months; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4)(b): a spouse of a preexisting parent if after the child has lived with the spouse of the preexisting parent:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4)(b)(i): the preexisting parent, or the spouse of the preexisting parent, dies;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4)(b)(ii): the preexisting parent, or the spouse of the preexisting parent, requests that the court enter the decree; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(4)(b)(iii): the child has lived in the same home as the spouse of the preexisting parent for at least six months.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(5): Upon request of a surviving preexisting parent, or a surviving parent for whom adoption of a child has been finalized, the court may enter a final decree of adoption declaring that a child is adopted by a deceased adoptive parent who was the spouse of the surviving parent at the time of the prospective adoptive parent's death.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(6): The court may enter a final decree of adoption declaring that a child is adopted by both deceased prospective adoptive parents if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(6)(a): both of the prospective adoptive parents die after the child is placed in the prospective adoptive parents' home; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(6)(b): it is in the best interests of the child to enter the decree.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-136.5(7): Nothing in this section shall be construed to grant any rights to the preexisting parents of a child to assert any interest in the child during the three-month or six-month periods described in this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-137 Decree of adoption -- Best interest of child -- Legislative findings.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court shall examine each person appearing before it in accordance with this chapter, separately, and, if satisfied that the interests of the child will be promoted by the adoption, it shall enter a final decree of adoption declaring that the child is adopted by the adoptive parent or parents and shall be regarded and treated in all respects as the child of the adoptive parent or parents.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144 Mutual-consent, voluntary adoption registry -- Procedures -- Fees.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(1): The office shall establish a mutual-consent, voluntary adoption registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(1)(a): An adult adoptee or a birth parent of an adult adoptee, upon presentation of positive identification, may request identifying information from the office, in the form established by the office.  A court of competent jurisdiction or a child-placing agency may accept that request from the adult adoptee or birth parent, in the form provided by the office, and transfer that request to the office.  The adult adoptee or birth parent is responsible for notifying the office of any change in information contained in the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(1)(b): Except as otherwise provided in this part, the office may only release identifying information to an adult adoptee or birth parent when it receives requests from both the adoptee and the adoptee's birth parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(1)(c): After matching the request of an adult adoptee with that of at least one of the adoptee's birth parents, the office shall notify both the adult adoptee and the birth parent that the requests have been matched, and disclose the identifying information to those parties.  However, if that adult adoptee has a sibling of the same birth parent who is under the age of 18 years, and who was raised in the same family setting as the adult adoptee, the office may not disclose the requested identifying information to that adult adoptee or the adoptee's birth parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2): (2)(d)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(a): Adult adoptees and adult siblings of adult adoptees, upon presentation of positive identification, may request identifying information from the office, in the form established by the office.  A court of competent jurisdiction or a child-placing agency may accept that request from the adult adoptee or adult sibling, in the form provided by the office, and transfer that request to the office.  The adult adoptee or adult sibling is responsible for notifying the office of any change in information contained in the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(b): The office may only release identifying information to an adult adoptee or adult sibling when it receives requests from both the adult adoptee and the adult adoptee's adult sibling.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(c): After matching the request of an adult adoptee with that of the adoptee's adult sibling, if the office determines that the office has sufficient information to make that match, the office shall notify both the adult adoptee and the adult sibling that the requests have been matched, and disclose the identifying information to those parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(d): (2)(d)(i) After receiving a request for information from an adult adoptee and a birth parent under this section, the office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(d)(i): search the office's vital records for the adult adoptee's birth parent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(d)(ii): (2)(d)(i) if the search described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(e): The office shall attempt to notify an individual who requests information under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(e)(i): of the results of the initial search for a match; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(2)(e)(ii): if the initial search does not produce a match, that the office will keep the request on file and will attempt to notify the individual in the event of a match.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-144(3): Information registered with the office under this section is available only to a registered adult adoptee and the adoptee's registered birth parent or registered adult sibling, under the terms of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-145 Restrictions on disclosure of information -- Violations -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-145(1): Information maintained or filed with the office under this chapter may not be disclosed except as provided by this chapter, or pursuant to a court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-145(2): Any person who discloses information obtained from the office's voluntary adoption registry in violation of this part, or knowingly allows that information to be disclosed in violation of this chapter is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146 Postadoption contact agreements.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(1)(a): "Postadoption contact agreement" means a document, agreed upon prior to the finalization of an adoption of a child in the custody of the division, that outlines the relationship between an adoptive parent, birth parent, or other birth relative, and an adopted child after the finalization of adoption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(1)(b): "Other birth relative" means a grandparent, stepparent, sibling, stepsibling, aunt, or uncle of the prospective adoptive child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(2)(a): Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, if a child in the custody of the division is placed for adoption, the prospective adoptive parent and birth parent, or other birth relative, may enter into a postadoption contact agreement as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(2)(b): A birth parent is not required to be a party to a postadoption contact agreement in order to permit an open adoption agreement between a prospective adoptive parent and another birth relative of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(3): In order to be legally enforceable, a postadoption contact agreement shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(3)(a): approved by the court before the finalization of the adoption, with the court making a specific finding that the agreement is in the best interest of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(3)(b): signed by each party claiming a right or obligation in the agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(3)(c): if the adopted child is 12 years old or older, approved by the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4): (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(iii) A postadoption contact agreement shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4)(a): (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(iii) describe:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4)(a)(i): visits, if any, that shall take place between the birth parent, other birth relative, adoptive parent, and adopted child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4)(a)(ii): the degree of supervision, if any, that shall be required during a visit between a birth parent, other birth relative, and adopted child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4)(a)(iii): the information, if any, that shall be provided to a birth parent, or other birth relative, about the adopted child and how often that information shall be provided;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4)(a)(iv): (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(iii) the grounds, if any, on which the adoptive parent may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4)(a)(iv)(A): (4)(a)(i) decline to permit visits, described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4)(a)(iv)(B): (4)(a)(iii) cease providing the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(4)(b): state that following the adoption, the court shall presume that the adoptive parent's judgment about the best interest of the child is correct in any action seeking to enforce, modify, or terminate the agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(5): A postadoption contact agreement may not limit the adoptive parent's ability to move out of state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(6): A postadoption contact agreement may only be modified with the consent of the adoptive parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(7): (7)(a); (7)(a) In an action seeking enforcement of a postadoption contact agreement:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(7)(a): an adoptive parent's judgment about the best interest of the child is entitled to a presumption of correctness;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(7)(b): (7)(a) if the party seeking to enforce the postadoption contact agreement successfully rebuts the presumption described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(7)(b)(i): the parties performed the duties outlined in the open adoption agreement in good faith;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(7)(b)(ii): there is a reasonable alternative that fulfills the spirit of the open adoption agreement without ordering mandatory compliance with the open adoption agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(7)(b)(iii): enforcement of the open adoption agreement is in the best interest of the adopted child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(7)(c): (7)(a) the court shall order the parties to attend mediation, if the presumption in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(8): An open adoption agreement that has been found not to be in the best interest of the adopted child shall not be enforced.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(9): Violation of an open adoption agreement is not grounds:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(9)(a): to set aside an adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(9)(b): for an award of money damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(10): Nothing in this section shall be construed to mean that an open adoption agreement is required before an adoption may be finalized.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(11): Refusal or failure to agree to a postadoption contact agreement is not admissible in any adoption proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-146(12): The court that approves a postadoption contact agreement retains jurisdiction over modification, termination, and enforcement of an approved postadoption contact agreement.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-201 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Alternative Dispute Resolution Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(1): "ADR" means alternative dispute resolution and includes arbitration, mediation, and other means of dispute resolution, other than court trial, authorized by the Judicial Council under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(2): "ADR organization" means an organization which provides training for ADR providers or offers other ADR services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(3): "ADR provider" means a neutral person who conducts an ADR procedure.  An arbitrator, mediator, and early neutral evaluator are ADR providers.  An ADR provider may be an employee of the court or an independent contractor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(4): 78B-6-206 "Arbitration" means a private hearing before a neutral or panel of neutrals who hear the evidence, consider the contentions of the parties, and enter a written award to resolve the issues presented pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(5): "Award" as used in connection with arbitration includes monetary or equitable relief and may include damages, interest, costs, and attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(6): "Civil action" means an action in which a party seeks monetary or equitable relief at common law or pursuant to statute.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(7): "Early neutral evaluation" means a confidential meeting with a neutral expert to identify the issues in a dispute, explore settlement, and assess the merits of the claims.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(8): "Mediation" means a private forum in which one or more impartial persons facilitate communication between parties to a civil action to promote a mutually acceptable resolution or settlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-202(9): "Summary jury trial" means a summary presentation of a case to a jury which results in a nonbinding verdict.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-203 Purpose and findings.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-203(1): The purpose of this part is to offer an alternative or supplement to the formal processes associated with a court trial and to promote the efficient and effective operation of the courts of this state by authorizing and encouraging the use of alternative methods of dispute resolution to secure the just, speedy, and inexpensive determination of civil actions filed in the courts of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-203(2): 80-3-201; 80-4-201 The Legislature finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-203(2)(a): the use of alternative methods of dispute resolution authorized by this part will secure the purposes of Article I, Section 11, Utah Constitution, by providing supplemental or complementary means for the just, speedy, and inexpensive resolution of disputes;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-203(2)(b): preservation of the confidentiality of ADR procedures will significantly aid the successful resolution of civil actions in a just, speedy, and inexpensive manner;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-203(2)(c): ADR procedures will reduce the need for judicial resources and the time and expense of the parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-203(2)(d): 80-3-201; 80-4-201 mediation has, in pilot programs, resulted in the just and equitable settlement of petitions for the protection of children under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-203(2)(e): the purpose of this part will be promoted by authorizing the Judicial Council to establish rules to promote the use of ADR procedures by the courts of this state as an alternative or supplement to court trial.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204 Dispute Resolution Programs -- Director -- Duties -- Report.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(1): Within the Administrative Office of the Courts, there shall be a director of Dispute Resolution Programs, appointed by the state court administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(2): The director shall be an employee of the Administrative Office of the Courts and shall be responsible for the administration of all court-annexed Dispute Resolution Programs.  The director shall have duties, powers, and responsibilities as the Judicial Council may determine.  The qualifications for employment of the director shall be based on training and experience in the management, principles, and purposes of alternative dispute resolution procedures.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(3): In order to implement the purposes of this part, the Administrative Office of the Courts may employ or contract with ADR providers or ADR organizations on a case-by-case basis, on a service basis, or on a program basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(4): (4)(a); Title 63G, Chapter 22, State Training and Certification Requirements The Administrative Office of the Courts shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(4)(a): establish programs for training ADR providers and orienting attorneys and their clients to ADR programs and procedures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(4)(b): (4)(a); Title 63G, Chapter 22, State Training and Certification Requirements ensure that any training described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(5): ADR providers and organizations are subject to the rules and fees set by the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(6): An ADR provider is immune from all liability when conducting proceedings under the rules of the Judicial Council and the provisions of this part, except for wrongful disclosure of confidential information, to the same extent as a judge of the courts in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(a): The director shall report annually to the Supreme Court, the Judicial Council, the governor, and the Utah State Bar on the operation of the Dispute Resolution Programs.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(b): The director shall provide the report to the Judiciary Interim Committee, if requested by the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(c): Copies of the report shall be available to the public at the Administrative Office of the Courts.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(d): The report shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(d)(i): identification of participating judicial districts and the methods of alternative dispute resolution that are available in those districts;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(d)(ii): the number and types of disputes received;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(d)(iii): the methods of alternative dispute resolution to which the disputes were referred;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(d)(iv): the course of the referral;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(d)(v): the status of cases referred to alternative dispute resolution or the disposition of these disputes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(d)(vi): any problems encountered in the administration of the program and the recommendations of the director as to the continuation or modification of any program.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-204(7)(e): Nothing may be included in a report which would impair the privacy or confidentiality of any specific ADR proceeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205 Judicial Council rules for ADR procedures.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(1): To promote the use of ADR procedures, the Judicial Council may by rule establish experimental and permanent ADR programs administered by the Administrative Office of the Courts under the supervision of the director of Dispute Resolution Programs.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(2): The rules of the Judicial Council shall be based upon the purposes and provisions of this part.  Any procedural and evidentiary rules adopted by the Supreme Court may not impinge on the constitutional rights of any parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3): 78B-11-124 The rules of the Judicial Council shall include provisions:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(a): to orient parties and their counsel to the ADR program, ADR procedures, and the rules of the Judicial Council;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(b): to identify types of civil actions that qualify for ADR procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(c): to refer to ADR procedures all or particular issues within a civil action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(d): to protect persons not parties to the civil action whose rights may be affected in the resolution of the dispute;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(e): to ensure that no party or its attorney is prejudiced for electing, in good faith, not to participate in an optional ADR procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(f): to exempt any case from the ADR program in which the objectives of ADR would not be realized;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(g): to create timetables to ensure that the ADR procedure is instituted and completed without undue delay or expense;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(h): to establish the qualifications of ADR providers for each form of ADR procedure including that formal education in any particular field may not, by itself, be either a prerequisite or sufficient qualification to serve as an ADR provider under the program authorized by this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(i): to govern the conduct of each type of ADR procedure, including the site at which the procedure is conducted;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(j): to establish the means for the selection of an ADR provider for each form of ADR procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(k): to determine the powers, duties, and responsibilities of the ADR provider for each form of ADR procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(l): to establish a code of ethics applicable to ADR providers with means for its enforcement;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(m): to protect and preserve the privacy and confidentiality of ADR procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(n): to protect and preserve the privacy rights of the persons attending the ADR procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(o): to permit waiver of all or part of fees assessed for referral of a case to the ADR program on a showing of indigency or other compelling reason;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(p): to authorize imposition of sanctions for failure of counsel or parties to participate in good faith in the ADR procedure assigned;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(q): to assess the fees to cover the cost of compensation for the services of the ADR provider and reimbursement for the provider's allowable, out-of-pocket expenses and disbursements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(3)(r): 78B-11-124 to allow vacation of an award by a court as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-205(4): The Judicial Council may, from time to time, limit the application of its ADR rules to particular judicial districts.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206 Minimum procedures for arbitration.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(1): An award in an arbitration proceeding shall be in writing and, at the discretion of the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, may state the reasons or otherwise explain the nature or amount of the award.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(2): The award shall be final and enforceable as any other judgment in a civil action, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(2)(a): within 30 days after the filing of the award with the clerk of the court any party files with the clerk of court a demand for a trial de novo upon which the case shall be returned to the trial calendar; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(2)(b): any party files with the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators and serves a copy on all other parties a written request to modify the award on the grounds:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(2)(b)(i): there is an evident miscalculation of figures or description of persons or property referred to in the award;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(2)(b)(ii): the award does not dispose of all the issues presented to the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators for resolution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(2)(b)(iii): the award purports to resolve issues not submitted for resolution in the arbitration process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(2)(c): The period for filing a demand for trial de novo is tolled until the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators have acted on the request to modify the award, which must be completed within 30 days of the filing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(3): The parties to an arbitration procedure may stipulate that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(3)(a): an award need not be filed with the court, except in those cases where the rights of third parties may be affected by the provisions of the award; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(3)(b): the case is dismissed in which the award was made.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(4): Title 78B, Chapter 11, Utah Uniform Arbitration Act
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(4)(a): Title 78B, Chapter 11, Utah Uniform Arbitration Act At any time the parties may enter into a written agreement for referral of the case or of issues in the case to arbitration pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-206(4)(b): The court may dismiss the case, or if less than all the issues are referred to arbitration, stay the case for a reasonable period for the parties to complete a private arbitration proceeding.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-207(1): A judge or court commissioner may refer to mediation any case for which the Judicial Council and Supreme Court have established a program or procedures. A party may file with the court an objection to the referral which may be granted for good cause.
