Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-851 Stipulation to expungement by parties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
All parties to an eviction may stipulate in a settlement agreement to the expungement of an eviction.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852 Automatic expungement of eviction.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852(1)(a): Without the filing of a petition, a court shall order expungement of all records of an eviction if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852(1)(a)(i): the entire case was dismissed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852(1)(a)(ii): there is no appeal pending for the case; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852(1)(a)(iii): at least three years have passed from the day on which the eviction was filed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852(1)(b): the parties to the eviction stipulated to expungement and have filed a stipulation with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852(2): (1) The court shall issue an order of expungement when the court determines that an eviction qualifies for automatic expungement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-852(3): This section applies to evictions filed on or after July 1, 2022.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-853(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-853(2)(a): A petitioner shall file a petition and provide notice to any other party to the eviction in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-853(2)(b): A petitioner shall bring a petition to expunge records of an eviction in the court that issued the order of restitution.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-901 Form of action -- Judgment -- Special execution.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-901(1): There is only one action for the recovery of any debt, or the enforcement of any right, secured solely by mortgage upon real estate and that action shall be in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-901(2): A judgment shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-901(2)(a): the amount due, with costs and disbursements;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-901(2)(b): an order for the sale of mortgaged property, or a portion of it to satisfy the amount and accruing costs;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-901(2)(c): direction to the sheriff to proceed and sell the property according to the provisions of law relating to sales on execution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-901(2)(d): a special execution or order of sale shall be issued for that purpose.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-902 Deficiency judgment -- Execution.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
If it appears that the proceeds of the sale are insufficient and a balance still remains due, the judgment shall be docketed by the clerk and execution may be issued for the balance as in other cases.  A general execution may not be issued until after the sale of the mortgaged property and the application of the amount realized to the preceding judgment.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-903 Necessary parties -- Unrecorded rights barred.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person holding a conveyance from or under the mortgagor or having a lien on the property, neither of which is properly documented or recorded in the proper office at the time of the commencement of the action, is not required to be made a party to the action.  The proceedings and any judgment rendered are conclusive against the party holding the unrecorded conveyance or lien as if the person had been made a party to the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-904 Sales -- Disposition of surplus money.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
If there is surplus money remaining after payment of the amount due on the mortgage, lien or encumbrance, with costs, the court may order the amount paid to the person entitled to it.  In the meantime the court may direct it to be deposited with the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-905 Sales -- When debt due in installments.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
If the debt for which the mortgage, lien, or encumbrance is held is not all due, then as soon as sufficient of the property has been sold to pay the amount due, with costs, the sale must cease.  As often as more becomes due on principal or interest, the court may, on motion, order more to be sold.  If the property cannot be sold in portions without injury to the parties, the entire parcel may be ordered sold and the entire debt and costs paid.  There shall be a rebate of interest where a rebate is proper.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-906 Right of redemption -- Sales by parcels -- Of land and water stock.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-906(1): Sales of real estate under judgments of foreclosure of mortgages and liens are subject to redemption as in case of sales under executions generally.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-906(2): In all cases where the judgment directs the sale of land, together with shares of corporate stock evidencing title to a water right used, intended to be used, or suitable for use, on the land, the court shall equitably apportion the water stock to the land.  If the court divides the land into individual parcels for sale, the water stock may also be divided and applied to each parcel.  The land and water stock in each parcel shall be sold together, and for the purpose of the sale shall be regarded as real estate and subject to redemption as previously specified.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-906(3): In all sales of real estate under foreclosure the court may determine the parcels and the order in which the parcels of property shall be sold.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-907 Restraining possessor from injuring property.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court or judge may upon a showing of good cause enjoin the party in possession of the property from doing any act to injure the property during the foreclosure of a mortgage on it, or after a sale on execution.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-908 Attorney fees.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-908(1): In all cases of foreclosure when an attorney's fee is claimed by the plaintiff, the amount shall be fixed by the court.  No other or greater amount shall be allowed or decreed than the sum which shall appear by the evidence to be actually charged by and to be paid to the attorney for the plaintiff.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-908(2): If it shall appear that there is an agreement or understanding to divide the fees between the plaintiff and his attorney, or between the attorney and any other person except an attorney associated with him in the cause, the defendant shall only be ordered to pay the amount to be retained by the attorney or attorneys.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-909 Environmental impairment to real property security interest -- Remedies of lender.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-909(1): 19-6-302; 19-5-102; 19-6-302 As used in this section:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1001 Right of action for waste -- Damages.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
If a guardian, tenant for life or years, joint tenant, or tenant in common, of real property commits waste on the property, any person aggrieved by the waste may bring an action against the person.  Judgment in the action may include treble damages.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1105 Tobacco smoke -- Legislative intent.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1105(1): The Legislature finds:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1105(1)(a): the federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has determined that environmental tobacco smoke is a Group A carcinogen, in the same category as other cancer-causing chemicals such as asbestos;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1105(1)(b): the EPA has determined that there is no acceptable level of exposure to Class A carcinogens; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1105(1)(c): the EPA has determined that exposure to environmental tobacco smoke also causes an increase in respiratory diseases and disorders among exposed persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1105(2): The Legislature finds that environmental tobacco smoke generated in a rental or condominium unit may drift into other units, exposing the occupants of those units to tobacco smoke, and that standard construction practices are not effective in preventing this drift of tobacco smoke.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1105(3): The Legislature further finds that persons who desire to not be exposed to drifting environmental tobacco smoke should be able to determine in advance of entering into a rental, lease, or purchase agreement whether the subject unit may be exposed to environmental tobacco smoke.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1106(2): 78B-6-1101(3); 78B-6-1101(3); (2)(c)(ii); (2)(c)(i) A cause of action for a nuisance under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1106(2)(a): the individual generating the tobacco smoke;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1106(2)(b): the renter or lessee who permits or fails to control the generation of tobacco smoke, in violation of the terms of the rental or lease agreement, on the premises he rents or leases; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1106(2)(c): 78B-6-1101(3); (2)(c)(ii); (2)(c)(i) the landlord, but only if:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1109 Abatement by eviction order -- Grounds.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
An order of abatement by eviction may issue only upon a showing by the applicant by a preponderance of the evidence that:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1109(1): the applicant will suffer irreparable harm unless the order of abatement by eviction issues;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1109(2): the threatened injury to the applicant outweighs whatever damage the proposed order of abatement by eviction may cause the party so ordered;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1109(3): the order of abatement by eviction, if issued, would not be adverse to the public interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1109(4): there is a substantial likelihood that the applicant will prevail on the merits of the underlying claim, or the case presents serious issues on the merits which should be the subject of further litigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1112 Security requirement -- Amount not a limitation -- Jurisdiction over surety.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1112(1): The court shall condition issuance of the order of abatement by eviction on the giving of security by the applicant, in such sum and form as the court determines proper, unless it appears that none of the parties will incur or suffer costs, attorney fees, or damage as the result of any wrongful order of abatement by eviction, or unless there exists some other substantial reason for dispensing with the requirement of security.  No such security shall be required of the United States, the State of Utah, or of an officer, agency, or subdivision of either; nor shall it be required when it is prohibited by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1112(3): A surety upon a bond or undertaking under this section submits to the jurisdiction of the court and irrevocably appoints the clerk of the court as agent upon whom any papers affecting the surety's liability on the bond or undertaking may be served.  The surety's liability may be enforced on motion without the necessity of an independent action.  The motion and such notice of the motion as the court prescribes may be served on the clerk of the court who shall immediately mail copies to the persons giving the security if their addresses are known.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1114 Award of costs and attorney fees.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1114(1): 78B-6-1107 The court may award costs, including the costs of investigation and discovery, and reasonable attorney fees, which are not compensated for pursuant to some other provision of law, to the prevailing party in any case in which a governmental agency, private citizen or citizens, corporation, partnership, or business seeks to abate the nuisance by eviction in or upon any building or place where the nuisance occurs as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1114(2): The court may award costs, including the costs of investigation and discovery, and reasonable attorney fees against a defendant landlord, owner, or designated agent only when the court finds that the defendant landlord, owner, or designated agent had actual notice of the nuisance action and willfully failed to take reasonable action within a reasonable time to abate the nuisance.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1115 Critical infrastructure materials operations -- Nuisance liability.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1115(1): Activities conducted in the normal and ordinary course of critical infrastructure materials operations or conducted in accordance with sound practices are presumed to be reasonable and not constitute a nuisance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1115(2): Critical infrastructure materials operations undertaken in conformity with federal, state, and local laws and regulations, including zoning ordinances, are presumed to be operating within sound critical infrastructure materials practices.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1201 Partition -- By cotenants of real property.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person who is a joint tenant or tenant in common with another of real property may bring an action to partition the property for the benefit of each tenant.  An action for partition may require the sale of the property if it appears that the partition cannot be made without prejudice to the owners.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1202 Complaint -- To set forth interests of all parties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1202(1): The interests of all persons in the property, whether the persons are known or unknown, shall be set forth in the complaint, specifically and particularly, as far as known to the plaintiff.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1202(2): If one or more of the parties, or the share or quantity of interest of any of the parties, is unknown to the plaintiff, uncertain or contingent, or the ownership of the inheritance depends upon an executory devise, or the remainder is a contingent remainder making the parties unknown, that fact must be set forth in the complaint.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1203 Parties -- Only holders of recorded rights necessary.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person who does not have a conveyance of, or claim a lien on, the property, or some part of it, is not required to be made a party to the action, unless the conveyance or lien has been properly recorded.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204 Lis pendens required.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(1): The plaintiff shall file a notice of the action with the recorders of all the counties in which the property is situated.  The notice shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(1)(a): a copy of such complaint; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(1)(b): a notice of the pendency of the action, containing:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(1)(b)(i): the names of all known parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(1)(b)(ii): the object of the action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(1)(b)(iii): a description of the property affected.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(2): Once the notice is filed, all persons having an interest in the property shall be considered to have notice of the pendency of the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(3): 38-1a-701; 38-10-106 This section does not apply if a plaintiff satisfies the requirements of a notice of pendency of an action required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1204(4): (1)(a) If a complaint described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1205 Summons -- To whom directed.
-------------------------------------------------------------
The summons shall be directed to:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1205(1): all joint tenants;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1205(2): tenants in common of all persons having any interest in, or recorded liens upon the property or any portion of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1205(3): any other person claiming any interest in the property.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1206 Service by publication.
--------------------------------------------------------
If a party having a share or interest is unknown, or any one of the known parties resides out of the state or cannot be found, the summons may be served upon them by publication in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1207 Answer must set forth interests claimed.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1207(1): All defendants shall set forth in their answers, fully and particularly, the origin, nature, and extent of their respective interests in the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1207(2): If a defendant claims a lien on the property by mortgage, judgment, or otherwise, the defendant shall state the original amount and date of the mortgage or judgment, and the amounts remaining unpaid.  The defendant shall also state whether the mortgage or judgment has been secured in any other way, and if secured, the extent and nature of the security.  If this information is not provided, the defendant shall be considered to have waived any rights to the lien.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1208 Right of all parties may be determined.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The rights of all parties may be put in issue, tried, and determined by the action.  If the court determines a sale of the premises is necessary, the title shall be ascertained to the satisfaction of the court before the judgment of sale can be made.  If service of the summons was made by publication, similar proof is required concerning the rights of absent or unknown parties before judgment is rendered.  If there are several unknown persons having an interest in the property, their rights may be considered together in the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1209 Partial partition allowed -- When.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1209(1): If the court determines that it is impracticable or highly inconvenient to make a complete partition among all the parties in interest, the court may first determine the shares or interests respectively held by the original cotenants as if they were the only parties to the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1209(2): (1) After the initial partition, the court may partition separately each portion allotted among those claiming under a specific tenant whose interest was determined in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1210 When all holders of recorded rights are not made parties -- Procedure -- Reference.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If there are outstanding liens or encumbrances of record upon the property when the action is commenced, the persons holding the liens shall be made parties to the action.  If the persons are not made parties, the court shall either order the persons made parties to the action by an amendment or supplemental complaint, or appoint a referee to determine whether the liens or encumbrances have been paid.  If the referee determines that amounts remain due, the referee shall determine whether the amounts are secured or unsecured and the order of precedence among all the liens or encumbrances on the property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1211 Notice of appearance before referee -- Referee's report.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1211(1): 78B-6-1210; 78B-6-1210 The referee appointed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1211(2): The summons shall state the specific time and place of the hearing and instruct the person to appear with proof of all amounts due.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1211(3): If the person cannot be found, the court may direct service to be made by publication in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1211(4): 78B-6-1210 The referee shall provide a report to the court detailing his findings.  The court shall confirm, modify, or set aside the findings.  If the findings are set aside, a new referee may be appointed in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1212 If partition prejudicial, sale in lieu thereof -- Partition by referees.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1212(1): If the court determines that the property or any part of it cannot be partitioned without great prejudice to the owners, the court may order the property sold.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1212(2): If the court determines that the property may be partitioned, it shall order a partition according to the respective rights of the parties determined by the court and appoint three referees to do the partition.  The court shall also designate a portion to remain undivided for the owners whose interests remain unknown or are not ascertained.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1212(3): 78B-6-1213(5); (11) If the action is for partition of a mining claim among the tenants in common, joint tenants, copartners, or parceners, the court, upon good cause shown by any party or parties in interest, may, instead of ordering partition to be made in the manner as provided, or a sale of the premises for cash, direct the referees to divide the claim in the manner provided in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213 Duties and powers of referees -- Procedure.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(1): In making the partition the referees must divide the property among the respective parties as determined by the court pursuant to the provisions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(2): The referees may designate the portions by proper landmarks, and may employ a surveyor with the necessary assistants to aid them.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(3): In all cases the court shall direct the referees making the partition to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(3)(a): allot the share of each of the parties owning an interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(3)(b): locate the share of each cotenant, including, if possible, the improvements made by the cotenant upon the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(4): The value of the improvements made by tenants in common shall be excluded from the valuation in making allotments if it can be done without material injury to the rights and interests of the other tenants in common.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(5): If the action is for partition of a mining claim, the court shall order the division of the claim by the referees not less than 20 nor more than 40 days from the date of the order, except by consent of all the parties in interest who have appeared in the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(6): On the day designated in the order the referees shall go to the property to be divided and proceed to divide the property.  If the division requires more than one day to complete, the referees shall continue from day to day until the division is completed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(7): Two or more of the tenants in common, joint tenants, copartners, or parceners may unite for the purposes of the division.  The parties shall give the referees written notice of any unions before the referees begin the division.  All who do not unite or give notice of separate action, shall, for the purposes of division, be considered to have united.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(8): The referees shall recognize:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(8)(a): those named in the court order, their agents and attorneys;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(8)(b): a guardian of a minor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(8)(c): a guardian entitled to the custody and the management of the estate of an incompetent or incapacitated person.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(9): At the time and place of division one of the referees shall be selected to conduct the proceedings in the manner of public auction.  The privilege of selecting first shall be offered to the party who agrees to take the smallest portion of the claim in proportion to that party's interest in the claim.  Once the bids are closed, the referees shall measure and mark off, by distinct metes and bounds, the portion of the claim designated by the lowest bidder.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(10): Once the referees have marked off and set apart the interest of the lowest bidder, they shall offer to the remaining parties the privilege of selection as provided, and shall upon closing the bids, proceed in the same manner to locate and mark off the portion of the lowest bidder.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1213(11): The bidding shall continue and the interest of the lowest bidder marked off until only one party in interest remains.  The party remaining shall become the owner of the remainder of the claim not marked off and set apart for the other parties.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1214 Report of referees.
----------------------------------------------------
The referees shall provide a written report of their proceedings, specifying the manner in which they executed their trust, describing the property divided, and the shares allotted to each party, with a particular description of each share.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215 Confirmation, modification, or vacation by court -- Effect of death of party before judgment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(1): (1)(c) The court may confirm, change, modify, or set aside the report, and if necessary, appoint new referees.  Upon the report being confirmed judgment must be rendered that the partition be effectual forever.  The judgment shall be binding and conclusive on all persons:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(1)(a): named as parties to the action and their legal representatives, who have at the time any interest in the property, whether as:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(1)(a)(i): owners in fee;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(1)(a)(ii): tenants for life or for years; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(1)(a)(iii): entitled to the reversion, remainder, or the inheritance of the property or of any portion after the determination of a particular estate in it;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(1)(b): who by any contingency may be entitled to a beneficial interest in the property, or who have an interest in any undivided share thereof as tenants for years or for life;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(1)(c): interested in the property who may be unknown, to whom notice of the action for partition has been given by publications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(1)(d): (1)(c) claiming from any parties or persons in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1215(2): A judgment is not invalid by reason of the death of any party before final judgment or decree, but the judgment or decree is as conclusive against the heirs, legal representatives, or assigns of the decedent as if it had been entered before the person's death.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1216 Tenant for years, less than 10, not affected by judgment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The judgment does not affect tenants for years, less than 10, of the whole of the property which is the subject of the partition.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1217 Referees' expenses and fees -- Apportionment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The expenses of the referees, including those of the surveyor and his assistants if employed, must be determined and allowed by the court, and the amount, together with the fees allowed by the court in its discretion to the referees, shall be apportioned equitably among the different parties to the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1218 Liens on undivided interests -- Apportionment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A lien on an undivided interest or estate of any of the parties shall only be a charge on the share assigned to the party after the share is charged with its just proportion of the costs of the partition in preference to the lien.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1219 Setoff of estate for life or for years.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
If there is an estate for life or years in an undivided share of the whole property and only a portion of the property is ordered to be sold, the estate may be set off in any part of the property not ordered to be sold.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1220 Proceeds of sale of encumbered property -- Disposition of.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The proceeds of the sale of encumbered property shall be applied under the direction of the court, as follows:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1220(1): to pay its just proportion of the general costs of the action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1220(2): to pay the costs of the reference;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1220(3): to satisfy and cancel all recorded liens in their order of priority, by payment of the sums due and to become due; the amount due to be verified by affidavit at the time of payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1220(4): the residue among the owners of the property sold according to their respective shares therein.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1221 Lienholders required to exhaust other security first.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any party to the action, who holds a lien upon the property or any portion of it and has other securities for the payment of the amount of the lien may be required by the court to exhaust the other securities before a distribution of the proceeds of sale.  The court may also order a just reduction to be made from the amount of the lien on the property in the amount of the securities.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1222 Distribution of proceeds or securities.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The proceeds of sale and the securities taken by the referees shall be distributed by the referees to the persons entitled to them whenever the court directs.  If no direction for distribution is given, all of the proceeds and securities must be paid into the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1223 Determination of adverse claims.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
When the proceeds of the sale of any share or parcel belonging to persons who are parties to the action, and who are known or unknown, are paid into court, the action may continue between the parties for the determination of their respective claims.  Further evidence may be taken by the court or a referee at the discretion of the court, and the court may, if necessary, require the parties to present the facts or law in controversy by pleadings as in an original action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1224 Sales at public auction -- Notice.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
All sales of real property made by referees under this part shall be made at public auction to the highest bidder, upon notice published in the manner required for the sale of real property on execution.  The notice shall state the terms of sale, and if the property or any part of it is to be sold subject to a prior estate, charge, or lien, that fact shall be stated also.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1225 Sales on credit -- Order for.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The court shall, in the order of sale, direct the terms of credit which may be allowed for the purchase money of any portion of the premises.  For that portion of which the purchase money is required, the court shall also order it to be invested for the benefit of unknown owners, minors or parties out of the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1226 Security for payment.
------------------------------------------------------
The referees may take separate mortgages and other securities;Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1226(1): for the whole or convenient portions of the purchase money;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1226(2): on any part of the property directed by the court to be sold on credit;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1226(3): for the shares of any known owner of full age, in the name of the owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1226(4): for the shares of a minor, in the name of the guardian of the minor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1226(5): for other shares, in the name of the clerk of the court and his successors in office.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1227 Compensation for interest of tenant for life or years.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person entitled to a tenancy for life or years whose estate has been sold, is entitled to receive a sum as reasonable compensation for the estate.  The person's consent to accept the sum shall be filed in writing with the clerk of the court.  Upon the filing of the consent, the clerk shall enter it in the minutes of the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1228 Court determines reasonable compensation for tenant.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If consent is not given, filed, and entered as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1229 If tenant unknown.
---------------------------------------------------
If persons entitled to the estate for life or years are unknown, the court shall provide for the protection of their rights in the same manner as if they were known and had appeared.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1230 Protection of vested, contingent, or future rights.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In all cases of sales if it appears that any person has a vested, contingent, or future right or estate in any of the property sold, the court shall ascertain and settle the proportionate value of the contingent or vested right or estate, and direct the proportion of the proceeds of the sale to be invested, secured, or paid over in a manner that would protect the rights and interests of the parties.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1231 Terms of sales -- Separate sale of distinct parcels.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In all cases of sales of property the terms shall be made known at the time, and if the premises consist of distinct farms or lots, they shall be sold separately.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1232 Who may not be purchaser.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1232(1): A referee or any person for the referee's benefit may not be interested in any purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1232(2): A guardian of a minor party may not be interested in the purchase of any real property which is the subject of an action under this part except for the benefit of the minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1232(3): All sales contrary to the provisions of this section are void.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233 Report of referees to the courts of sales.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233(1): Once the sale of the property or any portion ordered to be sold is complete, the referees shall file a report with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233(2): The report shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233(2)(a): a description of the different parcels of land sold to each purchaser;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233(2)(b): the name of the purchaser;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233(2)(c): the price paid or secured;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233(2)(d): the terms and conditions of the sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233(2)(e): the securities, if any, taken.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1233(3): The report shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1234 Referees' deed on confirmation -- Disposition of proceeds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the sale is confirmed by the court, an order shall be entered directing the referees to execute conveyances and authorizing them to take securities pursuant to sale.  The order may also give directions directing the disposition of the proceeds of the sale.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1235 Allowance on purchase price -- When interested party is purchaser.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a party entitled to a share of the property, or a lienholder entitled to have his lien paid out of the sale, becomes a purchaser, the referees may take his receipt for so much of the proceeds of the sale as belongs to him.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1236 Conveyance to be recorded -- Operates as a bar.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1236(1): The conveyances shall be recorded in the county where the property is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1236(2): The recording shall be a bar against:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1236(2)(a): all persons interested in the property in any way, who have been named as parties in the action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1236(2)(b): all parties or persons who were unknown, if the summons was served by publication, and all persons claiming under them; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1236(2)(c): all persons having unrecorded deeds or liens at the commencement of the action.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1237 Investment of sale proceeds for nonresidents or unknown parties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When there are proceeds of a sale belonging to an unknown owner or to a person outside the state who has no legal representative inside the state, the proceeds shall be invested in bonds of the United States, this state, or a political subdivision of the state for the benefit of the persons entitled the proceeds.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1238 Clerk of court to be custodian.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1238(1): If the security of the proceeds of the sale is taken, or when an investment of any proceeds is made, it shall be done, except as otherwise provided, in the name of the clerk of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1238(2): The clerk of the court shall hold the security for the use and benefit of the parties interested, subject to an order of the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1239 Distribution of securities to parties entitled.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If security is taken by the referees on a sale, and the parties interested in the security, by an instrument in writing delivered to the referees, agree upon the shares and proportions to which they are respectively entitled, or when shares and proportions have been previously adjudged by the court, the securities shall be taken in the names of, and payable to, the parties respectively entitled, and shall be delivered to the parties upon their receipt.  The agreement and receipt shall be filed with the clerk of the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1240 Investment of securities by court clerk -- Accounting.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The clerk of the court in whose name a security is taken or by whom an investment is made, and his successors in office, shall receive the interest and principal as it becomes due, and apply and invest the same as the court may direct.  The clerk shall also deposit with the county treasurer all securities taken, and keep an account, in a book provided and kept for that purpose in the clerk's office, free to inspection by all persons, of investments and money received and their disposition.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1241 Equalization.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1241(1): If a partition cannot be made equally among the parties according to their respective rights without prejudice to the rights and interests of some of them, and a partition is ordered, the courts may order compensation made by one party to another on account of the inequality.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1241(2): Compensation may not be required to be made to others by unknown owners or a minor, unless the court determines that the minor has sufficient personal property to make the payment and the minor's and the minor's interest will not be negatively affected.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1241(3): The court has the power in all cases to make compensatory adjustment among the parties according to the principles of equity.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1242 Interests of minor -- Payment to guardian.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the share of a minor is sold, the court may order the proceeds of the sale to be paid by the referee making the sale to the minor's general guardian or to the special guardian appointed for the minor in the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1243 Partition -- Payment of costs -- Enforcement of judgment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1243(1): The costs of partition, including reasonable attorney fees, expended by the plaintiff or any of the defendants for the common benefit, fees of referees and other disbursements shall be paid by the parties entitled to share in the lands divided, in proportion to their respective interests, and may be included and specified in the judgment.  The costs shall be a lien on the several shares, and the judgment may be enforced by execution against the shares and against other property held by the respective parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1243(2): If litigation arises between some of the parties, the court may require the expenses of the litigation to be paid by the parties to the litigation.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1244 One referee instead of three allowed by consent.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court, with the consent of the parties, may appoint a single referee instead of three referees in the proceedings under the provisions of this part, and the single referee has all the powers, and may perform all the duties, required of the three referees.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1245 Lien for costs and expenses advanced by one for benefit of all.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1245(1): The court shall allow expenses incurred, including attorney fees, in prosecuting or defending other actions or proceedings by any one of the tenants in common for the protection, confirmation or perfecting of the title, or setting the boundaries, or making a survey or surveys of the estate partitioned to be recovered by the party incurring the expenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1245(2): The court shall determine the amounts with interest from the date the expenditures occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1245(3): The costs shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1245(3)(a): pleaded and allowed by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1245(3)(b): included in the final judgment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1245(3)(c): a lien upon the share of each tenant, in proportion to the tenant's interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1245(3)(d): enforced in the same manner as taxable costs of partition are taxed and collected.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1246 Abstract of title -- Costs and inspection.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1246(1): If the court determines that it was necessary to have an abstract of the title to the property to be partitioned created and the abstract has been procured by a party to the proceeding, the cost of the abstract, with interest from the date if its creation and availability for inspection by the respective parties to the action, shall be allowed and taxed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1246(2): If the abstract is procured by the plaintiff before the commencement of the action the plaintiff shall file a notice with the complaint that an abstract of the title has been made and is available for the inspection and use of all the parties to the action.  The notice shall state where the abstract will be available for inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1246(3): If the plaintiff did not procure an abstract before commencing the action, and a defendant procures an abstract, the defendant shall, as soon as it has been directed it to be made, file a notice in the action with the clerk of the court, stating who is making the abstract and where it will be kept when finished.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1246(4): The court may direct who may have custody of the abstract.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1247 Interest on advances to be allowed.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Any disbursement made by a party under the direction of the court during the action shall accrue interest from the date it is made.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(1): "Ascendant" means an individual who precedes another individual in lineage, in the direct line of ascent from the other individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(2): "Collateral" means an individual who is related to another individual under the law of intestate succession of this state but who is not the other individual's ascendant or descendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(3): "Descendant" means an individual who follows another individual in lineage, in the direct line of descent from the other individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(4): 78B-6-1274; 78B-6-1278 "Determination of value" means a court order:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(4)(a): 78B-6-1274; 78B-6-1278 determining the fair market value of heirs' property under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(4)(b): adopting the valuation of the property agreed to by all the cotenants.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(5): "Heirs' property" means real property held in tenancy in common that satisfies all of the following requirements as of the filing of a partition action:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(5)(a): there is no agreement in a record binding all the cotenants that governs the partition of the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(5)(b): one or more of the cotenants acquired title from a relative, whether living or deceased; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(5)(c): any of the following applies:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(5)(c)(i): 20% or more of the interests are held by cotenants who are relatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(5)(c)(ii): 20% or more of the interests are held by an individual who acquired title from a relative, whether living or deceased; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(5)(c)(iii): 20% or more of the cotenants are relatives.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(6): 78B-6-1278 "Partition by sale" means a court-ordered sale of the entire heirs' property, whether by an auction, sealed bids, or an open-market sale conducted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(7): "Partition in kind" means the division of heirs' property into physically distinct and separately titled parcels.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(8): "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1270(9): "Relative" means an ascendant, a descendant, a collateral, or an individual otherwise related to another individual by blood, marriage, adoption, or a law of this state other than this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1271 Applicability -- Relation to other law.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1271(1): This part applies to partition actions filed on or after May 4, 2022.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1271(2): Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 12, Partition
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1271(2)(a): Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 12, Partition In an action to partition real property under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1271(2)(b): If the court determines that the property is heirs' property, the property shall be partitioned under this part, unless all of the cotenants otherwise agree in a record.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1271(3): Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 12, Partition; Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 12, Partition This part supplements


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1272 Service -- Notice by posting.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1272(1): This part does not limit or affect the method by which service of a complaint in a partition action may be made.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1272(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1272(2)(a): If the plaintiff in a partition action files a notice by publication and the court determines that the property is heirs' property, the plaintiff, no later than 10 days after the day on which the court determines the property is heirs' property, shall post and maintain while the action is pending a conspicuous sign on the property that is the subject of the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1272(2)(b): The sign shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1272(2)(b)(i): state that the action has commenced; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1272(2)(b)(ii): identify the name and address of the court and the common designation by which the property is known.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1272(2)(c): The court may require the plaintiff to publish on the sign the name of the plaintiff and the known defendants.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1273 Referees.
------------------------------------------
If the court appoints referees, each referee, in addition to the requirements and disqualifications applicable to referees in

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1274 Determination of value.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1274(1): (2); (3); (4) Except as otherwise provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1274(2): If all cotenants have agreed to the value of the property or to another method of valuation, the court shall adopt that value or the value produced by the agreed method of valuation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1274(3): If the court determines that the evidentiary value of an appraisal is outweighed by the cost of the appraisal, the court, after an evidentiary hearing, shall determine the fair market value of the property and send notice to the parties of the value.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1277 Considerations for partition in kind.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1277(1): 78B-6-1276(1) In determining under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1277(1)(c): evidence of the collective duration of ownership or possession of the property by a cotenant and one or more predecessors in title or predecessors in possession to the cotenant who are or were relatives of the cotenant or each other;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1277(1)(d): a cotenant's sentimental attachment to the property, including any attachment arising because the property has ancestral or other unique or special value to the cotenant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1277(1)(e): the lawful use being made of the property by a cotenant and the degree to which the cotenant would be harmed if the cotenant could not continue the same use of the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1277(1)(f): the degree to which the cotenants have contributed:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1277(1)(g): any other relevant factor.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278 Open-market sale, sealed bids, or auction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278(1): If the court orders a sale of heirs' property, the sale must be an open-market sale unless the court finds that a sale by sealed bids or an auction would be more economically advantageous and in the best interest of the cotenants as a group.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278(2)(a): If the court orders an open-market sale and the parties agree on a real estate broker licensed in this state to offer the property for sale no later than 10 days after the day on which the court entered the order, the court shall appoint the broker and establish a reasonable commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278(2)(b): (2)(a) If the parties do not agree on a broker during the 10-day period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278(2)(c): The broker shall offer the property for sale in a commercially reasonable manner at a price no lower than the determination of value of the property and on the terms and conditions established by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278(3): (2); 78B-6-1279 If the broker appointed under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278(4): (2) If the broker appointed under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1278(4)(c): order that the property be sold by sealed bids or at an auction.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1280 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this part, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of this uniform law with respect to the subject matter of the uniform law among states that enact this uniform law.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1281 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This part modifies, limits, and supersedes the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001 et seq., but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7003(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1301 Quiet title -- Action to determine adverse claim to property.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person may bring an action against another person to determine rights, interests, or claims to or in personal or real property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1302 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1302(1): "Claimant" means a person who files a notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1302(2): 78B-6-1304(5) "Guarantee" means an agreement by a claimant to pay an amount of damages:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1302(2)(a): specified by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1302(2)(b): suffered as a result of the maintenance of a notice;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1302(2)(c): to a person with an interest in the real property that is the subject of the notice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1302(2)(d): 78B-6-1304(5) if the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1302(3): 78B-6-1303 "Notice" means a notice of the pendency of an action filed under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303 Lis pendens -- Notice.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(1)(a): Any party to an action filed in the United States District Court for the District of Utah, the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Utah, a district court of this state, or the Business and Chancery Court of this state, that affects the title to, or the right of possession of, real property may file a notice of pendency of action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(1)(b): A party that chooses to file a notice of pendency of action shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(1)(b)(i): first, file the notice with the court that has jurisdiction of the action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(1)(b)(ii): second, record a copy of the notice filed with the court with the county recorder in the county where the property or any portion of the property is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(1)(c): A person may not file a notice of pendency of action unless a case has been filed and is pending in the United States District Court for the District of Utah, the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Utah, a district court of this state, or the Business and Chancery Court of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(2): The notice shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(2)(a): the caption of the case, with the names of the parties and the case number;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(2)(b): the object of the action or defense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(2)(c): the specific legal description of only the property affected.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1303(3): From the time of filing the notice, a purchaser, an encumbrancer of the property, or any other party in interest that may be affected by the action is considered to have constructive notice of pendency of action.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304 Motions related to a notice of pendency of an action.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(1): 78B-6-1303 Any time after a notice has been filed pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(1)(b): a person with an interest in the real property affected by the notice, including a prospective purchaser with an executed purchase contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(2): (1) A court shall order notice of pendency of action released if:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(2)(b): after a notice and hearing if determined to be necessary by the court, the court finds that the claimant has not established by a preponderance of the evidence the validity of the real property claim that is the subject of the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(3): (2) In deciding a motion under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(3)(a): the court finds that the party filing the action has failed to satisfy the statute of frauds for the transaction under which the claim is asserted relating to the real property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(3)(b): the court finds that the elements necessary to require specific performance have not been established by a preponderance of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(4): If a court releases a claimant's notice pursuant to this section, that claimant may not record another notice with respect to the same property without an order from the court in which the action is pending that authorizes the recording of a new notice of pendency.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(5): (1) Upon a motion by any person with an interest in the real property that is the subject of a notice of pendency, a court may, at any time after the notice has been recorded, require, as a condition of maintaining the notice, that the claimant provide security to the moving party in the amount and form directed by the court, regardless of whether the court has received an application to release under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(6): (5) A person who receives security under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(6)(b): the person receiving the security suffered damages as a result of the maintenance of the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(7): (5) The amount of security required by the court under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(8): A court shall award costs and attorney fees to a prevailing party on any motion under this section unless the court finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(8)(a): the nonprevailing party acted with substantial justification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(8)(b): other circumstances make the imposition of attorney fees and costs unjust.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304(9): 38-1a-701; 38-10-106 The motion permitted by this section does not apply to a notice of pendency of an action required by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304.5 Civil liability for recording wrongful notice of pendency -- Damages.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is liable to the record owner of real property, or to a person with a leasehold interest in the real property that is damaged by the maintenance of a notice of pendency, for $10,000 or for treble actual damages, whichever is greater, and for reasonable attorney fees and costs, if the person records or causes to be recorded a notice of pendency against the real property, knowing or having reason to know that:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304.5(1): 78B-6-1303 legal action against the property has not been filed as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304.5(2): the notice is groundless;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304.5(3): 78B-6-1303(2) the notice fails to comply with the notice requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1304.5(4): the notice contains an intentional material misstatement or false claim.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1305 Disclaimer or default by defendant -- Costs.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The plaintiff may not recover costs of the action if:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1305(1): the defendant disclaims in his answer any interest or estate in the property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1305(2): allows judgment to be taken against him by refusing to answer.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1306 Termination of title pending action -- Judgment -- Damages.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the plaintiff demonstrates a right to recover at the time the action is brought, but his right terminates during the pendency of the action, the verdict and judgment shall be according to the fact, and the plaintiff may recover damages for withholding the property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1307 Setoff or counterclaim for improvements made.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If permanent improvements have been made by a defendant, or persons under whom the defendant claims in good faith, the value of the improvements, except improvements made upon mining property, shall be allowed as a setoff or counterclaim against the damages recovered for withholding the property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1308 Right of entry pending action for purposes of action.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court in which an action is pending under this part or for damages for an injury to property may, on motion and upon notice to either party, for good cause shown, issue an order allowing a party the right to enter the property and take surveys and measurements including any tunnels, shafts, or drifts, even though entry must be made through other lands belonging to parties to the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1309 Order for entry -- Liability for injuries.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
The order shall describe the property, and a copy served on the owner or occupant.  The party may enter the property with necessary surveyors and assistants, and may take surveys and measurements.  The party shall be liable for any unnecessary injury done to the property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1310 Mortgage not considered a conveyance -- Foreclosure necessary.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A mortgage of real property may not be considered a conveyance which would enable the owner of the mortgage to recover possession of the real property without a foreclosure and sale.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1311 Alienation pending action not to prejudice recovery.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An action for the recovery of real property against a person in possession cannot be prejudiced by any alienation made by the person, either before or after the commencement of the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1312 Actions respecting mining claims -- Proof of customs and usage admissible.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In actions respecting mining claims proof must be admitted of the customs, usages, or regulations established and in force in the district, bar, diggings, or camp in which the claim is located.  The customs, usages, or regulations, if not in conflict with the laws of this state or of the United States, shall govern any decision in the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1313 Temporary injunction in actions involving title to mining claims.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1313(1): The court may grant a postponement if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1313(1)(a): the court is satisfied that the delay is necessary for either or both parties to adequately prepare for trial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1313(1)(b): the party requesting the postponement is not guilty of laches and is acting in good faith.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1313(2): The court may provide, as part of its order, that the party obtaining the postponement may not remove from the property which is the subject of the action any valuable quartz, rock, earth, or ores.  The court may vacate the postponement order or hold the party in contempt if the order is violated.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1314 Service of summons and conclusiveness of judgment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If service of process is made upon unknown defendants by publication, the action shall proceed against the unknown persons in the same manner as against the defendants who are named and upon whom service is made by publication.  Any unknown person who has or claims to have any right, title, estate, lien, or interest in the property, which is a cloud on the title and adverse to the plaintiff, who has been served as above, and anyone claiming under him, shall be concluded by any judgment in the action even though the unknown person may be under a legal disability.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1315 Judgment on default -- Court must require evidence -- Conclusiveness of judgment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1315(1): If the summons has been served and the time for answering has expired, the court shall proceed to hear the cause as in other cases.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1315(2): The court may examine and determine the legality of the plaintiff's title and the title and claims of all the defendants and all unknown persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1315(3): The court may not enter any judgment by default against unknown defendants, but in all cases shall require evidence of plaintiff's title and possession and hear the evidence offered respecting the claims and title of any of the defendants.  The court may enter judgment in accordance with the evidence and the law only after hearing all the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1315(4): The judgment shall be conclusive against all the persons named in the summons and complaint who have been served and against all unknown persons as stated in the complaint and summons who have been served by publication.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1501 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Structured Settlement Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
For purposes of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(1): "Annuity issuer" means an insurer that has issued a contract to fund periodic payments under a structured settlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(2): "Dependents" include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(2)(a): a payee's spouse;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(2)(b): a payee's minor children; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(2)(c): all other persons for whom the payee is legally obligated to provide support, including alimony.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(3): "Discounted present value" means the present value of future payments determined by discounting the payments to the present using the most recently published Applicable Federal Rate for determining the present value of an annuity, as issued by the United States Internal Revenue Service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(4): "Gross advance amount" means the sum payable to the payee or for the payee's account as consideration for a transfer of structured settlement payment rights before any reductions for transfer expenses or other deductions to be made from the consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(5): "Independent professional advice" means advice of an attorney, certified public accountant, actuary, or other licensed professional adviser.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(6): "Interested parties" means, with respect to any structured settlement:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(6)(a): the payee;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(6)(b): any beneficiary irrevocably designated under the annuity contract to receive payments following the payee's death;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(6)(c): the annuity issuer;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(6)(d): the structured settlement obligor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(6)(e): any other party that has continuing rights or obligations under the structured settlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(7): 78B-6-1503(5) "Net advance amount" means the gross advance amount less the aggregate amount of the actual and estimated transfer expenses required to be disclosed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(8): "Payee" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(8)(a): is receiving tax free payments under a structured settlement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(8)(b): proposes to make a transfer of payment rights under the settlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(9): "Periodic payments" includes both recurring payments and scheduled future lump sum payments.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(10): "Qualified assignment agreement" means an agreement providing for a qualified assignment within the meaning of Section 130 of the United States Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(11): "Responsible administrative authority" means, with respect to a structured settlement, any government authority vested by law with exclusive jurisdiction over the settled claim resolved by the structured settlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(12): "Settled claim" means the original tort claim resolved by a structured settlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(13): "Structured settlement" means an arrangement for periodic payment of damages for personal injuries or sickness established by settlement or judgment in resolution of a tort claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(14): "Structured settlement agreement" means the agreement, judgment, stipulation, or release embodying the terms of a structured settlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(15): "Structured settlement obligor" means, with respect to any structured settlement, the party that has the continuing obligation to make periodic payments to the payee under a structured settlement agreement or a qualified assignment agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(16): "Structured settlement payment rights" means rights to receive periodic payments under a structured settlement, whether from the structured settlement obligor or the annuity issuer if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(16)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(16)(a)(i): the payee is domiciled in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(16)(a)(ii): the domicile or principal place of business of the structured settlement obligor or the annuity issuer is located in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(16)(b): the structured settlement agreement is approved by a court in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(16)(c): the structured settlement agreement is expressly governed by the laws of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(17): "Terms of the structured settlement" include, with respect to any structured settlement, the terms of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(17)(a): the structured settlement agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(17)(b): the annuity contract;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(17)(c): any qualified assignment agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1502(17)(d): any order or other approval of any court or other government authority that authorized or approved the structured settlement.
