Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503 Required disclosures to payee.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Not less than three days prior to the date on which a payee signs a transfer agreement, the transferee shall provide to the payee a separate disclosure statement, in bold type no smaller than 14 point, setting forth:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503(1): the amounts and due dates of the structured settlement payments to be transferred;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503(2): the aggregate amount of the payments;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503(3): the discounted present value of the payments to be transferred, which shall be identified as the "calculation of current value of the transferred structured settlement payments under federal standards for valuing annuities," and the amount of the Applicable Federal Rate used in calculating the discounted present value;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503(4): the gross advance amount;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503(5): an itemized listing of all applicable transfer expenses, other than attorney fees and related disbursements payable in connection with the transferee's application for approval of the transfer, and the transferee's best estimate of the amount of any of the fees and disbursements;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503(6): the net advance amount;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503(7): the amount of any penalties or liquidated damages payable by the payee in the event of any breach of the transfer agreement by the payee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1503(8): a statement that the payee has the right to cancel the transfer agreement, without penalty or further obligation, not later than the third business day after the date the agreement is signed by the payee.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1504 Approval of transfers of structured settlement payment rights.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Direct or indirect transfer of structured settlement payment rights may not be effective and a structured settlement obligor or annuity issuer may not be required to make any payment directly or indirectly to any transferee of structured settlement payment rights unless the transfer has been approved in advance in a final court order based on express findings by the court that:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1504(1): the transfer is in the best interest of the payee, taking into account the welfare and support of the payee's dependents;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1504(2): the payee has been advised in writing by the transferee to seek independent professional advice regarding the transfer and has either received such advice or knowingly waived such advice in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1504(3): the transfer does not contravene any applicable statute or the order of any court or other government authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1505 Effects of transfer of structured settlement payment rights.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Following a transfer of structured settlement payment rights under this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1505(1): The structured settlement obligor and the annuity issuer shall, as to all parties except the transferee, be discharged and released from any and all liability for the transferred payments.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1505(2): The transferee shall be liable to the structured settlement obligor and the annuity issuer:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1505(2)(a): if the transfer contravenes the terms of the structured settlement, for any taxes incurred by the parties as a consequence of the transfer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1505(2)(b): for any other liabilities or costs, including reasonable costs and attorney fees, arising from compliance by the parties with the order of the court or arising as a consequence of the transferee's failure to comply with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1505(3): Neither the annuity issuer nor the structured settlement obligor may be required to divide any periodic payment between the payee and any transferee or assignee or between two or more transferees or assignees.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1505(4): Any further transfer of structured settlement payment rights by the payee may be made only after compliance with all of the requirements of this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506 Procedure for approval of transfers.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506(1): An application under this part for approval of a transfer of structured settlement payment rights shall be made by the transferee and may be brought in the county in which the payee resides, in the county in which the structured settlement obligor or the annuity issuer maintains its principal place of business, or in any court which approved the structured settlement agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506(2): 78B-6-1504; 78B-6-1503 Not less than 20 days prior to the scheduled hearing on any application for approval of a transfer of structured settlement payment rights under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506(2)(a): a copy of the transferee's application;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506(2)(b): a copy of the transfer agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506(2)(c): 78B-6-1503 a copy of the disclosure statement required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506(2)(d): a listing of each of the payee's dependents, together with each dependent's age;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506(2)(e): notification that any interested party is entitled to support, oppose, or otherwise respond to the transferee's application, either in person or by counsel, by submitting written comments to the court or responsible administrative authority or by participating in the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1506(2)(f): notification of the time and place of the hearing and notification of the manner in which and the time by which written responses to the application must be filed, which shall be not less than 15 days after service of the transferee's notice, in order to be considered by the court or responsible administrative authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507 General provisions -- Construction.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(1): The provisions of this part may not be waived by any payee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(2)(a): Any transfer agreement entered into on or after May 6, 2002 by a payee who resides in this state shall provide that disputes under the transfer agreement, including any claim that the payee has breached the agreement, shall be determined in and under the laws of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(2)(b): A transfer agreement may not authorize the transferee or any other party to confess judgment or consent to entry of judgment against the payee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(3): The transfer of structured settlement payment rights may not extend to any payments that are life-contingent unless, before the date on which the payee signs the transfer agreement, the transferee establishes and agrees to maintain procedures reasonably satisfactory to the annuity issuer and the structured settlement obligor for:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(3)(a): periodically confirming the payee's survival; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(3)(b): giving the annuity issuer and the structured settlement obligor prompt written notice in the event of the payee's death.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(4): A payee who proposes to make a transfer of structured settlement payment rights may not incur any of the following on the basis of a failure of the transfer to satisfy the requirements of this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(4)(a): a penalty;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(4)(b): a forfeiture of any application fee or other payment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(4)(c): any liability to the proposed transferee or any assignee based on any failure of the transfer to satisfy the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(5): 34A-2-422
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(5)(a): This part may not be construed to authorize any transfer of structured settlement payment rights in contravention of any law or to imply that any transfer under a transfer agreement entered into before May 6, 2002 is valid or invalid.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(5)(b): 34A-2-422 This part does not apply to a transfer of payment rights under workers' compensation, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1507(6): 78B-6-1503; 78B-6-1504 Compliance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1508 Effective date.
------------------------------------------------
This part shall apply to any transfer of structured settlement payment rights under a transfer agreement entered into on or after May 6, 2002; provided, however, that nothing contained in this part shall imply that any transfer under a transfer agreement reached prior to that date is either effective or ineffective.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1601 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Social Host Liability Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1602(6): (6)(b); (6)(a); (6)(a); (6)(b)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1605 Reservation of legal options -- Ordinances.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1605(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1605(1)(a): This part may not be construed as a waiver by a local entity of a right to seek reimbursement for actual costs of response services through another legal remedy or procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1605(1)(b): The procedure provided for in this part is in addition to any other civil or criminal statute.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1605(1)(c): This part does not limit the authority of a law enforcement officer or private citizen to make an arrest for a criminal offense arising out of conduct regulated by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1605(2): A local entity may impose by ordinance a stricter provision related to the conduct of an underage drinking gathering, including the imposition of a different civil penalty amount, except that the ordinance shall provide that a civil penalty for an underage drinking gathering may only be imposed by a local entity for which an emergency response provider provides services at the underage drinking gathering.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1606 Appeals.
-----------------------------------------
An individual upon whom is imposed a civil penalty under this part may appeal the imposition of the civil penalty pursuant to the procedures used by the local entity for appealing a traffic citation or a violation of an ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1801 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Renewal of Judgment Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1802 Renewal by motion.
---------------------------------------------------
A court of record may renew a judgment issued by a court if:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1802(1): a motion is filed within the original action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1802(2): the motion is filed before the statute of limitations on the original judgment expires;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1802(3): the motion includes an affidavit that contains an accounting of the original judgment and all postjudgment payments, credits, and other adjustments which are provided for by law or are contained within the original judgment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1802(4): the facts in the supporting affidavit are determined by the court to be accurate and the affidavit affirms that notice was sent to the most current address known for the judgment debtor;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1802(5): the time for responding to the motion has expired; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1802(6): 78A-2-301(1)(l) the fee required by Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1803 Notice.
----------------------------------------
Notice of a motion for renewal of judgment is served in accordance with the Rules of Civil Procedure and opposition may be filed pursuant to the rules.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1804 Date and duration of judgment.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Upon granting a motion for the renewal of judgment, the court shall enter an order which renews the original judgment from the date of entry of the order or from the scheduled expiration date of the original order, whichever occurs first, for the same amount of time as the original judgment.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1901 Title -- Purpose.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1901(1): This part is known as the "Distribution of Bad Faith Patent Infringement Letters Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1901(2): The Legislature acknowledges that it is preempted from passing any law that conflicts with federal patent law.  However, this part seeks to protect Utah businesses from the use of demand letters containing abusive and bad faith assertions of patent infringement, and build Utah's economy, while at the same time respecting federal law and not interfering with legitimate patent enforcement efforts.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1902 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1902(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1902(1)(a): "Demand letter" means a letter, email, or other written communication directed to a target and asserting or claiming that the target has engaged in patent infringement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1902(1)(b): "Demand letter" does not include a complaint filed in a United States District Court asserting patent infringement or discovery responses or other papers filed in an action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1902(2): "Target" means a person or entity residing in, incorporated in, or organized under the laws of this state that has received a demand letter and includes the customers, distributors, and agents of the person or entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1902(3): "Sponsor" means the party or parties responsible for distribution of a demand letter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1903 Prohibition against distribution of demand letters containing bad faith assertions of patent infringement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1903(1): A sponsor may not distribute a demand letter to a target that includes a bad faith assertion of patent infringement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1903(2): (2)(a)(ii); (2)(a)(iv) A court may consider the following factors as evidence in determining whether a sponsor has or has not distributed a demand letter containing a bad faith assertion of patent infringement, but no one factor may be considered conclusive as to whether a demand letter contains a bad faith assertion of patent infringement:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1903(2)(a): (2)(a)(ii); (2)(a)(iv) the demand letter does not contain all of the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1903(2)(a)(i): the patent numbers of the patent or patents being asserted;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1903(2)(b)(vi): a false or misleading statement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-1903(2)(b)(vii): the demand letter demands payment of a license fee or response within an unreasonably short period of time depending on the number and complexity of the claims.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2100 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as "Cause of Action for Minors Injured by Pornographic Material."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2101(1): "Minor" means an individual less than 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2101(2): "Pornographic material" means material that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2101(2)(a): the average person, applying contemporary community standards, finds that, taken as a whole, appeals to prurient interest in sex;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2101(2)(b): is patently offensive in the description or depiction of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement, sadomasochistic abuse, or excretion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2101(2)(c): taken as a whole does not have serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102 Exemptions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1): 76-10-1230 If the conditions of Subsection (2) are met, this part does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(a): the following, as defined in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(a)(i): an interactive computer service;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(a)(ii): a telecommunications service, information service, or mobile service, including a commercial mobile service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(a)(iii): a multichannel video programming distributor;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(b): an Internet service provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(c): a provider of an electronic communications service;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(d): a distributor of Internet-based video services;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(e): 76-10-1230 a host company as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(1)(f): a distributor of electronic or computerized game software that users manipulate through interactive devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(2): This part does not apply to an entity described in Subsection (1) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(2)(a): the distribution of pornographic material by the entity occurs only incidentally through the entity's function of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(2)(a)(i): transmitting or routing data from one person to another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(2)(a)(ii): providing a connection between one person and another person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(2)(a)(iii): providing data storage space or data caching to a person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2102(2)(b): the entity does not intentionally aid or abet in the distribution of the pornographic material.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103 Liability -- Safe harbor.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(1): 78B-6-2102 A person who is not exempt under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(1)(a): at the time the pornographic material is viewed by the person, the person is a minor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(1)(b): the pornographic material is the proximate cause for the person being harmed physically or psychologically, or by emotional or medical illnesses as a result of that pornographic material.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(2): Nothing in this part affects any private right of action existing under other law, including contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(3): Notwithstanding Subsection (1), a person who distributes or otherwise provides pornographic material is not liable under this section if the person who distributes or otherwise provides pornographic material:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(3)(a): provides a warning that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(3)(a)(i): is conspicuous;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(3)(a)(ii): appears before the pornographic material can be accessed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(3)(a)(iii): consists of a good faith effort to warn persons accessing the pornographic material that the pornographic material may be harmful to minors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(3)(b): makes a good faith effort to verify the age of a person accessing the pornographic material.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(4): Subsection (3) may not be interpreted as exempting a person from complying with Title 13, Chapter 39, Child Protection Registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(5): 78B-6-2105; 78B-6-2102; 78B-6-2105
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(5)(a): 78B-6-2105; 78B-6-2102; 78B-6-2105 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(5)(b): The use of virtual private networks or similar technology by the consumer to hide the consumer's location may not be included in a compliance rate calculation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2103(6): 78B-6-2105 Notwithstanding Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2104 Damages -- Class action.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2104(1): 78B-6-2103 If a court finds that a person is violating Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2104(1)(a): actual damages; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2104(1)(b): punitive damages, if it is proven that the person targeted minors.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2104(2): A class action may be brought under this part in accordance with Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 23.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(9)(a): the nature and extent of the violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(9)(b): the number and severity of the violations;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(9)(c): the economic effect of the penalty on the violator;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(9)(d): whether the violator took good faith measures to comply with this chapter and when those measures were taken;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(9)(e): the willfulness of the violator's misconduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(9)(f): the deterrent effect that the imposition of the penalty would have on both the violator and the regulated community as a whole; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(9)(g): any other factor that the court determines justice requires.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(10): Actions pursuant to this section may be brought by the attorney general's office in the name of the people of the state or by a private person in accordance with Subsection (11).

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(11)(b)(ii): the attorney general believes that there is no merit to the action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2105(11)(c): the alleged violator has not responded to the notice of alleged violation or returned the proof of compliance form provided in Subsection (17).

The alleged violator shall deliver the civil penalty to the noticing party within 30 days of receipt of the notice of alleged violation.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2201 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as "Cause of Action to Protect Minors from Unfiltered Devices."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(1): "Activate" means the process of powering on a device and associating it with a new user account.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(2): "Device" means a tablet or a smart phone sold in Utah and manufactured on or after January 1 of the year following the year this bill takes effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(3): "Filter" means software installed on a device that is capable of preventing the device from accessing or displaying material that is harmful to minors through the Internet or any applications owned and controlled by the manufacturer and installed on the device.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(4): 76-10-1201 "Harmful to minors" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(5): 13-40-102 "Internet" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(6): 16-17-102; 70-3a-103
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(6)(a): 16-17-102 "Manufacturer" means a person that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(6)(a)(i): is engaged in the business of manufacturing a device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(6)(a)(ii): 16-17-102 has a commercial registered agent as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(6)(b): 70-3a-103 "Manufacturer" includes a registrant as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(7): "Minor" means an individual under the age of 18 who is not emancipated, married, or a member of the armed forces of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(8): 63A-2-101.5 "Smart phone" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(9): "Tablet" means a mobile device that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(9)(a): is equipped with a mobile operating system, touchscreen display, and rechargeable battery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2202(9)(b): has the ability to support access to a cellular network.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203 Filter required.
-------------------------------------------------
Beginning on January 1 of the year following the year this bill takes effect, a manufacturer shall manufacture a device that, when activated in the state, automatically enables a filter that:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203(1): when enabled, prevents the user from accessing or downloading material that is harmful to minors on:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203(1)(a): mobile data networks;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203(1)(b): applications owned and controlled by the manufacturer;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203(1)(c): wired Internet networks; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203(1)(d): wireless Internet networks;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203(2): notifies the user of the device when the filter blocks the device from downloading an application or accessing a website;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203(3): gives a user with a passcode the opportunity to unblock a filtered application or website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2203(4): reasonably precludes a user other than a user with a passcode the opportunity to deactivate, modify, or uninstall the filter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2204 Liability.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2204(1): 78B-6-2203 Beginning January 1 of the year following the year this bill takes effect, a manufacturer of a device is liable to a minor in the state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2204(1)(a): the device is activated in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2204(1)(b): 78B-6-2203 the device does not, upon activation in the state, enable a filter that complies with the requirements described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2204(1)(c): the minor accesses material that is harmful to minors on the device.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2204(2): Nothing in this part affects any private right of action existing under other law, including contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2204(3): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2301 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2301(1): "Directive" means an ordinance, regulation, measure, rule, enactment, order, or policy issued, enacted, or required by a local or state governmental entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2301(2): 53-5a-102 "Firearm" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2301(3): 53-5a-102; 76-10-500 "Legislative firearm preemption" means the preemption provided for in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2301(4): "Local or state governmental entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2301(4)(a): a department, commission, board, council, agency, institution, officer, corporation, fund, division, office, committee, authority, laboratory, library, unit, bureau, panel, or other administrative unit of the state, including the Utah Board of Higher Education, each institution of higher education, and the boards of trustees of each higher education institution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2301(4)(b): a county, city, town, special district, local education agency, public school, school district, charter school, special service district under Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act, an entity created by interlocal cooperation agreement under Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, or any other governmental entity designated in statute as a political subdivision of the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2302 Violation of legislative preemption -- Exceptions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2302(1): A local or state governmental entity may not enact or enforce a directive that violates legislative firearm preemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2302(2): 76-8-311.3 This part does not prohibit the enactment or enforcement of a directive:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2302(2)(a): by a law enforcement agency if the directive pertains to a firearm issued to or used by a peace officer in the course of the peace officer's official duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2302(2)(b): 76-8-311.3 by a correctional facility or mental health facility under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2302(2)(c): of judicial administration if the directive establishes a secure courthouse;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2302(2)(d): by the State Tax Commission if the directive establishes a secure area within a State Tax Commission facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2302(2)(e): by a local or state governmental entity if the directive is developed in response to and in accordance with legislative authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303 Civil action -- Injunction -- Damages -- Immunity.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(1): A person who is harmed by a local or state governmental entity that makes or causes to be enforced a directive in violation of legislative firearm preemption may submit a written communication to the local or state governmental entity that harmed the person asking the local or state governmental entity that harmed the person to rescind or repeal the directive.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(2): (1); (2)(a); Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(2)(a): (1) If a local or state governmental entity fails to rescind or repeal a directive within 30 days after the day on which the local or state governmental entity receives a request described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(2)(b): (2)(a); Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah The suit described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(3): (3) If the court determines that the local or state governmental entity that failed to rescind or repeal the directive violated legislative firearm preemption, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(3)(a): order that the relevant directive is void;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(3)(b): prohibit the local or state governmental entity that failed to rescind or repeal the void directive from enforcing the void directive; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(3)(c): (3) award to the prevailing party:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(3)(c)(i): actual damages, which includes the cost of time in bringing the civil action or defending against the action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(3)(c)(ii): reasonable attorney fees and costs in accordance with the laws of this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2303(3)(c)(iii): (3) interest on the sums awarded under this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(1): "AMA guides" means the edition of the American Medical Association's Guides to the Evaluation of Permanent Impairment in effect at the time of the performance of an examination or test on an exposed individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(2): "Asbestos" means chrysotile, amosite, crocidolite, tremolite asbestos, anthophyllite asbestos, actinolite asbestos, asbestiform winchite, asbestiform richterite, asbestiform amphibole minerals, and any of these minerals that have been chemically treated or altered, including all minerals defined as asbestos in 29 C.F.R. Sec. 1910 at the time the asbestos action is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(3): "Asbestosis" means bilateral diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lungs caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(a): "Asbestos action" means a claim for damages or other civil or equitable relief presented in a civil action resulting from, based on, or related to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(a)(i): the health effects of exposure to asbestos, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(a)(i)(A): loss of consortium;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(a)(i)(B): wrongful death;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(a)(i)(C): mental or emotional injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(a)(i)(D): risk or fear of disease or other injury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(a)(i)(E): costs of medical monitoring or surveillance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(a)(ii): any other derivative claim made by or on behalf of an individual exposed to asbestos or a representative, spouse, parent, child, or other relative of that individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(4)(b): "Asbestos action" does not include a claim for workers' compensation or veterans benefits.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(5): "Asbestos trust" means a:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(5)(a): government-approved or court-approved trust that is intended to provide compensation to claimants arising out of, based on, or related to the health effects of exposure to asbestos or asbestos-containing products;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(5)(b): qualified settlement fund that is intended to provide compensation to claimants arising out of, based on, or related to the health effects of exposure to asbestos or asbestos-containing products;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(5)(c): compensation fund or claims facility created as a result of an administrative or legal action that is intended to provide compensation to claimants arising out of, based on, or related to the health effects of exposure to asbestos or asbestos-containing products;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(5)(d): court-approved bankruptcy that is intended to provide compensation to claimants arising out of, based on, or related to the health effects of exposure to asbestos or asbestos-containing products; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(5)(e): plan of reorganization or trust pursuant to 11 U.S.C. Sec. 524(g) or 11 U.S.C. Sec. 1121(a) or other applicable provision of law that is intended to provide compensation to claimants arising out of, based on, or related to the health effects of exposure to asbestos or asbestos-containing products.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(6): "ATS testing standards" means the official technical statements from the American Thoracic Society for pulmonary function testing in effect at the time of the performance of an examination or test on an exposed individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(7): "Board-certified physician in internal medicine" means a licensed physician who is certified by the American Board of Internal Medicine or the American Osteopathic Board of Internal Medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(8): "Board-certified physician in occupational medicine" means a licensed physician who is certified in the specialty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(8)(a): occupational medicine by the American Board of Preventative Medicine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(8)(b): occupational and environmental medicine by the American Osteopathic Board of Preventative Medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(9): "Board-certified physician in pathology" means a licensed physician:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(9)(a): who holds primary certification in anatomic pathology or clinical pathology from the American Board of Pathology or the American Osteopathic Board of Pathology; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(9)(b): whose professional practice is principally in the field of pathology involving regular evaluation of pathology materials obtained from surgical or postmortem specimens.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(10): "Board-certified physician in pulmonary medicine" means a licensed physician who is certified in the specialty of pulmonary medicine by the American Board of Internal Medicine or the American Osteopathic Board of Internal Medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(11): "Certified B reader" means a physician who is certified as a B reader by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(12): "Chest x-ray" means a chest film taken in accordance with applicable state and federal laws and taken in the posterior-anterior view.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(13): "Exposed individual" means an individual whose exposure to asbestos is the basis for the asbestos action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(14): "FEV1" means the maximal volume of air expelled in the first second during performance of spirometry.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(15): "FEV1/FVC ratio" means the ratio that is calculated from FEV1 divided by FVC.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(16): "FVC" means the maximal volume of air expired with maximum effort from a position of full inspiration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(17): "ILO system" means the system for the classification of chest x-rays provided in the International Labour Office's Guidelines for the Use of ILO International Classification of Radiographs of Pneumoconioses in effect at the time of the performance of an examination or test on an exposed individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(18): "Law firm" means a person that employs a lawyer.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(19): "Lawyer" means an individual who is authorized to provide legal services in any state or territory of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(20): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(20)(a): "Nonmalignant condition" means a condition that may be caused by asbestos other than a diagnosed cancer.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(20)(b): "Nonmalignant condition" does not include asbestos-related lung cancer accompanied by asbestosis.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(21): "Pathological evidence of asbestosis" means a statement by a board-certified physician in pathology that more than one representative section of lung tissue demonstrates a pattern of peribronchiolar or parenchymal scarring in the presence of characteristic asbestos bodies and there is no other more likely explanation for the presence of the fibrosis.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(22): "Plaintiff" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(22)(a): the person bringing the asbestos action, including a personal representative if the asbestos action is brought by an estate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(22)(b): a conservator or next friend if the asbestos action is brought on behalf of a minor or legally incapacitated individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(23): "Plethysmography" means the test for determining lung volume in which the exposed individual is enclosed in a chamber equipped to measure pressure, flow, or volume change.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(24): "Predicted lower limit of normal" means the fifth percentile of healthy populations based on age, height, and gender as referenced in the AMA guides.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(25): "Pulmonary function testing" means spirometry, lung volume testing, and diffusion capacity testing, including appropriate measurements, quality control data, and graphs, that are performed in accordance with the methods of calibration and techniques provided in the AMA guides and the ATS testing standards in effect at the time of the performance of a test on an exposed individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26): "Qualified physician" means a licensed physician who:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(a): is a board-certified physician in internal medicine, a board-certified physician in occupational medicine, a board-certified physician in pathology, or a board-certified physician in pulmonary medicine, as is appropriate to the diagnostic specialty in question;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(b)(i): conducted a physical examination of the exposed individual and took a detailed occupational, exposure, medical, smoking, and social history from the exposed individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(b)(ii): if the exposed individual is deceased, reviewed the pathology material and took a detailed history from the individual most knowledgeable about the information forming the basis of the asbestos action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(c)(i): treated the exposed individual and had a physician-patient relationship with the exposed individual at the time of the physical examination; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(c)(ii): if the licensed physician is a board-certified physician in pathology, examined tissue samples or pathological slides of the exposed individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(d): prepared or directly supervised the preparation and final review of a medical report under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(26)(e): has not relied on any examinations, tests, radiographs, reports, or opinions of a doctor, clinic, laboratory, or testing company that performed an examination, test, radiograph, or screening of the exposed individual in violation of a law, regulation, licensing requirement, or medical ethics requirement of the state in which the examination, test, radiograph, or screening of the exposed individual was conducted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(27): "Radiological evidence of asbestosis" means a quality 1 or 2 chest x-ray showing bilateral small, irregular opacities, classified by width as s, t, or u, that occur primarily in the lower lung zones graded by a certified B reader as at least 1/0 on the ILO system.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(28): "Radiological evidence of diffuse bilateral pleural thickening" means a quality 1 or 2 chest x-ray showing diffuse bilateral pleural thickening of at least b2 on the ILO system and blunting of at least one costophrenic angle as classified by a certified B reader.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(29): "Spirometry" means a test of air capacity of the lung through a spirometer that measures the volume of air inspired and expired.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(30): "Supporting test results" means a report by a certified B reader, x-ray examinations, diagnostic imaging of the chest, pathology reports, pulmonary function testing, and other tests, which are reviewed by the diagnosing physician or qualified physician in reaching the physician's conclusions.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(31): 78B-18a-102 "Sworn declaration" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(32): "Timed gas dilution" means a method for measuring total lung capacity in which the individual breaths into a spirometer containing a known concentration of an inert and insoluble gas for a specific time and the concentration of that inert and insoluble gas in the lung is compared to the concentration of that type of gas in the spirometer.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(33): "Total lung capacity" means the volume of gas contained in the lungs at the end of the maximal inspiration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(34): "Trust claims materials" means a final executed proof of claim and all other documents and information related to a claim against an asbestos trust, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(34)(a): claims forms and supplementary materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(34)(b): affidavits;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(34)(c): depositions and trial testimony;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(34)(d): work history;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(34)(e): medical and health records;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(34)(f): documents reflecting the status of a claim against an asbestos trust; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(34)(g): all documents relating to the settlement of the trust claim if the trust claim has settled.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(35): "Trust governance documents" means all documents that relate to eligibility and payment levels, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(35)(a): claims payment matrices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(35)(b): trust distribution procedures or plans for reorganization for an asbestos trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(36): " Veterans benefits" means a program for benefits in connection with military service administered by the United States Department of Veterans Affairs under United States Code,
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(37): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(37)(a): "Workers' compensation" means a program administered by the United States or a state to provide benefits, funded by a responsible employer or the employer's insurance carrier, for occupational diseases or injuries or for disability or death caused by occupational diseases or injuries.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(37)(b): "Workers' compensation" includes the Longshore and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act, 33 U.S.C. Sec. 901 et seq., and Federal Employees' Compensation Act, 5 U.S.C. Sec. 8101 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2401(37)(c): "Workers' compensation" does not include the Federal Employers' Liability Act, 45 U.S.C. Sec. 51 et seq.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402 Required disclosures by plaintiff within 21 days of filing asbestos action.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(1): (1) Within 21 days after the day on which the first answer is filed in response to the plaintiff's complaint in an asbestos action, the plaintiff shall provide all parties with a sworn declaration stating the evidence providing the basis for each claim against each defendant, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(1)(a): the name, address, date of birth, marital status, occupation, smoking history, and current and past employers and worksites of the exposed individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(1)(b): the name and address of each individual who is knowledgeable about each exposure to asbestos and the exposed individual's relationship to that individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(1)(c): the manufacturer or seller and the specific name of each asbestos-containing product, including any brand or trade name of that product, to which the exposed individual was exposed to asbestos or the other individual was exposed to asbestos if the exposed individual's exposure to asbestos was through another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(1)(d): the specific sites and the location at the sites that establish the direct connection between the exposed individual, or the other individual if the exposed individual's exposure to asbestos was through another individual, and each defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(1)(e): the beginning and ending dates of each exposure and the frequency of each exposure for the exposed individual or the other individual if the exposed individual's exposure to asbestos was through another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(1)(f): the condition that is alleged to have been caused by exposure to asbestos; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(1)(g): (1) any supporting documentation relating to the information required under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(2): (1); 78B-6-2403; 78B-6-2405 The sworn declaration under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(3): (4); (1); (1) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(3)(a): (1) against a defendant if the defendant's asbestos-containing product or site is not specifically identified in the sworn declaration under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(3)(b): (1) against all defendants if the plaintiff fails to comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2402(4): (3) The court may not dismiss a plaintiff's asbestos claim under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403 Requirements for asbestos action alleging nonmalignant condition -- Evidence.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(1): Within 90 days after the day on which the plaintiff files the complaint in an asbestos action alleging a nonmalignant condition, the plaintiff shall file a detailed narrative medical report and diagnosis, signed under oath by a qualified physician and accompanied by supporting test results, constituting prima facie evidence that the exposed individual has a physical impairment for which exposure to asbestos was a substantial contributing factor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(2): A defendant shall have a reasonable opportunity before trial to challenge the adequacy of the prima facie evidence required under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(3): A court shall dismiss an asbestos action without prejudice upon a finding that the plaintiff failed to make the prima facie showing required by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4): (1) To make a prima facie showing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(a)(i): radiological evidence of asbestosis or pathological evidence of asbestosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(a)(ii): radiological evidence of diffuse bilateral pleural thickening; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(a)(iii): a high-resolution computed tomography scan showing evidence of asbestosis or diffuse pleural thickening;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(b): a detailed occupational and exposure history from the exposed individual, or the individual most knowledgeable about the exposed individual's exposure to asbestos if the exposed individual is deceased, that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(b)(i): the exposed individual's principal places of employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(b)(ii): the exposed individual's exposure to airborne contaminants; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(b)(iii): whether the exposed individual's principal places of employment involved any exposure to airborne contaminants, including asbestos fibers or other disease-causing dusts or fumes that may cause a physical impairment and the nature, duration, and level of that exposure;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(c): a detailed medical, social, and smoking history from the exposed individual, or the individual most knowledgeable about the exposed individual's exposure to asbestos if the exposed individual is deceased, that includes a thorough review of the past and present medical problems of the exposed individual and the likely cause of the medical problems;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(d): evidence verifying that at least 15 years have passed between the exposed individual's date of first exposure to asbestos and the date of diagnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(e): evidence that the exposed individual has a permanent respiratory impairment rating of at least class 2 as defined by and evaluated in accordance with the AMA guides;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(f): evidence that asbestosis or diffuse bilateral pleural thickening, rather than chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, is a substantial factor to the exposed individual's physical impairment based on a determination that the exposed individual has:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(f)(i): FVC below the predicted lower limit of normal and a FEV1/FVC ratio, using actual values, equal to or above the predicted lower limit of normal;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(f)(ii): total lung capacity, by plethysmography or timed gas dilution, below the predicted lower limit of normal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(f)(iii): a chest x-ray showing bilateral small, irregular opacities, classified by width as s, t, or u, and graded by a certified B reader as at least 2/1 on the ILO system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(4)(g): a statement from the qualified physician that exposure to asbestos was a substantial contributing factor to the exposed individual's physical impairment and was likely not the result of any other cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(5): (4)(g) A statement by the qualified physician that the exposed individual's physical impairment is consistent with, or compatible with, an exposure to asbestos, or words to that effect, does not satisfy the requirements under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(6): Evidence relating to the prima facie showing under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(6)(a): shall comply with the quality controls, equipment requirements, methods of calibration, and techniques provided in the AMA guides and ATS testing standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(6)(b): may not be based on testing or examination that violates a law, regulation, licensing requirement, or medical ethics requirement of the state in which the test or examination was conducted;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(6)(c): may not be obtained under the condition that the plaintiff retains the services of the lawyer or law firm sponsoring the examination, test, or screening;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(6)(d): does not create a presumption that the exposed individual has an asbestos-related injury or impairment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(6)(e): is not conclusive as to the liability of any defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(7): A party in an asbestos action may not offer evidence at trial regarding, and the jury may not be informed of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(7)(a): the grant or denial of a motion to dismiss an asbestos action under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(7)(b): the requirements of a prima facie showing under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(8): (8)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(8)(a): (8)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2403(8)(b): The parties to an asbestos action may conduct discovery in regard to establishing or challenging a prima facie showing under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2404 Accrual of action alleging nonmalignant condition.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding the requirements of SectionUtah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2404(1): 78B-6-2403 the exposed individual is diagnosed with a physical impairment that meets the prima facie evidence requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2404(2): 78B-6-2403 the exposed individual discovered facts that would have led a reasonable individual to obtain a diagnosis with respect to the existence of a physical impairment from exposure to asbestos that would have met the prima facie evidence requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2404(3): the exposed individual dies.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405 Required disclosures by plaintiff in asbestos action within 120 days of trial. 
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(1): For each asbestos action filed in this state, the plaintiff shall provide all parties with a sworn declaration identifying all asbestos trust claims that have been filed by the plaintiff or by anyone on the plaintiff's behalf, including claims with respect to asbestos-related conditions other than those that are the basis for the asbestos action or that potentially could be filed by the plaintiff against an asbestos trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(2): The sworn declaration shall be provided no later than 120 days prior to the date set for trial for the asbestos action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(3): For each asbestos trust claim or potential asbestos trust claim identified in the sworn declaration, the sworn declaration shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(3)(a): the name, address and contact information for the asbestos trust;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(3)(b): the amount claimed or to be claimed by the plaintiff;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(3)(c): the date the plaintiff filed the claim;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(3)(d): the disposition of the claim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(3)(e): whether there has been a request to defer, delay, suspend, or toll the claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(4): The sworn declaration shall include an attestation from the plaintiff, under penalties of perjury, that the sworn declaration is complete and based on a good faith investigation of all potential claims against asbestos trusts.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(5): The plaintiff shall make available to all parties all trust claims materials for each asbestos trust claim that has been filed by the plaintiff or by anyone on the plaintiff's behalf against an asbestos trust, including any asbestos-related disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(6): The plaintiff shall supplement the information and materials provided pursuant to this section within 90 days after the day on which the plaintiff files an additional asbestos trust claim, supplements an existing asbestos trust claim, or receives additional information or materials related to any claim or potential claim against an asbestos trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(7): Failure by the plaintiff to make available to all parties all trust claims materials as required by this part shall constitute grounds for the court to extend the trial date in an asbestos action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(8): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(8)(a): (2) A court shall stay an asbestos action if the court finds that the plaintiff has failed to make the disclosures required by this section within the time period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2405(8)(b): If a plaintiff identifies a potential asbestos trust claim in the disclosures required by this section, the court may stay the asbestos action until the plaintiff files the asbestos trust claim and provides all parties with all trust claims materials for the asbestos trust claim.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406 Identification of additional or alternative asbestos trusts by defendant before trial.  
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(1): Not less than 90 days before trial, if a defendant identifies an asbestos trust claim not previously identified by the plaintiff that the defendant reasonably believes the plaintiff can file, the defendant shall meet and confer with the plaintiff to discuss why the defendant believes the plaintiff has an additional asbestos trust claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(2): (1) The defendant may move the court for an order to require the plaintiff to file the asbestos trust claim after the meeting under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(3): (2) The defendant shall produce or describe the documentation that the defendant possesses or is aware of in support of the motion under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(4): (2) Within 10 days after the day on which the plaintiff receives the defendant's motion under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(4)(a): file the asbestos trust claim;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(4)(b): file a written response with the court setting forth the reasons why there is insufficient evidence for the plaintiff to file the asbestos trust claim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(4)(c): file a written response with the court requesting a determination that the plaintiff's expenses or the plaintiff's attorney fees and expenses to prepare and file the asbestos trust claim identified in the defendant's motion exceed the plaintiff's reasonably anticipated recovery from the trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(5)(a): If the court determines that there is a sufficient basis for the plaintiff to file the asbestos trust claim identified by the defendant, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(5)(a)(i): order the plaintiff to file the asbestos trust claim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(5)(a)(ii): stay the asbestos action until the plaintiff files the asbestos trust claim and provides all parties with all trust claims materials no later than 30 days before trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2406(5)(b): If the court determines that the plaintiff's expenses or the plaintiff's attorney fees and expenses to prepare and file the asbestos trust claim identified in the defendant's motion exceed the plaintiff's reasonably anticipated recovery from the asbestos trust, the court shall stay the asbestos action until the plaintiff files with the court and provides all parties with a verified statement of the plaintiff's history of exposure, usage, or other connection to asbestos covered by the asbestos trust.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2407 Discovery of materials and documents for asbestos trust claim -- Use of asbestos trust materials.  
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2407(1): Trust claims materials and trust governance documents are presumed to be relevant and authentic and are admissible in evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2407(2): Claims of privilege may not apply to any trust claims materials or trust governance documents.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2407(3): A defendant in an asbestos action may seek discovery from an asbestos trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2407(4): The plaintiff may not claim privilege or confidentiality to bar discovery and shall provide consent or other expression of permission that may be required by the asbestos trust to release information and materials sought by a defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2407(5): If a plaintiff proceeds to trial in an asbestos action before an asbestos trust claim is resolved, the filing of the asbestos trust claim may be considered as relevant and admissible evidence.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(1): "Activate" means the process of powering on a device and associating the device with a user account.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(2): "Device" means a tablet or a smart phone manufactured on or after January 1, 2025.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(3): "Filter" means generally accepted and commercially reasonable software used on a device that is capable of preventing the device from accessing or displaying obscene material through Internet browsers or search engines owned or controlled by the manufacturer in accordance with prevailing industry standards including blocking known websites linked to obscene content via mobile data networks, wired Internet networks, and wireless Internet networks.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(4): 13-40-102 "Internet" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(5): 16-17-102 "Manufacturer" means a person that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(5)(a)(i): is engaged in the business of manufacturing a device;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(5)(a)(ii): holds the patents for the device the person manufactures; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(5)(a)(iii): holds the patents for the operating system on a device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(5)(b): 16-17-102 has a commercial registered agent as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(6): "Minor" means an individual under the age of 18 who is not emancipated, married, or a member of the armed forces of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(7): 32B-1-504 "Obscenity" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(8): "Operating system" means software that manages all of the other application
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(9): "Password" means a string of characters or other secure method used to enable, deactivate, modify, or uninstall a filter on a device.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(10)(a): "Retailer" means a person, that is not a manufacturer, that sells a device directly to consumers.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(10)(b): "Retailer" includes an employee of a retailer acting in the course and scope of the employee's employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(11): 63A-2-101.5 "Smart phone" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(12): "Tablet" means a mobile device that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(12)(a): is equipped with a mobile operating system, touchscreen display, and rechargeable battery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(12)(b): has the ability to support access to a cellular network.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2601(13): "Video game console" means a discrete computing system, including the system's components and peripherals, primarily used for playing video games, but does not include a smartphone or tablet.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2602 Filter required.
-------------------------------------------------
All devices activated in the state shall:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2602(1): contain a filter;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2602(2): ask the user to provide the user's age during activation and account set-up;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2602(3): automatically enable the filter when the user is a minor based on the age provided by the user as described in Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2602(4): allow a password to be established for the filter;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2602(5): notify the user of the device when the filter blocks the device from accessing a website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2602(6): allow a non-minor user who has a password the option to deactivate and re-activate the filter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603 Manufacturer liability.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(1): 78B-6-2602 A manufacturer of a device is subject to civil liability if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(1)(a): a device is activated in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(1)(b): 78B-6-2602 the device does not, upon activation in the state, enable a filter that complies with the requirements described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(1)(c): the minor accesses material that is obscene on the device.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(2): 78B-6-2602 Notwithstanding Subsection (1), this section does not apply to a manufacturer that makes a good faith effort to provide a device that, upon activation of the device in the state, automatically enables a filter in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(3): Nothing in this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(3)(a): applies to a device manufactured before January 1, 2025;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(3)(b): applies to a video game console; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2603(3)(c): creates a cause of action against a retailer of a device.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2604 Individual liability.
------------------------------------------------------
With the exception of a minor's parent or legal guardian, a person may be liable in a civil and criminal action for intentionally enabling the password to remove the filter on a device in the possession of a minor if the minor accesses content that is obscene on the device.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2605 Proceedings by the attorney general.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2605(1): The attorney general may bring an action in court against a person for a violation of this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2605(1)(a): to enjoin any action that constitutes a violation of this chapter by the issuance of a temporary restraining order or preliminary or permanent injunction;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2605(1)(b): to recover from a violator a civil penalty not to exceed $5,000 per violation, and not to exceed a total of $50,000 in aggregate, as determined by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2605(1)(c): to recover from a violator the attorney general's reasonable expenses, investigative costs, and attorney fees; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2605(1)(d): to obtain other appropriate relief as provided for under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2605(2): The attorney general may seek revocation of any license or certificate authorizing a manufacturer to engage in business in this state if, after the manufacturer is found to have violated provisions of this part, the manufacturer demonstrates a repeated pattern of violations of the provisions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-6-2605(3): 78B-6-2602 For purposes of assessing a penalty under this section, a manufacturer is considered to have committed a separate violation for each device manufactured on or after January 1, 2025, that violates the provisions of Section

This chapter is known and may be cited as "Protective Orders and Stalking Injunctions."

--------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-102(3)(b): Part 4, Dating Violence Protective Orders

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-102(11)(c)(i)(F): whether other reasons exist that support or detract from a finding that a dating relationship exists; and

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-109 Continuing duty to inform court of other proceedings -- Effect of other proceedings.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-109(1): Each party has a continuing duty to inform the court of each proceeding for a civil protective order or a criminal protective order, any civil litigation, each proceeding in juvenile court, and each criminal case involving either party, including the case name, the file number, and the county and state of the proceeding, if that information is known by the party.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-109(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-109(2)(a): A civil protective order issued under this chapter is in addition to and not in lieu of any other available civil or criminal proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-109(2)(b): A petitioner is not barred from seeking a civil protective order because of other pending proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-109(2)(c): A court may not delay granting a civil protective order under this chapter because of the existence of a pending civil action between the parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-109(3): A petitioner may omit the petitioner's address from all documents filed with the court under this chapter, but shall separately provide the court with a mailing address that is not to be made part of the public record, but that may be provided to a peace officer or entity for service of process.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-116(2)(a): A person entitled to protection under a foreign protection order may file the order in any district court by filing with the court a certified copy of the order.  A filing fee may not be required.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-116(2)(b): The person filing the foreign protection order shall swear under oath in an affidavit, that to the best of the person's knowledge the order is presently in effect as written and the respondent was personally served with a copy of the order.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-116(2)(f): After a foreign protection order is filed, the district court shall furnish a certified copy of the order to the person who filed the order.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117 Court order for transfer of wireless telephone number.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(1): As used in this section, "wireless service provider" means a provider of commercial mobile service under Section 332(d) of the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(2): 78B-7-804; 78B-7-603 At or after the time that a court issues a sentencing protective order or continuous protective order under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(2)(a): the perpetrator is the account holder for the wireless telephone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(2)(b): the number is assigned to a telephone that is primarily used by the victim or an individual who will reside with the victim during the time that the protective order or the order of protection is in effect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(2)(c): the victim requests transfer of the wireless telephone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(3): An order transferring a wireless telephone number under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(3)(a): direct a wireless service provider to transfer the rights to, and the billing responsibility for, the wireless telephone number to the victim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(3)(b): include the wireless telephone number to be transferred, the name of the transferee, and the name of the account holder.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(4): A wireless service provider shall comply with an order issued under this section, unless compliance is not reasonably possible due to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(4)(a): the account holder having already terminated the account;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(4)(b): differences in network technology that prevent the victim's device from functioning on the network to which the number is to be transferred;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(4)(c): geographic or other service availability constraints; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(4)(d): other barriers outside the control of the wireless service provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(5): A wireless service provider that fails to comply with an order issued under this section shall, within four business days after the day on which the wireless service provider receives the order, provide notice to the victim stating:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(5)(a): that the wireless service provider is not able to reasonably comply with the order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(5)(b): the reason that the wireless service provider is not able to reasonably comply with the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(6): The victim has full financial responsibility for each wireless telephone number transferred to the victim by an order under this section, beginning on the day on which the wireless telephone number is transferred, including monthly service costs and costs for any mobile device associated with the wireless telephone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(7): (6) This section does not preclude a wireless service provider from applying standard requirements for account establishment to the victim when transferring financial responsibility under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-117(8): A wireless service provider, and any officer, employee, or agent of the wireless service provider, is not civilly liable for action taken in compliance with an order issued under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-118 Construction with Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
To the extent the provisions of this chapter are more specific than the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure regarding a civil protective order the provisions of this chapter govern.
