Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204 Content of orders -- Modification of orders -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(1): 76-5-108 A child protective order or an ex parte child protective order may contain the following provisions the violation of which is a class A misdemeanor under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(1)(a): enjoin the respondent from threatening to commit or committing abuse of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(1)(b): prohibit the respondent from harassing, telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the child, directly or indirectly;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(1)(c): prohibit the respondent from entering or remaining upon the residence, school, or place of employment of the child and the premises of any of these or any specified place frequented by the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(1)(d): upon finding that the respondent's use or possession of a weapon may pose a serious threat of harm to the child, prohibit the respondent from purchasing, using, or possessing a firearm or other specified weapon; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(1)(e): determine ownership and possession of personal property and direct the appropriate law enforcement officer to attend and supervise the petitioner's or respondent's removal of personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(2): A child protective order or an ex parte child protective order may contain the following provisions the violation of which is contempt of court:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(2)(a): determine temporary custody of the child who is the subject of the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(2)(b): determine parent-time with the child who is the subject of the petition, including denial of parent-time if necessary to protect the safety of the child, and require supervision of parent-time by a third party;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(2)(c): determine child support in accordance with Title 81, Chapter 6, Child Support; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(2)(d): order any further relief the court considers necessary to provide for the safety and welfare of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(3)(a): If the child who is the subject of the child protective order attends the same school or place of worship as the respondent, or is employed at the same place of employment as the respondent, the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(3)(a)(i): may not enter an order under Subsection (1)(c) that excludes the respondent from the respondent's school, place of worship, or place of employment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(3)(a)(ii): may enter an order governing the respondent's conduct at the respondent's school, place of worship, or place of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(3)(b): A violation of an order under Subsection (3)(a) is contempt of court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(a): A respondent may petition the court to modify or vacate a child protective order after notice and a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(b): At the hearing described in Subsection (4)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(b)(i): the respondent shall have the burden of proving by clear and convincing evidence that modification or vacation of the child protective order is in the best interest of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(b)(ii): the court shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(b)(ii)(A): the nature and duration of the abuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(b)(ii)(B): the pain and trauma inflicted on the child as a result of the abuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(b)(ii)(C): if the respondent is a parent of the child, any reunification services provided in accordance with Title 80, Chapter 3, Abuse, Neglect, and Dependency Proceedings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(b)(ii)(D): any other evidence the court finds relevant to the determination of the child's best interests, including recommendations by the other parent or a guardian of the child, or a mental health professional.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-204(4)(c): The child is not required to attend the hearing described in Subsection (4)(a).

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-301 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Uniform Interstate Enforcement of Domestic Violence Protection Orders Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302(1): "Foreign protection order" means a protection order issued by a tribunal of another state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302(2): "Issuing state" means the state whose tribunal issues a protection order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302(3): "Mutual foreign protection order" means a foreign protection order that includes provisions in favor of both the protected individual seeking enforcement of the order and the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302(4): "Protected individual" means an individual protected by a protection order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302(5): "Protection order" means an injunction or other order, issued by a tribunal under the domestic violence, family-violence, or anti-stalking laws of the issuing state, to prevent an individual from engaging in violent or threatening acts against, harassment of, contact or communication with, or physical proximity to, another individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302(6): "Respondent" means the individual against whom enforcement of a protection order is sought.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302(7): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.  The term includes an Indian tribe or band that has jurisdiction to issue protection orders.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-302(8): "Tribunal" means a court, agency, or other entity authorized by law to issue or modify a protection order.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303 Judicial enforcement of order.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(1): A person authorized by the law of this state to seek enforcement of a protection order may seek enforcement of a valid foreign protection order in a tribunal of this state.  The tribunal shall enforce the terms of the order, including terms that provide relief that a tribunal of this state would lack power to provide but for this section.  The tribunal shall enforce the order, whether the order was obtained by independent action or in another proceeding, if it is an order issued in response to a complaint, petition, or motion filed by or on behalf of an individual seeking protection.  In a proceeding to enforce a foreign protection order, the tribunal shall follow the procedures of this state for the enforcement of protection orders.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(2): A tribunal of this state may not enforce a foreign protection order issued by a tribunal of a state that does not recognize the standing of a protected individual to seek enforcement of the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(3): A tribunal of this state shall enforce the provisions of a valid foreign protection order which govern custody and visitation, if the order was issued in accordance with the jurisdictional requirements governing the issuance of custody and visitation orders in the issuing state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(4): A foreign protection order is valid if it:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(4)(a): identifies the protected individual and the respondent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(4)(b): is currently in effect;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(4)(c): was issued by a tribunal that had jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter under the law of the issuing state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(4)(d): was issued after the respondent was given reasonable notice and had an opportunity to be heard before the tribunal issued the order or, in the case of an order ex parte, the respondent was given notice and has had or will have an opportunity to be heard within a reasonable time after the order was issued, in a manner consistent with the rights of the respondent to due process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(5): A foreign protection order valid on its face is prima facie evidence of its validity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(6): Absence of any of the criteria for validity of a foreign protection order is an affirmative defense in an action seeking enforcement of the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(7): A tribunal of this state may enforce provisions of a mutual foreign protection order which favor a respondent only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(7)(a): the respondent filed a written pleading seeking a protection order from the tribunal of the issuing state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(7)(b): the tribunal of the issuing state made specific findings in favor of the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(8): (8)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(8)(a): The juvenile court has jurisdiction to enforce foreign protection orders under this section over which the juvenile court would have had jurisdiction if the order had been originally sought in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(8)(b): (8)(a) The district court has jurisdiction to enforce foreign protection orders under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(8)(b)(i): over which the district court would have had jurisdiction if the order had been originally sought in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-303(8)(b)(ii): (8)(a) that are not under the jurisdiction of the juvenile court under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-304 Nonjudicial enforcement of order.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-304(1): A law enforcement officer of this state, upon determining that there is probable cause to believe that a valid foreign protection order exists and that the order has been violated, shall enforce the order as if it were the order of a tribunal of this state.  Presentation of a protection order that identifies both the protected individual and the respondent and, on its face, is currently in effect constitutes probable cause to believe that a valid foreign protection order exists.  For the purposes of this section, the protection order may be inscribed on a tangible medium or may have been stored in an electronic or other medium if it is retrievable in perceivable form.  Presentation of a certified copy of a protection order is not required for enforcement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-304(2): If a foreign protection order is not presented, a law enforcement officer of this state may consider other information in determining whether there is probable cause to believe that a valid foreign protection order exists.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-304(3): If a law enforcement officer of this state determines that an otherwise valid foreign protection order cannot be enforced because the respondent has not been notified or served with the order, the officer shall inform the respondent of the order, make a reasonable effort to serve the order upon the respondent, and allow the respondent a reasonable opportunity to comply with the order before enforcing the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-304(4): Registration or filing of an order in this state is not required for the enforcement of a valid foreign protection order pursuant to this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-305 Registration of order.
------------------------------------------------------
Any individual may register a foreign protection order in this state under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-306 Immunity.
-----------------------------------------
This state or a local governmental agency, or a law enforcement officer, prosecuting attorney, clerk of court, or any state or local governmental official acting in an official capacity, is immune from civil and criminal liability for an act or omission arising out of the registration or enforcement of a foreign protection order or the detention or arrest of an alleged violator of a foreign protection order if the act or omission was done in good faith in an effort to comply with this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-307 Other remedies.
-----------------------------------------------
A protected individual who pursues remedies under this part is not precluded from pursuing other legal or equitable remedies against the respondent.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-308 Uniformity of application and construction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration must be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-309 Severability clause.
----------------------------------------------------
If any provision of this part or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect other provisions or applications of this part which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this part are severable.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-310 Transitional provision.
-------------------------------------------------------
This part applies to protection orders issued before July 1, 2006 and to continuing actions for enforcement of foreign protection orders commenced before July 1, 2006.  A request for enforcement of a foreign protection order made on or after July 1, 2006 for violations of a foreign protection order occurring before July 1, 2006 is governed by this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-402 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-402(1): "Dating violence protective order" means an order issued under this part after a hearing on the petition, of which the petitioner and respondent have been given notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-402(2): "Ex parte dating violence protective order" means an order issued without notice to the respondent under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-402(3): "Protective order" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-402(3)(a): a dating violence protective order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-402(3)(b): an ex parte dating violence protective order.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403 Abuse or danger of abuse -- Dating violence protective orders.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(1): An individual may seek a protective order if the individual is subjected to, or there is a substantial likelihood the individual will be subjected to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(1)(a): abuse by a dating partner of the individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(1)(b): dating violence by a dating partner of the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(2): (1) An individual may seek an order described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(3): (1) An individual seeking a protective order may include another party in the petition for a protective order if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(3)(a): (1) the individual seeking the order meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(3)(b): the other party:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(3)(b)(i): is a family or household member of the individual seeking the protective order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(3)(b)(ii): there is a substantial likelihood the other party will be subjected to abuse by the dating partner of the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(4): An individual seeking a protective order under this part shall, to the extent possible, provide information to facilitate identification of the respondent, including a name, social security number, driver license number, date of birth, address, telephone number, and physical description.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(5): A petition seeking a protective order under this part may not be withdrawn without written order of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(6): Part 6, Cohabitant Abuse Protective Orders
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(6)(a): An individual may not seek a protective order against an intimate partner of the individual under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-403(6)(b): Part 6, Cohabitant Abuse Protective Orders An individual may seek a protective order against a cohabitant or an intimate partner of the individual under


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404 Dating violence protective orders -- Ex parte dating violence protective orders -- Modification of orders -- Service of process -- Duties of the court.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(1): If it appears from a petition for a protective order or a petition to modify an existing protective order that a dating partner of the petitioner has abused or committed dating violence against the petitioner, the court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(1)(a): without notice, immediately issue an ex parte dating violence protective order against the dating partner or modify an existing dating protective order ex parte if necessary to protect the petitioner and all parties named in the petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(1)(b): upon notice to the respondent, issue a dating violence protective order or modify a dating violence protective order after a hearing, regardless of whether the respondent appears.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2): (4) A court may grant the following relief without notice in a dating violence protective order or a modification issued ex parte:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(a): prohibit the respondent from threatening to commit or committing dating violence or abuse against the petitioner and any designated family or household member described in the protective order;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(b): prohibit the respondent from telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the petitioner or any designated family or household member, directly or indirectly;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(c): (4) order that the respondent:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(c)(i): is excluded and shall stay away from the petitioner's residence and its premises;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(c)(ii): (4) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(c)(ii)(A): school and the school's premises; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(c)(ii)(B): place of employment and its premises; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(c)(iii): stay away from any specified place frequented by the petitioner or any designated family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(d): prohibit the respondent from being within a specified distance of the petitioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(e): prohibit the respondent from physically injuring, threatening to injure, or taking possession of a household animal that is owned or kept by the petitioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(f): prohibit the respondent from physically injuring or threatening to injure a household animal that is owned or kept by the respondent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(2)(g): order any further relief that the court considers necessary to provide for the safety and welfare of the petitioner and any designated family or household member.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(3): (2); (5) A court may grant the following relief in a dating violence protective order or a modification of a dating violence protective order, after notice and a hearing, regardless of whether the respondent appears:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(3)(a): (2) the relief described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(3)(b): (5) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(4): (2)(c)(ii) If the petitioner or a family or household member designated in the protective order attends the same school as the respondent, or is employed at the same place of employment as the respondent, the district court:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(4)(a): (2)(c)(ii) may not enter an order under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(4)(b): may enter an order governing the respondent's conduct at the respondent's school or place of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(5): The court may not prohibit the respondent from possessing a firearm:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(5)(a): if the respondent has not been given notice of the petition for a protective order and an opportunity to be heard; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(5)(b): unless the petition establishes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(5)(b)(i): by a preponderance of the  evidence that the respondent has committed abuse or dating violence against the petitioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(5)(b)(ii): by clear and convincing evidence that the respondent's use or possession of a firearm poses a serious threat of harm to petitioner or the designated family or household member.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(6): 78B-7-113 After the court issues a dating violence protective order, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(6)(a): as soon as possible, deliver the order to the county sheriff for service of process;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(6)(b): make reasonable efforts at the hearing to ensure that the dating violence protective order is understood by the petitioner and the respondent, if present;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(6)(c): transmit electronically, by the end of the business day after the day on which the order is issued, a copy of the dating violence protective order to the local law enforcement agency designated by the petitioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(6)(d): 78B-7-113 transmit a copy of the protective order issued under this part in the same manner as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(7): (6)(a); 78B-7-113
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(7)(a): (6)(a); 78B-7-113 The county sheriff that receives the order from the court, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(7)(a)(i): provide expedited service for protective orders issued in accordance with this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(7)(a)(ii): 78B-7-113 after the order has been served, transmit verification of service of process to the statewide network described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(7)(b): This section does not prohibit another law enforcement agency from providing service of process if that law enforcement agency:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(7)(b)(i): has contact with the respondent and service by that law enforcement agency is possible; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(7)(b)(ii): determines that, under the circumstances, providing service of process on the respondent is in the best interests of the petitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(8): When a protective order is served on a respondent in jail, or other holding facility, the law enforcement agency managing the facility shall make a reasonable effort to provide notice to the petitioner at the time the respondent is released from incarceration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(9): A court may modify or vacate a protective order under this part after notice and hearing, if the petitioner:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(9)(a): is personally served with notice of the hearing, as provided in the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, and appears before the court to give specific consent to the modification or vacation of the provisions of the protective order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-404(9)(b): submits an affidavit agreeing to the modification or vacation of the provisions of the protective order.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-407 Penalties.
------------------------------------------
A violation of a protective order issued under this part is a class A misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408 Duties of law enforcement officers -- Notice to victims.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(1): (2) A law enforcement officer who responds to an allegation of dating violence shall use all reasonable means to protect the victim and prevent further violence, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(1)(a): taking action that, in the officer's discretion, is reasonably necessary to provide for the safety of the victim and any family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(1)(b): confiscating the weapon or weapons involved in the alleged dating violence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(1)(c): making arrangements for the victim and any child to obtain emergency housing or shelter;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(1)(d): providing protection while the victim removes essential personal effects;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(1)(e): arranging, facilitating, or providing for the victim and any child to obtain medical treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(1)(f): (2) arranging, facilitating, or providing the victim with immediate and adequate notice of the rights of victims and of the remedies and services available to victims of dating violence, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(2)(a): A law enforcement officer shall give written notice to the victim in simple language, describing the rights and remedies available under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(2)(b): The written notice shall also include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(2)(b)(i): a statement that the forms needed in order to obtain a protective order are available from the court clerk's office in the judicial district where the victim resides or is temporarily domiciled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(2)(b)(ii): a list of shelters, services, and resources available in the appropriate community, together with telephone numbers, to assist the victim in accessing any needed assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-408(3): If a weapon is confiscated under this section, the law enforcement agency shall return the weapon to the individual from whom the weapon is confiscated if a dating protective order is not issued or once the dating protective order is terminated.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-409 Mutual dating violence protective orders.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-409(1)(a): files an independent petition against the other for a dating violence protective order, and both petitions are served;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-409(1)(b): makes a showing at a due process dating violence protective order hearing of abuse or dating violence committed by the other party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-409(1)(c): demonstrates the abuse or dating violence did not occur in self-defense.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-409(2): (1) If the court issues mutual dating violence protective orders, the court shall include specific findings of all elements of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(1): "Ex parte sexual violence protective order" means an order issued without notice to the respondent under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(2): "Protective order" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(2)(a): a sexual violence protective order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(2)(b): an ex parte sexual violence protective order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(3): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 5b, Part 2, Sexual Exploitation; 76-5-308.1; 76-5-310 "Sexual violence" means the commission or the attempt to commit:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(3)(a): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 5b, Part 2, Sexual Exploitation any sexual offense described in
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(3)(b): 76-5-308.1 human trafficking for sexual exploitation under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(3)(c): 76-5-310 aggravated human trafficking for forced sexual exploitation under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-502(4): "Sexual violence protective order" means an order issued under this part after a hearing on the petition, of which the petitioner and respondent have been given notice.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-503 Sexual violence -- Sexual violence protective orders.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-503(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-503(1)(a): An individual may seek a protective order under this part if the individual has been subjected to sexual violence and is neither a cohabitant nor a dating partner of the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-503(1)(b): An individual may not seek a protective order on behalf of a child under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-503(2): A petition seeking a sexual violence protective order may not be withdrawn without written order of the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504 Sexual violence protective orders -- Ex parte protective orders -- Modification of orders.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(1): If it appears from a petition for a protective order or a petition to modify an existing protective order that sexual violence has occurred, the district court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(1)(a): without notice, immediately issue an ex parte sexual violence protective order against the respondent or modify an existing sexual violence protective order ex parte, if necessary to protect the petitioner or any party named in the petition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(1)(b): upon notice to the respondent, issue a sexual violence protective order or modify a sexual violence protective order after a hearing, regardless of whether the respondent appears.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2): (4) The district court may grant the following relief with or without notice in a protective order or in a modification to a protective order:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(a): prohibit the respondent from threatening to commit or committing sexual violence against the petitioner and a family or household member designated in the protective order;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(b): prohibit the respondent from telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the petitioner or a family or household member designated in the protective order, directly or indirectly;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(c): (4) order that the respondent:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(c)(i): is excluded and shall stay away from the petitioner's residence and its premises;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(c)(ii): (4) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(c)(ii)(A): school and its premises;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(c)(ii)(B): place of employment and its premises; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(c)(ii)(C): place of worship and its premises; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(c)(iii): stay away from any specified place frequented by the petitioner or a family or household member designated in the protective order;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(d): prohibit the respondent from being within a specified distance of the petitioner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(2)(e): order any further relief that the district court considers necessary to provide for the safety and welfare of the petitioner and a family or household member designated in the protective order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(3): (2); (5) The district court may grant the following relief in a sexual violence protective order or a modification of a sexual violence protective order, after notice and a hearing, regardless of whether the respondent appears:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(3)(a): (2) the relief described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(3)(b): (5) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(4): If the petitioner or a family or household member designated in the protective order attends the same school as the respondent, is employed at the same place of employment as the respondent, or attends the same place of worship as the respondent, the court may enter an order:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(4)(a): that excludes the respondent from the respondent's school, place of employment, or place of worship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(4)(b): governing the respondent's conduct at the respondent's school, place of employment, or place of worship.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(5): The district court may not prohibit the respondent from possessing a firearm:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(5)(a): if the respondent has not been given notice of the petition for a protective order and an opportunity to be heard; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(5)(b): unless the petition establishes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(5)(b)(i): by a preponderance of the evidence that the respondent committed sexual violence against the petitioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(5)(b)(ii): by clear and convincing evidence that the respondent's use or possession of a firearm poses a serious threat of harm to the petitioner or a family or household member designated in the protective order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(6): 78B-7-113 After the day on which the district court issues a sexual violence protective order, the district court shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-504(6)(c): transmit electronically, by the end of the business day after the day on which the court issues the order, a copy of the sexual violence protective order to a local law enforcement agency designated by the petitioner; and

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509 Duties of law enforcement officers -- Notice to victims.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(1): (2) A law enforcement officer who responds to an allegation of sexual violence shall use all reasonable means to protect the victim and prevent further sexual violence, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(1)(a): taking action that, in the officer's discretion, is reasonably necessary to provide for the safety of the victim and any family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(1)(b): making arrangements for the victim and any child to obtain emergency housing or shelter;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(1)(c): arranging, facilitating, or providing for the victim and any child to obtain medical treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(1)(d): (2) arranging, facilitating, or providing the victim with immediate and adequate notice of the rights of the victim and of the remedies and services available to victims of sexual violence, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(2)(a): A law enforcement officer shall give written notice to the victim in simple language, describing the rights and remedies available under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(2)(b): The written notice shall also include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(2)(b)(i): a statement that the forms needed in order to obtain a protective order are available from the court clerk's office in the judicial district where the victim resides or is temporarily domiciled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-509(2)(b)(ii): a list of shelters, services, and resources available in the appropriate community, together with telephone numbers, to assist the victim in accessing any needed assistance.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-601(1): "Cohabitant abuse protective order" means an order issued under this part after a hearing on the petition, of which the petitioner and respondent have been given notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-601(2): "Ex parte cohabitant abuse protective order" means an order issued without notice to the respondent under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-601(3): "Protective order" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-601(3)(a): a cohabitant abuse protective order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-601(3)(b): an ex parte cohabitant abuse protective order.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-602 Abuse or danger of abuse -- Cohabitant abuse protective orders.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-602(1): Any cohabitant who has been subjected to abuse or domestic violence, or to whom there is a substantial likelihood of abuse or domestic violence, may seek a protective order in accordance with this part, whether or not the cohabitant has left the residence or the premises in an effort to avoid further abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-602(2): A petition for a protective order may be filed under this part regardless of whether an action for divorce between the parties is pending.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-602(3): A petition seeking a protective order may not be withdrawn without approval of the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605 Dismissal.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(1): 78B-7-603 Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(1)(a): the basis for the issuance of the protective order no longer exists;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(1)(b): the petitioner has repeatedly acted in contravention of the protective order provisions to intentionally or knowingly induce the respondent to violate the protective order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(1)(c): the petitioner's actions demonstrate that the petitioner no longer has a reasonable fear of the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(2): The court shall enter sanctions against either party if the court determines that either party acted:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(2)(a): in bad faith; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(2)(b): with intent to harass or intimidate the other party.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(3): If a divorce proceeding is pending between parties to a protective order action, the court shall dismiss the protective order when the court issues a decree of divorce for the parties if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(3)(a): the respondent files a motion to dismiss a protective order in both the divorce action and the protective order action and personally serves the petitioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(3)(b)(i): the parties stipulate in writing or on the record to dismiss the protective order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-605(3)(b)(ii): based on evidence at the divorce trial, the court determines that the petitioner no longer has a reasonable fear of future harm, abuse, or domestic violence.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-607 Penalties.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-607(1): A violation of a criminal provision of a protective order issued under this part is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-607(2): A violation of a civil provision of a protective order issued under this part is contempt of court.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-608 No denial of relief solely because of lapse of time.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court may not deny a petitioner relief requested under this part solely because of a lapse of time between an act of domestic violence or abuse and the filing of the petition for a protective order.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-609 Prohibition of court-ordered or court-referred mediation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any case brought under the provisions of this part, the court may not order the parties into mediation for resolution of the issues in a petition for a protective order.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701 Ex parte civil stalking injunction -- Civil stalking injunction.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(1): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(1)(a): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(1)(a)(i): (1)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(1)(a)(ii): A minor with the minor's parent or guardian may file a petition on the minor's own behalf, or a parent, guardian, or custodian may file a petition on the minor's behalf.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(1)(b): A stalking injunction may not be obtained against a law enforcement officer, governmental investigator, or licensed private investigator, who is acting in official capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(2): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(2)(a): (2)(b) Except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(2)(a)(v): corroborating evidence of stalking, which may be in the form of a police report, affidavit, record, statement, item, letter, or any other evidence which tends to prove the allegation of stalking.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(2)(b)(i): The petitioner's address shall be disclosed to the court for purposes of service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(2)(b)(ii): On request of the petitioner, the petitioner's address may not be listed on the petition, and shall be protected and maintained in a separate document or automated database, not subject to release, disclosure, or any form of public access except as ordered by the court for good cause shown.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3): 78B-7-603
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3)(a): If the court determines that there is reason to believe that an offense of stalking has occurred, an ex parte civil stalking injunction may be issued by the court that includes any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3)(a)(i): respondent may be enjoined from committing stalking;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3)(a)(ii): respondent may be restrained from coming near the residence, place of employment, or school of the other party or specifically designated locations or persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3)(a)(iii): respondent may be restrained from contacting, directly or indirectly, the other party, including personal, written or telephone contact with the other party, the other party's employers, employees, fellow workers or others with whom communication would be likely to cause annoyance or alarm to the other party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3)(a)(iv): any other relief necessary or convenient for the protection of the petitioner and other specifically designated individuals under the circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3)(b): 78B-7-603
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3)(b)(i): 78B-7-603 If the petitioner and respondent have minor children, the court shall follow the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(3)(b)(ii): If the court issues a civil stalking injunction, but declines to address custody and parent-time issues, a copy of the stalking injunction shall be filed in any action in which custody and parent-time issues are being considered.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(a): Within 10 days after the day on which the the ex parte civil stalking injunction is served, the respondent is entitled to request, in writing, an evidentiary hearing on the civil stalking injunction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(b)(i): The court shall hold a hearing requested by the respondent at the earliest possible time and within 10 days after the day on which the request is filed with the court unless the court finds compelling reasons to continue the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(b)(ii): At the hearing, the burden is on the petitioner to show by a preponderance of the evidence that stalking of the petitioner by the respondent has occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(c): An ex parte civil stalking injunction issued under this section shall state on the civil stalking injunction's face:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(c)(i): that the respondent is entitled to a hearing, upon written request within 10 days after the day on which the order is served;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(c)(ii): the name and address of the court where the request may be filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(c)(iii): that if the respondent fails to request a hearing within 10 days after the day on which the ex parte civil stalking injunction is served, the ex parte civil stalking injunction is automatically modified to a civil stalking injunction without further notice to the respondent and the civil stalking injunction expires three years after the day on which the ex parte civil stalking injunction is served; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(4)(c)(iv): that if the respondent requests, in writing, a hearing after the ten-day period after service, the court shall set a hearing within a reasonable time from the date requested.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(5)(a): At the hearing, the court may modify, revoke, or continue the injunction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(5)(b): At the hearing, the burden is on the petitioner to show by a preponderance of the evidence that stalking of the petitioner by the respondent has occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(6)(a): The ex parte civil stalking injunction shall be served on the respondent within 90 days after the day on which the ex parte civil stalking injunction is signed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(6)(b): An ex parte civil stalking injunction is effective upon service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(6)(c): If a hearing is not requested in writing by the respondent within 10 days after the day on which the ex parte civil stalking injunction is served, the ex parte civil stalking injunction automatically becomes a civil stalking injunction without further notice to the respondent and expires three years after the day on which the ex parte civil stalking injunction is served.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(7)(a): If the respondent requests a hearing after the 10-day period after service, the court shall set a hearing within a reasonable time from the date requested.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(7)(b): At the hearing, the burden is on the respondent to show good cause why the civil stalking injunction should be dissolved or modified.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(8)(a): Within 24 hours after the affidavit or acceptance of service is returned, excluding weekends and holidays, the clerk of the court from which the ex parte civil stalking injunction was issued shall enter a copy of the ex parte civil stalking injunction and proof of service or acceptance of service in the statewide network for warrants or a similar system.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(8)(b): The effectiveness of an ex parte civil stalking injunction or civil stalking injunction does not depend upon entry of the ex parte civil stalking injunction or civil stalking injunction in the statewide system and, for enforcement purposes, a certified copy of an ex parte civil stalking injunction or civil stalking injunction is presumed to be a valid existing order of the court for a period of three years after the day on which the ex parte civil stalking injunction is served on the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(8)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(8)(c)(i): Any changes or modifications of the ex parte civil stalking injunction are effective upon service on the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(8)(c)(ii): The original ex parte civil stalking injunction continues in effect until service of the changed or modified civil stalking injunction on the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(9): Within 24 hours after the affidavit or acceptance of service is returned, excluding weekends and holidays, the clerk of the court shall enter a copy of the changed or modified civil stalking injunction and proof of service or acceptance of service in the statewide network for warrants or a similar system.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(10): The ex parte civil stalking injunction or civil stalking injunction may be dissolved at any time upon application of the petitioner to the court that granted the ex parte civil stalking injunction or civil stalking injunction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(11): An ex parte civil stalking injunction and a civil stalking injunction shall be served by a sheriff or constable in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(12): The remedies provided in this chapter for enforcement of the orders of the court are in addition to any other civil and criminal remedies available.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(13): The court shall hear and decide all matters arising under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(14): After a hearing with notice to the affected party, the court may enter an order requiring any party to pay the costs of the action, including reasonable attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-701(15): This section does not apply to preliminary injunctions issued under an action for dissolution of marriage or legal separation.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-703 Violation.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-703(1): 76-5-106.5 A violation of an ex parte civil stalking injunction or of a civil stalking injunction issued under this part constitutes the criminal offense of stalking under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-703(2): A violation of an ex parte civil stalking injunction or of a civil stalking injunction issued under this part may be enforced by a civil action initiated by the petitioner, a criminal action initiated by a prosecuting attorney, or both.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801 Definitions.

As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(1): (1)(a); 80-6-201
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(1)(a): "Jail release agreement" means a written agreement that is entered into by an individual who is arrested or issued a citation, regardless of whether the individual is booked into jail:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(1)(a)(i): under which the arrested or cited individual agrees to not engage in any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(1)(a)(i)(A): telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the alleged victim, directly or indirectly;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(1)(a)(i)(C): knowingly entering onto the premises of the alleged victim's residence or on premises temporarily occupied by the alleged victim, unless, after a law enforcement officer or the law enforcement officer's employing agency notifies or attempts to notify the alleged victim, the individual enters the premises while accompanied by a law enforcement officer for the purpose of retrieving the individual's personal belongings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(1)(a)(ii): that specifies other conditions of release from jail or arrest.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(2)(a): orders an arrested or cited individual not to engage in any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(2)(a)(i): telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the alleged victim, directly or indirectly;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(2)(a)(ii): threatening or harassing the alleged victim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-801(2)(a)(iii): knowingly entering onto the premises of the alleged victim's residence or on premises temporarily occupied by the alleged victim, unless, after a law enforcement officer or the law enforcement officer's employing agency notifies or attempts to notify the alleged victim, the individual enters the premises while accompanied by a law enforcement officer for the purpose of retrieving the individual's personal belongings; and

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803 Pretrial protective orders.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(1): 77-36-2.6; (4); 77-36-2.1; 78B-7-804; 78B-7-805; Title 80, Chapter 6, Part 7, Adjudication and Disposition
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(1)(a): 77-36-2.6 When an alleged perpetrator is charged with a crime involving a qualifying offense, the court shall, at the time of the alleged perpetrator's court appearance under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(1)(a)(i): determine the necessity of imposing a pretrial protective order or other condition of pretrial release; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(1)(a)(ii): state the court's findings and determination in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(1)(b): (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(1)(c): 77-36-2.1 When determining the necessity of imposing a pretrial protective order or other condition of pretrial release, a court may consider the results of any relevant lethality assessment conducted in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2): A court may include any of the following provisions in a pretrial protective order:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2)(a): an order enjoining the alleged perpetrator from threatening to commit or committing acts of domestic violence or abuse against the victim and any designated family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2)(b): an order prohibiting the alleged perpetrator from harassing, telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the victim, directly or indirectly;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2)(c): an order removing and excluding the alleged perpetrator from the victim's residence and the premises of the residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2)(d): an order requiring the alleged perpetrator to stay away from the victim's residence, school, or place of employment, and the premises of any of these, or any specified place frequented by the victim and any designated family member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2)(e): an order for any other relief that the court considers necessary to protect and provide for the safety of the victim and any designated family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2)(f): an order identifying and requiring an individual designated by the victim to communicate between the alleged perpetrator and the victim if and to the extent necessary for family related matters;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2)(g): an order requiring the alleged perpetrator to participate in an electronic or other type of monitoring program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(2)(h): if the alleged victim and the alleged perpetrator share custody of one or more minor children, an order for indirect or limited contact to temporarily facilitate parent visitation with a minor child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(3): If the court issues a pretrial protective order, the court shall determine whether to allow provisions for transfer of personal property to decrease the need for contact between the parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(4): A pretrial protective order issued under this section against an alleged perpetrator who is a minor expires on the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(4)(a): 78B-7-804; 78B-7-805 the day on which the alleged perpetrator is served with an order issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(4)(b): Title 80, Chapter 6, Part 7, Adjudication and Disposition the day on which the court makes a disposition of the alleged perpetrator's case under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(4)(c): the day on which the juvenile court terminates jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(5): 78B-7-804; 78B-7-805 A pretrial protective order issued under this section against an alleged perpetrator who is not a minor expires on the earliest of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(5)(a): the day on which the court dismisses the case;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(5)(b): the day on which the court dismisses the pretrial protective order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-803(5)(c): 78B-7-804; 78B-7-805 the day on which the alleged perpetrator is served with an order issued under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804 Sentencing and continuous protective orders for a domestic violence offense -- Modification -- Expiration.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(1): Before a perpetrator who has been convicted of or adjudicated for a domestic violence offense may be placed on probation, the court shall consider the safety and protection of the victim and any member of the victim's family or household.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(2): The court may condition probation or a plea in abeyance on the perpetrator's compliance with a sentencing protective order that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(2)(a): an order enjoining the perpetrator from threatening to commit or committing acts of domestic violence against the victim or other family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(2)(b): an order prohibiting the perpetrator from harassing, telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the victim, directly or indirectly;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(2)(c): an order requiring the perpetrator to stay away from the victim's residence, school, place of employment, and the premises of any of these, or a specified place frequented regularly by the victim or any designated family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(2)(d): an order prohibiting the perpetrator from purchasing, using, or possessing a firearm or other specified weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(2)(e): an order directing the perpetrator to surrender any weapons the perpetrator owns or possesses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(2)(f): an order imposing any other condition necessary to protect the victim and any other designated family or household member or to rehabilitate the perpetrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(a): Because of the serious, unique, and highly traumatic nature of domestic violence crimes, the high recidivism rate of violent offenders, and the demonstrated increased risk of continued acts of violence subsequent to the release of a perpetrator who is convicted of or adjudicated for domestic violence, it is the finding of the Legislature that domestic violence crimes warrant the issuance of continuous protective orders under this Subsection (3) because of the need to provide ongoing protection for the victim and to be consistent with the purposes of protecting victims' rights under Title 77, Chapter 38, Crime Victims, and Article I, Section 28 of the Utah Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(b): Except as provided in Subsection (6), if a perpetrator is convicted of a domestic violence offense resulting in a sentence of imprisonment, including jail, that is to be served after conviction, the court shall issue a continuous protective order at the time of the conviction or sentencing limiting the contact between the perpetrator and the victim unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(b)(i): the court determines by clear and convincing evidence that the victim does not a have a reasonable fear of future harm or abuse; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(b)(ii): the court conducts a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(c)(i): The court shall notify the perpetrator of the right to request a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(c)(ii): A victim has a right to request a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(c)(iii): If the perpetrator or the victim requests a hearing under this Subsection (3)(c), the court shall hold the hearing at the time determined by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(c)(iv): The continuous protective order shall be in effect while the hearing is being scheduled and while the hearing is pending.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(c)(v): A prosecutor shall use reasonable efforts to notify a victim of a hearing described in Subsection (3)(b)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(d): A continuous protective order is permanent in accordance with this Subsection (3) and may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(d)(i): an order enjoining the perpetrator from threatening to commit or committing acts of domestic violence against the victim or other family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(d)(ii): an order prohibiting the perpetrator from harassing, telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the victim, directly or indirectly;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(d)(iii): an order prohibiting the perpetrator from going to the victim's residence, school, place of employment, and the premises of any of these, or a specified place frequented regularly by the victim or any designated family or other household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(d)(iv): an order directing the perpetrator to pay restitution to the victim as may apply, and shall be enforced in accordance with Title 77, Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(3)(d)(v): any other order the court considers necessary to fully protect the victim and members of the victim's family or other household member.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(4): A continuous protective order may be modified or dismissed only if the court determines by clear and convincing evidence that all requirements of Subsection (3) have been met and the victim does not have a reasonable fear of future harm or abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(5): Except as provided in Subsection (6), in addition to the process of issuing a continuous protective order described in Subsection (3), a district court may issue a continuous protective order at any time if the victim files a petition with the court, and after notice and hearing the court finds that a continuous protective order is necessary to protect the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(6): 80-6-504; 80-6-807
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(6)(a): 80-6-504 Unless the juvenile court transfers jurisdiction of the offense to the district court under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(6)(b): 80-6-807 Unless the court sets an earlier date for expiration, a sentencing protective order issued under this section against a perpetrator who is a minor expires on the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(6)(b)(i): the day on which the juvenile court terminates jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-804(6)(b)(ii): 80-6-807 in accordance with Section

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(1): Before a perpetrator has been convicted of or adjudicated for an offense that is not domestic violence is placed on probation, the court may consider the safety and protection of the victim and any member of the victim's family or household.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(2): The court may condition probation or a plea in abeyance on the perpetrator's compliance with a sentencing protective order that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(2)(a): an order enjoining the perpetrator from threatening to commit or committing acts of domestic violence against the victim or other family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(2)(b): an order prohibiting the perpetrator from harassing, telephoning, contacting, or otherwise communicating with the victim, directly or indirectly;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(2)(d): an order prohibiting the perpetrator from purchasing, using, or possessing a firearm or other specified weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(2)(e): an order directing the perpetrator to surrender any weapons the perpetrator owns or possesses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(2)(f): an order imposing any other condition necessary to protect the victim and any other designated family or household member or to rehabilitate the perpetrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(3): 78B-7-804

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-805(3)(b):

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806 Penalties.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(1): 78B-7-802(1); 78B-7-802(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(1)(a): 78B-7-802(1) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(1)(b): 78B-7-802(2) An individual who knowingly violates a jail release court order or jail release agreement executed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(1)(b)(i): a third degree felony, if the original arrest was for a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(1)(b)(ii): a class A misdemeanor, if the original arrest was for a misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(2): A violation of a pretrial protective order issued under this part is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(2)(a): a third degree felony, if the original arrest or subsequent charge filed is a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(2)(b): a class A misdemeanor, if the original arrest or subsequent charge filed is a misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(3): A violation of a sentencing protective order and of a continuous protective order issued under this part is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(3)(a): a third degree felony, if the conviction was a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-806(3)(b): a class A misdemeanor, if the conviction was a misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002 Retroactive application.
---------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this part apply retroactively to all civil orders issued before, on, or after May 4, 2022.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1 Eligibility for removing the link between personal identifying information and court case dismissed.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(1): As used in this section, "personal identifying information" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(1)(a): a current name, former name, nickname, or alias; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(1)(b): date of birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(2): If a civil order is sought against an individual and the court denies the civil order, the individual may move the court for an order to remove the link between the individual's personal identifying information from the dismissed case in any publicly searchable database of the Utah state courts.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(3): If a motion is filed under Subsection (2), the court shall grant the motion if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(3)(a): 30 days have passed from the day on which the case is denied; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(3)(b): an appeal has not been filed in the denied case within the 30-day period described in Subsection (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(4): Removing the link to personal identifying information of a court record under Subsection (3) does not affect another agency's records.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1002.1(5): A case history, unless expunged under this chapter, remains public and accessible through a search by case number.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003 Requirements for expungement of protective order or stalking injunction -- Venue.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(1)(a): An individual against whom a civil order is sought may petition the court to expunge records of the civil order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(1)(b): A petitioner shall bring a petition for expungement under Subsection (1) in the court that issued the civil order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(2): The petitioner shall file the petition for expungement under Subsection (1)in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(a): The petitioner shall provide notice to the individual filed the civil order against the petitioner in accordance with Rule 4 of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(b): The individual who filed the civil order against the petitioner:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(b)(i): may file a written objection with the court within 30 days after the day on which the petition is received by the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(b)(ii): if the individual files a written objection, provide a copy of the written objection to the petitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(c): If the court receives a written objection to the petition for expungement of a civil order, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(c)(i): set a date for a hearing on the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(c)(ii): provide notice at least 30 days before the day on which the hearing is held to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(c)(ii)(A): all parties of the civil order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(c)(ii)(B): any other person or agency that the court has reason to believe may have relevant information related to the expungement of the civil order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(3)(d): The petitioner may respond, in writing, to any written objection within 14 days after the day on which the written objection is received by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(4): If no written objection is received within 60 days from the day on which the petition for expungement is filed under Subsection (1), the court may grant the expungement in accordance with Subsection (5) or (6) without a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5): A court may expunge an ex parte civil protective order or an ex parte civil stalking injunction if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(a): the ex parte civil protective order or the ex parte civil stalking injunction was issued but:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(a)(i): the ex parte civil protective order or the ex parte civil stalking injunction is dismissed, dissolved, or expired upon a hearing by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(a)(ii): the court did not issue a civil protective order or a civil stalking injunction on the same circumstances for which the ex parte civil protective order or the ex parte civil stalking injunction was issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(a)(iii): at least 30 days have passed from the day on which the ex parte civil protective order or the ex parte civil stalking injunction was issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(a)(iv): the petitioner has not been arrested, charged, or convicted for violating the ex parte civil protective order or ex parte civil stalking injunction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(a)(v): there are no criminal proceedings pending against the petitioner in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(b)(i): the individual who filed the ex parte civil protective order or the ex parte civil stalking injunction failed to appear for the hearing on the ex parte civil protective order or ex parte civil stalking injunction;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(b)(ii): at least 30 days have passed from the day on which the hearing on the ex parte civil protective order or the ex parte civil stalking injunction was set to occur, including any continuance, postponement, or rescheduling of the hearing;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(b)(iii): the petitioner has not been arrested, charged, or convicted for violating the ex parte civil protective order or ex parte civil stalking injunction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(5)(b)(iv): there are no criminal proceedings pending against the petitioner in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(6): A court may expunge a civil protective order or a civil stalking injunction if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(6)(a): the civil protective order or the civil stalking injunction has been dismissed, dissolved, vacated, or expired;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(6)(b): three years have passed from the day on which the civil protective order or the civil stalking injunction is dismissed, dissolved, vacated, or expired;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(6)(c): the petitioner has not been arrested, charged, or convicted for violating the civil protective order or the civil stalking injunction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1003(6)(d): there are no criminal proceedings pending against the petitioner in the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004 Distribution and effect of order of expungement -- Penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(1): 78B-7-1003 An individual who receives an order of expungement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(2): (1) Upon receipt of an order of expungement as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(3): 78B-7-1003 Upon entry of an expungement order by a court under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(3)(a): the civil order is considered to never have occurred; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(3)(b): the petitioner may reply to an inquiry on the matter as though there was never a civil order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(4)(a): Unless ordered by a court to do so, an agency or official may not divulge information or records that have been expunged under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(4)(b): An expungement order may not restrict an agency's use or dissemination of records in the agency's ordinary course of business until the agency has received a copy of the expungement order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(4)(c): Any action taken by an agency after issuance of the expungement order but before the agency's receipt of a copy of the expungement order may not be invalidated by the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(5): An expungement order under this part may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(5)(a): terminate or invalidate any pending administrative proceedings or actions of which the individual had notice according to the records of the administrative body before issuance of the expungement order;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(5)(b): affect the enforcement of any order or findings issued by an administrative body pursuant to the administrative body's lawful authority prior to issuance of the expungement order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(5)(c): prevent an agency from maintaining, sharing, or distributing any record required by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(6): An employee or agent of an agency that is prohibited from disseminating information from an expunged record under this section who knowingly or intentionally discloses identifying information from the expunged record, unless allowed by law, is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(7): Records expunged under this part may be released to, or viewed by, the following individuals:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(7)(a): the petitioner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(7)(b): parties to a civil action arising out of the expunged civil order, providing the information is kept confidential and utilized only in the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1004(8): This part does not preclude a court from considering the same circumstances or evidence for which an expunged civil order was issued in any proceeding that occurs after the civil order is expunged.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(1): "Employee" means an employee in the service of an employer for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(2): "Employer" means a person who employs an individual in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(3): "Ex parte workplace violence protective order" means an order issued without notice to the respondent under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(4): "Protective order" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(4)(a): a workplace violence protective order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(4)(b): an ex parte workplace violence protective order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5): "Workplace violence" means knowingly causing or threatening to cause bodily injury to, or significant damage to the property of, a person, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5)(a): the person is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5)(a)(i): an employer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5)(a)(ii): an employee performing the employee's duties as an employee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5)(b)(i): the action would cause a reasonable person to feel terrorized, frightened, intimidated, or harassed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5)(b)(ii): the threat:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5)(b)(ii)(A): would cause a reasonable person to fear that the threat will be carried out; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(5)(b)(ii)(B): if carried out, would cause a reasonable person to feel terrorized, frightened, intimidated, or harassed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1101(6): "Workplace violence protective order" means an order issued under this part after a hearing on the petition, of which the petitioner and respondent have been given notice.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1102(1): An employer may seek, or authorize an agent to seek, a protective order in accordance with this part, if the employer reasonably believes workplace violence has occurred against the employer or an employee of the employer.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1103(1)(b): upon notice to the respondent, issue a workplace violence protective order or modify a workplace violence protective order after a hearing, regardless of whether the respondent appears.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1103(5): The existence of a protective order may not be used as evidence of liability or damages in a lawsuit between the petitioner and the respondent regardless of whether the petitioner or respondent seeks to admit the facts underlying the protective order as evidence.
