Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1107 Penalties.
-------------------------------------------
A violation of a protective order issued under this part is a class A misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1108 Employer liability.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1108(1): An employer is immune from civil liability for:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1108(1)(a): seeking a workplace violence protective order, if the employer acts in good faith in seeking the order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1108(1)(b): failing to seek a workplace violence protective order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1108(2): An employer's action or statement made under this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1108(2)(a): is not an admission of any fact; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1108(2)(b): may be used for purposes of impeachment.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1109 Limitations of part.
-----------------------------------------------------
This part does not:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1109(1): modify the duty of an employer to provide a safe workplace for the employees of the employer;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1109(2): prohibit a person from engaging in constitutionally protected exercise of free speech, including non-threatening speech and speech involving labor disputes concerning organized labor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-7-1109(3): prohibit a person from engaging in an activity that is part of a labor dispute.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201 Basis for punitive damages awards -- Section inapplicable to DUI cases or providing illegal controlled substances -- Division of award with state.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(1): (1)(a); 41-6a-502; 78B-3-801; 78B-3-108; (1)(a); 78B-3-108
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(1)(a): Except as otherwise provided by statute, punitive damages may be awarded only if compensatory or general damages are awarded and it is established by clear and convincing evidence that the acts or omissions of the tortfeasor are the result of willful and malicious or intentionally fraudulent conduct, or conduct that manifests a knowing and reckless indifference toward, and a disregard of, the rights of others.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(1)(b): (1)(a); 41-6a-502; 78B-3-801 The limitations, standards of evidence, and standards of conduct of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(1)(b)(i): 41-6a-502 operation of a motor vehicle or motorboat while voluntarily intoxicated or under the influence of any drug or combination of alcohol and drugs as prohibited by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(1)(b)(ii): 78B-3-801 causing death of another person by providing or administering an illegal controlled substance to the person under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(1)(b)(iii): providing an illegal controlled substance to any person in the chain of transfer that connects directly to a person who subsequently provided or administered the substance to a person whose death was caused in whole or in part by the substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(1)(c): 78B-3-108; (1)(a); 78B-3-108 The award of a penalty under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(2): (2)(a); 41-6a-502; 78B-3-801 Evidence of a party's wealth or financial condition shall be admissible only after a finding of liability for punitive damages has been made.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(2)(a): Discovery concerning a party's wealth or financial condition may only be allowed after the party seeking punitive damages has established a prima facie case on the record that an award of punitive damages is reasonably likely against the party about whom discovery is sought and, if disputed, the court is satisfied that the discovery is not sought for the purpose of harassment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(2)(b): (2)(a); 41-6a-502; 78B-3-801 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(2)(b)(i): 41-6a-502 operation of a motor vehicle or motorboat while voluntarily intoxicated or under the influence of any drug or combination of alcohol and drugs as prohibited by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(2)(b)(ii): 78B-3-801 causing death of another person or causing a person to be addicted by providing or administering an illegal controlled substance to the person under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(2)(b)(iii): providing an illegal controlled substance to any person in the chain of transfer that connects directly to a person who subsequently provided or administered the substance to a person whose death was caused in whole or in part by the substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3): 63A-3-301; 63A-3-502; (3)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(a): In any case where punitive damages are awarded, the court shall enter judgment as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(a)(i): for the first $50,000, judgment shall be in favor of the injured party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(a)(ii): any amount in excess of $50,000 shall be divided equally between the state and the injured party, and judgment to each entered accordingly.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(b)(i): The actual and bona fide attorney fees and costs incurred in obtaining and collecting the judgment for punitive damages shall be considered to have been incurred by the state and the injured party in proportion to the judgment entered in each party's behalf.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(b)(i)(A): The state and injured party shall be responsible for each one's proportionate share only.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(b)(i)(B): The state is liable to pay its proportionate share only to the extent it receives payment toward its judgment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(b)(ii): If the court awards attorney fees and costs to the injured party as a direct result of the punitive damage award, the state shall have a corresponding credit in a proportionate amount based on the amounts of the party's respective punitive damage judgments.  This credit may be applied as an offset against the amount of attorney fees and costs charged to the state for obtaining the punitive damage judgment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(c): 63A-3-301; 63A-3-502; (3)(e) The state shall have all rights due a judgment creditor to collect the full amounts of both punitive damage judgments until the judgments are fully satisfied.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(c)(i): Neither party is required to pursue collection.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(c)(ii): 63A-3-301; 63A-3-502; (3)(e) In pursuing collection, the state may exercise any of its collection rights under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(d): Unless all affected parties, including the state, expressly agree otherwise, collection on the punitive damages judgment shall be deferred until all other judgments have been fully paid.  Any payment by or on behalf of any judgment debtor, whether voluntary, by execution, or otherwise, shall be distributed and applied in the following order:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(d)(i): to the judgment for compensatory damage and any applicable judgment for attorney fees and costs;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(d)(ii): to the initial $50,000 of the punitive damage judgment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(d)(iii): to any judgment for attorney fees and costs awarded as a direct result of the punitive damages; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(d)(iv): to the remaining judgments for punitive damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(e): Any partial payments shall be distributed equally between the state and injured party.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-201(3)(f): After the payment of attorney fees and costs, all amounts paid on the state's judgment shall be remitted to the state treasurer to be deposited into the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202 Punitive damages -- Notification procedure.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202(1): Whenever it appears from a return of a jury verdict in any court jury trial or from entry of a finding or order in any court bench trial, that punitive damages have been awarded to the plaintiff in a court action, the clerk of the court shall immediately notify the attorney general and state treasurer of the verdict, finding, or order.  The notice shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202(1)(a): the names of both parties to the action, and their attorneys;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202(1)(b): the case number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202(1)(c): the location of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202(2): (1) In addition to the notice required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202(2)(a): the name of the party and his attorney, against whom the judgment was ordered;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202(2)(b): the amount of the judgment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-202(2)(c): the date on which the judgment was entered.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-203 Drug exception.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-203(1): Punitive damages may not be awarded if a drug causing the claimant's harm:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-203(1)(a): received premarket approval or licensure by the Federal Food and Drug Administration under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Section 301 et seq. or the Public Health Service Act, 42 U.S.C. Section 201 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-203(1)(b): is generally recognized as safe and effective under conditions established by the Federal Food and Drug Administration and applicable regulations, including packaging and labeling regulations.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-203(2): This limitation on liability for punitive damages does not apply if it is shown by clear and convincing evidence that the drug manufacturer knowingly withheld or misrepresented information required to be submitted to the Federal Food and Drug Administration under its regulations, which information was material and relevant to the claimant's harm.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-301 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Process Server Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302 Process servers.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(1): A complaint, a summons, or a subpoena may be served by an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(1)(a): 18 years old or older at the time of service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(1)(b): not a party to the action or a party's attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(2): Except as provided in Subsection (5), the following may serve all process issued by the courts of this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(2)(a): a peace officer employed by a political subdivision of the state acting within the scope and jurisdiction of the peace officer's employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(2)(b): a sheriff or appointed deputy sheriff employed by a county of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(2)(c): a constable, or the constable's deputy, serving in compliance with applicable law;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(2)(d): an investigator employed by the state and authorized by law to serve civil process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(2)(e): a private investigator licensed in accordance with Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(3): A private investigator licensed in accordance with Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act, may not make an arrest pursuant to a bench warrant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4): While serving process, a private investigator shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4)(a): have on the investigator's body a visible form of credentials and identification identifying:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4)(a)(i): the investigator's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4)(a)(ii): that the investigator is a licensed private investigator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4)(a)(iii): the name and address of the agency employing the investigator or, if the investigator is self-employed, the address of the investigator's place of business;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4)(b): verbally communicate to the person being served that the investigator is acting as a process server; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4)(c): print on the first page of each document served:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4)(c)(i): the investigator's name and identification number as a private investigator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(4)(c)(ii): the address and phone number for the investigator's place of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(5): 53-13-103; 53-13-105 The following may only serve process under this section when the use of force is authorized on the face of the document, or when a breach of the peace is imminent or likely under the totality of the circumstances:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(5)(a): 53-13-103 a law enforcement officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(5)(b): 53-13-105 a special function officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(5)(b)(i): employed as an appointed deputy sheriff by a county of the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(5)(b)(ii): a constable.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(6): 77-41-102 The following may not serve process issued by a court:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(6)(a): 77-41-102 an individual convicted of a felony violation of an offense listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(6)(b): an individual who is a respondent in a proceeding described in Title 78B, Chapter 7, Protective Orders and Stalking Injunctions, in which a court has granted the petitioner a protective order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(7): An individual serving process shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(7)(a): legibly document the date and time of service on the front page of the document being served;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(7)(b): legibly print the process server's name, address, and telephone number on the return of service;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(7)(c): sign the return of service in substantial compliance with Title 78B, Chapter 18a, Uniform Unsworn Declarations Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(7)(d): if the process server is a peace officer, sheriff, or deputy sheriff, legibly print the badge number of the process server on the return of service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-302(7)(e): if the process server is a private investigator, legibly print the private investigator's identification number on the return of service.

--------------------------------------------------
If the rates charged by private process servers exceed the rates established by law for service of process by persons under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-304 Violations of service of process authority.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-304(1): It is a class A misdemeanor for a person serving process to falsify a return of service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-304(2): It is an infraction for a person to bill falsely for process service.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(1): "Blood or contaminated body fluids" includes blood, saliva, amniotic fluid, pericardial fluid, peritoneal fluid, pleural fluid, synovial fluid, cerebrospinal fluid, semen, and vaginal secretions, and any body fluid visibly contaminated with blood.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(2): 78B-4-517 "COVID-19" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(3): "Disease" means Human Immunodeficiency Virus infection, acute or chronic Hepatitis B infection, Hepatitis C infection, COVID-19 or another infectious disease that may cause Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, and any other infectious disease specifically designated by the Labor Commission, in consultation with the Department of Health and Human Services, for the purposes of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(4): 53-2d-402 "Emergency services provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(4)(a): 53-2d-402 an individual licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(4)(b): an individual who provides for the care, control, support, or transport of a prisoner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(5): "First aid volunteer" means a person who provides voluntary emergency assistance or first aid medical care to an injured person prior to the arrival of an emergency medical services provider or peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(6): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(7): "Medical testing procedure" means a nasopharyngeal swab, a nasal swab, a capillary blood sample, a saliva test, or a blood draw.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(8): 53-1-102 "Peace officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(9): 76-5-101 "Prisoner" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(10): "Significant exposure" and "significantly exposed" mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(10)(a): exposure of the body of one individual to the blood or body fluids of another individual by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(10)(a)(i): percutaneous injury, including a needle stick, cut with a sharp object or instrument, or a wound resulting from a human bite, scratch, or similar force; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(10)(a)(ii): contact with an open wound, mucous membrane, or nonintact skin because of a cut, abrasion, dermatitis, or other damage;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(10)(b): exposure of the body of one individual to the body fluids, including airborne droplets, of another individual if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(10)(b)(i): the other individual displays symptoms known to be associated with COVID-19 or another infectious disease that may cause Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(10)(b)(ii): other evidence exists that would lead a reasonable person to believe that the other individual may be infected with COVID-19 or another infectious disease that may cause Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-401(10)(c): exposure that occurs by any other method of transmission defined by the Labor Commission, in consultation with the Department of Health and Human Services, as a significant exposure.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402 Petition -- Disease testing -- Notice -- Payment for testing.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(1): An emergency services provider or first aid volunteer who is significantly exposed during the course of performing the emergency services provider's duties or during the course of performing emergency assistance or first aid, or a health care provider acting in the course and scope of the health care provider's duties as a health care provider may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(1)(a): request that the person to whom the emergency services provider, first aid volunteer, or health care provider was significantly exposed voluntarily submit to testing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(1)(b): petition the district court or a magistrate for an order requiring that the person to whom the emergency services provider, first aid volunteer, or health care provider was significantly exposed submit to testing to determine the presence of a disease and that the results of that test be disclosed to the petitioner by the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2): 41-6a-523
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(a): A law enforcement agency may submit on behalf of the petitioner by electronic or other means an ex parte request for a warrant ordering a medical testing procedure of the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(b): The court or magistrate shall issue a warrant ordering the respondent to submit to a medical testing procedure within two hours, and that reasonable force may be used, if necessary, if the court or magistrate finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(b)(i): the petitioner was significantly exposed during the course of performing the petitioner's duties as an emergency services provider, first aid volunteer, or health care provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(b)(ii): the respondent refused to give consent to the medical testing procedure or is unable to give consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(b)(iii): there may not be an opportunity to obtain a sample at a later date; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(b)(iv): a delay in administering available FDA-approved post-exposure treatment or prophylaxis could result in a lack of effectiveness of the treatment or prophylaxis.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(c): 41-6a-523
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(c)(i): 41-6a-523 If the petitioner requests that the court order the respondent to submit to a blood draw, the petitioner shall request a person authorized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(c)(ii): If the petitioner requests that the court order the respondent to submit to a medical testing procedure, other than a blood draw, the petitioner shall request that a qualified medical professional, including a physician, a physician's assistant, a registered nurse, a licensed practical nurse, or a paramedic, perform the medical testing procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(d)(i): A sample drawn in accordance with a warrant following an ex parte request shall be sent to the Department of Health and Human Services for testing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(d)(ii): If the Department of Health and Human Services is unable to perform a medical testing procedure ordered by the court under this section, a qualified medical laboratory may perform the medical testing procedure if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(d)(ii)(A): the Department of Health and Human Services requests that the medical laboratory perform the medical testing procedure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(2)(d)(ii)(B): the result of the medical testing procedure is provided to the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(3): (2) If a petitioner does not seek or obtain a warrant pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(4): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(4)(a): (3) The petition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(4)(b): The petitioner shall submit to testing to determine the presence of a disease, when the petition is filed or within three days after the petition is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(5): The petitioner shall cause the petition required under this section to be served on the person who the petitioner is requesting to be tested in a manner that will best preserve the confidentiality of that person.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(6)(a): The court shall set a time for a hearing on the matter within 10 days after the petition is filed and shall give the petitioner and the individual who is the subject of the petition notice of the hearing at least 72 hours prior to the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(6)(b): The individual who is the subject of the petition shall also be notified that the individual may have an attorney present at the hearing and that the individual's attorney may examine and cross-examine witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(6)(c): The hearing shall be conducted in camera.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(7): The district court may enter an order requiring that an individual submit to testing, including a medical testing procedure, for a disease if the court finds probable cause to believe:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(7)(a): the petitioner was significantly exposed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(7)(b): the exposure occurred during the course of the emergency services provider's duties, the provision of emergency assistance or first aid by a first aid volunteer, or the health care provider acting in the course and scope of the provider's duties as a health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(8): The court may order that the use of reasonable force is permitted to complete an ordered test if the individual who is the subject of the petition is a prisoner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(9): The court may order that additional, follow-up testing be conducted and that the individual submit to that testing, as it determines to be necessary and appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(10): The court is not required to order an individual to submit to a test under this section if it finds that there is a substantial reason, relating to the life or health of the individual, not to enter the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(11): 26B-7-217; 26B-7-203

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-402(11)(b): The court shall send the order to the Department of Health and Human Services and to the local health department ordered to conduct or oversee the test.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-403 Confidentiality -- Disclosure -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person or entity entitled to receive confidential information under this part, other than the individual tested and identified in the information, who violates this part by releasing or making public that confidential information, or by otherwise breaching the confidentiality requirements of this part, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-404 Department authority -- Rules.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The Labor Commission, in consultation with the Department of Health and Human Services, has authority to establish rules necessary for the purposes of Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-405 Construction.
---------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part may be construed as prohibiting a person from voluntarily consenting to the request of a health care provider to submit to testing following a significant exposure.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-501 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Small Business Equal Access to Justice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-502 Legislative findings -- Purpose.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that small businesses may be deterred from seeking review of or defending against substantially unjustified governmental action because of the expense involved in securing the vindication of their rights.  The purpose of this part is to entitle small businesses, under conditions set forth in this act, to recover reasonable litigation expenses.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-503 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-503(1): "Prevail" means to obtain favorable final judgment, the right to all appeals having been exhausted, on the merits, on substantially all counts or charges in the action and with respect to the most significant issue or set of issues presented, but does not include the settlement of any action, either by stipulation, consent decree or otherwise, whether or not settlement occurs before or after any hearing or trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-503(2): "Reasonable litigation expenses" means court costs, administrative hearing costs, attorney fees, and witness fees of all necessary witnesses, not in excess of $25,000 which a court finds were reasonably incurred in opposing action covered under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-503(3): "Small business" means a commercial or business entity, including a sole proprietorship, which does not have more than 250 employees, but does not include an entity which is a subsidiary or affiliate of another entity which is not a small business.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-503(4): Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 31, Utah Antitrust Act "State" means any department, board, institution, hospital, college, or university of the state of Utah or any political subdivision thereof, except with respect to actions brought under


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-504 Litigation expense award authorized in actions by state.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any civil judicial action commenced by the state, which involves the business regulatory functions of the state, a court may award reasonable litigation expenses to any small business which is a named party in the action if the small business prevails and the court finds that the state action was undertaken without substantial justification.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-505 Litigation expense award authorized in appeals from administrative decisions.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-505(1): In any civil judicial appeal taken from an administrative decision regarding a matter in which the administrative action was commenced by the state, and which involves the business regulatory functions of the state, a court may award reasonable litigation expenses to any small business which is a named party if the small business prevails in the appeal and the court finds that the state action was undertaken without substantial justification.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-505(2): Any state agency or political subdivision may require by rule or ordinance that a small business exhaust administrative remedies prior to making a claim under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-506 Payment of expenses awarded -- Statement required in agency's budget.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Expenses awarded under this part shall be paid from funds in the regular operating budget of the state entity. If sufficient funds are not available in the budget of the entity, the expenses shall be considered a claim governed by the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
For purposes of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-601(1): "Forest products" means any tree or portion thereof before it is manufactured into dimensional lumber, timbers, and ties, or mill peeled and made into power poles or house logs, including but not limited to coniferous and deciduous trees, Christmas trees, sawlogs, poles, posts, pulp logs, and fuelwood.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-601(2): "Native vegetation" means all other forest, desert, or rangeland vegetation including but not limited to shrubs, flora, roots, bulbs, and seed.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602 Proof of ownership required to harvest or transport forest products or native vegetation -- Requirements for proof of ownership.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(1): It is unlawful for any person, firm, company, partnership, corporation, or business to harvest or transport timber, forest products, or other native vegetation without proof of ownership.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(2): Proof of ownership requires possession of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(2)(a): a contract, permit, or other writing issued by the landowner or proper state or federal agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(2)(b): a bill of sale, or other sales receipt;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(2)(c): a bill of lading or product load receipt;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(2)(d): a ticket issued by the seller authorizing harvesting or removal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(2)(e): any other legal instrument.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3): (1) The document required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3)(a): date of execution;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3)(b): name and address of person authorized to harvest or transport the products, if different from the purchaser;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3)(c): a legal or other sufficient description of the property from which the products are harvested or removed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3)(d): the estimated amount or volume, species, and other pertinent information regarding the products harvested or transported;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3)(e): the delivery or scaling point;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3)(f): the name and address of the purchaser of the products;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3)(g): the name and address of the landowner, agency, or vendor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-602(3)(h): an expiration date.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-603 Transportation of forest products or native vegetation into or through the state.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Timber, forest products, or native vegetation transported into or through the state shall be accompanied by a shipping permit or proof of ownership.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-604 Enforcement.
--------------------------------------------
Any law enforcement officer specified in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 78B-8-604(1): stop any vehicle or means of conveyance, including common carriers, containing timber, forest products, or native vegetation upon any road or highway of this state for the purpose of making an inspection and investigation but may not unduly detain a driver of such vehicle or means of conveyance;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-604(2): inspect the timber, forest product, or native vegetation in any vehicle, or other means of conveyance, including common carrier, to determine whether the provisions of this chapter have been complied with;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-604(3): seize and hold any timber, forest product, or native vegetation harvested, removed, or transported in violation of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-604(4): sell or dispose of the timber, forest product, or native vegetation as provided by rule by the appropriate agency.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-605 Exemptions.
-------------------------------------------
The provisions of this part do not apply to the transportation of:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-605(1): wood chips, sawdust, and bark;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-605(2): products transported by the owner of the property or his agent from which the products were removed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-605(3): products for personal consumption incidental to camping and picnicking which is limited to the amount:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-605(3)(a): needed for the duration of the picnic or campout; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-605(3)(b): used at the campsite.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-606 Violation as misdemeanor.
---------------------------------------------------------
Violation of Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-701 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-701(1): "Americans with Disabilities Act" means the public accommodation protections of Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. Secs. 12181 through 12189.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-701(2): "Prospective defendant" means a person that is an owner, lessor, or operator of a public accommodation, or a designated agent of the owner, lessor, or operator for service of process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-701(3): "Prospective plaintiff" means an individual with a disability who may bring a cause of action under the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 12188.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-701(4): "Public accommodation" means the same as that term is defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 12181.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-704 Filing a civil action.
------------------------------------------------------
This part does not prevent a prospective plaintiff from seeking any available remedies for an alleged violation under the Americans with Disabilities Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-705 Severability.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-705(1): If any provision of this part or the application of any part to any person or circumstance is held invalid by a court, the remainder of this part shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-8-705(2): The provisions of this part are severable.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-107(2)(c): the last day for filing a petition for writ of certiorari in the Utah Supreme Court or the United States Supreme Court, if no petition for writ of certiorari is filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-107(2)(d): the entry of the denial of the petition for writ of certiorari or the entry of the decision on the petition for certiorari review, if a petition for writ of certiorari is filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-107(2)(e): the date on which petitioner knew or should have known, in the exercise of reasonable diligence, of evidentiary facts on which the petition is based; or

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(1)(a): 78B-22-902 If any portion of the petition is not summarily dismissed, the court may, upon the request of an indigent petitioner, appoint counsel on a pro bono basis or from the Indigent Appellate Defense Division, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(1)(b): Counsel who represented the petitioner at trial or on the direct appeal may not be appointed to represent the petitioner under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(2): In determining whether to appoint counsel, the court may consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(2)(a): whether the petitioner is incarcerated;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(2)(b): the likelihood that an evidentiary hearing will be necessary;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(2)(c): the likelihood that an investigation will be necessary;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(2)(d): the complexity of the factual and legal issues; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(2)(e): any other factor relevant to the particular case.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-109(3): An allegation that counsel appointed under this section was ineffective cannot be the basis for relief in any subsequent postconviction petition.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-110 Appeal -- Jurisdiction.
-------------------------------------------------------
Any party may appeal from the trial court's final judgment on a petition for post-conviction relief to the appellate court having jurisdiction pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-201 Post-conviction remedies -- 30 days.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A post-conviction remedy may not be applied for or entertained by any court within 30 days prior to the date set for execution of a capital sentence, unless the grounds for application are based on facts or circumstances which developed or first became known within that period of time.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302 Effect of petition for postconviction DNA testing -- Requests for appointment of counsel -- Appeals -- Subsequent postconviction petitions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(1): The filing of a petition for DNA testing constitutes the person's consent to provide samples of body fluids for use in the DNA testing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(2): The data from any DNA samples or test results obtained as a result of the petition may be entered into law enforcement DNA databases.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(3): The filing of a petition for DNA testing constitutes the person's waiver of any statute of limitations in all jurisdictions as to any felony offense the person has committed which is identified through DNA database comparison.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(4): The person filing the petition for postconviction DNA testing bears the cost of the testing unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(4)(a): the person is serving a sentence of imprisonment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(4)(b): the person is indigent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(4)(c): the DNA test is favorable to the petitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(5): 78B-9-109(1); (2); 78B-9-109(3)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(5)(a): 78B-9-109(1); (2) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-302(5)(b): 78B-9-109(3) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303 Consequences of postconviction DNA testing when result is favorable to person -- Procedures.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(1)(a): If the result of postconviction DNA testing is favorable to the person, the person may file a motion to vacate the conviction.  The court shall give the state 30 days to respond in writing, to present evidence, and to be heard in oral argument prior to issuing an order to vacate the conviction.  The state may by motion request an extension of the 30 days, which the court may grant upon good cause shown.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(1)(b): The state may stipulate to the conviction being vacated, or may request a hearing and attempt to demonstrate through evidence and argument that, despite the DNA test results, the state possesses sufficient evidence of the person's guilt so that the person is unable to demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that the person is factually innocent of one or more offenses of which the person was convicted, and all the lesser included offenses related to those offenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2): (1)(b); (1)(b); (1)(b); (2)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(a): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(a)(i): (1)(b) If the result of postconviction DNA testing is favorable to the person and the state opposes vacating the conviction, the court shall consider all the evidence presented at the original trial and at the hearing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(a)(ii): The court may consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(a)(ii)(A): evidence that was suppressed or would be suppressed at a criminal trial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(a)(ii)(B): hearsay evidence, and may consider that the evidence is hearsay in evaluating its weight and credibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(b): If the court, after considering all the evidence, determines that the DNA test result demonstrates by clear and convincing evidence that the person is factually innocent of one or more offenses of which the person was convicted, the court shall order that those convictions be vacated with prejudice and those convictions be expunged from the person's record.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(c): (1)(b) If the court, after considering all the evidence presented at the original trial and at the hearing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(d): (1)(b); (2)(c) If the court, after considering all the evidence presented at the original trial and at the hearing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-303(2)(e): Any party may appeal from the trial court's final ruling on the petition under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-304 Consequences of postconviction DNA testing when result is unfavorable to person -- Procedures.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-304(1): If the result of postconviction DNA testing is not favorable to the person, the court shall deny the person's petition, and the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-304(1)(a): report the unfavorable result to the Board of Pardons and Parole; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-304(1)(b): order the person to pay for the costs of the DNA testing unless the petitioner has already paid that cost.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-304(2): This section does not apply if the DNA test is inconclusive.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as "Postconviction Determination of Factual Innocence."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(1): "Bona fide and compelling issue of factual innocence" means that the newly discovered material evidence presented by the petitioner, if credible, would clearly establish the factual innocence of the petitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(2): "Factual innocence" or "factually innocent" means a person did not:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(2)(a): engage in the conduct for which the person was convicted;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(2)(b): engage in conduct relating to any lesser included offenses of the crime for which the person was convicted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(2)(c): commit any other felony arising out of or reasonably connected to the facts supporting the indictment or information upon which the person was convicted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(3): Part 1, General Provisions "Newly discovered material evidence" means evidence that was not available to the petitioner at trial or during the resolution on the merits by the trial court of any motion to withdraw a guilty plea or motion for new trial and which is relevant to the determination of the issue of factual innocence, and may also include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(3)(a): evidence which was discovered prior to or in the course of any appeal or postconviction proceedings that served in whole or in part as the basis for vacatur or reversal of the conviction of petitioner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(3)(b): Part 1, General Provisions evidence that supports the claims within a petition filed under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-401.5(4): "Period of incarceration" means any sentence of imprisonment, including jail, which was served after judgement of conviction.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402 Petition for determination of factual innocence -- Sufficient allegations -- Notification of victim -- Payment to surviving spouse.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(1): A person who has been convicted of a felony offense may petition the district court in the county in which the person was convicted for a hearing to establish that the person is factually innocent of the crime or crimes of which the person was convicted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(a): The petition shall contain an assertion of factual innocence under oath by the petitioner and shall aver, with supporting affidavits or other credible documents, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(a)(i): newly discovered material evidence exists that, if credible, establishes that the petitioner is factually innocent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(a)(ii): the specific evidence identified by the petitioner in the petition establishes innocence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(a)(iii): the material evidence is not merely cumulative of evidence that was known;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(a)(iv): the material evidence is not merely impeachment evidence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(a)(v): viewed with all the other evidence, the newly discovered evidence demonstrates that the petitioner is factually innocent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(b)(i): The court shall review the petition in accordance with the procedures in Subsection (9)(b), and make a finding that the petition has satisfied the requirements of Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(2)(b)(ii): If the court finds the petition does not meet all the requirements of Subsection (2)(a), the court shall dismiss the petition without prejudice and send notice of the dismissal to the petitioner and the attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(a): The petition shall also contain an averment that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(a)(i): neither the petitioner nor the petitioner's counsel knew of the evidence at the time of trial or sentencing or in time to include the evidence in any previously filed post-trial motion or postconviction motion, and the evidence could not have been discovered by the petitioner or the petitioner's counsel through the exercise of reasonable diligence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(a)(ii): a court has found ineffective assistance of counsel for failing to exercise reasonable diligence in uncovering the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(b)(i): Upon entry of a finding that the petition is sufficient under Subsection (2)(a), the court shall then review the petition to determine if Subsection (3)(a) has been satisfied.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(b)(ii): If the court finds that the requirements of Subsection (3)(a) have not been satisfied, the court may dismiss the petition without prejudice and give notice to the petitioner and the attorney general of the dismissal, or the court may waive the requirements of Subsection (3)(a) if the court finds the petition should proceed to hearing based upon the strength of the petition, and that there is other evidence that could have been discovered through the exercise of reasonable diligence by the petitioner or the petitioner's counsel at trial, and the other evidence:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(b)(ii)(A): was not discovered by the petitioner or the petitioner's counsel;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(b)(ii)(B): is material upon the issue of factual innocence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(3)(b)(ii)(C): has never been presented to a court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(4)(a): If the conviction for which the petitioner asserts factual innocence was based upon a plea of guilty, the petition shall contain the specific nature and content of the evidence that establishes factual innocence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(4)(b): The court shall review the evidence and may dismiss the petition at any time in the course of the proceedings, if the court finds that the evidence of factual innocence relies solely upon the recantation of testimony or prior statements made by a witness against the petitioner, and the recantation appears to the court to be equivocal or self serving.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(5): A person who has already obtained postconviction relief that vacated or reversed the person's conviction or sentence may also file a petition under this part in the same manner and form as described above, if no retrial or appeal regarding this offense is pending.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(6): 78B-9-301 If some or all of the evidence alleged to be exonerating is biological evidence subject to DNA testing, the petitioner shall seek DNA testing in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(7): Except as provided in Subsection (9), the petition and all subsequent proceedings shall be in compliance with and governed by Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 65C and shall include the underlying criminal case number.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(8): After a petition is filed under this section, prosecutors, law enforcement officers, and crime laboratory personnel shall cooperate in preserving evidence and in determining the sufficiency of the chain of custody of the evidence which is the subject of the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(a): A person who files a petition under this section shall serve notice of the petition and a copy of the petition upon the office of the prosecutor who obtained the conviction and upon the Utah attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(b)(i): The assigned judge shall conduct an initial review of the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(b)(ii): If it is apparent to the court that the petitioner is either merely relitigating facts, issues, or evidence presented in previous proceedings or presenting issues that appear frivolous or speculative on their face, the court shall dismiss the petition, state the basis for the dismissal, and serve notice of dismissal upon the petitioner and the attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(b)(iii): If, upon completion of the initial review, the court does not dismiss the petition, the court shall order the attorney general to file a response to the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(b)(iv): The attorney general shall, within 30 days after the day on which the attorney general receives the court's order, or within any additional period of time the court allows, answer or otherwise respond to all proceedings initiated under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(c)(i): After the time for response by the attorney general under Subsection (9)(b) has passed, the court shall order a hearing if the court finds the petition meets the requirements of Subsections (2) and (3) and finds there is a bona fide and compelling issue of factual innocence regarding the charges of which the petitioner was convicted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(c)(ii): No bona fide and compelling issue of factual innocence exists if the petitioner is merely relitigating facts, issues, or evidence presented in a previous proceeding or if the petitioner is unable to identify with sufficient specificity the nature and reliability of the newly discovered evidence that establishes the petitioner's factual innocence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(d)(i): If the parties stipulate that the evidence establishes that the petitioner is factually innocent, the court may find the petitioner is factually innocent without holding a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(9)(d)(ii): If the state will not stipulate that the evidence establishes that the petitioner is factually innocent, no determination of factual innocence may be made by the court without first holding a hearing under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(10): The court may not grant a petition for a hearing under this part during the period in which criminal proceedings in the matter are pending before any trial or appellate court, unless stipulated to by the parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(11): 77-38-3 Any victim of a crime that is the subject of a petition under this part, and who has elected to receive notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(12)(a): A petition to determine factual innocence under this part, or Part 3, Postconviction Testing of DNA, shall be filed separately from any petition for postconviction relief under Part 1, General Provisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(12)(b): Separate petitions may be filed simultaneously in the same court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(13): The procedures governing the filing and adjudication of a petition to determine factual innocence apply to all petitions currently filed or pending in the district court and any new petitions filed on or after June 1, 2012.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(14): 78B-9-405; 78B-9-405
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(14)(a): As used in this Subsection (14) and in Subsection (15):
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(14)(a)(i): "Married" means the legal marital relationship established between two individuals and as recognized by the law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(14)(a)(ii): "Spouse" means an individual married to the petitioner at the time the petitioner was found guilty of the offense regarding which a petition is filed and who has since then been continuously married to the petitioner until the petitioner's death.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(14)(b): A claim for determination of factual innocence under this part is not extinguished upon the death of the petitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(14)(c): 78B-9-405; 78B-9-405

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-402(14)(c)(ii): Payments cease upon the death of the spouse.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404 Hearing upon petition -- Procedures -- Court determination of factual innocence.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(1)(a): In any hearing conducted under this part, the Utah attorney general shall represent the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(1)(b): The burden is upon the petitioner to establish the petitioner's factual innocence by clear and convincing evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(2): The court may consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(2)(a): evidence that was suppressed or would be suppressed at a criminal trial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(2)(b): hearsay evidence, and may consider that the evidence is hearsay in evaluating its weight and credibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(3): In making its determination the court shall consider, in addition to the evidence presented at the hearing under this part, the record of the original criminal case and at any postconviction proceedings in the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(4): If the court, after considering all the evidence, determines by clear and convincing evidence that the petitioner:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(4)(a): is factually innocent of one or more offenses of which the petitioner was convicted, the court shall order that those convictions:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(4)(a)(i): be vacated with prejudice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(4)(a)(ii): be expunged from the petitioner's record; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(4)(b): did not commit one or more offenses of which the petitioner was convicted, but the court does not find by clear and convincing evidence that the petitioner did not commit any lesser included offenses relating to those offenses, the court shall modify the original conviction and sentence of the petitioner as appropriate for the lesser included offense, whether or not the lesser included offense was originally submitted to the trier of fact.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(5): (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(5)(a): (4)(b) If the court, after considering all the evidence, does not determine by clear and convincing evidence that the petitioner is factually innocent of the offense or offenses the petitioner is challenging and does not find that Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(5)(b): If the court finds that the petition was brought in bad faith, it shall enter the finding on the record, and the petitioner may not file a second or successive petition under this section without first applying to and obtaining permission from the court which denied the prior petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(6): At least 30 days prior to a hearing on a petition to determine factual innocence, the petitioner and the respondent shall exchange information regarding the evidence each intends to present at the hearing.  This information shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(6)(a): a list of witnesses to be called at the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(6)(b): a summary of the testimony or other evidence to be introduced through each witness, including any expert witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(7): Each party is entitled to a copy of any expert report to be introduced or relied upon by that expert or another expert at least 30 days prior to hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-404(8): 78B-9-401.5(2); 78B-9-402; 78B-9-401.5(3) The court, after considering all the evidence, may not find the petitioner to be factually innocent unless:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-501 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Conviction Integrity Units Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(1): "Bona fide and compelling evidence" means that the evidence presented by the petitioning prosecutor establishes by a preponderance of the evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(1)(a): the convicted person is significantly likely to be factually innocent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(1)(b): newly discovered material evidence, if presented at or before the time of trial, judgment of conviction, or sentencing, would have resulted in a significant probability that the result would have been different; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(1)(c): there exists information discovered or received by the petitioning prosecution agency after a judgment of conviction and sentencing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(1)(c)(i): if disclosed to the convicted person prior to trial, judgment of conviction, or sentencing, would have resulted in a significant probability that the result would have been different; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(1)(c)(ii): significantly calls into question the legitimacy of the jury verdict, judgment of conviction, or sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(2): "Convicted person" means the person whose conviction or sentence is under review.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(3): "Conviction Integrity Unit" means a program established by a prosecution agency to conduct extrajudicial, fact-based reviews of criminal convictions and sentences.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(4): "Establishing office" means the prosecution agency establishing a conviction integrity unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(5): 78B-9-401.5 "Factually innocent" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(6): "Legitimacy" means consistent with the United States and Utah constitutions, federal and state law, and all rules and principles of a fair and just legal system.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(7): 78B-9-401.5 "Newly discovered material evidence" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(8): "Petitioning prosecutor" means the prosecutor who files a civil petition seeking relief under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(9): "Prosecution agency" means a county attorney, district attorney, the Office of the Attorney General, or other prosecution agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-502(10): "Significant" or "significantly likely," for purposes of this part, means to a large degree or of a noticeably or measurably large amount.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503 Conviction Integrity Unit.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(1): A prosecution agency may establish a conviction integrity unit to investigate:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(1)(a): plausible allegations of factual innocence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(1)(b): newly discovered material evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(1)(c): information discovered or received by the prosecution agency after trial, judgment of conviction, or sentencing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(1)(c)(i): if disclosed to the convicted person prior to trial, judgment of conviction, or sentencing, would have resulted in a significant probability that the result would have been different; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(1)(c)(ii): significantly calls into question the legitimacy of the jury verdict, judgment of conviction, or sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2): A conviction integrity unit may review a conviction or sentence if the conviction and sentence:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(a)(i): occurred within the judicial district of the establishing office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(a)(ii): was prosecuted by the establishing office or another prosecution agency under the direct control and supervision of the establishing office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(b)(i): occurred within a different judicial district or was prosecuted by another prosecution agency not under the direct control and supervision of the establishing office;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(b)(ii)(A): the prosecution agency that prosecuted the case has not established a conviction integrity unit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(b)(ii)(B): the prosecution agency that prosecuted the case has established a conviction integrity unit but determines that review of the conviction or sentence should be conducted by a conviction integrity unit established by another prosecution agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(2)(b)(iii): the district attorney, county attorney, attorney general, or other prosecutor that directly oversees and supervises the requesting agency requests the review.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(3): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(3)(a): (2) An individual convicted of a crime may submit an application to a conviction integrity unit requesting review of the individual's conviction or sentence as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(3)(b): If a convicted person submits an application for review of a conviction that resulted in a sentence of death, and the application is submitted to any conviction integrity unit other than a conviction integrity unit established by the Office of the Attorney General, the conviction integrity unit that receives the application shall forward copies of the application to the Office of the Attorney General and to the convicted person's current counsel of record.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(3)(c): If a conviction integrity unit other than a conviction integrity unit established by the Office of the Attorney General, undertakes any review of a conviction that resulted in a sentence of death, the conviction integrity unit shall send the findings and recommendations promptly upon completion to the Office of the Attorney General and to the convicted person's current counsel of record.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(3)(d): If a conviction integrity unit other than a conviction integrity unit established by the Office of the Attorney General discovers or receives any information relevant to a conviction that resulted in a sentence of death, the conviction integrity unit that discovers or receives the information shall promptly notify the Office of the Attorney General and the convicted person's current counsel of record.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-9-503(4): The form of the application for review and its contents shall be determined by the establishing office.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 10 - Utah Uniform Mediation Act
*************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Uniform Mediation Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(1): "Mediation" means a process in which a mediator facilitates communication and negotiation between parties to assist them in reaching a voluntary agreement regarding their dispute.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(2): "Mediation communication" means conduct or a statement, whether oral, in a record, verbal, or nonverbal, that occurs during a mediation or is made for purposes of considering, conducting, participating in, initiating, continuing, or reconvening a mediation or retaining a mediator.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(3): "Mediation party" means a person that participates in a mediation and whose agreement is necessary to resolve the dispute.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(4): "Mediator" means an individual who is neutral and conducts a mediation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(5): "Nonparty participant" means a person, other than a party or mediator, that participates in a mediation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(6): "Person" means an individual, corporation, estate, trust, business trust, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture, government, governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, public corporation, or any other legal or commercial entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(7): "Proceeding" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(7)(a): a judicial, administrative, arbitral, or other adjudicative process, including related prehearing and posthearing motions, conferences, and discovery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(7)(b): a legislative hearing or similar process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(8): "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(9): "Sign" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(9)(a): to execute or adopt a tangible symbol with the present intent to authenticate a record; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-102(9)(b): to attach or logically associate an electronic symbol, sound, or process to or with a record with the present intent to authenticate a record.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103 Scope.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(1): (2); (3) Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(1)(a): the mediation parties are required to mediate by statute, court, or administrative agency rule or referred to mediation by a court, administrative agency, or arbitrator;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(1)(b): the mediation parties and the mediator agree to mediate in a record that demonstrates an expectation that mediation communications will be privileged against disclosure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(1)(c): the mediation parties use as a mediator an individual who holds himself or herself out as a mediator or the mediation is provided by an entity that holds itself out as providing mediation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(2): The chapter does not apply to a mediation:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(2)(a): relating to the establishment, negotiation, administration, or termination of a collective bargaining relationship;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(2)(b): relating to a dispute that is pending under or is part of the processes established by a collective bargaining agreement, except that the chapter applies to a mediation arising out of a dispute that has been filed with an administrative agency or court;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(2)(c): conducted by a judge as a part of the judge's official judicial duties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-103(2)(d): conducted under the auspices of:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-110 Participation in mediation.
------------------------------------------------------------
An attorney or other individual designated by a party may accompany the party to, and participate in, a mediation.  A waiver of participation given before the mediation may be rescinded.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-111 International commercial mediation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-111(1): In this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-111(1)(a): "International commercial mediation" means an international commercial conciliation as defined in Article 1 of the Model Law.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-111(1)(b): "Model Law" means the Model Law on International Commercial Conciliation adopted by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law on 28 June 2002 and recommended by the United Nations General Assembly in a resolution (A/RES/57/18) dated 19 November 2002.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-111(4): If the parties to an international commercial mediation agree under Article 1, Section (7), of the Model Law that the Model Law does not apply, this chapter applies.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-112 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, or supersedes the federal Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Section 7001 et seq., but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of that act or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10-113 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this chapter, consideration should be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 10a - Tort Arbitration
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-101 Title.
----------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Tort Arbitration."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-102 General provisions -- Filing -- Notice -- Limits.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-102(1): 31A-22-303; 31A-22-305; 31A-22-305.3; 78B-3-401; 63G-7-401; (1)(a)(ii); (1)(a)(i) Except for bodily injury cases involving a motor vehicle as described in Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-102(1)(a)(ii): filed a notice to submit the claim to arbitration within 14 days after the complaint is answered; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-102(1)(b): (1)(a)(ii); (1)(a)(i) the notice required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-102(2): All parties shall respond within 30 days to the notice either agreeing or refusing to agree to arbitration.  If a party does not respond, it is considered a refusal.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-102(2)(a): If all parties agree to arbitration, the arbitration shall proceed in accordance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-102(2)(b): If the parties do not agree to arbitration, the action shall proceed to trial.  The request for arbitration may not be revealed during a trial or while a damage award is being deliberated.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-102(3): (1) If the parties agree to submit a bodily injury or property damage claim to arbitration under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-103 Punitive damages.
---------------------------------------------------
A claim for punitive damages may not be made in an arbitration proceeding in accordance with this chapter or any subsequent proceeding, even if the claim is later resolved through a trial de novo in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104 Rescission -- Discovery.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1)(a): Any party who has agreed to arbitration in accordance with this chapter may rescind the agreement if the rescission is made within:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1)(a)(i): 90 days after the agreement to arbitrate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1)(a)(ii): not less than 30 days before any scheduled arbitration hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1)(b): A person seeking to rescind an agreement to arbitrate in accordance with this chapter shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1)(b)(i): file a notice of the rescission of the agreement to arbitrate with the district court where the matter was filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1)(b)(ii): send copies of the notice of the rescission of the agreement to arbitrate to all counsel of record in the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1)(c): All discovery completed in anticipation of the arbitration hearing shall be available for use by the parties as allowed by the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure and Utah Rules of Evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(1)(d): A party who has agreed to arbitrate in accordance with this chapter and then rescinded the agreement to arbitrate may not subsequently request to arbitrate the claim again.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(2)(a): Unless otherwise agreed to by the parties or by order of the court, an arbitration process agreed to in accordance with this chapter is subject to Rule 26, Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-104(2)(b): Unless otherwise agreed to by the parties or ordered by the court, discovery shall be completed within 150 days after the date arbitration is elected in accordance with this chapter or the date the answer is filed, whichever is longer.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-106 Governing provisions.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-106(1): Title 78B, Chapter 11, Utah Uniform Arbitration Act Except as otherwise provided in this chapter and unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the parties, an arbitration proceeding conducted in accordance with this chapter shall be governed by
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-106(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-106(2)(a): Subject to the provisions of this chapter, the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure and Utah Rules of Evidence apply to arbitration proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-106(2)(b): The Utah Rules of Civil Procedure and the Utah Rules of Evidence shall be applied with the intent of concluding the claim in a timely and cost-efficient manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-106(2)(c): Discovery shall be conducted in accordance with Rules 26 through 37 of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure and shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the district court in which the matter is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-106(2)(d): Dispositive motions shall be filed, heard, and decided by the district court prior to the arbitration proceeding in accordance with the court's scheduling order.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-107 Decision -- Award -- Court action.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-107(1): A written decision by a single arbitrator or by a majority of the arbitration panel shall constitute a final decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-107(2): An arbitration award issued in accordance with this chapter shall be the final resolution of all property damage or bodily injury claims between the parties and may be reduced to judgment by the court upon motion and notice unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-107(2)(a): either party, within 20 days after service of the arbitration award:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-107(2)(a)(i): files a notice requesting a trial de novo in the district court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-107(2)(a)(ii): serves the nonmoving party with a copy of the notice requesting a trial de novo; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-107(2)(b): the arbitration award has been satisfied.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-10a-109 Interest.
