Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-712 Personal information -- Limit on use.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Personal information gathered or transmitted under this part may be used only for the purposes for which it was gathered or transmitted.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-713 Record in original language -- English translation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A record filed with a tribunal of this state under this part shall be in the original language and, if not in English, shall be accompanied by an English translation.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-801 Grounds for rendition.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-801(1): For purposes of this part, "governor" includes an individual performing the functions of governor or the executive authority of a state covered by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-801(2): The governor of this state may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-801(2)(a): demand that the governor of another state surrender an individual found in the other state who is charged criminally in this state with having failed to provide for the support of an obligee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-801(2)(b): on the demand of the governor of another state, surrender an individual found in this state who is charged criminally in the other state with having failed to provide for the support of an obligee.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-801(3): A provision for extradition of individuals not inconsistent with this chapter applies to the demand even if the individual whose surrender is demanded was not in the demanding state when the crime was allegedly committed and has not fled therefrom.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-802 Conditions of rendition.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-802(1): Before making demand that the governor of another state surrender an individual charged criminally in this state with having failed to provide for the support of an obligee, the governor of this state may require a prosecutor of this state to demonstrate that at least 60 days previously the obligee had initiated proceedings for support pursuant to this chapter or that the proceeding would be of no avail.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-802(2): If, under this chapter or a law substantially similar to this chapter, the governor of another state makes a demand that the governor of this state surrender an individual charged criminally in that state with having failed to provide for the support of a child or other individual to whom a duty of support is owed, the governor may require a prosecutor to investigate the demand and report whether a proceeding for support has been initiated or would be effective.  If it appears that a proceeding would be effective but has not been initiated, the governor may delay honoring the demand for a reasonable time to permit the initiation of a proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-802(3): If a proceeding for support has been initiated and the individual whose rendition is demanded prevails, the governor may decline to honor the demand.  If the petitioner prevails and the individual whose rendition is demanded is subject to a support order, the governor may decline to honor the demand if the individual is complying with the support order.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-901 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter is a uniform act.  In applying and construing it, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-902 Transitional provision.
--------------------------------------------------------
This chapter applies to proceedings begun on or after July 1, 2015:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-902(1): to establish a support order or determine parentage of a child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-14-902(2): to register, recognize, enforce, or modify a prior support order, determination, or agreement, whenever issued or entered.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 15 - Utah Uniform Parentage Act
*************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Uniform Parentage Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(1): "Adjudicated father" means a man who has been adjudicated by a tribunal to be the father of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(2): "Alleged father" means a man who alleges himself to be, or is alleged to be, the genetic father or a possible genetic father of a child, but whose paternity has not been determined.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(3)(a): "Assisted reproduction" means a method of causing pregnancy other than sexual intercourse.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(3)(b): "Assisted reproduction" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(3)(b)(i): intrauterine insemination;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(3)(b)(ii): donation of eggs;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(3)(b)(iii): donation of embryos;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(3)(b)(iv): in vitro fertilization and transfer of embryos; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(3)(b)(v): intracytoplasmic sperm injection.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(4): "Birth expenses" means all medical costs associated with the birth of a child, including the related expenses for the biological mother during her pregnancy and delivery.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(5): "Birth mother" means the biological mother of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(6): "Child" means an individual of any age whose parentage may be determined under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(7): "Commence" means to file the initial pleading seeking an adjudication of parentage in the appropriate tribunal of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(8): "Declarant father" means a male who, along with the biological mother claims to be the genetic father of a child, and signs a voluntary declaration of paternity to establish the man's paternity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(9): "Determination of parentage" means the establishment of the parent-child relationship by the signing of a valid declaration of paternity under Part 3, Voluntary Declaration of Paternity Act, or adjudication by a tribunal.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(10)(a): "Donor" means an individual who produces eggs or sperm used for assisted reproduction, whether or not for consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(10)(b): "Donor" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(10)(b)(i): a husband who provides sperm, or a wife who provides eggs, to be used for assisted reproduction by the wife;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(10)(b)(ii): a woman who gives birth to a child by means of assisted reproduction, except as otherwise provided in Part 8, Gestational Agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(10)(b)(iii): a parent under Part 7, Assisted Reproduction, or an intended parent under Part 8, Gestational Agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(11): "Ethnic or racial group" means, for purposes of genetic testing, a recognized group that an individual identifies as all or part of the individual's ancestry or that is so identified by other information.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(12): 81-6-101 "Financial support" means a base child support award as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(13)(a): "Genetic testing" means an analysis of genetic markers to exclude or identify a man as the father or a woman as the mother of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(13)(b): "Genetic testing" includes an analysis of one or a combination of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(13)(b)(i): deoxyribonucleic acid; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(13)(b)(ii): blood-group antigens, red-cell antigens, human-leukocyte antigens, serum enzymes, serum proteins, or red-cell enzymes.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(14): "Gestational mother" means an adult woman who gives birth to a child under a gestational agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(15): "Man" means a male individual of any age.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(16): "Medical support" means a provision in a support order that requires the purchase and maintenance of appropriate insurance for health and dental expenses of dependent children, and assigns responsibility for uninsured medical expenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(17): 78B-15-201 "Parent" means an individual who has established a parent-child relationship under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(18)(a): "Parent-child relationship" means the legal relationship between a child and a parent of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(18)(b): "Parent-child relationship" includes the mother-child relationship and the father-child relationship.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(19): "Paternity index" means the likelihood of paternity calculated by computing the ratio between:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(19)(a): the likelihood that the tested man is the father, based on the genetic markers of the tested man and child, conditioned on the hypothesis that the tested man is the father of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(19)(b): the likelihood that the tested man is not the father, based on the genetic markers of the tested man and child, conditioned on the hypothesis that the tested man is not the father of the child and that the father is of the same ethnic or racial group as the tested man.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(20): 78B-15-204 "Presumed father" means a man who, by operation of law under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(21): "Probability of paternity" means the measure, for the ethnic or racial group to which the alleged father belongs, of the probability that the man in question is the father of the child, compared with a random, unrelated man of the same ethnic or racial group, expressed as a percentage incorporating the paternity index and a prior probability.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(22): "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(23): "Signatory" means an individual who authenticates a record and is bound by its terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(24): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, any territory, Native American Tribe, or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(25): "Support-enforcement agency" means a public official or agency authorized under Title IV-D of the Social Security Act which has the authority to seek:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(25)(a): enforcement of support orders or laws relating to the duty of support;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(25)(b): establishment or modification of child support;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(25)(c): determination of parentage; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(25)(d): location of child-support obligors and their income and assets.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-102(26): "Tribunal" means a court of law, administrative agency, or quasi-judicial entity authorized to establish, enforce, or modify support orders or to determine parentage.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-103 Scope -- Choice of law.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-103(1): This chapter applies to determinations of parentage in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-103(2): The tribunal shall apply the law of this state to adjudicate the parent-child relationship.  The applicable law may not depend upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-103(2)(a): the place of birth of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-103(2)(b): the past or present residence of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-103(3): This chapter may not create, enlarge, or diminish parental rights or duties under other laws of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-104 Jurisdiction -- Authority of Office of Recovery Services -- Dismissal of petition.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-104(1): 78A-6-104(1)(a)(i); 78A-6-104(1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-104(1)(a): 78A-6-104(1)(a)(i) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-104(1)(b): 78A-6-104(1)(a)(i) If the juvenile court has concurrent jurisdiction under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-104(2): Title 26B, Chapter 9, Recovery Services and Administration of Child Support; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The Office of Recovery Services is authorized to establish paternity in accordance with this chapter,
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-104(3): 78B-6-121; 78B-6-122 A court shall, without adjudicating paternity, dismiss a petition that is filed under this chapter by an unmarried biological father if he is not entitled to consent to the adoption of the child under Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-105 Protection of participants.
------------------------------------------------------------
Proceedings under this chapter are subject to other laws of this state governing the health, safety, privacy, and liberty of a child or other individual who could be jeopardized by disclosure of identifying information, including address, telephone number, place of employment, Social Security number, the child's day-care facility, or school.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-106 Determination of maternity.
------------------------------------------------------------
Provisions of this chapter relating to determination of paternity also apply to determinations of maternity.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-107 Effect.
----------------------------------------
An adjudication or declaration of paternity shall be filed with the state registrar in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-108 Obligation to provide address.
---------------------------------------------------------------
A party to an action under this chapter has a continuing obligation to keep the tribunal informed of the party's current address.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-109 Limitation on recovery from the obligor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The obligor's liabilities for past support are limited to the period of four years preceding the commencement of an action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-110 Duty of attorney general and county attorney.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever the state commences an action under this chapter, it shall be the duty of the attorney general or the county attorney of the county where the obligee resides to represent the state.  Neither the attorney general nor the county attorney represents or has an attorney-client relationship with the obligee or the obligor in carrying out his responsibilities under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-111 Default judgment.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Rule of Civil Procedure 55, Default Judgment, shall apply to paternity actions commenced under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-112 Standard of proof.
---------------------------------------------------
The standard of proof in a trial to determine paternity is "by clear and convincing evidence."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-113 Parent-time rights of father.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-113(1): If the tribunal determines that the alleged father is the father, the tribunal may upon the tribunal's own motion or upon motion of the father, order parent-time rights in accordance with Title 81, Chapter 9, Custody, Parent-time, and Visitation, as the tribunal considers appropriate under the circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-113(2): Parent-time rights may not be granted to a father if the child has been subsequently adopted.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-114 Social Security number in tribunal records.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Social Security number of any individual who is subject to a paternity determination shall be placed in the records relating to the matter.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-115 Settlement agreements.
-------------------------------------------------------
An agreement of settlement with the alleged father is binding only when approved by the tribunal.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201 Establishment of parent-child relationship.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(1): Part 8, Gestational Agreement; Part 8, Gestational Agreement; 78B-15-204; 78B-15-201(2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(1)(a): Part 8, Gestational Agreement; Part 8, Gestational Agreement; 78B-15-204 The mother-child relationship is established between a woman and a child by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(1)(a)(i): Part 8, Gestational Agreement the woman's having given birth to the child, except as otherwise provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(1)(a)(ii): an adjudication of the woman's maternity;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(1)(a)(iii): adoption of the child by the woman;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(1)(a)(iv): Part 8, Gestational Agreement an adjudication confirming the woman as a parent of a child born to a gestational mother if the agreement was validated under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(1)(a)(v): 78B-15-204 an unrebutted presumption of maternity of the child established in the same manner as under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(1)(b): 78B-15-201(2)(a) In this chapter, the presumption of maternity shall be treated the same as a presumption of paternity as established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(2): 78B-15-204; Part 3, Voluntary Declaration of Paternity Act; Part 7, Assisted Reproduction; Part 8, Gestational Agreement The father-child relationship is established between a man and a child by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(2)(a): 78B-15-204 an unrebutted presumption of the man's paternity of the child under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(2)(b): Part 3, Voluntary Declaration of Paternity Act an effective declaration of paternity by the man under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(2)(c): an adjudication of the man's paternity;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(2)(d): adoption of the child by the man;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(2)(e): Part 7, Assisted Reproduction the man having consented to assisted reproduction by a woman under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-201(2)(f): Part 8, Gestational Agreement an adjudication confirming the man as a parent of a child born to a gestational mother if the agreement was validated under


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-202 No discrimination based on marital status.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
A child born to parents who are not married to each other whose paternity has been determined under this chapter has the same rights under the law as a child born to parents who are married to each other.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-203 Consequences of establishment of parentage.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless parental rights are terminated, a parent-child relationship established under this chapter applies for all purposes, except as otherwise specifically provided by other law of this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204 Presumption of paternity.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(1): A man is presumed to be the father of a child if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(1)(a): he and the mother of the child are married to each other and the child is born during the marriage;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(1)(b): he and the mother of the child were married to each other and the child is born within 300 days after the marriage is terminated by death, annulment, declaration of invalidity, or divorce, or after a decree of separation;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(1)(c): before the birth of the child, he and the mother of the child married each other in apparent compliance with law, even if the attempted marriage is or could be declared invalid, and the child is born during the invalid marriage or within 300 days after its termination by death, annulment, declaration of invalidity, or divorce or after a decree of separation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(1)(d): after the birth of the child, he and the mother of the child married each other in apparent compliance with law, whether or not the marriage is, or could be declared, invalid, he voluntarily asserted his paternity of the child, and there is no other presumptive father of the child, and:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(1)(d)(i): the assertion is in a record filed with the Office of Vital Records;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(1)(d)(ii): he agreed to be and is named as the child's father on the child's birth certificate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(1)(d)(iii): he promised in a record to support the child as his own.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(2): 78B-15-607 A presumption of paternity established under this section may only be rebutted in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-204(3): 78B-15-607 If a child has an adjudicated father, the results of genetic testing are inadmissable to challenge paternity except as set forth in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-301 Declaration of paternity.
----------------------------------------------------------
The mother of a child and a man claiming to be the genetic father of the child may sign a declaration of paternity to establish the paternity of the child.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302 Execution of declaration of paternity.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1): 78B-15-307 A declaration of paternity must:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1)(a): be in a record;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1)(b): be signed, or otherwise authenticated, under penalty of perjury, by the mother and by the declarant father;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1)(c): be signed by the birth mother and declarant father in the presence of two witnesses who are not related by blood or marriage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1)(d): state that the child whose paternity is being declared:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1)(d)(i): does not have a presumed father, or has a presumed father whose full name is stated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1)(d)(ii): does not have another declarant or adjudicated father;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1)(e): state whether there has been genetic testing and, if so, that the declarant man's claim of paternity is consistent with the results of the testing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(1)(f): 78B-15-307 state that the signatories understand that the declaration is the equivalent of a legal finding of paternity of the child and that a challenge to the declaration is permitted only under the limited circumstances described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(2): If either the birth mother or the declarant father is a minor, the voluntary declaration must also be signed by that minor's parent or legal guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(3): 78B-15-303 A declaration of paternity is void if it:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(3)(a): 78B-15-303 states that another man is a presumed father, unless a denial of paternity signed or otherwise authenticated by the presumed father is filed with the Office of Vital Records in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(3)(b): states that another man is a declarant or adjudicated father; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(3)(c): falsely denies the existence of a presumed, declarant, or adjudicated father of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(4): A presumed father may sign or otherwise authenticate an acknowledgment of paternity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(5): The declaration of paternity shall be in a form prescribed by the Office of Vital Records and shall be accompanied with a written and verbal notice of the alternatives to, the legal consequences of, and the rights and responsibilities that arise from signing the declaration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(6): The Social Security number of any person who is subject to declaration of paternity shall be placed in the records relating to the matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(7): The declaration of paternity shall become an amendment to the original birth certificate.  The original certificate and the declaration shall be marked as to be distinguishable.  The declaration may be included as part of subsequently issued certified copies of the birth certificate.  Alternatively, electronically issued copies of a certificate may reflect the amended information and the date of the amendment only.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(8): A declaration of paternity may be completed and signed any time after the birth of the child.  A declaration of paternity may not be signed or filed after consent to or relinquishment for adoption has been signed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-302(9): A declaration of paternity shall be considered effective when filed and entered into a database established and maintained by the Office of Vital Records.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-303 Denial of paternity.
-----------------------------------------------------
A presumed or declarant father may sign a denial of his paternity.  The denial is valid only if:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-303(1): 78B-15-305 a declaration of paternity signed, or otherwise authenticated, by another man is filed pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-303(2): the denial is in a form prescribed by and filed with the Office of Vital Records, and is signed, or otherwise authenticated, under penalty of perjury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-303(3): 78B-15-306; 78B-15-307 the presumed or declarant father has not previously:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-303(3)(a): 78B-15-306; 78B-15-307 declared his paternity, unless the previous declaration has been rescinded pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-303(3)(b): been adjudicated to be the father of the child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-304 Rules for declaration and denial of paternity.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-304(1): A declaration of paternity and a denial of paternity shall be contained in a single document.  If the declaration and denial are both necessary, neither is valid until both are signed and filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-304(2): A declaration of paternity or a denial of paternity may not be signed before the birth of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-304(3): (1) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-304(4): A declaration of paternity or denial of paternity signed by a minor and by the minor's parent or legal guardian is valid if it is otherwise in compliance with this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-305 Effect of declaration or denial of paternity.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-305(1): 78B-15-306; 78B-15-307 Except as otherwise provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-305(2): When a declaration of paternity is filed, it shall be recognized as a basis for a child support order without any further requirement or proceeding regarding the establishment of paternity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-305(2)(a): The liabilities of the father include, but are not limited to, the reasonable expense of the mother's pregnancy and confinement and for the education, necessary support, and any funeral expenses for the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-305(2)(b): When a father declares paternity, his liability for past amounts due is limited to the period of four years immediately preceding the date that the voluntary declaration of paternity was filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-305(3): 78B-15-306; 78B-15-307 Except as otherwise provided in Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-306(1)(b): the date of notice of the first adjudicative proceeding to which the signatory is a party, before a tribunal to adjudicate an issue relating to the child, including a proceeding that establishes support.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-308 Procedure for rescission or challenge.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-308(1): Every signatory to a declaration of paternity and any related denial of paternity must be made a party to a proceeding to rescind or challenge the declaration or denial.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-308(2): For the purpose of rescission of, or challenge to, a declaration of paternity or denial of paternity, a signatory submits to personal jurisdiction of this state by signing the declaration or denial, effective upon the filing of the document with the Office of Vital Records.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-308(3): Except for good cause shown, during the pendency of a proceeding to rescind or challenge a declaration of paternity or denial of paternity, the tribunal may not suspend the legal responsibilities of a signatory arising from the declaration, including the duty to pay child support.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-308(4): Part 6, Adjudication of Parentage A proceeding to rescind or to challenge a declaration of paternity or denial of paternity must be conducted in the same manner as a proceeding to adjudicate parentage under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-308(5): At the conclusion of a proceeding to rescind or challenge a declaration of paternity or denial of paternity, the tribunal shall order the Office of Vital Records to amend the birth record of the child, if appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-308(6): If the declaration is rescinded, the declarant father may not recover child support he paid prior to the entry of an order of rescission.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-309 Ratification barred.
-----------------------------------------------------
A tribunal or administrative agency conducting a judicial or administrative proceeding may not ratify an unchallenged declaration of paternity.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-310 Full faith and credit.
-------------------------------------------------------
A tribunal of this state shall give full faith and credit to a declaration of paternity or denial of paternity effective in another state if the declaration or denial has been signed and is otherwise in compliance with the law of the other state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-311 Forms for declaration and denial of paternity and for rescission of paternity.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-311(1): To facilitate compliance with this part, the Office of Vital Records shall prescribe forms for the declaration, denial, and rescission of paternity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-311(2): A valid declaration of paternity or denial of paternity is not affected by a later modification of the prescribed form.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-312 Release of information.
--------------------------------------------------------
The Office of Vital Records may release information relating to the declaration of paternity or denial of paternity to a signatory of the declaration or denial and to tribunals and federal, tribal, and state support-enforcement agencies of this or another state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-501 Scope of part.
-----------------------------------------------
This part governs genetic testing of an individual to determine parentage, whether the individual:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-501(1): voluntarily submits to testing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-501(2): is tested pursuant to an order of a tribunal or a support-enforcement agency.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-502 Order for testing.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-502(1): Part 6, Adjudication of Parentage Upon the motion of any party to the action, except as otherwise provided in this part and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-502(1)(a): alleging paternity and stating facts establishing a reasonable probability of the requisite sexual contact between the individuals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-502(1)(b): denying paternity and stating facts establishing a possibility that sexual contact between the individuals, if any, did not result in the conception of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-502(2): If a request for genetic testing of a child is made before birth, the tribunal may not order in-utero testing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-502(3): If two or more men are subject to an order for genetic testing, the testing may be ordered concurrently or sequentially.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-503 Requirements for genetic testing.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-503(1): Genetic testing must be of a type reasonably relied upon by experts in the field of genetic testing and performed in a testing laboratory accredited by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-503(1)(a): the American Association of Blood Banks, or a successor to its functions;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-503(1)(b): the American Society for Histocompatibility and Immunogenetics, or a successor to its functions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-503(1)(c): an accrediting body designated by the federal Secretary of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-503(2): A specimen used in genetic testing may consist of one or more samples, or a combination of samples, of blood, buccal cells, bone, hair, or other body tissue or fluid.  The specimen used in the testing need not be of the same kind for each individual undergoing genetic testing.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504 Report of genetic testing.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504(1): A report of genetic testing must be in a record and signed under penalty of perjury by a designee of the testing laboratory.  A report made under the requirements of this part is self-authenticating.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504(2): Documentation from the testing laboratory of the following information is sufficient to establish a reliable chain of custody that allows the results of genetic testing to be admissible without testimony:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504(2)(a): the names and photographs of the individuals whose specimens have been taken;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504(2)(b): the names of the individuals who collected the specimens;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504(2)(c): the places and dates the specimens were collected;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504(2)(d): the names of the individuals who received the specimens in the testing laboratory;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504(2)(e): the dates the specimens were received; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-504(2)(f): the fingerprints of the individuals whose specimens have been taken.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505 Genetic testing results -- Rebuttal.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505(1): Under this chapter, a man is presumed to be identified as the father of a child if the genetic testing complies with this part and the results disclose that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505(1)(a): the man has at least a 99% probability of paternity, using a prior probability of 0.50, as calculated by using the combined paternity index obtained in the testing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505(1)(b): a combined paternity index of at least 100 to 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505(2): (1) A man identified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505(2)(a): excludes the man as a genetic father of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505(2)(b): identifies another man as the possible father of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505(3): If an issue is raised as to whether the appropriate ethnic or racial group database was used by the testing laboratory, the testing laboratory will be asked to rerun the test using the correct ethnic or racial group database.  If the testing laboratory does not have an adequate database, another testing laboratory may be engaged to perform the calculations.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-505(4): If a presumption of paternity is not rebutted by a second test, the tribunal shall issue an order establishing paternity.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-506 Costs of genetic testing.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-506(1): Part 6, Adjudication of Parentage Subject to assessment of costs under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-506(1)(a): by a support-enforcement agency in a proceeding in which the support-enforcement agency is providing services;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-506(1)(b): by the individual who made the request;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-506(1)(c): as agreed by the parties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-506(1)(d): as ordered by the tribunal.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-506(2): In cases in which the cost is advanced by the support-enforcement agency, the agency may seek reimbursement from a man who is rebuttably identified as the father.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-507 Additional genetic testing.
------------------------------------------------------------
The tribunal shall order additional genetic testing upon the request of a party who contests the result of the original testing.  If the previous genetic testing identified a man as the father of the child under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-509 Deceased individual.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-510 Identical brothers.
----------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-604 Personal jurisdiction.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-604(1): An individual may not be adjudicated to be a parent unless the tribunal has personal jurisdiction over the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-604(2): 78B-14-201 A tribunal of this state having jurisdiction to adjudicate parentage may exercise personal jurisdiction over a nonresident individual, or the guardian or conservator of the individual, if the conditions prescribed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-604(3): Lack of jurisdiction over one individual does not preclude the tribunal from making an adjudication of parentage binding on another individual over whom the tribunal has personal jurisdiction.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-605 Venue.
---------------------------------------
Venue for a judicial proceeding to adjudicate parentage is in the county of this state in which:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-605(1): the child resides or is found;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-605(2): the respondent resides or is found if the child does not reside in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-605(3): a proceeding for probate or administration of the presumed or alleged father's estate has been commenced.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-606 No limitation -- Child having no declarant or adjudicated father.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A proceeding to adjudicate the parentage of a child having no declarant or adjudicated father may be commenced at any time.  If initiated after the child becomes an adult, only the child may initiate the proceeding.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607 Limitation -- Child having presumed father.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(1): 78B-15-204(1)(a); (b); (c); 78B-15-608 Paternity of a child conceived or born during a marriage with a presumed father, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(1)(a): 78B-15-608 If the issue is raised prior to the adjudication, genetic testing may be ordered by the tribunal in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(1)(b): If the presumed father seeks to rebut the presumption of paternity, then denial of a motion seeking an order for genetic testing or a decision to disregard genetic test results shall be based on a preponderance of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(1)(c): If the mother seeks to rebut the presumption of paternity, the mother has the burden to show by a preponderance of the evidence that it would be in the best interests of the child to disestablish the parent-child relationship.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(1)(d): If a support enforcement agency seeks to rebut the presumption of parentage and the presumptive parent opposes the rebuttal, the agency's request shall be denied.  Otherwise, the denial of the agency's motion seeking an order for genetic testing or a decision to disregard genetic test results shall be based on a preponderance of the evidence, taking into account the best interests of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(2): 78B-15-204(1)(d) For the presumption outside of marriage described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(3): 78B-15-505 The presumption may be rebutted by:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(3)(a): genetic test results that exclude the presumed father;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(3)(b): 78B-15-505 genetic test results that rebuttably identify another man as the father in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(3)(c): evidence that the presumed father and the mother of the child neither cohabited nor engaged in sexual intercourse with each other during the probable time of conception; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(3)(d): an adjudication under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-607(4): There is no presumption to rebut if the presumed father was properly served and there has been a final adjudication of the issue.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608 Authority to deny motion for genetic testing or disregard test results.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(1): In a proceeding to adjudicate the parentage of a child having a presumed father or to challenge the paternity of a child having a declarant father, the tribunal may deny a motion seeking an order for genetic testing of the mother, the child, and the presumed or declarant father, or if testing has been completed, the tribunal may disregard genetic test results that exclude the presumed or declarant father if the tribunal determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(1)(a): the conduct of the mother or the presumed or declarant father estops that party from denying parentage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(1)(b): it would be inequitable to disrupt the father-child relationship between the child and the presumed or declarant father.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2): In determining whether to deny a motion seeking an order for genetic testing or to disregard genetic test results under this section, the tribunal shall consider the best interest of the child, including the following factors:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(a): the length of time between the proceeding to adjudicate parentage and the time that the presumed or declarant father was placed on notice that he might not be the genetic father;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(b): the length of time during which the presumed or declarant father has assumed the role of father of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(c): the facts surrounding the presumed or declarant father's discovery of his possible nonpaternity;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(d): the nature of the relationship between the child and the presumed or declarant father;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(e): the age of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(f): the harm that may result to the child if presumed or declared paternity is successfully disestablished;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(g): the nature of the relationship between the child and any alleged father;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(h): the extent to which the passage of time reduces the chances of establishing the paternity of another man and a child-support obligation in favor of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(2)(i): other factors that may affect the equities arising from the disruption of the father-child relationship between the child and the presumed or declarant father or the chance of other harm to the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-608(3): If the tribunal denies a motion seeking an order for genetic testing or disregards genetic test results that exclude the presumed or declarant father, it shall issue an order adjudicating the presumed or declarant father to be the father of the child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-609 Limitation -- Child having declarant father.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-609(1): 78B-15-306; 78B-15-307 If a child has a declarant father, a signatory to the declaration of paternity or denial of paternity or a support-enforcement agency may commence a proceeding seeking to rescind the declaration or denial or challenge the paternity of the child only within the time allowed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-609(2): 78B-15-608 A proceeding under this section is subject to the application of the principles of estoppel established in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610 Joinder of judicial proceedings -- Court reliance of custody and parent-time standards.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(1): Except as otherwise provided in Subsection (2), a judicial proceeding to adjudicate parentage may be joined with a proceeding for adoption, termination of parental rights, child custody or visitation, child support, divorce, annulment, legal separation or separate maintenance, probate or administration of an estate, or other appropriate proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(2): A respondent may not join a proceeding described in Subsection (1) with a proceeding to adjudicate parentage brought under Title 78B, Chapter 14, Utah Uniform Interstate Family Support Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(3): A court may determine issues of custody, parent-time, visitation, and child support in accordance with Title 81, Chapter 6, Child Support, and Title 81, Chapter 9, Custody, Parent-time, and Visitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4): 81-9-103(1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4)(a): 81-9-103(1)(b) If a parentage action is determining issues of custody or parent-time for a child and the parents of the child are not married, the parties shall attend the mandatory parenting course described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4)(a)(i): for the petitioner, 60 days after the day on which the petition is filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4)(a)(ii): for the respondent, 30 days after the day on which the respondent is served.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4)(b): The clerk of the court shall provide notice to a petitioner that the petitioner is required to attend the parenting course.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4)(c): A petition shall include information regarding the parenting course when the petition is served on the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4)(d): The court may not grant a final custody or parent-time order in a parentage action until:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4)(d)(i): both parties have attended the parenting course; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(4)(d)(ii): both parties have presented a certificate of course completion to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(5): For a party that is unable to pay the costs of the parenting course, and before the court enters an order for custody or parent-time in the parentage action, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(5)(a): make a final determination of indigency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(5)(b): order the party to pay the costs of the parenting course if the court determines the party is not indigent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(6)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (4), the court may waive the requirement that the parties attend the parenting course, on the court's own motion or on the motion of one of the parties, if the court determines course attendance and completion are not necessary, appropriate, or feasible, or in the best interest of the parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-610(6)(b): If the requirement is waived, the court may proceed with entering a final custody or parent-time order.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-611 Proceeding before birth.
---------------------------------------------------------
A proceeding to determine parentage may be commenced before the birth of the child, but may not be concluded until after the birth of the child.  The following actions may be taken before the birth of the child:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-611(1): service of process;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-611(2): discovery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-611(3): 78B-15-502 except as prohibited by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-612 Minor as party -- Representation.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-612(1): A minor is a permissible party, but is not a necessary party to a proceeding under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-612(2): 78A-2-703; 78A-2-803; 78A-2-705 The tribunal may appoint an attorney guardian ad litem under Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-613 Admissibility of results of genetic testing -- Expenses.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-613(2): A party objecting to the results of genetic testing may call one or more genetic-testing experts to testify in person or by telephone, video conference, deposition, or another method approved by the tribunal.  Unless otherwise ordered by the tribunal, the party offering the testimony bears the expense for the expert testifying.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-614 Consequences of failing to submit to genetic testing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-614(1): An order for genetic testing is enforceable by contempt.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-614(2): If an individual whose paternity is being determined fails to submit to genetic testing ordered by the tribunal, the tribunal for that reason may adjudicate parentage contrary to the position of that individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-614(3): Genetic testing of the mother of a child is not a condition precedent to testing the child and a man whose paternity is being determined.  If the mother is unavailable or fails to submit to genetic testing, the tribunal may order the testing of the child and every man who is potentially the father of the child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-615 Admission of paternity authorized.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-615(1): A respondent in a proceeding to adjudicate parentage may admit to the paternity of a child by filing a pleading to that effect or by admitting paternity under penalty of perjury when making an appearance or during a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-615(2): If the tribunal finds that the admission of paternity satisfies the requirements of this section and finds that there is no reason to question the admission, the tribunal shall issue an order adjudicating the child to be the child of the man admitting paternity.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616 Temporary order.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616(1): 78B-15-505 In a proceeding under this part, the tribunal shall issue a temporary order for support of a child if the order is appropriate and the individual ordered to pay support is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616(1)(a): a presumed father of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616(1)(b): petitioning to have his paternity adjudicated;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616(1)(c): 78B-15-505 identified as the father through genetic testing under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616(1)(d): an alleged father who has failed to submit to genetic testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616(1)(e): shown by clear and convincing evidence to be the father of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616(1)(f): the mother of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-616(2): A temporary tribunal order may include provisions for custody and visitation as provided by other laws of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-617 Rules for adjudication of paternity.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The tribunal shall apply the following rules to adjudicate the paternity of a child:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-617(1): The paternity of a child having a presumed, declarant, or adjudicated father may be disproved only by admissible results of genetic testing excluding that man as the father of the child or identifying another man as the father of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-617(2): 78B-15-505; 78B-15-608 Unless the results of genetic testing are admitted to rebut other results of genetic testing, a man identified as the father of a child under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-617(3): 78B-15-505 If the tribunal finds that genetic testing under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-617(4): Unless the results of genetic testing are admitted to rebut other results of genetic testing, a man properly excluded as the father of a child by genetic testing must be adjudicated not to be the father of the child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-618 Adjudication of parentage -- Jury trial prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A jury trial is prohibited to adjudicate paternity of a child.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-619 Adjudication of parentage -- Hearings -- Inspection of records.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-619(1): On request of a party and for good cause shown, the tribunal may close a proceeding under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-619(2): A final order in a proceeding under this part is available for public inspection.  Other papers and records are available only with the consent of the parties or on order of the tribunal for good cause.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-620 Adjudication of parentage -- Order on default.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The tribunal shall issue an order adjudicating the paternity of a man who:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-620(1): after service of process, is in default; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-620(2): is found by the tribunal to be the father of a child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-621 Adjudication of parentage -- Dismissal for want of prosecution.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The tribunal may issue an order dismissing a proceeding commenced under this chapter for want of prosecution only without prejudice.  An order of dismissal for want of prosecution purportedly with prejudice is void and has only the effect of a dismissal without prejudice.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-622 Order adjudicating parentage.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-622(1): The tribunal shall issue an order adjudicating whether a man alleged or claiming to be the father is the parent of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-622(2): An order adjudicating parentage must identify the child by name and date of birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-622(3): (4) Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-622(4): The tribunal may not assess fees, costs, or expenses against the support-enforcement agency of this state or another state, except as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-622(5): On request of a party and for good cause shown, the tribunal may order that the name of the child be changed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-622(6): If the order of the tribunal is at variance with the child's birth certificate, the tribunal shall order the Office of Vital Records to issue an amended birth registration.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623 Binding effect of determination of parentage.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(1): 78B-14-201 Except as otherwise provided in Subsection (2), a determination of parentage is binding on:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(1)(a): all signatories to a declaration or denial of paternity as provided in Part 3, Voluntary Declaration of Paternity Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(1)(b): 78B-14-201 all parties to an adjudication by a tribunal acting under circumstances that satisfy the jurisdictional requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(2): A child is not bound by a determination of parentage under this chapter unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(2)(a): the determination was based on an unrescinded declaration of paternity and the declaration is consistent with the results of genetic testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(2)(b): the adjudication of parentage was based on a finding consistent with the results of genetic testing and the consistency is declared in the determination or is otherwise shown; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(2)(c): the child was a party or was represented in the proceeding determining parentage by a guardian ad litem.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(3): In a proceeding to dissolve a marriage, the tribunal is considered to have made an adjudication of the parentage of a child if the question of paternity is raised and the tribunal adjudicates according to Part 6, Adjudication of Parentage, and the final order:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(3)(a): expressly identifies a child as a "child of the marriage," "issue of the marriage," or similar words indicating that the husband is the father of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(3)(b): provides for support of the child by the husband unless paternity is specifically disclaimed in the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(4): The tribunal is not considered to have made an adjudication of the parentage of a child if the child was born at the time of entry of the order and other children are named as children of the marriage, but that child is specifically not named.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(5): Once the paternity of a child has been adjudicated, an individual who was not a party to the paternity proceeding may not challenge the paternity, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(5)(a): the party seeking to challenge can demonstrate a fraud upon the tribunal;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(5)(b): the challenger can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that the challenger did not know about the adjudicatory proceeding or did not have a reasonable opportunity to know of the proceeding; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(5)(c): there would be harm to the child to leave the order in place.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(6): A party to an adjudication of paternity may challenge the adjudication only under law of this state relating to appeal, vacation of judgments, or other judicial review.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-623(7): A party to an adjudication may not bring a challenge under Subsection (6) if the party committed the fraud.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-701 Scope.
---------------------------------------
This part does not apply to the birth of a child conceived by means of sexual intercourse, or as result of a gestational agreement as provided in

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-702 Parental status of donor.
----------------------------------------------------------
A donor is not a parent of a child conceived by means of assisted reproduction.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-703 Husband's paternity of child of assisted reproduction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a husband provides sperm for, or consents to, assisted reproduction by his wife as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-704 Consent to assisted reproduction.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-704(1): A consent to assisted reproduction by a married woman must be in a record signed by the woman and her husband.  This requirement does not apply to the donation of eggs for assisted reproduction by another woman.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-704(2): (1) Failure of the husband to sign a consent required by Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705 Limitation on husband's dispute of paternity.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705(1): (2) Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705(1)(a): within two years after learning of the birth of the child he commences a proceeding to adjudicate his paternity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705(1)(b): the tribunal finds that he did not consent to the assisted reproduction, before or after the birth of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705(2): A proceeding to adjudicate paternity may be maintained at any time if the tribunal determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705(2)(a): the husband did not provide sperm for, or before or after the birth of the child consent to, assisted reproduction by his wife;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705(2)(b): the husband and the mother of the child have not cohabited since the probable time of assisted reproduction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705(2)(c): the husband never openly treated the child as his own.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-705(3): The limitation provided in this section applies to a marriage declared invalid after assisted reproduction.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-706 Effect of dissolution of marriage.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-706(1): If a marriage is dissolved before placement of eggs, sperm, or an embryo, the former spouse is not a parent of the resulting child unless the former spouse consented in a record that if assisted reproduction were to occur after a divorce, the former spouse would be a parent of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-706(2): The consent of the former spouse to assisted reproduction may be revoked by that individual in a record at any time before placement of eggs, sperm, or embryos.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-707 Parental status of deceased spouse.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
If a spouse dies before placement of eggs, sperm, or an embryo, the deceased spouse is not a parent of the resulting child unless the deceased spouse consented in a record that if assisted reproduction were to occur after death, the deceased spouse would be a parent of the child.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-708 Access to identifying information and medical history.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-708(1): A person conceived through assisted reproduction who is at least 18 years of age shall be provided, upon the person's request, access to the nonidentifying medical history of the donor who assisted in the reproduction process that resulted in the person's birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-708(2): Under no circumstance may a person who donated to a fertility clinic for the purpose of assisted reproduction be liable for financial support to the child conceived through assisted reproduction or the child's parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-708(3): Except as provided in this section, a donor's request to remain anonymous shall be given full deference.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801 Gestational agreement authorized.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(1): A prospective gestational mother, the prospective gestational mother's spouse if the prospective gestational mother is married, a donor or the donors, and the intended parents may enter into a written agreement providing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(1)(a): the prospective gestational mother agrees to pregnancy by means of assisted reproduction;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(1)(b): the prospective gestational mother, the prospective gestational mother's spouse if the prospective gestational mother is married, and the donors relinquish all rights and duties as the parents of a child conceived through assisted reproduction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(1)(c): the intended parents become the parents of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(2): The intended gestational mother may not currently be receiving Medicaid or any other state assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(3)(a): The intended parents shall be married.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(3)(b): Both intended parents must be parties to the gestational agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(4): 78B-15-803 A gestational agreement is enforceable only if validated as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(5): A gestational agreement does not apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(5)(a): to the birth of a child conceived by means of sexual intercourse; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(5)(b): if neither intended parent is a donor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(6): The parties to a gestational agreement shall be 21 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(7): The gestational mother's eggs may not be used in the assisted reproduction procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-801(8): If the gestational mother is married, the gestational mother's spouse's sperm or eggs may not be used in the assisted reproduction procedure.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-802 Requirements of petition.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-802(1): The intended parents and the prospective gestational mother may file a petition in the district tribunal to validate a gestational agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-802(2): A petition to validate a gestational agreement may not be maintained unless either the mother or intended parents have been residents of this state for at least 90 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-802(3): The prospective gestational mother's spouse, if the prospective gestational mother is married, must join in the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-802(4): A copy of the gestational agreement must be attached to the petition.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803 Hearing to validate gestational agreement.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(1): If the requirements of Subsection (2) are satisfied, a tribunal may issue an order validating the gestational agreement and declaring that the intended parents will be the parents of a child born during the term of the agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2): 78B-15-802; 78B-6-128; 78B-6-131 The tribunal may issue an order under Subsection (1) only on finding that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(a): 78B-15-802 the residence requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(b): 78B-6-128; 78B-6-131 unless waived by the tribunal, a home study of the intended parents has been conducted in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(c): all parties have participated in counseling with a licensed mental health professional as evidenced by a certificate:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(c)(i): signed by the licensed mental health professional that affirms that all parties have discussed options and consequences of the agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(c)(ii): presented to the tribunal;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(d): all parties have voluntarily entered into the agreement and understand the agreement's terms;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(e): the prospective gestational mother has had at least one pregnancy and delivery and the prospective gestational mother's bearing another child will not pose an unreasonable health risk to the unborn child or to the physical or mental health of the prospective gestational mother;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(f): adequate provision has been made for all reasonable health-care expense associated with the gestational agreement until the birth of the child, including responsibility for all reasonable health-care expense if the agreement is terminated;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(g): the consideration, if any, paid to the prospective gestational mother is reasonable;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(h): all the parties to the agreement are 21 years old or older;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(i): the gestational mother's eggs are not being used in the assisted reproduction procedure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(2)(j): if the gestational mother is married, the gestational mother's spouse's sperm or eggs are not being used in the assisted reproduction procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-803(3): Whether to validate a gestational agreement is within the discretion of the tribunal, subject only to review for abuse of discretion.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-804 Inspection of records.
-------------------------------------------------------
The proceedings, records, and identities of the individuals to a gestational agreement under this part are subject to inspection under the confidentiality standards applicable to adoptions as provided under other laws of this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-805 Exclusive, continuing jurisdiction.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to the jurisdictional standards of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-806 Termination of gestational agreement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-806(1): After issuance of an order under this part, but before the prospective gestational mother becomes pregnant by means of assisted reproduction, the prospective gestational mother, the prospective gestational mother's spouse, or either of the intended parents may terminate the gestational agreement only by giving written notice of termination to all other parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-806(2): The tribunal for good cause shown also may terminate the gestational agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-806(3): An individual who terminates an agreement shall file notice of the termination with the tribunal.  On receipt of the notice, the tribunal shall vacate the order issued under this part.  An individual who does not notify the tribunal of the termination of the agreement is subject to appropriate sanctions.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-806(4): A prospective gestational mother, or the prospective gestational mother's spouse if married, is not liable to the intended parents for terminating an agreement pursuant to this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-807 Parentage under validated gestational agreement.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-807(1): Upon birth of a child to a gestational mother, the intended parents shall file notice with the tribunal that a child has been born to the gestational mother within 300 days after assisted reproduction.  Thereupon, the tribunal shall issue an order:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-807(1)(a): confirming that the intended parents are the parents of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-807(1)(b): if necessary, ordering that the child be surrendered to the intended parents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-807(1)(c): directing the Office of Vital Records to issue a birth certificate naming the intended parents as parents of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-807(2): If the parentage of a child born to the gestational mother is in dispute as not the result of an assisted reproduction, the tribunal shall order genetic testing to determine the parentage of the child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-808 Gestational agreement -- Miscellaneous provisions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-808(1): A gestational agreement may provide for payment of consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-808(2): A gestational agreement may not limit the right of the gestational mother to make decisions to safeguard the gestational mother's health or that of the embryo or fetus.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-808(3): After the issuance of an order under this part, subsequent marriage of the gestational mother does not affect the validity of a gestational agreement, and the gestational mother's spouse's consent to the agreement is not required, nor is the gestational mother's spouse a presumed parent of the resulting child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-809 Effect of nonvalidated gestational agreement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-809(1): A gestational agreement, whether in a record or not, which is not validated by a tribunal is not enforceable.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-809(2): Part 2, Parent and Child Relationship If a birth results under a gestational agreement that is not judicially validated as provided in this part, the parent-child relationship is determined as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-809(3): (3); 78B-15-622 The individuals who are parties to a nonvalidated gestational agreement as intended parents may be held liable for support of the resulting child, even if the agreement is otherwise unenforceable.  The liability under this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-901 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter is a uniform law.  In applying and construing this chapter, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among the states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-15-902 Transitional provision.
--------------------------------------------------------
A proceeding to adjudicate parentage which was commenced before May 1, 2005 is governed by the law in effect at the time the proceeding was commenced.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 16 - Utah Uniform Child Abduction Prevention Act
******************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Uniform Child Abduction Prevention Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
In this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(1): "Abduction" means the wrongful removal or wrongful retention of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(2): "Child" means an unemancipated individual who is less than 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(3): "Child custody determination" means a judgment, decree, or other order of a court providing for the legal custody, physical custody, or visitation with respect to a child.  The term includes a permanent, temporary, initial, and modification order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(4): "Child custody proceeding" means a proceeding in which legal custody, physical custody, visitation, or parent-time with respect to a child is at issue.  The term includes a proceeding for divorce, dissolution of marriage, separation, neglect, abuse, dependency, guardianship, paternity, termination of parental rights, or protection from domestic violence.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(5): "Court" means an entity authorized under the law of a state to establish, enforce, or modify a child custody determination.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(6): "Petition" includes a motion or its equivalent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(7): "Record" means information inscribed on a tangible medium or stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(8): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.  The term includes a federally recognized Indian tribe or nation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(9): "Travel document" means records relating to a travel itinerary, including travel tickets, passes, reservations for transportation, or accommodations.  The term does not include a passport or visa.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(10): "Wrongful removal" means the taking of a child that breaches rights of custody, visitation, or parent-time given or recognized under the law of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-102(11): "Wrongful retention" means the keeping or concealing of a child that breaches rights of custody, visitation, or parent-time given or recognized under the law of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-103 Cooperation and communication among courts.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-104 Actions for abduction prevention measures.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-104(1): A court on its own motion may order abduction prevention measures in a child custody proceeding if the court finds that the evidence establishes a credible risk of abduction of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-104(2): A party to a child custody determination or another individual or entity having a right under the law of this state or any other state to seek a child custody determination for the child may file a petition seeking abduction prevention measures to protect the child under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-104(3): 78B-13-315; 78B-16-109 A prosecutor or public authority designated under Section

----------------------------------------------
