Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-105(2): 78B-13-204 A court of this state has temporary emergency jurisdiction under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106 Contents of petition.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106(1): 78B-16-107 A petition under this chapter must be verified and include a copy of any existing child custody determination, if available.  The petition must specify the risk factors for abduction, including the relevant factors described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106(2): 78B-13-209(5); 78B-13-209 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106(2)(a): the name, date of birth, and gender of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106(2)(b): the customary address and current physical location of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106(2)(c): the identity, customary address, and current physical location of the respondent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106(2)(d): a statement of whether a prior action to prevent abduction or domestic violence has been filed by a party or other individual or entity having custody of the child, and the date, location, and disposition of the action;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106(2)(e): a statement of whether a party to the proceeding has been arrested for a crime related to domestic violence, stalking, or child abuse or neglect, and the date, location, and disposition of the case; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-106(2)(f): 78B-13-209 any other information required to be submitted to the court for a child custody determination under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107 Factors to determine risk of abduction.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1): In determining whether there is a credible risk of abduction of a child, the court shall consider any evidence that the petitioner or respondent:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(a): has previously abducted or attempted to abduct the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(b): has threatened to abduct the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(c): has recently engaged in activities that may indicate a planned abduction, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(c)(i): abandoning employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(c)(ii): selling a primary residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(c)(iii): terminating a lease;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(c)(iv): closing bank or other financial management accounts, liquidating assets, hiding or destroying financial documents, or conducting any unusual financial activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(c)(v): applying for a passport or visa or obtaining travel documents for the respondent, a family member, or the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(c)(vi): seeking to obtain the child's birth certificate or school or medical records;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(d): has engaged in domestic violence, stalking, or child abuse or neglect;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(e): has refused to follow a child custody determination;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(f): lacks strong familial, financial, emotional, or cultural ties to the state or the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(g): has strong familial, financial, emotional, or cultural ties to another state or country;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h): is likely to take the child to a country that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(i): is not a party to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and does not provide for the extradition of an abducting parent or for the return of an abducted child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(ii): is a party to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction but:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(ii)(A): the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is not in force between the United States and that country;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(ii)(B): is noncompliant according to the most recent compliance report issued by the United States Department of State; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(ii)(C): lacks legal mechanisms for immediately and effectively enforcing a return order under the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(iii): poses a risk that the child's physical or emotional health or safety would be endangered in the country because of specific circumstances relating to the child or because of human rights violations committed against children;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(iv): has laws or practices that would:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(iv)(A): enable the respondent, without due cause, to prevent the petitioner from contacting the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(iv)(B): restrict the petitioner from freely traveling to or exiting from the country because of the petitioner's gender, nationality, marital status, or religion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(iv)(C): restrict the child's ability legally to leave the country after the child reaches the age of majority because of a child's gender, nationality, or religion;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(v): is included by the United States Department of State on a current list of state sponsors of terrorism;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(vi): does not have an official United States diplomatic presence in the country; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(h)(vii): is engaged in active military action or war, including a civil war, to which the child may be exposed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(i): is undergoing a change in immigration or citizenship status that would adversely affect the respondent's ability to remain in the United States legally;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(j): has had an application for United States citizenship denied;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(k): has forged or presented misleading or false evidence on government forms or supporting documents to obtain or attempt to obtain a passport, a visa, travel documents, a Social Security card, a driver license, or other government-issued identification card or has made a misrepresentation to the United States government;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(l): has used multiple names to attempt to mislead or defraud; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(1)(m): has engaged in any other conduct the court considers relevant to the risk of abduction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-107(2): In the hearing on a petition under this chapter, the court shall consider any evidence that the respondent believed in good faith that the respondent's conduct was necessary to avoid imminent harm to the child or respondent and any other evidence that may be relevant to whether the respondent may be permitted to remove or retain the child.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108 Provisions and measures to prevent abduction.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(1): If a petition is filed under this chapter, the court may enter an order which must include:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(1)(a): the basis for the court's exercise of jurisdiction;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(1)(b): the manner in which notice and opportunity to be heard were given to the persons entitled to notice of the proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(1)(c): a detailed description of each party's custody and visitation rights and residential arrangements for the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(1)(d): a provision stating that a violation of the order may subject the party in violation to civil and criminal penalties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(1)(e): identification of the child's country of habitual residence at the time of the issuance of the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(2): (1); (3); (4); (5) If, at a hearing on a petition under this chapter or on the court's own motion, the court after reviewing the evidence finds a credible risk of abduction of the child, the court shall enter an abduction prevention order.  The order must include the provisions required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3): (3)(e)(i) An abduction prevention order may include one or more of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(a): an imposition of travel restrictions that require that a party traveling with the child outside a designated geographical area provide the other party with the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(a)(i): the travel itinerary of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(a)(ii): a list of physical addresses and telephone numbers at which the child can be reached at specified times; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(a)(iii): copies of all travel documents;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(b): a prohibition of the respondent directly or indirectly:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(b)(i): removing the child from this state, the United States, or another geographic area without permission of the court or the petitioner's written consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(b)(ii): removing or retaining the child in violation of a child custody determination;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(b)(iii): removing the child from school or a child-care or similar facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(b)(iv): approaching the child at any location other than a site designated for supervised visitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(c): a requirement that a party to register the order in another state as a prerequisite to allowing the child to travel to that state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(d): with regard to the child's passport:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(d)(i): a direction that the petitioner place the child's name in the United States Department of State's Child Passport Issuance Alert Program;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(d)(ii): a requirement that the respondent surrender to the court or the petitioner's attorney any United States or foreign passport issued in the child's name, including a passport issued in the name of both the parent and the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(d)(iii): a prohibition upon the respondent from applying on behalf of the child for a new or replacement passport or visa;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(e): (3)(e)(i) as a prerequisite to exercising custody, visitation, or parent-time, a requirement that the respondent provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(e)(i): to the United States Department of State Office of Children's Issues and the relevant foreign consulate or embassy, an authenticated copy of the order detailing passport and travel restrictions for the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(e)(ii): (3)(e)(i) to the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(e)(ii)(A): (3)(e)(i) proof that the respondent has provided the information in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(e)(ii)(B): an acknowledgment in a record from the relevant foreign consulate or embassy that no passport application has been made, or passport issued, on behalf of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(e)(iii): to the petitioner, proof of registration with the United States Embassy or other United States diplomatic presence in the destination country and with the Central Authority for the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, if that convention is in effect between the United States and the destination country, unless one of the parties objects; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(e)(iv): a written waiver under the Privacy Act, 5 U.S.C. Section 552a, with respect to any document, application, or other information pertaining to the child authorizing its disclosure to the court and the petitioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(3)(f): upon the petitioner's request, a requirement that the respondent obtain an order from the relevant foreign country containing terms identical to the child custody determination issued in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(4): In an abduction prevention order, the court may impose conditions on the exercise of custody or visitation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(4)(a): limit visitation or require that visitation with the child by the respondent be supervised until the court finds that supervision is no longer necessary and order the respondent to pay the costs of supervision;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(4)(b): require the respondent to post a bond or provide other security in an amount sufficient to serve as a financial deterrent to abduction, the proceeds of which may be used to pay for the reasonable expenses of recovery of the child, including reasonable attorney fees and costs if there is an abduction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(4)(c): require the respondent to obtain education on the potentially harmful effects to the child from abduction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(5): 78B-16-109 To prevent imminent abduction of a child, a court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(5)(a): 78B-16-109 issue a warrant to take physical custody of the child under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(5)(b): direct the use of law enforcement to take any action reasonably necessary to locate the child, obtain return of the child, or enforce a custody determination under this chapter or the law of this state other than this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(5)(c): grant any other relief allowed under the law of this state other than this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-108(6): The remedies provided in this chapter are cumulative and do not affect the availability of other remedies to prevent abduction.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-109 Warrant to take physical custody of child.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-109(1): If a petition under this chapter contains allegations, and the court finds that there is a credible risk that the child is imminently likely to be wrongfully removed, the court may issue an ex parte warrant to take physical custody of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-109(2): (1) The respondent on a petition under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-109(3)(d): provide for the safe interim placement of the child pending further order of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-109(4): If feasible, before issuing a warrant and before determining the placement of the child after the warrant is executed, the court may order a search of the relevant databases of the National Crime Information Center system and similar state databases to determine if either the petitioner or respondent has a history of domestic violence, stalking, or child abuse or neglect.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-109(5): The petition and warrant must be served on the respondent when or immediately after the child is taken into physical custody.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-109(6): A warrant to take physical custody of a child, issued by this state or another state, is enforceable throughout this state.  If the court finds that a less intrusive remedy will not be effective, it may authorize law enforcement officers to enter private property to take physical custody of the child.  If required by exigent circumstances, the court may authorize law enforcement officers to make a forcible entry at any hour.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-110 Duration of abduction prevention order.
------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-110(4): 78B-13-201; 78B-13-203 the time the order is modified, revoked, vacated, or superseded by a court with jurisdiction under Sections

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-16-112 Relation to electronic signatures in global and national commerce act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, and supersedes the federal Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Section 7001, et seq., but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of the act, 15 U.S.C. Section 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Section 7003(b).

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 17 - Utah Uniform Interstate Depositions and Discovery Act
****************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Uniform Interstate Depositions and Discovery Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102(1): "Foreign jurisdiction" means a state other than Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102(2): "Foreign subpoena" means a subpoena issued under authority of a court of record of a foreign jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102(3): "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture, public corporation, government or governmental subdivision, agency or instrumentality, or any other legal or commercial entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102(4): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, a federally recognized Indian tribe, or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102(5): "Subpoena" means a document, however denominated, issued under authority of a court of record requiring a person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102(5)(a): attend and give testimony at a deposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102(5)(b): produce and permit inspection and copying of designated books, documents, records, electronically stored information, or tangible things in the possession, custody, or control of the person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-102(5)(c): permit inspection of premises under the control of the person.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-103 Scope -- Unauthorized practice of law prohibited -- Reciprocity required.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-103(1): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-103(2): 78B-17-201(1)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-103(3): Parties resident in another state may use the provisions of this chapter for issuance, service, or enforcement of subpoenas only if the other state has enacted this uniform act or enacted provisions substantially similar to this uniform act.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-201 Issuance of subpoena.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-201(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-201(1)(a): To request issuance of a subpoena under this section, a party must submit a foreign subpoena to a court in the judicial district in which discovery is sought to be conducted in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-201(1)(b): A request for the issuance of a subpoena under this chapter does not constitute an appearance in the courts of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-201(2): When a party submits a foreign subpoena to a clerk of court in Utah, the clerk, in accordance with that court's procedure, shall promptly issue a subpoena for service upon the person to whom the foreign subpoena is directed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-201(3): (2) A subpoena under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-201(3)(a): incorporate the terms used in the foreign subpoena; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-17-201(3)(b): contain or be accompanied by the names, addresses, and telephone numbers of all counsel of record in the proceeding to which the subpoena relates and of any party not represented by counsel.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 18a - Uniform Unsworn Declarations Act
********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-101 Title.
----------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Uniform Unsworn Declarations Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
In this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(1): "Law" includes a statute, judicial decision or order, rule of court, executive order, and administrative rule, regulation, or order.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(2): "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(3): "Sign" means, with present intent to authenticate or adopt a record:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(3)(a): to execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(3)(b): to attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic symbol, sound, or process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(4)(a): "Sworn declaration" means a declaration in a signed record given under oath.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(4)(b): "Sworn declaration" includes a sworn statement, verification, certificate, and affidavit.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-18a-102(5): Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 5, Falsification in Official Matters "Unsworn declaration" means a declaration in a signed record not given under oath but given under penalty of

------------------------------------------------
This chapter applies to an unsworn declaration by a declarant who at the time of making the declaration is physically located within or outside the boundaries of the United States, whether or not the location is subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 19 - Utah Uniform Collaborative Law Act
*********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter may be cited as the "Utah Uniform Collaborative Law Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
In this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(1): "Collaborative law communication" means a statement, whether oral or in a record, or verbal or nonverbal, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(1)(a): is made to conduct, participate in, continue, or reconvene a collaborative law process; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(1)(b): occurs after the parties sign a collaborative law participation agreement and before the collaborative law process is concluded.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(2): "Collaborative law participation agreement" means an agreement by persons to participate in a collaborative law process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(3): "Collaborative law process" means a procedure intended to resolve a collaborative matter without intervention by a tribunal in which persons:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(3)(a): sign a collaborative law participation agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(3)(b): are represented by collaborative lawyers.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(4): "Collaborative lawyer" means a lawyer who represents a party in a collaborative law process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(5): "Collaborative matter" means a dispute, transaction, claim, problem, or issue for resolution described in a collaborative law participation agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(6): "Law firm" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(6)(a): lawyers who practice law together in a partnership, professional corporation, sole proprietorship, limited liability company, or association;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(6)(b): lawyers employed in a legal services organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(6)(c): the legal department of a corporation or other organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(6)(d): the legal department of a government or governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(7): "Nonparty participant" means a person, other than a party and the party's collaborative lawyer, that participates in a collaborative law process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(8): "Party" means a person that signs a collaborative law participation agreement and whose consent is necessary to resolve a collaborative matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(9): "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture, public corporation, government or governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, or any other legal or commercial entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(10): "Proceeding" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(10)(a): a judicial, administrative, arbitral, or other adjudicative process before a tribunal, including related pre-hearing and post-hearing motions, conferences, and discovery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(10)(b): a legislative hearing or similar process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(11): "Prospective party" means a person that discusses with a prospective collaborative lawyer the possibility of signing a collaborative law participation agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(12): "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(13): "Related to a collaborative matter" means involving the same parties, transaction or occurrence, nucleus of operative fact, dispute, claim, or issue as the collaborative matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(14): "Sign" means, with present intent to authenticate or adopt a record:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(14)(a): to execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(14)(b): to attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic symbol, sound, or process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(15): "Tribunal" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(15)(a): a court, arbitrator, administrative agency, or other body acting in an adjudicative capacity which, after presentation of evidence or legal argument, has jurisdiction to render a decision affecting a party's interests in a matter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-102(15)(b): a legislative body conducting a hearing or similar process.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-103 Applicability.
-----------------------------------------------
This chapter applies to a collaborative law participation agreement that meets the requirements of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104 Collaborative law participation agreement -- Requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104(1): A collaborative law participation agreement must:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104(1)(a): be in a record;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104(1)(b): be signed by the parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104(1)(c): state the parties' intention to resolve a collaborative matter through a collaborative law process under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104(1)(d): describe the nature and scope of the matter;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104(1)(e): identify the collaborative lawyer who represents each party in the process; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104(1)(f): contain a statement by each collaborative lawyer confirming the lawyer's representation of a party in the collaborative law process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-104(2): Parties may agree to include in a collaborative law participation agreement additional provisions not inconsistent with this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105 Beginning and concluding a collaborative law process.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(1): A collaborative law process begins when the parties sign a collaborative law participation agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(2): A tribunal may not order a party to participate in a collaborative law process over that party's objection.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(3): A collaborative law process is concluded by a:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(3)(a): resolution of a collaborative matter as evidenced by a signed record;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(3)(b): resolution of a part of the collaborative matter, evidenced by a signed record, in which the parties agree that the remaining parts of the matter will not be resolved in the process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(3)(c): termination of the process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4): (5) A collaborative law process terminates:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4)(a): when a party gives notice to other parties in a record that the process is ended; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4)(b): when a party:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4)(b)(i): begins a proceeding related to a collaborative matter without the agreement of all parties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4)(b)(ii): in a pending proceeding related to the matter:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4)(b)(ii)(A): initiates a pleading, motion, order to show cause, or request for a conference with the tribunal;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4)(b)(ii)(B): requests that the proceeding be put on the tribunal's calendar; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4)(b)(ii)(C): takes similar action requiring notice to be sent to the parties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(4)(c): (5) except as otherwise provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(5): A party's collaborative lawyer shall give prompt notice to all other parties of a discharge or withdrawal, in accordance with the Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(6): A party may terminate a collaborative law process with or without cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(7): (4)(c) Notwithstanding the discharge or withdrawal of a collaborative lawyer, a collaborative law process continues, if not later than 30 days after the date that the notice of the discharge or withdrawal of a collaborative lawyer required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(7)(a): the unrepresented party engages a successor collaborative lawyer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(7)(b): in a signed record:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(7)(b)(i): the parties consent to continue the process by reaffirming the collaborative law participation agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(7)(b)(ii): the agreement is amended to identify the successor collaborative lawyer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(7)(b)(iii): the successor collaborative lawyer confirms the lawyer's representation of a party in the collaborative process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(8): A collaborative law process does not conclude if, with the consent of the parties, a party requests a tribunal to approve a resolution of the collaborative matter or any part thereof as evidenced by a signed record.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-105(9): A collaborative law participation agreement may provide additional methods of concluding a collaborative law process.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-106 Proceedings pending before tribunal -- Status report.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-106(1): (3); 78B-19-107; 78B-19-108 Persons in a proceeding pending before a tribunal may sign a collaborative law participation agreement to seek to resolve a collaborative matter related to the proceeding.  Parties shall file promptly with the tribunal a notice of the agreement after it is signed.  Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-106(2): Parties shall file promptly with the tribunal notice in a record when a collaborative law process concludes and request the stay to be lifted.  The notice may not specify any reason for termination of the process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-106(3): (1) A tribunal in which a proceeding is stayed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-106(4): A tribunal shall provide parties notice and an opportunity to be heard before dismissing a proceeding in which a notice of collaborative process is filed based on delay or failure to prosecute.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-107 Emergency orders.
--------------------------------------------------
During a collaborative law process, a court may issue emergency orders, including protective orders in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-108 Approval of agreement by tribunal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
A court may approve an agreement resulting from a collaborative law process.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-109 Disclosure of information.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Except as provided by law other than this chapter, during the collaborative law process, on the request of another party, a party shall make timely, full, candid, and informal disclosure of information related to the collaborative matter without formal discovery.  A party also shall update promptly previously disclosed information that has materially changed.  Parties may define the scope of disclosure during the collaborative law process.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-110 Standards of professional responsibility and mandatory reporting not affected.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not affect:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-110(1): the professional responsibility obligations and standards applicable to a lawyer or other licensed professional; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-110(2): the obligation of a person to report abuse or neglect, abandonment, or exploitation of a child or adult under the law of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-111 Appropriateness of collaborative law process.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Before a prospective party signs a collaborative law participation agreement, a prospective collaborative lawyer shall:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-111(1): assess with the prospective party factors the lawyer reasonably believes relate to whether a collaborative law process is appropriate for the prospective party's matter;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-111(2): provide the prospective party with information that the lawyer reasonably believes is sufficient for the party to make an informed decision about the material benefits and risks of a collaborative law process as compared to the material benefits and risks of other reasonably available alternatives for resolving the proposed collaborative matter, such as litigation, mediation, arbitration, or expert evaluation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-111(3): advise the prospective party that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-111(3)(a): after signing an agreement if a party initiates a proceeding or seeks tribunal intervention in a pending proceeding related to the collaborative matter, the collaborative law process terminates;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-111(3)(b): participation in a collaborative law process is voluntary and any party has the right to terminate unilaterally a collaborative law process with or without cause; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-111(3)(c): the collaborative lawyer and any lawyer in a law firm with which the collaborative lawyer is associated may not appear before a tribunal to represent a party in a proceeding related to the collaborative matter, except as authorized by the Rules of Professional Conduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-112 Coercive or violent relationship.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-112(1): Before a prospective party signs a collaborative law participation agreement, a prospective collaborative lawyer shall make reasonable inquiry whether the prospective party has a history of a coercive or violent relationship with another prospective party.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-112(2): Throughout a collaborative law process, a collaborative lawyer reasonably and continuously shall assess whether the party the collaborative lawyer represents has a history of a coercive or violent relationship with another party.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-112(3): If a collaborative lawyer reasonably believes that the party the lawyer represents or the prospective party who consults the lawyer has a history of a coercive or violent relationship with another party or prospective party, the lawyer may not begin or continue a collaborative law process unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-112(3)(a): the party or the prospective party requests to begin or to continue a process; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-112(3)(b): the collaborative lawyer reasonably believes that the safety of the party or prospective party can be protected adequately during a process.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-113 Confidentiality of collaborative law communication.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A collaborative law communication is confidential to the extent agreed by the parties in a signed record or as provided by law of this state other than this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-114 Authority of tribunal in case of noncompliance.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-114(1): 78B-19-104; 78B-19-111; 78B-19-112 If an agreement fails to meet the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-114(1)(a): signed a record indicating an intention to enter into a collaborative law participation agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-114(1)(b): reasonably believed they were participating in a collaborative law process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-114(2): (1); 78B-19-105; 78B-19-106 If a court makes the findings specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-114(2)(a): enforce an agreement evidenced by a record resulting from the process in which the parties participated;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-114(2)(b): 78B-19-105; 78B-19-106 apply the disqualification provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-114(2)(c): apply the privileges in the Utah Rules of Evidence.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-115 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-19-116 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, and supersedes the federal Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C.A. Sec. 7001 et seq. (2009), but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of that act, 15 U.S.C.A. Sec. 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Sec. 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C.A. Sec. 7003(b).

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 20 - Uniform Deployed Parents Custody, Parent-time, and Visitation Act
****************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Uniform Deployed Parents Custody, Parent-Time, and Visitation Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(1): "Adult" means an individual who has attained 18 years old or is an emancipated minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(2)(a): "Caretaking authority" means the right to live with and care for a child on a day-to-day basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(2)(b): "Caretaking authority" includes physical custody, parent-time, right to access, and visitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(3): "Child" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(3)(a): an unemancipated individual who has not attained 18 years old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(3)(b): an adult son or daughter by birth or adoption, or under law of this state other than this chapter, who is the subject of a court order concerning custodial responsibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(4): "Court" means a tribunal, including an administrative agency, authorized under the law of this state other than this chapter to make, enforce, or modify a decision regarding custodial responsibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(5): "Custodial responsibility" includes all powers and duties relating to caretaking authority and decision-making authority for a child.  The term includes physical custody, legal custody, parent-time, right to access, visitation, and authority to grant limited contact with a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(6): "Decision-making authority" means the power to make important decisions regarding a child, including decisions regarding the child's education, religious training, health care, extracurricular activities, and travel.  The term does not include the power to make decisions that necessarily accompany a grant of caretaking authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(7): "Deploying parent" means a service member who is deployed or has been notified of impending deployment and is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(7)(a): a parent of a child under the law of this state other than this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(7)(b): an individual who has custodial responsibility for a child under the law of this state other than this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(8): "Deployment" means the movement or mobilization of a service member for more than 90 days but less than 18 months pursuant to uniformed service orders that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(8)(a): are designated as unaccompanied;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(8)(b): do not authorize dependent travel; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(8)(c): otherwise do not permit the movement of family members to the location to which the service member is deployed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(9): "Family care plan" means a formal written contingency plan mandated by regulation of the various departments and components of the uniformed service that requires certain service member parents of minor children to plan in advance for the smooth, rapid transfer of parental responsibilities to designees during the absence of the service member due to death, incapacity, short-term absences, long-term absences, including deployments, or noncombatant evacuation operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(10): "Family member" means a sibling, aunt, uncle, cousin, stepparent, or grandparent of a child, or an individual recognized to be in a familial relationship with a child under the law of this state other than this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(11)(a): "Limited contact" means the authority of a nonparent to visit a child for a limited time.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(11)(b): "Limited contact" includes authority to take the child to a place other than the residence of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(12): "Nonparent" means an individual other than a deploying parent or other parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(13): "Other parent" means an individual who, in common with a deploying parent, is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(13)(a): a parent of a child under the law of this state other than this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(13)(b): an individual who has custodial responsibility for a child under the law of this state other than this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(14): "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(15): "Return from deployment" means the conclusion of a service member's deployment as specified in uniformed service orders.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(16): " Service member" means a member of a uniformed service.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(17): "Sign" means, with present intent to authenticate or adopt a record:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(17)(a): to execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(17)(b): to attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic symbol, sound, or process.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(18): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(19): "Uniformed service" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(19)(a): active and reserve components of the United States armed forces;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(19)(b): the United States Merchant Marine;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(19)(c): the commissioned corps of the United States Public Health Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(19)(d): the commissioned corps of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-102(19)(e): the National Guard of a state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-103 Remedies for noncompliance.
------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to other remedies under the law of this state other than this chapter, if a court finds that a party to a proceeding under this chapter has acted in bad faith or intentionally failed to comply with this chapter or a court order issued under this chapter, the court may assess reasonable attorney fees and costs against the party and order other appropriate relief.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-104 Jurisdiction.
----------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-107 General consideration in custody proceeding of parent's military service.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In a proceeding for custodial responsibility of a child of a service member, a court may not consider a parent's past deployment or possible future deployment in itself in determining the best interest of the child but may consider any significant impact on the best interest of the child of the parent's past or possible future deployment.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201 Form of agreement.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(1): The parents of a child may enter into a temporary agreement under this part granting custodial responsibility during deployment. When the parents of a child include one or more servicemembers, the parents should enter into an agreement granting custodial responsibility before notice of deployment, but may also enter into an agreement granting custodial responsibility following notice of deployment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(2): (1) An agreement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(2)(a): in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(2)(b): signed by both parents and any nonparent to whom custodial responsibility is granted.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(3): (4); (1); Part 4, Return from Deployment; 78B-20-205 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(3)(a): identify the destination, duration, and conditions of the deployment that is the basis for the agreement if the deployment has been noticed;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(3)(b): specify the allocation of caretaking authority among the deploying parent, the other parent, and any nonparent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(3)(c): specify any decision-making authority that accompanies a grant of caretaking authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(3)(d): specify any grant of limited contact to a nonparent;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(3)(e): if under the agreement custodial responsibility is shared by the other parent and a nonparent, or by other nonparents, provide a process to resolve any dispute that may arise;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-201(3)(f): specify the frequency, duration, and means, including electronic means, by which the deploying parent will have contact with the child, any role to be played by the other parent in facilitating the contact, and the allocation of any costs of contact;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-204 Power of attorney.
---------------------------------------------------
A deploying parent, by power of attorney, may delegate all or part of custodial responsibility to an adult nonparent for the period of deployment if no other parent possesses custodial responsibility under the law of this state other than this chapter or if a court order currently in effect prohibits contact between the child and the other parent.  The deploying parent may revoke the power of attorney by signing a revocation of the power.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-205 Filing agreement or power of attorney with court.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-205(1): An agreement or power of attorney under this part shall be filed within a reasonable time with any court that has entered an order on custodial responsibility or child support that is in effect concerning the child who is the subject of the agreement or power.  The case number and heading of the pending case concerning custodial responsibility or child support shall be provided to the court with the agreement or power.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-205(2): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-301 Definition.
--------------------------------------------
In this part, "close and substantial relationship" means a relationship in which a significant bond exists between a child and a nonparent.

The motion shall be filed in a pending proceeding for custodial responsibility in a court with jurisdiction under Section

---------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-304 Testimony by electronic means.
---------------------------------------------------------------
In a proceeding under this part, a party or witness who is not reasonably available to appear personally may appear, provide testimony, and present evidence by electronic means unless the court finds good cause to require a personal appearance.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-306 Grant of caretaking or decision-making authority to nonparent.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-306(1): On motion of a deploying parent and in accordance with the law of this state other than this chapter, if it is in the best interest of the child a court may grant caretaking authority to a nonparent who is an adult family member of the child with whom the child has a close and substantial relationship.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-306(2): (1) Unless a grant of caretaking authority to a nonparent under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-306(2)(a): the amount of time granted to the deploying parent under a permanent custody order, but the court may add unusual travel time necessary to transport the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-306(2)(b): in the absence of a permanent custody order that is currently in effect, the amount of time that the deploying parent habitually cared for the child before being notified of deployment, but the court may add unusual travel time necessary to transport the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-306(3): A court may grant part of a deploying parent's decision-making authority, if the deploying parent is unable to exercise that authority, to a nonparent who is an adult family member of the child with whom the child has a close and substantial relationship.  If a court grants the authority to a nonparent, the court shall specify the decision-making powers granted, including decisions regarding the child's education, religious training, health care, extracurricular activities, and travel.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-307 Grant of limited contact.
----------------------------------------------------------
On motion of a deploying parent, and in accordance with the law of this state other than this chapter, unless the court finds that the contact would be contrary to the best interest of the child, a court shall grant limited contact to a nonparent who is a family member of the child or an individual with whom the child has a close and substantial relationship.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-402 Consent procedure for terminating temporary grant of custodial responsibility established by court order.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
At any time after a deploying parent returns from deployment, the deploying parent and the other parent may file with the court an agreement to terminate a temporary order for custodial responsibility issued under

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-403 Visitation before termination of temporary grant of custodial responsibility.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
After a deploying parent returns from deployment until a temporary agreement or order for custodial responsibility established under Part 2, Agreement Addressing Custodial Responsibility During Deployment, or a provision of a court order specifying temporary custodial responsibility during deployment issued under Part 3, Judicial Procedure for Granting Custodial Responsibility During Deployment, or Title 81, Chapter 9, Custody, Parent-time, and Visitation, is terminated, the court shall issue a temporary order granting the deploying parent reasonable contact with the child unless it is contrary to the best interest of the child, even if the time of contact exceeds the time the deploying parent spent with the child before deployment.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-404 Termination by operation of law of temporary grant of custodial responsibility established by court order.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-404(1): If an agreement between the parties to terminate a court order for temporary custodial responsibility during deployment under Part 3, Judicial Procedure for Granting Custodial Responsibility During Deployment, or to terminate a provision of an order for temporary custodial responsibility during deployment entered under Title 81, Chapter 9, Custody, Parent-time, and Visitation, has not been filed, the temporary order terminates 30 days after the day on which the deploying parent gives notice to the other parent and any nonparent granted custodial responsibility that the deploying parent has returned from deployment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-404(2): A proceeding seeking to prevent termination of a temporary order for custodial responsibility is governed by the law of this state other than this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-501 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-502 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, or supersedes the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001 et seq., but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7003(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-20-503 Savings clause.
------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not affect the validity of a temporary court order concerning custodial responsibility during deployment that was entered before May 10, 2016.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 21 - Uniform Commercial Real Estate Receivership Act
**********************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Uniform Commercial Real Estate Receivership Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1): (1)(a)(ii); (1)(b)(i); (ii) "Affiliate" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(a): (1)(a)(ii) with respect to an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(a)(i): a companion of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(a)(ii): a lineal ancestor or descendant, whether by blood or adoption, of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(a)(ii)(A): the individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(a)(ii)(B): a companion of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(a)(iii): (1)(a)(ii) a companion of an ancestor or descendant described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(a)(iv): a sibling, aunt, uncle, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, niece, nephew, grandniece, or grandnephew of the individual, whether related by the whole or the half blood or adoption, or a companion of a sibling, aunt, uncle, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, niece, nephew, grandniece, or grandnephew of the individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(a)(v): any other individual occupying the residence of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(b): (1)(b)(i); (ii) with respect to a person other than an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(b)(i): another person that directly or indirectly controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(b)(ii): an officer, director, manager, member, partner, employee, or trustee or other fiduciary of the person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(1)(b)(iii): (1)(b)(i); (ii) a companion of, or an individual occupying the residence of, an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(2): "Companion" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(2)(a): the spouse of an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(2)(b): the domestic partner of an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(2)(c): another individual in a civil union with an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(3): Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration "Court" means a court of this state with jurisdiction over the action under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(4): "Executory contract" means a contract, including a lease, under which each party has an unperformed obligation and the failure of a party to complete performance would constitute a material breach.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(5): "Governmental unit" means an office, department, division, bureau, board, commission, or other agency of this state or a subdivision of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(6): "Lien" means an interest in property that secures payment or performance of an obligation.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(7): "Mortgage" means a record, however denominated, that creates or provides for a consensual lien on real property or rents, even if the mortgage also creates or provides for a lien on personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(8): "Mortgagee" means a person entitled to enforce an obligation secured by a mortgage.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(9): "Mortgagor" means a person that grants a mortgage or a successor in ownership of the real property described in the mortgage.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(10): "Owner" means the person for whose property a receiver is appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(11): "Person" means an individual, estate, business or nonprofit entity, public corporation, government or governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, or other legal entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(12): "Proceeds" means the following property:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(12)(a): whatever is acquired on the sale, lease, license, exchange, or other disposition of receivership property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(12)(b): whatever is collected on, or distributed on account of, receivership property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(12)(c): rights arising out of receivership property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(12)(d): to the extent of the value of receivership property, claims arising out of the loss, nonconformity, or interference with the use of, defects or infringement of rights in, or damage to the property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(12)(e): to the extent of the value of receivership property and to the extent payable to the owner or mortgagee, insurance payable by reason of the loss or nonconformity of, defects or infringement of rights in, or damage to the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(13): "Property" means all of a person's right, title, and interest, both legal and equitable, in real and personal property, tangible and intangible, wherever located and however acquired. The term includes proceeds, products, offspring, rents, or profits of or from the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(14): "Receiver" means a person appointed by the court as the court's agent, and subject to the court's direction, to take possession of, manage, and, if authorized by this chapter or court order, transfer, sell, lease, license, exchange, collect, or otherwise dispose of receivership property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(15): "Receivership" means a proceeding in which a receiver is appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(16): "Receivership property" means the property of an owner that is described in the order appointing a receiver or a subsequent order. The term includes any proceeds, products, offspring, rents, or profits of or from the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(17): "Record" means, when used as a noun, information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored on an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(18): "Rents" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(18)(a): sums payable for the right to possess or occupy, or for the actual possession or occupation of, real property of another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(18)(b): sums payable to a mortgagor under a policy of rental-interruption insurance covering real property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(18)(c): claims arising out of a default in the payment of sums payable for the right to possess or occupy real property of another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(18)(d): sums payable to terminate an agreement to possess or occupy real property of another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(18)(e): sums payable to a mortgagor for payment or reimbursement of expenses incurred in owning, operating, and maintaining real property or constructing or installing improvements on real property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(18)(f): other sums payable under an agreement relating to the real property of another person which constitute rents under law of the state other than this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(19): "Secured obligation" means an obligation the payment or performance of which is secured by a security agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(20): "Security agreement" means an agreement that creates or provides for a lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(21): "Sign" means, with present intent to authenticate or adopt a record:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(21)(a): to execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-102(21)(b): to attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic sound, symbol, or process.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104 Scope -- Exclusions.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(1): (2); (3) Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(2): This chapter does not apply to a receivership for an interest in real property improved by one to four dwelling units unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(2)(a): the interest is used for agricultural, commercial, industrial, or mineral-extraction purposes, other than incidental uses by an owner occupying the property as the owner's primary residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(2)(b): the interest secures an obligation incurred at a time when the property was used or planned for use for agricultural, commercial, industrial, or mineral-extraction purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(2)(c): the owner planned or is planning to develop the property into one or more dwelling units to be sold or leased in the ordinary course of the owner's business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(2)(d): the owner is collecting or has the right to collect rents or other income from the property from a person other than an affiliate of the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(3): This chapter does not apply to a receivership authorized by law of this state other than this chapter in which the receiver is a governmental unit or an individual acting in an official capacity on behalf of the governmental unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(4): This chapter does not limit the authority of a court to appoint a receiver under other state law.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-104(5): Unless displaced by a particular provision of this chapter, the principles of law and equity supplement this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-105 Power of court.
------------------------------------------------
The court that appoints a receiver under this chapter has exclusive jurisdiction to direct the receiver and determine any controversy related to the receivership or receivership property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106 Appointment of receiver.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(1): The court may appoint a receiver:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(1)(a): before judgment, to protect a party that demonstrates an apparent right, title, or interest in real property that is the subject of the action, if the property or the property's revenue-producing potential:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(1)(b)(ii): to preserve nonexempt real property pending appeal or when an execution has been returned unsatisfied and the owner refuses to apply the property in satisfaction of the judgment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(1)(c): in an action in which a receiver for real property may be appointed on equitable grounds; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(1)(d): during the time allowed for redemption, to preserve a property sold in an execution or foreclosure sale and secure the property's rents to the person entitled to the property's rents.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(2)(c): the owner agreed, after default and in a signed record, to appointment of a receiver;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(2)(d): the property and any other collateral held by the mortgagee are not sufficient to satisfy the secured obligation;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(2)(e): the owner fails to turn over to the mortgagee proceeds or rents the mortgagee was entitled to collect; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-106(2)(f): the holder of a subordinate lien obtains appointment of a receiver for the property.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-108(2)(b): The receiver may not use receivership property as alternative security.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-108(2)(c): Interest that accrues on deposited funds must be paid to the receiver on the receiver's discharge.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-108(3): The court may authorize a receiver to act before the receiver posts the bond or alternative security required by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-108(4): A claim against a receiver's bond or alternative security must be made not later than one year after the date the receiver is discharged.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-109 Status of receiver as lien creditor.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
On appointment of a receiver, the receiver has the status of a lien creditor under:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-109(1): Title 70A, Chapter 9a, Uniform Commercial Code - Secured Transactions
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-109(2): Title 57, Chapter 9, Marketable Record Title


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-110 Security agreement covering after-acquired property.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided by law of this state other than this chapter, property that a receiver or owner acquires after appointment of the receiver is subject to a security agreement entered into before the appointment to the same extent as if the court had not appointed the receiver.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-111 Collection and turnover of receivership property.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-111(1): (3) Unless the court orders otherwise, on demand by a receiver:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-111(1)(a): a person that owes a debt that is receivership property and is matured or payable on demand or on order shall pay the debt to or on the order of the receiver, except to the extent the debt is subject to setoff or recoupment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-111(1)(b): (3) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-111(2): A person that has notice of the appointment of a receiver and owes a debt that is receivership property may not satisfy the debt by payment to the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-111(3): If a creditor has possession, custody, or control of receivership property and the validity, perfection, or priority of the creditor's lien on the property depends on the creditor's possession, custody, or control, the creditor may retain possession, custody, or control until the court orders adequate protection of the creditor's lien.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-111(4): Unless a bona fide dispute exists about a receiver's right to possession, custody, or control of receivership property, the court may sanction as civil contempt a person's failure to turn the property over when required by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112 Powers and duties of receiver.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1): 78B-21-115 Except as limited by court order or law of this state other than this chapter, a receiver may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(a): collect, control, manage, conserve, and protect receivership property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(b): operate a business constituting receivership property, including preservation, use, sale, lease, license, exchange, collection, or disposition of the property in the ordinary course of business;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(c): in the ordinary course of business, incur unsecured debt and pay expenses incidental to the receiver's preservation, use, sale, lease, license, exchange, collection, or disposition of receivership property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(d): assert a right, claim, cause of action, or defense of the owner that relates to receivership property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(e): seek and obtain instruction from the court concerning receivership property, exercise of the receiver's powers, and performance of the receiver's duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(f): on subpoena, compel a person to submit to examination under oath, or to produce and permit inspection and copying of designated records or tangible things, with respect to receivership property or any other matter that may affect administration of the receivership;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(g): 78B-21-115 engage a professional as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(h): apply to a court of another state for appointment as ancillary receiver with respect to receivership property located in that state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(1)(i): exercise any power conferred by court order, this chapter, or a law of the state other than this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(2): 78B-21-116; 78B-21-117; 78B-21-121; 78B-21-115; 78B-21-120; 78B-21-120 With court approval, a receiver may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(2)(a): incur debt for the use or benefit of receivership property other than in the ordinary course of business;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(2)(b): make improvements to receivership property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(2)(c): 78B-21-116 use or transfer receivership property other than in the ordinary course of business as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(2)(g): 78B-21-120 make a distribution of receivership property as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-112(4): The powers and duties of a receiver may be expanded, modified, or limited by court order.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113 Duties of owner.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(1): An owner shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(1)(a): assist and cooperate with the receiver in the administration of the receivership and the discharge of the receiver's duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(1)(b): preserve and turn over to the receiver all receivership property in the owner's possession, custody, or control;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(1)(c): identify all records and other information relating to the receivership property, including a password, authorization, or other information needed to obtain or maintain access to or control of the receivership property, and make available to the receiver the records and information in the owner's possession, custody, or control;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(1)(d): on subpoena, submit to examination under oath by the receiver concerning the acts, conduct, property, liabilities, and financial condition of the owner or any matter relating to the receivership property or the receivership; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(1)(e): perform any duty imposed by court order, this chapter, or a law of the state other than this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(2): If an owner is a person other than an individual, this section applies to each officer, director, manager, member, partner, trustee, or other person exercising or having the power to exercise control over the affairs of the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(3): If a person knowingly fails to perform a duty imposed by this section, the court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(3)(a): award the receiver actual damages caused by the person's failure, reasonable attorney fees, and costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-113(3)(b): sanction the failure as civil contempt.

----------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-117(8): A receiver may not reject an unexpired lease of real property under which the owner is the landlord if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-117(8)(a): the tenant occupies the leased premises as the tenant's primary residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-117(8)(b): the receiver was appointed at the request of a person other than a mortgagee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-117(8)(c): the receiver was appointed at the request of a mortgagee and:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-117(8)(c)(i): the lease is superior to the lien of the mortgage;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-117(8)(c)(ii): the tenant has an enforceable agreement with the mortgagee or the holder of a senior lien under which the tenant's occupancy will not be disturbed as long as the tenant performs the tenant's obligations under the lease;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-117(8)(c)(iii): the mortgagee has consented to the lease, either in a signed record or by the mortgagee's failure to timely object that the lease violated the mortgage; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-117(8)(c)(iv): the terms of the lease were commercially reasonable at the time the lease was agreed to and the tenant did not know or have reason to know that the lease violated the mortgage.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-118 Defenses and immunities of receiver.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-118(1): A receiver is entitled to all defenses and immunities provided by law of this state other than this chapter for an act or omission within the scope of the receiver's appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-118(2): A receiver may be sued personally for an act or omission in administering receivership property only with approval of the court that appointed the receiver.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-119 Interim report of receiver.
------------------------------------------------------------
A receiver may file, or if ordered by the court shall file, an interim report that includes:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-119(1): the activities of the receiver since appointment or a previous report;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-119(2): receipts and disbursements, including a payment made or proposed to be made to a professional engaged by the receiver;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-119(3): receipts and dispositions of receivership property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-119(4): fees and expenses of the receiver and, if not filed separately, a request for approval of payment of the fees and expenses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-119(5): any other information required by the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-121 Fees and expenses.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-121(1): The court may award a receiver from receivership property the reasonable and necessary fees and expenses of performing the duties of the receiver and exercising the powers of the receiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-121(2): 78B-21-106(1)(a) The court may order one or more of the following to pay the reasonable and necessary fees and expenses of the receivership, including reasonable attorney fees and costs:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-121(2)(a): a person that requested the appointment of the receiver, if the receivership does not produce sufficient funds to pay the fees and expenses; or
