Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122 Removal of receiver -- Replacement -- Termination of receivership.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122(1): The court may remove a receiver for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122(2): The court shall replace a receiver that dies, resigns, or is removed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122(3): If the court finds that a receiver that resigns or is removed, or the representative of a receiver that is deceased, has accounted fully for and turned over to the successor receiver all receivership property and has filed a report of all receipts and disbursements during the service of the replaced receiver, the replaced receiver is discharged.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122(4)(a): The court may discharge a receiver and terminate the court's administration of the receivership property if the court finds that appointment of the receiver was improvident or that the circumstances no longer warrant continuation of the receivership.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122(4)(b): If the court finds that the appointment was sought wrongfully or in bad faith, the court may assess against the person that sought the appointment:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122(4)(b)(i): the fees and expenses of the receivership, including reasonable attorney fees and costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-122(4)(b)(ii): actual damages caused by the appointment, including reasonable attorney fees and costs.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-126 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to the law's subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-127 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, or supersedes the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001 et seq., but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7003(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-128 Transition.
--------------------------------------------
This chapter does not apply to a receivership for which the receiver was appointed before May 9, 2017.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-21-129 Finality of orders.
----------------------------------------------------
A court order that is entered pursuant to this chapter and that resolves a discrete factual dispute or legal issue is a final appealable order within the meaning of Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 54(a), unless expressly stated otherwise in the court order.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 22 - Indigent Defense Act
*******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Indigent Defense Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(1): 78B-22-405 "Account" means the Indigent Defense Resources Restricted Account created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(2): 78B-22-401 "Commission" means the Utah Indigent Defense Commission created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(3): "Child welfare case" means a proceeding under Title 80, Chapter 3, Abuse, Neglect, and Dependency Proceedings, or Title 80, Chapter 4, Termination and Restoration of Parental Rights.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(4): 78B-22-451; 78B-22-453 "Executive Director" means the executive director of the Office of Indigent Defense Services, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(5): "Indigent defense resources" means the resources necessary to provide an effective defense for an indigent individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(6): 78B-22-203 "Indigent defense service provider" means an attorney or entity appointed to represent an indigent individual through:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(6)(a): a contract with an indigent defense system to provide indigent defense services;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(6)(b): 78B-22-203 an order issued by the court under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(6)(c): direct employment with an indigent defense system.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(7): "Indigent defense services" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(7)(a): the representation of an indigent individual by an indigent defense service provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(7)(b): the provision of indigent defense resources for an indigent individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(8): "Indigent defense system" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(8)(a): a city or town that is responsible for providing indigent defense services;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(8)(b): a county that is responsible for providing indigent defense services in the district court, juvenile court, and the county's justice courts; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(8)(c): an interlocal entity, created pursuant to Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, that is responsible for providing indigent defense services according to the terms of an agreement between a county, city, or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(9): 78A-6-103; 78B-22-201; 78B-22-202 "Indigent individual" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(9)(a): 78A-6-103 a minor who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(9)(a)(i): 78A-6-103 arrested and admitted into detention for an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(9)(a)(ii): charged by petition or information in the juvenile or district court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(9)(a)(iii): described in this Subsection (9)(a), who is appealing an adjudication or other final court action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(9)(b): 78B-22-201; 78B-22-202 an individual listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(10): 80-1-102 "Minor" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(11): 78B-22-451 "Office" means the Office of Indigent Defense Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-102(12): 78B-22-702; 78B-22-703 "Participating county" means a county that complies with this chapter for participation in the Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund as provided in Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5 Affidavit of indigency.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(1): (5); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2): An affidavit of indigency shall include the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(a): the individual's identifying information, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(a)(i): the individual's legal name and any known aliases;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(a)(ii): the individual's mobile or residential phone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(a)(iii): the individual's residential address; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(a)(iv): the individual's date of birth; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(b): the individual's financial information, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(b)(i): any financial support or benefit that the individual receives from a state or federal government;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(b)(ii): the individual's monthly income, including any alimony or child support that contributes to the individual's monthly income;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(b)(iii): the individual's monthly expenses, including any alimony or child support obligation that the individual is responsible for paying;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(b)(iv): the individual's ownership of, or any interest in, personal or real property, including any savings or checking accounts or cash;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(b)(v): the number, ages, and relationships of any dependents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(2)(b)(vi): any extraordinary financial conditions that would prevent the individual from retaining private counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(3): 76-8-504 The affidavit of indigency shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(3)(a): require the signature of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(3)(b): 76-8-504 include a statement that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(3)(b)(i): by signing the affidavit the individual confirms that, to the best of the individual's knowledge, the information in the affidavit is true;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(3)(b)(ii): 76-8-504 the individual may be subject to a criminal penalty for a written false statement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(3)(b)(iii): the individual authorizes an indigent defense system to contact or request information from the individual or a third party to verify whether an individual is indigent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(3)(b)(iv): the individual may be ordered to pay the cost of the individual's indigent defense services if a court determines that the individual is not indigent.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(4): (2) The Judicial Council or Supreme Court shall adopt an affidavit of indigency form described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-201.5(5): This section does not apply to a minor, who is appointed an indigent defense service provider, or the minor's parent or legal guardian.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202 Determining indigency.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1): A court shall find an individual indigent if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1)(a): has an income level at or below 150% of the United States poverty level as defined by the most recent poverty income guidelines published by the United States Department of Health and Human Services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1)(b): has insufficient income or other means to pay for legal counsel and the necessary expenses of representation without depriving the individual or the individual's family of food, shelter, clothing, or other necessities, considering:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1)(b)(i): the individual's ownership of, or any interest in, personal or real property;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1)(b)(ii): the amount of debt owed by the individual or that might reasonably be incurred by the individual because of illness or other needs within the individual's family;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1)(b)(iii): the number, ages, and relationships of any dependents;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1)(b)(iv): the probable expense and burden of defending the case;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1)(b)(v): the reasonableness of fees and expenses charged by an attorney and the scope of representation undertaken when represented by privately retained defense counsel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(1)(b)(vi): any other factor the court considers relevant.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(2): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(3): 78B-22-201.5; 78B-22-201.5; 78B-22-203
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(3)(a): 78B-22-201.5 The court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(3)(a)(i): make a finding of indigency at any time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(3)(a)(ii): 78B-22-201.5 rely on information contained in an affidavit of indigency described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(3)(b): 78B-22-201.5; 78B-22-203 An individual's inability to submit, or to provide the information required in, an affidavit of indigency under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(3)(b)(i): making a finding about whether an individual is an indigent individual under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-202(3)(b)(ii): 78B-22-203 appointing an indigent defense service provider under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203 Order for indigent defense services.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (6), a court shall appoint an indigent defense service provider who is employed by an indigent defense system or who has a contract with an indigent defense system to provide indigent defense services for an individual over whom the court has jurisdiction if:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(1)(a)(i): the individual is an indigent individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(1)(a)(ii): the individual does not have private counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(1)(b): An indigent defense service provider appointed by the court under Subsection (1)(a) shall provide indigent defense services for the indigent individual in all court proceedings in the matter for which the indigent defense service provider is appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(2)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (1), the court may order that indigent defense services be provided by an indigent defense service provider who does not have a contract with an indigent defense system if the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(2)(a)(i): all the contracted indigent defense service providers:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(2)(a)(i)(A): have a conflict of interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(2)(a)(i)(B): do not have sufficient expertise to provide indigent defense services for the indigent individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(2)(a)(ii): the indigent defense system does not have a contract with an indigent defense service provider for indigent defense services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(2)(b): A court may not order indigent defense services under Subsection (2)(a) unless the court conducts a hearing with proper notice to the indigent defense system by sending notice of the hearing to the county clerk or municipal recorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(a): A court may order reasonable indigent defense resources for an individual who has retained private counsel only if the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(a)(i): the individual is an indigent individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(a)(ii): the individual would be prejudiced by the substitution of a contracted indigent defense service provider and the prejudice cannot be remedied;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(a)(iii): at the time that private counsel was retained, the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(a)(iii)(A): entered into a written contract with private counsel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(a)(iii)(B): had the ability to pay for indigent defense resources, but no longer has the ability to pay for the indigent defense resources in addition to the cost of private counsel;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(a)(iv): there has been an unforeseen change in circumstances that requires indigent defense resources beyond the individual's ability to pay; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(a)(v): any representation under this Subsection (3)(a) is made in good faith and is not calculated to allow the individual or retained private counsel to avoid the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(b): A court may not order indigent defense resources under Subsection (3)(a) until the court conducts a hearing with proper notice to the indigent defense system by sending notice of the hearing to the county clerk or municipal recorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(c): At the hearing, the court shall conduct an in camera review of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(c)(i): the private counsel contract;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(c)(ii): the costs or anticipated costs of the indigent defense resources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(3)(c)(iii): other relevant records.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(4): A court may only order the representation of an indigent individual by an indigent defense service provider in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(5): A court may not order indigent defense resources be provided to an indigent individual, except as provided in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(6): 78B-22-701
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(6)(a): 78B-22-701 For an individual prosecuted for aggravated murder and found indigent, a court from a county participating in the Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-203(6)(b): The office shall assign an indigent defense service provider qualified under Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure, Rule 8, with whom the office has a preliminary contract to provide indigent defense services for an assigned rate.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-204 Waiver by a minor.
---------------------------------------------------
A minor may not waive the right to be represented by counsel at all stages of court proceedings unless:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-204(1): the minor has consulted with counsel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-204(2): the court is satisfied that in light of the minor's unique circumstances and attributes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-204(2)(a): the minor's waiver is knowing and voluntary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-204(2)(b): the minor understands the consequences of the waiver.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-303 Pro bono provision of indigent defense services -- Liability limits.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A defense attorney is immune from suit if the defense attorney provides indigent defense services to an indigent individual:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-303(1): at no cost; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-303(2): without gross negligence or willful misconduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-304 Reimbursement for indigent defense services.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A court may order a parent or legal guardian of a minor who is appointed indigent defense services under this chapter to reimburse the cost of the minor's indigent defense services, as determined by the court, unless the court finds the parent or legal guardian indigent under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-401 Utah Indigent Defense Commission -- Creation -- Purpose.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-401(1): There is created the Utah Indigent Defense Commission within the State Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-401(2): 78B-22-451 The purpose of the commission is to assist:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-401(2)(a): the state in meeting the state's obligations for the provision of indigent defense services, consistent with the United States Constitution, the Utah Constitution, and the Utah Code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-401(2)(b): 78B-22-451 the Office of Indigent Defense Services, created in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402 Commission members -- Member qualifications -- Terms -- Vacancy.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1): 78B-22-802
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(a): The commission is composed of 15 members.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b): 78B-22-802 The governor, with the advice and consent of the Senate, and in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies, shall appoint the following 11 members:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(i): two practicing criminal defense attorneys  recommended by the Utah Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(ii): one attorney practicing in juvenile delinquency defense recommended by the Utah Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(iii): 78B-22-802 one attorney who represents parents in child welfare cases, recommended by an entity funded under the Child Welfare Parental Representation Program created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(iv): one attorney representing minority interests recommended by the Utah Minority Bar Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(v): one member recommended by the Utah Association of Counties from a county of the first or second class;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(vi): one member recommended by the Utah Association of Counties from a county of the third through sixth class;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(vii): a director of a county public defender organization recommended by the Utah Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(viii): two members recommended by the Utah League of Cities and Towns from its membership; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(b)(ix): one retired judge recommended by the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(c): The speaker of the House of Representatives and the president of the Senate shall appoint two members of the Utah Legislature, one from the House of Representatives and one from the Senate.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(d): The Judicial Council shall appoint a member from the Administrative Office of the Courts.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(1)(e): The executive director of the State Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice or the executive director's designee is a member of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(2): A member appointed by the governor shall serve a four-year term, except as provided in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(3): The governor shall stagger the initial terms of appointees so that approximately half of the members appointed by the governor are appointed every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(4): A member appointed to the commission shall have significant experience in indigent criminal defense , representing parents in child welfare cases, or in juvenile defense in delinquency  proceedings or have otherwise demonstrated a strong commitment to providing effective representation in indigent defense services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(5): An individual who is currently employed solely as a criminal prosecuting attorney may not serve as a member of the commission .
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(6): A commission member shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(7): The commission may remove a member for incompetence, dereliction of duty, malfeasance, misfeasance, or nonfeasance in office, or for any other good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(8): If a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, a replacement shall be appointed for the remaining unexpired term in the same manner, and in accordance with the same procedure, as the original appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(9)(a): The commission shall elect annually a chair from the commission's membership to serve a one-year term.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(9)(b): A commission member may not serve as chair of the commission for more than three consecutive terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(10): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(10)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(10)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(10)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(11)(a): A majority of the members of the commission constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(11)(b): If a quorum is present, the action of a majority of the voting members present constitutes the action of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-402(11)(c): A member shall comply with the conflict of interest provisions described in Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404 Powers and duties of the commission.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1): 78B-22-701 The commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a): adopt core principles for an indigent defense system to ensure the effective representation of indigent individuals consistent with the requirements of the United States Constitution, the Utah Constitution, and the Utah Code, which principles at a minimum shall address the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(i): an indigent defense system shall ensure that in providing indigent defense services:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(i)(A): an indigent individual receives conflict-free indigent defense services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(i)(B): there is a separate contract for each type of indigent defense service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii): an indigent defense system shall ensure an indigent defense service provider has:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii)(A): the ability to exercise independent judgment without fear of retaliation and is free to represent an indigent individual based on the indigent defense service provider's own independent judgment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii)(B): adequate access to indigent defense resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii)(C): the ability to provide representation to accused individuals in criminal cases at the critical stages of proceedings, and at all stages to indigent individuals in juvenile delinquency and child welfare proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii)(D): a workload that allows for sufficient time to meet with clients, investigate cases, file appropriate documents with the courts, and otherwise provide effective assistance of counsel to each client;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii)(E): adequate compensation without financial disincentives;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii)(F): appropriate experience or training in the area for which the indigent defense service provider is representing indigent individuals;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii)(G): compensation for legal training and education in the areas of the law relevant to the types of cases for which the indigent defense service provider is representing indigent individuals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(a)(ii)(H): the ability to meet the obligations of the Utah Rules of Professional Conduct, including expectations on client communications and managing conflicts of interest;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(b): encourage and aid indigent defense systems in the state in the regionalization of indigent defense services to provide for effective and efficient representation to the indigent individuals;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(c): emphasize the importance of ensuring constitutionally effective indigent defense services;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(d): encourage members of the judiciary to provide input regarding the delivery of indigent defense services;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(e): oversee individuals and entities involved in providing indigent defense services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(1)(f): 78B-22-701 manage county participation in the Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(2): 78B-22-455; 78B-22-804 The commission may:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(2)(a): make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to carry out the commission's duties under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(2)(b): assign duties related to indigent defense services to the office to assist the commission with the commission's statutory duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(2)(c): 78B-22-455 request supplemental appropriations from the Legislature to address a deficit in the Indigent Inmate Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-404(2)(d): 78B-22-804 request supplemental appropriations from the Legislature to address a deficit in the Child Welfare Parental Representation Fund created in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405 Indigent Defense Resources Restricted Account -- Administration.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(1)(a): There is created within the General Fund a restricted account known as the "Indigent Defense Resources Restricted Account."
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(1)(b): Appropriations from the account are nonlapsing.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(2): The account consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(2)(a): money appropriated by the Legislature based upon recommendations from the commission consistent with principles of shared state and local funding;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(2)(b): any other money received by the commission from any source to carry out the purposes of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(2)(c): any interest and earnings from the investment of account money.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(3): 78B-22-406 The commission shall administer the account and, subject to appropriation, disburse money from the account for the following purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(3)(a): to establish and maintain a statewide indigent defense data collection system;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(3)(b): 78B-22-406 to establish and administer a grant program to provide grants of state money and other money to indigent defense systems as set forth in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(3)(c): to provide training and continuing legal education for indigent defense service providers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-405(3)(d): for administrative costs.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406 Indigent defense services grant program.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(1): The commission may award grants:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(1)(a): to supplement local spending by an indigent defense system for indigent defense services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(1)(b): for contracts to provide indigent defense services for appeals from juvenile court proceedings in a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(2): 78B-22-804(2); Title 80, Chapter 4, Termination and Restoration of Parental Rights The commission may use grant money:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(2)(a): to assist an indigent defense system to provide indigent defense services that meet the commission's core principles for the effective representation of indigent individuals;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(2)(b): to establish and maintain local indigent defense data collection systems;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(2)(c): to provide indigent defense services in addition to indigent defense services that are currently being provided by an indigent defense system;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(2)(d): to provide training and continuing legal education for indigent defense service providers;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(2)(e): to assist indigent defense systems with appeals from juvenile court proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(2)(f): 78B-22-804(2) to pay for indigent defense resources and costs and expenses for parental representation attorneys as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(2)(g): Title 80, Chapter 4, Termination and Restoration of Parental Rights to reimburse an indigent defense system for the cost of providing indigent defense services in an action initiated by a private party under
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(3): To receive a grant from the commission, an indigent defense system shall demonstrate to the commission's satisfaction that:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(3)(a): the indigent defense system has incurred or reasonably anticipates incurring expenses for indigent defense services that are in addition to the indigent defense system's average annual spending on indigent defense services in the three fiscal years immediately preceding the grant application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(3)(b)(i): a grant from the commission is necessary for the indigent defense system to meet the commission's core principles for the effective representation of indigent individuals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(3)(b)(ii): the indigent defense system shall use the grant in an innovative manner that meets the commission's core principles for the effective representation of indigent individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-406(4): The commission may revoke a grant if an indigent defense system fails to meet requirements of the grant or any of the commission's core principles for the effective representation of indigent individuals.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-407 Cooperation and participation with the commission.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Indigent defense systems and indigent defense service providers shall cooperate and participate with the commission in the collection of data, investigation, audit, and review of indigent defense services.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452 Duties of the office.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1): 78B-22-405; 78B-22-406; 78B-22-454; 17-50-501; 78B-22-203 The office shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(g)(i): 17-50-501 is incarcerated in a state prison located in a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class as classified in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(g)(iii): 78B-22-203 has been appointed counsel in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(j): administer the Child Welfare Parental Representation Program in accordance with Part 8, Child Welfare Parental Representation Program;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(k): administer the Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund in accordance with Part 7, Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(l): assign an indigent defense service provider to represent an individual prosecuted for aggravated murder in accordance with Part 7, Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(m): annually report to the governor, Legislature, Judiciary Interim Committee, and Judicial Council, regarding:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(m)(iii): compliance with the commission's core principles by indigent defense systems receiving grants from the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(n): submit recommendations to the commission for improving indigent defense services in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(o): publish an annual report on the commission's website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(1)(p): perform all other duties assigned by the commission related to indigent defense services.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(2): The office may enter into contracts and accept, allocate, and administer funds and grants from any public or private person to accomplish the duties of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-452(3): 78B-22-404 Any contract entered into under this part shall require that indigent defense services are provided in a manner consistent with the commission's core principles implemented under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-451 Office of Indigent Defense Services -- Creation.

There is created under the commission the Office of Indigent Defense Services.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-454 Defense of indigent inmates.
-------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-454(3): The county attorney or district attorney of a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class shall function as the prosecuting entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-454(4): 78B-22-455; 78B-22-455(6)
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-454(4)(a): A county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class where a state prison is located may impose an additional property tax levy by ordinance at .0001 per dollar of taxable value in the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-454(4)(b): 78B-22-455 If the county governing body imposes the additional property tax levy by ordinance, the revenue shall be deposited into the Indigent Inmate Fund as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-454(4)(c): 78B-22-455(6) Upon notification that the fund has reached the amount specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-454(4)(d): A county that chooses not to impose the additional levy by ordinance may not receive any benefit from the Indigent Inmate Fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701 Establishment of Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund -- Use of fund -- Compensation for indigent legal defense from fund.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(1): As used in this part, "fund" means the Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(2)(a): There is established a custodial fund known as the "Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund."
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(2)(b): The office shall disburse money from the fund at the direction of the commission and subject to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(3): 78B-22-702; 78B-22-703; 78B-22-703 The fund consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(3)(a): 78B-22-702; 78B-22-703 money received from participating counties as provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(3)(b): 78B-22-703 appropriations made to the fund by the Legislature as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(3)(c): interest and earnings from the investment of fund money.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(4): The state treasurer shall invest fund money with the earnings and interest accruing to the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(5): The fund shall be used to fulfill the constitutional and statutory mandates for the provision of constitutionally effective defense for indigent individuals prosecuted for the violation of state laws in cases involving aggravated murder.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(6): Money allocated to or deposited into the fund is used only:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(6)(a): to pay an indigent defense service provider appointed to represent an individual prosecuted for aggravated murder;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(6)(b): for defense resources necessary to effectively represent the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701(6)(c): for costs associated with the management of the fund and defense service providers.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701.5 Administration of Indigent Aggravated Murder Defense Fund.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701.5(1): The commission shall establish rules and procedures for the application by a county for disbursements, and the screening and approval of the applications for the money from the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701.5(2): 78B-22-701 The office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701.5(2)(a): receive, screen, and approve, or disapprove the application of a county for disbursements from the fund;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701.5(2)(b): calculate the amount of the annual contribution to be made to the fund by each participating county;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701.5(2)(c): prescribe forms for the application for money from the fund;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701.5(2)(d): 78B-22-701 oversee and approve the disbursement of money from the fund as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-701.5(2)(e): negotiate, enter into, and administer contracts with legal counsel, qualified under and meeting the standards consistent with this chapter, to provide indigent defense services to an indigent individual prosecuted in a participating county for an offense involving aggravated murder.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702 County participation.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(1)(a): A county may participate in the fund subject to the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(1)(b): A county that does not participate in the fund, or is not current in the county's assessments for the fund, is ineligible to receive money from the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(1)(c): The commission may revoke a county's participation in the fund if the county fails to pay the county's assessments when due.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(2): 78B-22-703 To participate in the fund, the legislative body of a county shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(2)(a): 78B-22-703 adopt a resolution approving participation in the fund and committing that county to fulfill the assessment requirements as set forth in Subsection (3) and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(2)(b): submit a certified copy of that resolution together with an application to the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(3): 78B-22-703 By January 15 of each year, a participating county shall contribute to the fund an amount computed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(4): A participating county may withdraw from participation in the fund upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(4)(a): adoption by the county's legislative body of a resolution to withdraw; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(4)(b): notice to the commission by January 1 of the year before withdrawal.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(5): A county withdrawing from participation in the fund, or whose participation in the fund has been revoked for failure to pay the county's assessments when due, shall forfeit the right to:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(5)(a): any previously paid assessment;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(5)(b): relief from the county's obligation to pay the county's assessment during the period of the county's participation in the fund; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-702(5)(c): any benefit from the fund, including reimbursement of costs that accrued after the last day of the period for which the county has paid the county's assessment.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703 County and state obligations.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(1): 78B-22-701
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), a participating county shall pay into the fund annually an amount calculated by multiplying the average of the percent of the county's population to the total population of all participating counties and of the percent of the county's taxable value of the locally and centrally assessed property located within that county to the total taxable value of the locally and centrally assessed property to all participating counties by the total fund assessment for that year to be paid by all participating counties as is determined by the commission to be sufficient such that it is unlikely that a deficit will occur in the fund in any calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(1)(b): The fund minimum is equal to or greater than 50 cents per person of all counties participating.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(1)(c): 78B-22-701 The amount paid by a participating county under this Subsection (1) is the total county obligation for payment of costs in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(2)(a): A county that elects to initiate participation in the fund, or reestablish participation in the fund after participation was terminated, is required to make an equity payment in addition to the assessment required by Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(2)(b): The equity payment is determined by the commission and represent what the county's equity in the fund would be if the county had made assessments into the fund for each of the previous two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(3): If the fund balance after contribution by the state and participating counties is insufficient to replenish the fund annually to at least $250,000, the commission by a majority vote may terminate the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(4): If the fund is terminated, the remaining money shall continue to be administered and disbursed in accordance with the provision of this chapter until exhausted, at which time the fund shall cease to exist.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(5)(a): If the fund runs a deficit during any calendar year, the state is responsible for the deficit.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(5)(b): In the calendar year following a deficit year, the commission shall increase the assessment required by Subsection (1) by an amount at least equal to the deficit of the previous year, which combined amount becomes the base assessment until another deficit year occurs.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(6): In a calendar year in which the fund runs a deficit, or is projected to run a deficit, the commission shall request a supplemental appropriation to pay for the deficit from the Legislature in the following general session.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-703(7): The state shall pay any or all of the reasonable and necessary money for the deficit into the fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-704 Application and qualification for fund money.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-704(1): A participating county may apply to the office for benefits from the fund if that county has incurred, or reasonably anticipates incurring, expenses for indigent defense services provided to an indigent individual for an offense involving aggravated murder.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-704(2): An application may not be made nor benefits provided from the fund for a case filed before September 1, 1998.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-704(3): If the application of a participating county is approved by the office, the office shall negotiate, enter into, and administer a contract for the cost of indigent defense services with an attorney or entity appointed to represent the indigent individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-704(4): A nonparticipating county is responsible for paying for indigent defense services in the nonparticipating county and is not eligible for any legislative relief.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-804 Child Welfare Parental Representation Fund -- Contracts for coverage by the fund.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-804(1): There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the "Child Welfare Parental Representation Fund."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-804(3): The fund consists of:

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-804(3)(c): interest and earnings from the investment of fund money;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-804(3)(d): proceeds deposited by contributing counties under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-804(3)(e): private contributions to the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-22-804(4): Title 51, Chapter 7, State Money Management Act The state treasurer shall invest the money in the fund by following the procedures and requirements of

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 24 - Uniform Unregulated Child Custody Transfer Act
*********************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(1): "Child" means an unemancipated individual under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(2)(a): "Child-placing agency" means a person with authority under other law of this state to identify or place a child for adoption.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(2)(b): "Child-placing agency" does not include a parent of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(3): "Custody" means the exercise of physical care and supervision of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(4)(a): "Intercountry adoption" means an adoption or placement for adoption of a child who resides in a foreign country at the time of adoption or placement.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(4)(b): "Intercountry adoption" includes an adoption finalized in the child's country of residence or in a state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(5): "Parent" means an individual recognized as a parent under other law of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(6): "Person" means an individual, estate, business or nonprofit entity, public corporation, government or governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, or other legal entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(7): "Record" means information:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(7)(a): inscribed on a tangible medium; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(7)(b): stored in an electronic or other medium and retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(8)(a): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, or any other territory or possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-101(8)(b): "State" includes a federally recognized Indian tribe.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-102 Limitations on applicability.
--------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not apply to custody of an Indian child, as defined in the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Sec. 1903, to the extent governed by the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Sec. 1901 through 1963.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-201 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-201(1): "Guardian" means a person recognized as a guardian under other law of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-201(2): "Intermediary" means a person that assists or facilitates a transfer of custody of a child, whether or not for compensation.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-202 Applicability.
-----------------------------------------------
This part does not apply to a transfer of custody of a child by a parent or guardian of the child to:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-202(1): a parent of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-202(2): a stepparent of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-202(3): an adult who is related to the child by blood, marriage, or adoption;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-202(4): an adult who, at the time of the transfer, had a close relationship with the child or the parent or guardian of the child for a substantial period, and whom the parent or guardian reasonably believed, at the time of the transfer, to be a fit custodian of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-202(5): an Indian custodian, as defined in the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Sec. 1903, of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-202(6): a member of the child's customary family unit recognized by the child's indigenous group.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-301 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part, "prospective adoptive parent" means an individual who has been approved or permitted under other law of this state to adopt a child.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-302 Scope.
---------------------------------------
This part applies to placement for adoption of a child who:Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-302(1): has been or is in foster or institutional care;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-302(2): previously has been adopted in a state;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-302(3): has been or is being adopted under the law of a foreign country;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-302(4): has come or is coming to a state from a foreign country to be adopted;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-302(5): is not a citizen of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-302(6): has an attachment or trauma-related disorder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-302(7): suffered from prenatal exposure to alcohol or drugs.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-305 Guidance and instruction.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-305(2)(a)(iv): neglect, abuse, drug exposure, or similar adversity;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-305(2)(a)(v): separation from a sibling or significant caregiver; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-305(2)(a)(vi): a difference in ethnicity, race, or cultural identity between the child and the prospective adoptive parent or other child of the parent;

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-305(2)(c): any other matter the child-placing agency considers material to the adoption.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-307(2)(a): The Office of Licensing may initiate a proceeding to determine whether a child-placing agency has failed to comply with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-307(2)(b): If the Office of Licensing finds that the child-placing agency has failed to comply, the Office of Licensing may suspend or revoke the child-placing agency's license or take other action permitted by law of the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-308 Rulemaking authority.
------------------------------------------------------
The Division of Licensing and Background Checks, created in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-401 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, a court shall consider the promotion of uniformity of the law among jurisdictions that enact the uniform act.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-402 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, or supersedes the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001 et seq., but does not modify, limit, or supersede 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7003(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-403 Transitional provisions.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-403(1): Part 2, Prohibition of Unregulated Custody Transfer
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-403(1)(a): a transfer of custody on or after May 4, 2022; and
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-403(1)(b): soliciting or advertising on or after May 4, 2022.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-403(2): Part 3, Information and Guidance


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-24-404 Severability.
----------------------------------------------
If a provision of this chapter or the provision's application to a person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect another provision or application that can be given effect without the invalid provision.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 78B - Chapter 25 - Uniform Public Expression Protection Act
***************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter may be cited as the "Uniform Public Expression Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102 Scope.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(1)(a): "Goods or services" does not include the creation, dissemination, exhibition, or advertisement or similar promotion of a dramatic, literary, musical, political, journalistic, or artistic work.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(1)(b): "Governmental unit" means a public corporation or government or governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(1)(c): "Person" means an individual, estate, trust, partnership, business or nonprofit entity, governmental unit, or other legal entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(2)(a): communication in a legislative, executive, judicial, administrative, or other governmental proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(2)(b): communication on an issue under consideration or review in a legislative, executive, judicial, administrative, or other governmental proceeding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(2)(c): exercise of the right of freedom of speech or of the press, the right to assemble or petition, or the right of association, guaranteed by the United States Constitution or Utah Constitution, on a matter of public concern.
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(3): This chapter does not apply to a cause of action asserted:
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(3)(a): against a governmental unit or an employee or agent of a governmental unit acting or purporting to act in an official capacity;
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(3)(b): by a governmental unit or an employee or agent of a governmental unit acting in an official capacity to enforce a law to protect against an imminent threat to public health or safety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-102(3)(c): against a person primarily engaged in the business of selling or leasing goods or services if the cause of action arises out of a communication related to the person's sale or lease of the goods or services.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-103 Special motion for expedited relief.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Not later than 60 days after the day on which a party is served with a complaint, crossclaim, counterclaim, third-party claim, or other pleading that asserts a cause of action to which this chapter applies, or at a later time on a showing of good cause, the party may file a special motion for expedited relief to dismiss the cause of action or part of the cause of action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-108 Ruling.
----------------------------------------
The court shall rule on a motion under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-109 Appeal.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-109(1): 78B-25-103 A moving party may appeal as a matter of right from an order denying, in whole or in part, a motion under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-109(2): The appeal shall be filed in accordance with Utah Rules of Appellate Procedure, Rule 4.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-110 Costs, attorney fees, and expenses.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
On a motion under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 78B-25-110(1): to the moving party if the moving party prevails on the motion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-110(2): to the responding party if the responding party prevails on the motion and the court finds that the motion was frivolous or filed solely with intent to delay the proceeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-111 Construction.
----------------------------------------------
This chapter shall be broadly construed and applied to protect the exercise of the right of freedom of speech and of the press, the right to assemble and petition, and the right of association, guaranteed by the United States Constitution or the Utah Constitution.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-112 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to the uniform law's subject matter among states that enact the uniform law.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-113 Transitional provision.
--------------------------------------------------------
This chapter applies to a civil action filed or cause of action asserted in a civil action on or after May 3, 2023.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-114 Savings clause.
------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not affect a cause of action asserted before May 3, 2023, in a civil action or a motion under Laws of Utah 2008, Chapter 3, Sections 1087 and 1088, regarding the cause of action.

Utah Code Annotated § 78B-25-115 Severability.
----------------------------------------------
If any provision of this chapter or the chapter's application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect other provisions or applications of this chapter which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this chapter are severable.
